('32', 3, 0, 1, 3290) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 3, 1, 2, 3330) 10. AN APPEAL 1
('32', 3, 2, 3, 3346) June 17, 1925
('32', 3, 3, 4, 3360) DEAR COUNTRYMEN, The nation is in mourning for Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das.
('32', 3, 3, 5, 3436) And yet why should we mourn?
('32', 3, 3, 6, 3465) For though Deshbandhu is dead, he shall live in us.
('32', 3, 3, 7, 3517) We must take up the work at the point he has left it.
('32', 3, 3, 8, 3571) Our first lesson must commence with rendering the honours that are due to the dead.
('32', 3, 3, 9, 3655) Let our affection be not blind but intelligent.
('32', 3, 3, 10, 3703) When the remains reach the Sealdah station, there is likely to be a great rush of people.
('32', 3, 3, 11, 3793) If we are to satisfy the desire of everyone to pay his or her respect to the remains, the following rules must be observed : 1. There must be no shouting.
('32', 3, 3, 12, 3948) 2. There must be no rush towards the carriage.
('32', 3, 3, 13, 3995) People should stand where they find themselves and must not push their way through the crowd.
('32', 3, 3, 14, 4089) 3. A clear way must be kept for the coffin bearers to pass.
('32', 3, 3, 15, 4149) 4. There should be no one in front save the authorized band of Kirtankars and others.
('32', 3, 3, 16, 4235) Those who wish to take part in the procession will kindly take up the rear.
('32', 3, 3, 17, 4311) They must not break through the line.
('32', 3, 3, 18, 4349) 5. At the burning ghat, there should be no rush made towards the funeral pyre.
('32', 3, 3, 19, 4428) It will not be possible to expose the body to view as it is feared that, three days having already elapsed, it must be in a state of decomposition.
('32', 3, 3, 20, 4576) 6. Please remember that respect for the memory of the deceased patriot demands not any outward temporary show of affection, but an inward determination to deserve heritage the Deshbandhu has left us.
('32', 3, 4, 21, 4776) I am your servant,
('32', 3, 5, 22, 4795) M. K. GANDHI Amrita Bazar Patrika, 19 6 1925
('32', 3, 6, 23, 4840) 11. THE GREAT BEREAVEMENT CALCUTTA, June 17, 1925 When the heart feels a deep cut, the pen refuses to move.
('32', 3, 6, 24, 4948) I am too much in the centre of grief to be able to send much for the
('32', 3, 7, 25, 5017) 1 This was distributed in the form of leaflet.
('32', 4, 0, 1, 5064) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 5
('32', 4, 1, 2, 5108) readers of Young India across the wire.
('32', 4, 1, 3, 5148) The five days of communion with the great patriot which I had at Darjeeling brought us nearer to each other than we ever were before.
('32', 4, 1, 4, 5282) I realized not only how great Deshbandhu was, but also how good he was.
('32', 4, 1, 5, 5354) India has lost a jewel.
('32', 4, 1, 6, 5378) But we must regain it by gaining swaraj.
('32', 4, 2, 7, 5419) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 18 6 1925
('32', 4, 3, 8, 5455) 12. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('32', 4, 4, 9, 5483) Wednesday, June 17, 1925
('32', 4, 5, 10, 5508) RAMDAS, I am waiting for a train at Khulna.
('32', 4, 5, 11, 5552) On reaching Khulna from Barisal by steamer I received a telegram that Deshbandhu Das 1 was no more.
('32', 4, 5, 12, 5652) I am deeply shocked; because we had come very close at Darjeeling 2. My anguish has a selfish cause: But it is there and I am not able to get over it.
('32', 4, 5, 13, 5803) I have sent a few telegrams.
('32', 4, 6, 14, 5832) After debating whether I should eat or fast I came to the conclusion that it would be proper to eat.
('32', 4, 6, 15, 5933) And then of course there was the meeting here.
('32', 4, 6, 16, 5980) I attended it.
('32', 4, 6, 17, 5995) 4 But for that meeting I would have gone straight to Calcutta.
('32', 4, 6, 18, 6058) At the meeting I broke down although I did my best not to.
('32', 4, 6, 19, 6117) After that I had no desire left to write.
('32', 4, 6, 20, 6159) So I span.
('32', 4, 6, 21, 6170) Spinning brought comfort.
('32', 4, 6, 22, 6196) Then I bathed and ate.
('32', 4, 6, 23, 6219) Then the post was brought.
('32', 4, 6, 24, 6246) It included your letter and many others.
('32', 4, 6, 25, 6287) I went through them.
('32', 4, 6, 26, 6308) And now I have sat down to write to you, because this is the most convenient time.
('32', 4, 6, 27, 6391) It means a lot to me that you have started taking interest in the work there.
('32', 4, 6, 28, 6469) May that interest continue.
('32', 4, 6, 29, 6497) Try to read the Gita occasionally, and if possible regularly.
('32', 4, 6, 30, 6559) Even if you read only two verses you must read them along with the meaning.
('32', 4, 6, 31, 6635) Your report about Kundla is interesting.
('32', 4, 6, 32, 6676) If you overcome your fear, you will see that you have a lot of strength.
('32', 4, 7, 33, 6749) 1 Chitta Ranjan Das had passed away at Darjeeling on June 16, 1925. 2 Where Gandhiji had staved with C. R. Das from June 3 to June 6. 1925; vide “At Darjeeling”, 10 7 1925. 3 Vide “Telegram to Basanti Devi Das”, 17 6 1925, “Telegram Satcouripati Roy”, 17 6 1925, “Telegram to Urmila Devi”, 17 6 1925, “Telegram to Mona Das”, 17 6 1925, “Telegram to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 17 6 1925, “Telegram to Sarojini Naidu”, 17 6 1925 and “Telegram Shaukat Ali”, 17 6 1925. 4 Vide “Speech at Public Meeting, Khulna”, 17 6 1925.
('32', 5, 0, 1, 7262) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 5, 1, 2, 7302) In view of the above circumstances you may take it that I shall be in Calcutta for the time being.
('32', 5, 1, 3, 7401) I shall write more from there.
('32', 5, 1, 4, 7432) Only this much for now.
('32', 5, 1, 5, 7456) Blessings from BAPU
('32', 5, 2, 6, 7476) [PS.] Surendra’s letter is worth reading.
('32', 5, 2, 7, 7518) I am sending it to you.
('32', 5, 2, 8, 7542) You may tear it up after reading.
('32', 5, 3, 9, 7576) From the Gujarati original: Ramdas Gandhi Papers.

('32', 5, 4, 11, 7670) 13. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KHULNA 1
('32', 5, 5, 12, 7709) June 17, 1925 You have heard from Acharya Ray what a terrible blow has befallen us, but I know that if we are true servants of the country, no blow, however great, will break our spirit.
('32', 5, 5, 13, 7896) I was faced with a conflict of duties this morning as soon as the sad news was broken to me.
('32', 5, 5, 14, 7989) It was my duty to leave for Calcutta by the first train available.
('32', 5, 5, 15, 8056) It was also my duty to go through the programme you had fixed up for me.
('32', 5, 5, 16, 8129) The spirit of service in me prompted me to finish the work here, but whilst I have preferred to stop here, to meet those who have come from distant places, I shall, instead of my usual speech on Congress work, devote it to the memory of the departed Deshbandhu.
('32', 5, 5, 17, 8391) I am sure that my staying here to go through the programme in preference to running up to Calcutta will please his soul.
('32', 5, 5, 18, 8512) Mr. Das was one of the greatest of men.
('32', 5, 5, 19, 8552) 2 I have had the privilege of knowing him for the last six years, and, when I parted from him only a few days ago at Darjeeling, I said to a friend that the closer I came to him the more I came to love him.
('32', 5, 5, 20, 8759) I saw during my brief stay at Darjeeling that no thought but that of the welfare of India occupied his mind.
('32', 5, 5, 21, 8868) He dreamed and thought and talked of the freedom of India and of nothing else and I may tell you that, until the moment I took leave of him in Darjeeling, he was asking me to stop longer in Bengal to bring the different parties together, so that the energies of all may be concentrated on one
('32', 5, 6, 22, 9161) 1 Seven addresses were presented to Gandhiji on behalf of the local bodies, the Municipality, the District Board and the People’s Association.
('32', 5, 6, 23, 9304) Sir P. C. Ray announced the news of the death of C. R. Das.
('32', 5, 6, 24, 9364) 2 The newspaper reports that Gandhiji broke down and was unable to proceed for a minute or two.
('32', 6, 0, 1, 9460) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 7
('32', 6, 1, 2, 9504) purpose throughout my tour in Bengal.
('32', 6, 1, 3, 9542) Those who had differences with him, those who bitterly criticized him did not hesitate to admit that no other man could take his place in Bengal.
('32', 6, 1, 4, 9688) He was fearless.
('32', 6, 1, 5, 9705) He was brave.
('32', 6, 1, 6, 9719) His love for the young men of Bengal was boundless.
('32', 6, 1, 7, 9771) There is not a young man but has told me that never had his request to Mr. Das for help gone in vain.
('32', 6, 1, 8, 9873) He earned lakhs and gave away lakhs to the young men of Bengal.
('32', 6, 1, 9, 9937) His sacrifice was matchless.
('32', 6, 1, 10, 9966) And who am I to talk of his great intellect and his statesmanship?
('32', 6, 1, 11, 10033) On more than one occasion at Darjeeling, he told me that the freedom of India depends on non violence and truth.
('32', 6, 1, 12, 10146) The Hindus and Mussalmans of India should know that his heart knew no difference between the Hindus and the Mussalmans.
('32', 6, 1, 13, 10266) I would like to tell all Englishmen in India that he bore no ill will to them.
('32', 6, 1, 14, 10345) “If I live I live for swaraj; if I die I die for swaraj,” that was his vow to his motherland.
('32', 6, 1, 15, 10439) What shall we do to perpetuate his memory?
('32', 6, 1, 16, 10482) It is easy to shed tears, but no tears can help us or his nearest and dearest.
('32', 6, 1, 17, 10561) Only if everyone of us, Hindus, Mussalmans, Parsis and Christians, all who call themselves Indians, pledge ourselves to do the work in which he lived, moved and had his being, shall we have done something.
('32', 6, 1, 18, 10767) We are all believers in God.
('32', 6, 1, 19, 10796) We should know that the body is ever perishing.
('32', 6, 1, 20, 10844) The soul is imperishable.
('32', 6, 1, 21, 10870) The body that held Mr. Das has perished, but his soul will never perish, not only the soul, but even the name of him who had served and sacrificed so much will remain immortal and every one, young and old, who follow his example to ever so little an extent will help to perpetuate his memory.
('32', 6, 1, 22, 11163) We have none of us his intellect, but we can imitate the spirit in which he served the motherland.
('32', 6, 1, 23, 11262) Mr. Das tried to learn spinning in Patna, and in Darjeeling I gave him spinning lessons and he promised me that he would try to learn spinning and spin so long as his body allowed.
('32', 6, 1, 24, 11443) He had converted his Darjeeling House into a spinning club.
('32', 6, 1, 25, 11503) His good wife pledged herself to spin at least for half an hour every day, excepting when she was ill, and his daughter who was there, his sister and sister’s daughter were all regularly spinning.
('32', 6, 1, 26, 11700) Often would he say to me : ‘I think it is essential to go to the Councils, but spinning is equally essential and not only is it essential, it is impossible to make Council work effective without spinning.’ It is not for me to say how much he had done to bring the Hindus and Mussalmans together; and as to his love for the untouchables, I need only tell you what I heard last night from a Namasudra leader at Barisal.
('32', 6, 1, 27, 12118) He said that the first to help him with
('32', 7, 0, 1, 12158) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 7, 1, 2, 12198) money was Mr. Das and the next was Dr. Ray.
('32', 7, 1, 3, 12242) You cannot all go to the Councils, but you can do all the three things that were dear to him.
('32', 7, 1, 4, 12336) I regard myself as a loyal servant of India and a loyal brother and colleague of the late Mr. Das and as such I publicly declare that I shall, consistently with my principle, try to give hence forward, if it is possible, even more help to the followers of Mr. Das than I have up to now done in their Council programme.
('32', 7, 1, 5, 12655) I pray to God that He may ever keep me from doing or speaking aught calculated to injure his work.
('32', 7, 1, 6, 12754) Our differences regarding the Council entry remained, but our hearts were one.
('32', 7, 1, 7, 12833) Differences in political methods will remain until the end of time, but they should never separate people or make of them mutual enemies.
('32', 7, 1, 8, 12971) The same love of the motherland which prompted me to do one thing prompted him to do something else and such honest difference means no detriment to the cause of the country.
('32', 7, 1, 9, 13146) Not differences in methods, but insincerity is the curse.
('32', 7, 1, 10, 13204) During my stay at Darjeeling, I could see that Mr. Das’s tenderness towards his political opponents was every day increasing, but I must not attempt to describe those sacred memories.
('32', 7, 1, 11, 13388) Mr. Das was one of the jewels among the servants of the country.
('32', 7, 1, 12, 13453) His service and his sacrifice were matchless.
('32', 7, 1, 13, 13499) May their memory ever remain with us and may his example inspire us to noble efforts!
('32', 7, 1, 14, 13585) Our way is long and dreary and nothing will stand us in good stead as our own reliance on ourselves.
('32', 7, 1, 15, 13686) Self reliance was Mr. Das’s watchword and may it long inspire us!
('32', 7, 1, 16, 13752) May his soul rest in peace!
('32', 7, 1, 17, 13780) The Hindu, 18 6 1925
('32', 7, 2, 18, 13801) 14. NOTES
('32', 7, 3, 19, 13811) SPINNING IN DARJEELING But for the presence of Deshbandhu Das in Darjeeling, I hardly think I would have gone there though the sight of the snowy range was a temptation.
('32', 7, 3, 20, 13981) I had thought that, for me, to deliver the message of the charkha to the fashionable people of Darjeeling would be simple folly.
('32', 7, 3, 21, 14110) My fear was wholly unjustified.
('32', 7, 3, 22, 14142) I was privileged to address a meeting of ladies who listened to the message of the wheel with sympathy.
('32', 7, 3, 23, 14246) Mrs. Blair, the late W. C. Bonnerjee’s daughter, was to start a spinning class for the fashionable ladies.
('32', 7, 3, 24, 14353) I was privileged, too, to deliver my message to a small meeting of missionaries.
('32', 7, 3, 25, 14434) Of this, however, perhaps more later.
('32', 7, 3, 26, 14472) Nor did I know that I should have the good fortune to see so
('32', 8, 0, 1, 14533) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 9
('32', 8, 1, 2, 14577) many Nepali, Bhutia and other people.
('32', 8, 1, 3, 14615) They evinced the greatest interest in the massage.
('32', 8, 1, 4, 14666) But my keenest joy was to see Shrimati Basanti Devi Das learning spinning and taking a vow religiously to spin every day for at least half an hour except in cases of illness.
('32', 8, 1, 5, 14841) Her daughter knew it already.
('32', 8, 1, 6, 14871) But she had neglected.
('32', 8, 1, 7, 14894) She has now returned to it and added spinning by the takli which she picked in ten minutes.
('32', 8, 1, 8, 14986) Shrimati Urmila Devi and her children have been spinning regularly for some time now.
('32', 8, 1, 9, 15072) And Deshbandhu himself took lessons on the takli.
('32', 8, 1, 10, 15122) But he finds spinning harder than giving defeats to the Government or winning cases for clients.
('32', 8, 1, 11, 15219) “My husband can hardly turn the key of his box right; I have always to help him”, pleaded Basanti Devi on behalf of her husband.
('32', 8, 1, 12, 15348) “You can, therefore, understand why it is so difficult for him to learn spinning.” But Deshbandhu has assured me that he is going to insist on learning spinning.
('32', 8, 1, 13, 15510) He had lessons in spinning at the wheel in Patna.
('32', 8, 1, 14, 15560) They were interrupted by his illness.
('32', 8, 1, 15, 15598) He told me that he thoroughly believed in the charkha and wanted to help it in every way possible.
('32', 8, 1, 16, 15697) It was a perfect pleasure to me to see the whole house hold of the Mayor of Calcutta plying the charkha in fashionable Darjeeling creating a charkha atmosphere there.
('32', 8, 1, 17, 15864) Needless to say, they were all dressed in khaddar.
('32', 8, 1, 18, 15915) For Deshbandhu khaddar is not ceremonial wear.
('32', 8, 1, 19, 15962) It is habitual with him.
('32', 8, 1, 20, 15987) He tells me it would be difficult for him to revert to the foreign or mill made cloth even if he wished to.
('32', 8, 2, 21, 16095) WANTED A SECRETARY Those who are interested in cow protection will not, I hope, think that I am neglecting the trust imposed upon me.
('32', 8, 2, 22, 16229) At the time of accepting it, I warned the members of the Committee that I should be perfectly useless for any work for the Association if I did not succeed in finding a good secretary.
('32', 8, 2, 23, 16414) I regret to inform them, and others interested, that I have as yet failed to find one to my satisfaction.
('32', 8, 2, 24, 16520) He must have a competent knowledge of English and at least a working knowledge of Hindustani.
('32', 8, 2, 25, 16614) He should be a whole time worker with no other calls upon his time.
('32', 8, 2, 26, 16682) He must be a lover of the cow and have faith in the programme sketched by the Association to achieve its object.
('32', 8, 2, 27, 16795) He must have a pure character and a healthy body.
('32', 8, 2, 28, 16845) He will be paid according to his needs so long as they are not extraordinary.
('32', 8, 2, 29, 16923) Lastly, he must be a student capable of application; for he will be expected to study the literature connected with cow protection.

('32', 9, 1, 3, 17452) TILAK SWARAJ FUND
('32', 9, 2, 4, 17470) What use has been made of this fund is a question that still continues to worry people.
('32', 9, 2, 5, 17558) A Punjabi correspondent says that, in the course of his khaddar tour, he finds people inquiring about the disposal of the fund.
('32', 9, 2, 6, 17686) I have repeatedly stated in these columns that full and certified balance sheets have been published from time to time.
('32', 9, 2, 7, 17806) Let the public also realize that the fund was distributed among twenty one provinces and that several lacs were earmarked.
('32', 9, 2, 8, 17929) Not only has the A.I.C.C. published an all India balance sheet, but the Provinces too, have done likewise.
('32', 9, 2, 9, 18036) Though there has been here and there misapplication of the funds and even defalcation, on the whole I am satisfied that the money has been spent for the purpose intended.
('32', 9, 2, 10, 18207) Any patient student of Congress affairs can, whenever he wishes, study the printed figures and find out for himself how the money was used.
('32', 9, 2, 11, 18347) WHAT OF PURSES?
('32', 9, 3, 12, 18363) The same Punjabi correspondent asks how the purses presented to me at the different places are utilized.
('32', 9, 3, 13, 18468) As a rule, the money is left at the places where it is given with instructions for its use in the khaddar propaganda.
('32', 9, 3, 14, 18586) Only, where I find no one whom I want to entrust with the use of the money given, I keep it with me and use it through the Ashram for khaddar propaganda.
('32', 9, 3, 15, 18740) Where the money is earmarked, naturally, I have nothing to do but to hand the contents for the earmarked purpose to the persons concerned.
('32', 9, 3, 16, 18879) HAS NO USE NOW
('32', 9, 4, 17, 18894) The correspondent writes :
('32', 9, 5, 18, 18921) During my hawking tours I find people saying: “As the Congress is on the wane, why are you giving yourself the useless trouble of hawking khaddar?
('32', 9, 5, 19, 19068) When the Congress becomes strong again, we will buy khaddar; now we wear foreign cloth.
('32', 9, 5, 20, 19156) Let us give ourselves the pleasure of using it for the time being.” Thus talked to me several pleaders.
('32', 9, 5, 21, 19260) This is one side of the picture.
('32', 9, 5, 22, 19293) I met a pleader who bought some himself and took us to people and promised to hawk khaddar twice every week among all sorts of people.
('32', 9, 5, 23, 19428) The instances of steady work can be multiplied.
('32', 9, 5, 24, 19476) But I have never yet met anyone to say what these pleader friends in the Punjab are reported to have said.
('32', 9, 5, 25, 19583) Surely, they do not need to be told that khaddar is not for temporary use.
('32', 9, 5, 26, 19658) It is a permanent article of wear as wheat and rice are permanent article of food.
('32', 9, 5, 27, 19741) And they
('32', 10, 0, 1, 19750) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 11
('32', 10, 1, 2, 19795) could only have been joking when they said that they wanted the pleasure of wearing foreign cloth.
('32', 10, 1, 3, 19894) Is there pleasure in wearing it?
('32', 10, 1, 4, 19927) Is it not the same thing as saying that there is pleasure in slavery?
('32', 10, 1, 5, 19997) It was not an uncommon experience, when slavery was abolished in the Southern States, to find slaves refusing freedom; slavery had become second nature with them.
('32', 10, 2, 6, 20160) ‘FEED THE MILLIONS’ A member of the 49 Bengal Regiment writes:
('32', 10, 3, 7, 20223) It is admitted on all hands that you are the greatest leader of the world.
('32', 10, 3, 8, 20298) What is the greatest leader for?
('32', 10, 3, 9, 20331) The greatest leader is for providing the starving millions of India!
('32', 10, 3, 10, 20400) Isn’t it?
('32', 10, 3, 11, 20410) So long as you are not able to feed and clothe the thirty two crores of Indians, you can’t expect swaraj.
('32', 10, 3, 12, 20516) I can give you swaraj in no time, if you can give me one hundred crores of rupees.
('32', 10, 3, 13, 20599) You speak of swaraj, you speak of charkha, etc., but you do not speak of feeding the starving people.
('32', 10, 3, 14, 20701) The man who does not get proper food, cannot take to charkha.
('32', 10, 3, 15, 20763) First of all “belly” then cloth.
('32', 10, 3, 16, 20796) I can remain stark naked for a day, but I cannot remain without food even for a couple of hours.
('32', 10, 3, 17, 20893) If you can feed and give money to the Indians, the Indian masses will at once respond to your call, otherwise not.
('32', 10, 3, 18, 21008) In the first place, let me repudiate the “greatest man” title though I do not need to do it, as I have never claimed or accepted it.
('32', 10, 3, 19, 21141) Daily do I feel both my littleness and helplessness.
('32', 10, 3, 20, 21194) I have never yet realized my greatness.
('32', 10, 3, 21, 21234) But if ‘providing the starving millions’ can make me great, I am on the way to greatness.
('32', 10, 3, 22, 21324) For I claim nothing less for my prescription, the charkha.
('32', 10, 3, 23, 21383) It is designed to feed and clothe the starving millions.
('32', 10, 3, 24, 21440) Clothing, I admit, is a secondary consideration.
('32', 10, 3, 25, 21489) But the charkha is intended to feed first and then to clothe.
('32', 10, 3, 26, 21551) I have proposed to give not merely one hundred crores of rupees once for all.
('32', 10, 3, 27, 21629) My proposal is to give sixty crores at least every year.
('32', 10, 3, 28, 21686) I gladly accept the formula that the famishing masses will respond to the call only of those who give them food and money.
('32', 10, 3, 29, 21809) My gift includes both.
('32', 10, 3, 30, 21832) But who will bell the cat?
('32', 10, 3, 31, 21859) A physician can prescribe an infallible remedy, he cannot compel the patient to adopt it.
('32', 10, 3, 32, 21949) The disease of the masses is not want of money so much as it is want of work.
('32', 10, 3, 33, 22027) Labour is money.
('32', 10, 3, 34, 22044) He who provides dignified labour for the millions in their cottages, provides food and clothing or, which is the same thing, money.
('32', 10, 3, 35, 22176) The charkha provides such labour.
('32', 10, 3, 36, 22210) Till a better substituted is found, it must, therefore, hold the field.
('32', 10, 3, 37, 22282) NATIONALISM V. INTERNATIONALISM
('32', 10, 4, 38, 22314) A gentleman met me in Darjeeling and related to me the story of a nurse who preferred not to serve her nation to the injury
('32', 11, 0, 1, 22438) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 11, 1, 2, 22479) of others.
('32', 11, 1, 3, 22490) The story was, I could see at once, related for my edification.
('32', 11, 1, 4, 22554) I gently explained to the friend that evidently he had not followed my writings of doings, though he claimed to have done so.
('32', 11, 1, 5, 22680) I told him, too, that my patriotism was not narrow, and that, it included not merely the welfare of India but the whole world.
('32', 11, 1, 6, 22807) I told him further, that being a humble man knowing my own limitations, I was satisfied with the service of my own country, taking care at the same time that I did nothing with the intention of injuring another country.
('32', 11, 1, 7, 23027) In my opinion, it is impossible for one to be internationalist without being a nationalist.
('32', 11, 1, 8, 23119) Internationalism is possible only when nationalism becomes a fact, i.e., when peoples belonging to different countries have organized themselves and are able to act as one man.
('32', 11, 1, 9, 23296) It is not nationalism that is evil, it is the narrowness, selfishness, exclusiveness which is the bane of modern nations which is evil.
('32', 11, 1, 10, 23432) Each wants to profit at the expense of and rise on the ruin of the other.
('32', 11, 1, 11, 23506) Indian nationalism has, I hope, struck a different path.
('32', 11, 1, 12, 23563) It wants to organize itself or to find full self expression for the benefit and service of humanity at large.
('32', 11, 1, 13, 23673) Anyway, there is no uncertainty about my patriotism or nationalism.
('32', 11, 1, 14, 23741) God having cast my lot in the midst of the people of India, I should be untrue to my Maker if I failed to serve them.
('32', 11, 1, 15, 23859) If I do not know how to serve them, I shall never know how to serve humanity.
('32', 11, 1, 16, 23937) And cannot possibly go wrong so long as I do not harm other nations in the act of serving my country.

('32', 14, 2, 25, 32316) 16. A DOMESTIC CHAPTER
('32', 14, 3, 26, 32339) A vakil from Layallpur sends the following letter addressed to the Editor, Young India :
('32', 14, 4, 27, 32428) About three or four years ago, a company, “All India Stores Ltd.”, was started at Calcutta with Mr. H. M. Gandhi, son of our Mahatmaji, as one of the directors, as advertised by a representative of the said company at Rawalpindi.
('32', 14, 4, 28, 32658) A client of mine was persuaded to pay certain sums to the said representative and also to the company in pursuance of his having
('32', 15, 0, 1, 32787) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 15, 1, 2, 32828) been so persuaded to become a shareholder.
('32', 15, 1, 3, 32871) I have written to the known and notified address, 22 Amratalla Street, Calcutta, of the company and so has my client.
('32', 15, 1, 4, 32989) My client fears that perhaps it was a bogus affair and he has been done out of his money.
('32', 15, 1, 5, 33079) In the interests of your (Mahatma’s) good name and the economic welfare of this poor country, I fondly hope and wish and even pray, my client’s fears may be unfounded.
('32', 15, 1, 6, 33247) The post office has returned all our letters back through the Dead Letter Office.
('32', 15, 1, 7, 33329) So, some ground at least exists for my client’s suspecting that the company is no more.
('32', 15, 1, 8, 33417) Is it a fact that Mahatmaji’s son was a Director in it, and is it a fact that such a company came into being and is still existing, and where?
('32', 15, 2, 9, 33560) Please excuse my writing to you about it.
('32', 15, 2, 10, 33602) My client who is a
('32', 15, 3, 11, 33621) Mohammedan gentleman and whose respect for Mahatmaji led him to
('32', 15, 4, 12, 33685) become a shareholder in the company, wants to verify these facts.
('32', 15, 5, 13, 33751) the query.

('32', 15, 5, 15, 33916) It was necessary to publish it also, because it is highlylikely that many shareholders feel like the vakil’s client.
('32', 15, 5, 16, 34033) They too should have such satisfaction as I could render to them.
('32', 15, 5, 17, 34099) I do indeed happen to be the father of Harilal M. Gandhi.
('32', 15, 5, 18, 34157) He is my eldest boy, is over 36 years old and is father of four children, the eldest being 19 years old.
('32', 15, 5, 19, 34262) His ideals and mine having been discovered over fifteen years ago to be different, he has been having separately from me and, since 1915 has not been supported by or through me.
('32', 15, 5, 20, 34440) It has been my invariable rule to regard my boys as my friends and equals as soon as they completed their sixteen years.
('32', 15, 5, 21, 34561) The tremendous changes that my outer life has undergone from time to time were bound to leave their impress on my immediate surroundings,—especially on my children.
('32', 15, 5, 22, 34726) Harilal who was witness to all the changes, being old enough to understand them, was naturally influenced by the Western veneer that my life at one time did have.
('32', 15, 5, 23, 34889) His commercial undertakings were totally independent of me.
('32', 15, 5, 24, 34949) Could I have influenced him, he would have been found associated with me in my several public activities and earning, at the same time, a decent livelihood.
('32', 15, 5, 25, 35106) But he chose, as he had every right to do, a different and independent path.
('32', 15, 5, 26, 35183) He was and is still ambitious.
('32', 15, 5, 27, 35214) He wants to become rich and that too, easily.
('32', 15, 5, 28, 35260) Possibly he has a grievance against me that, when it was open to me to do so, I did not equip him and my other children for careers that lead to wealth and fame that wealth brings.
('32', 15, 5, 29, 35441) He started the Stores in question without any the least assistance of any kind whatsoever from me.
('32', 15, 5, 30, 35540) I did not lend my name to them.

('32', 16, 1, 2, 35655) anybody either privately or openly.
('32', 16, 1, 3, 35691) Those who helped him did so on the merits of the enterprise.
('32', 16, 1, 4, 35752) No doubt his sonship must have helped him.
('32', 16, 1, 5, 35795) As long as the world lasts, and in spite of its protest against varnashrama, it will give credit to heredity.
('32', 16, 1, 6, 35905) Being my son, he must be good and straight, cautious in his pecuniary affairs and as reliable as his father.
('32', 16, 1, 7, 36014) So must many have argued.
('32', 16, 1, 8, 36040) They have my sympathy, but beyond that nothing more.

('32', 16, 1, 10, 36310) I have enough to be responsible for myself.
('32', 16, 1, 11, 36354) I alone know my sorrows and my troubles in the course of the eternal duel going on within me and which admits of no truce.
('32', 16, 1, 12, 36477) I ask the reader to believe me when I say that it taxes all my energy, and if I feel as a rule stronger for the combat, it is only because I remain wide awake.
('32', 16, 1, 13, 36637) I make the reader a present of the thought that even my swaraj activity has a bearing on that duel.
('32', 16, 1, 14, 36737) It is for the supreme satisfaction of my soul that I engage in it.

('32', 16, 1, 16, 36870) I quickly agreed with him.
('32', 16, 1, 17, 36897) I do not know Harilal’s affairs.
('32', 16, 1, 18, 36930) He meets me occasionally, but I never pry into his affairs.

('32', 16, 1, 26, 37523) I co operate with all that is good.
('32', 16, 1, 27, 37559) I desire to non co operate with all that is evil,—whether it is associated with my wife, son or myself.
('32', 16, 1, 28, 37663) I have no desire to shield any of the two.

('32', 16, 1, 31, 37861) I never make the slightest attempt to hide them, for I know that concealment can only hurt us.
('32', 16, 1, 32, 37956) There is much in Harilal’s life that I dislike.

('32', 25, 3, 22, 58945) 23. NEED FOR PROTECTION
('32', 25, 4, 23, 58969) The history of the world shows that no business has prospered in the past without protection or help.
('32', 25, 4, 24, 59071) Help is of three kinds; it can come from the State of society or the individual himself.
('32', 25, 4, 25, 59160) In any new venture started with the intention of making money, the rich man invests his money without any hope of immediate return on his capital.
('32', 25, 4, 26, 59307) In a trade venture started for the benefit of society as a whole, the latter bears the material.
('32', 25, 4, 27, 59404) Where the Government is well organized and run for the benefit of the people, it will protect the new industry by subsidizing it.
('32', 25, 4, 28, 59534) The propagation of khadi is not for the benefit of any single individual and, therefore, it cannot receive protection from one person; even if it does, beyond a certain point such protection will be ineffective, for propagation of khadi cannot be achieved with money only.
('32', 25, 4, 29, 59807) If we can get the enthusiastic and unstinted support of the Government in this popular cause, what more could we want?
('32', 25, 4, 30, 59926) That would be evidence of change of heart on its part and
('32', 26, 0, 1, 59984) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 27
('32', 26, 1, 2, 60029) we would gladly co operate with it.
('32', 26, 1, 3, 60065) Now about the support of society.
('32', 26, 1, 4, 60099) Without it, we cannot expect the use of khadi to become universal in the immediate future.
('32', 26, 1, 5, 60190) We have been trying to secure this support in three ways, the aim being to make khadi cheaper and to improve its quality.
('32', 26, 1, 6, 60312) In the first place, we reduce the cost of khadi by obtaining monetary help from the wealthy.
('32', 26, 1, 7, 60405) Next, it is being helped through the franchise qualification.
('32', 26, 1, 8, 60467) One of the aims behind the inclusion of spinning as a qualification for the franchise is that people may donate half an hour’s daily labour to spinning and help reduce the cost of khadi and improve its quality.
('32', 26, 1, 9, 60678) The third way of helping the movement is to increase the number of khadi experts.
('32', 26, 1, 10, 60760) Efforts to help the cause in all three ways are going on simultaneously.
('32', 26, 1, 11, 60833) During my tours I could see that there is enough love for khadi among the people, or in other words, they are ready to wear it; but are not prepared to suffer the inconvenience of looking for it, or to spend more on it than they do on foreign cloth.
('32', 26, 1, 12, 61083) We have thus reached a stage when we can say that, if we can reduce the cost of producing khadi or sell it at cheaper prices, people will use it.
('32', 26, 1, 13, 61229) We have not received enough help from the wealthy.
('32', 26, 1, 14, 61280) Spinning has been included as a qualification for the franchise, but it has not been sincerely welcomed by the people so that the yarn produced in consequence may influence the price.
('32', 26, 1, 15, 61464) Thus, if society is not prepared to do even this for Mother India, how can we spread the use of khadi as widely as we would like?
('32', 26, 1, 16, 61594) Besides, as long as voluntary workers who are experts in spinning are not available in large numbers, the quality of yarn and of khadi cannot be improved.
('32', 26, 1, 17, 61749) All the three aims can be realized with the help of the middle class, that is, by a minority of the people.
('32', 26, 1, 18, 61857) If they are realized, people will take to khadi very soon.
('32', 26, 1, 19, 61916) It is, therefore, the middle class which is to blame, whether for a serious lapse or for inadequate effort.
('32', 26, 1, 20, 62024) If this class—the educated class— understands the importance of khadi it will not be difficult to spread its use; for then we shall be able to lower the price of khadi as much as we wish.
('32', 26, 1, 21, 62212) If we have a sufficient number of experts in spinning, we can have, in the same time, double or one and a half times the quantity of yarn we get now and of correspondingly better quality.
('32', 26, 1, 22, 62400) In their absence, we work on spinning wheels of indifferent quality and accept yarn of any quality we get.
('32', 26, 1, 23, 62507) These experts will repair defects in the spinning wheels and so help in increasing the out put of yarn and removing defects in its quality.
('32', 26, 1, 24, 62647) As a result, weaving will also cost less.
('32', 26, 1, 25, 62689) Handspun yarn, being of uneven quality, takes a
('32', 27, 0, 1, 62737) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 27, 1, 2, 62778) longer time to weave and so the weaving charges are higher than for the mill yarn.
('32', 27, 1, 3, 62861) Unfortunately, in the whole country we have only a limited number of spinning experts.
('32', 27, 1, 4, 62948) With the scanty preparation with which we started propaganda for spinning, we could have made no progress in any other activity.
('32', 27, 1, 5, 63077) The progress we have made despite our inadequate preparation is evidence of the power of khadi and its great importance for the country.
('32', 27, 1, 6, 63214) It is my firm belief that the khadi work is the most important among the activities going on in the country.
('32', 27, 1, 7, 63323) No other countrywide activity aiming at people’s welfare has involved as much circulation of money as khadi during the past four years, or has as many workers engaged in it and earning an honest livelihood through it or working for it honorarily.
('32', 27, 1, 8, 63570) The number is daily increasing.
('32', 27, 1, 9, 63602) If such a beneficial activity which requires only a modest effort to yield results receives help in all the three ways we have explained and in the right measure, I am sure that the country would become khadi minded in no time.
('32', 27, 1, 10, 63830) Let the wealthy give money, yet all men and women—Hindus, Muslims, Parsis and Christians—give at least half an hour [to spinning] and let khadi lovers become experts in its science and give the benefit of their knowledge.
('32', 27, 1, 11, 64052) The country will then become khadiminded, the flow of sixty crore rupees from it to foreign countries will stop and the money will be distributed among the poor, and, lastly, the country will acquire confidence in its own strength.

('32', 30, 1, 2, 69690) 25. APPEAL FOR DESHBANDHU MEMORIAL FUND
('32', 30, 2, 3, 69730) CALCUTTA, June 22, 1925 The public may be aware that the late Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das gave, during his lifetime, his mansion at Russa Road, situated on over 4 bighas of land, in trust for several public objects.
('32', 30, 2, 4, 69946) We are informed by the trustees that the present value of the property is estimated at Rs. 3,25,000 and that it is burdened with a debt of Rs. 2,20,000. The net value of the donation is therefore about Rs. 1,05,000. We the undersigned feel sure that Bengal would desire to erect a Memorial worthy of the deceased patriot.
('32', 30, 2, 5, 70268) Indeed, the unexampled manifestation of grief witnessed in Calcutta on the 18th instant and the public meetings held all over the country to honour the memory of the deceased are positive proof of such a desire.
('32', 30, 2, 6, 70480) We think that the best way to carry out what appears to us to be the central idea of Deshbandhu in creating the trust referred to by us would be to help in the uplift of the womanhood of Bengal.
('32', 30, 2, 7, 70675) The founding of a hospital for women irrespective of caste or creed and an institution for the training of nurses is, we believe, a project eminently calculated to promote Deshbandhu’s intention.
('32', 30, 2, 8, 70871) It is estimated that nothing less than Rs. 10,00,000 would meet the requirements.
('32', 30, 2, 9, 70953) We believe, too, that 10 lakhs is in no way an extravagant sum for a Memorial to our deceased countryman.
('32', 30, 2, 10, 71059) We, therefore, appeal to the public of Bengal for the sum.
('32', 30, 2, 11, 71118) Our desire is to make this a non party Memorial so that all who know the worth of Deshbandhu, although they might not have shared his politics, might take part in subscribing to the memorial.

('32', 35, 2, 5, 78057) 31. INTERVIEW TO “THE STATESMAN”
('32', 35, 3, 6, 78090) [Before June 24, 1925]
('32', 35, 4, 7, 78113) In the course of an interview which he granted to a representative of The Statesman in Calcutta he said : I shall remain here as long as I feel that I am required, or as long as the trusted lieutenants of Mr. Das want me.
('32', 35, 4, 8, 78335) I have placed myself unreservedly at their disposal.
('32', 35, 4, 9, 78388) I have already suggested that Memorial services should be held throughout India on July 1. I am hoping that people representing every variety of opinion will attend in every important centre in India and I am likely to remain here at least up to that date.
('32', 35, 5, 10, 78645) Asked for his opinion regarding the future, Mr. Gandhi said : It is very difficult to say as a man of the world what the future will be, but as a man of faith I can say that the virtues which I was privileged to see in the late Mr. Das will be an asset, resulting in nothing but good.
('32', 35, 5, 11, 78930) How it will work out I do not know.
('32', 35, 6, 12, 78966) Referring to a suggestion which he had previously made that the death of Mr. Das should be marked by a union of parties, Mr. Gandhi said : If the union can be brought about, not mechanical, but real, it would be for that united party to formulate its demand.
('32', 35, 6, 13, 79225) It is no use myself personally saying what it should be, but I can say this that, whatever I may wish, I shall not stand in the way of what the majority may wish.
('32', 35, 7, 14, 79388) “What is your definition of swaraj?” Mr. Gandhi was asked.
('32', 35, 7, 15, 79447) My definition of swaraj is the will for the time being of the people of India, as expressed through their representatives.
('32', 35, 7, 16, 79570) There cannot be any hard and fast definition of swaraj, as you have, for instance, of a straight line in geometry.
('32', 35, 7, 17, 79685) It has a varying value according to the variation in the temperament of the people domi nated by various circumstances.
('32', 35, 7, 18, 79805) Therefore, the immediate definition of swaraj is “Dominion Home Rule”.
('32', 35, 8, 19, 79876) Mr. Gandhi was asked whether he would advise the abandonment of obstructive

('32', 36, 2, 4, 80257) I would like Bengal not to be despondent, not to lose faith, because that would be betrayal of the great leader who has passed away.
('32', 36, 2, 5, 80390) I know that he believed often, when there was absolutely no valid reason for belief, and yet his belief was justified by events.

('32', 38, 1, 2, 83269) 35. NOTES
('32', 38, 2, 3, 83279) NO INJUSTICE MEANT
('32', 38, 3, 4, 83298) When you say you have not attracted educated India to your message, are you not doing an injustice to educated Indians?
('32', 38, 3, 5, 83418) Look at Rajagopalachari, your right hand man, not to mention the band of selfless educated Indian workers scattered throughout the length and breadth of India whom you rarely even mention in Young India!
('32', 38, 3, 6, 83622) Where would you have been but for them?
('32', 38, 3, 7, 83662) It is all
('32', 38, 4, 8, 83672) very well to talk of village work, but you are doing that too by their aid!
('32', 38, 4, 9, 83748) This question raises a false issue.
('32', 38, 4, 10, 83784) One swallow does not make a summer.
('32', 38, 4, 11, 83820) The handful of selfless educated Indians who are silently serving and spreading the message of the spinning wheel are, indeed, a credit to themselves and the country.
('32', 38, 4, 12, 83987) Without them I should be perfectly helpless.
('32', 38, 4, 13, 84032) But they are no more representatives of educated India than I am.
('32', 38, 4, 14, 84098) As a class, educated Indians stand aloof, not because they are unwilling, but because they are unconvinced.
('32', 38, 4, 15, 84206) When I wrote the passage 1, I had in my mind such men as Messrs Sastri, Jinnah, Chintamani, Sapru and a whole host of our distinguished educated countrymen.
('32', 38, 4, 16, 84363) The rank and file, though they like me personally, have a horror for my views and methods.
('32', 38, 4, 17, 84454) Some of them occasionally but earnestly plead with me to mend my ways so as to make it possible for them to work with me.
('32', 38, 4, 18, 84576) Nor did I write the passage referred to by way of complaint.
('32', 38, 4, 19, 84637) I have simply stated the fact with the object of my showing limitations and showing, too, that they are as necessary for the national uplift as the tallest among those who represent the spinning wheel with all its implications.
('32', 38, 4, 20, 84865) I own again that the leadership of the Congress should be rightly theirs and that I must not force the issue by a mere shuffling of votes.
('32', 38, 4, 21, 85004) On the contrary, I must patiently wait till I have convinced them of the supreme necessity of the spinning wheel and khaddar even for the political emancipation of India.
('32', 38, 5, 22, 85175) INSTITUTIONS BEFORE PARENTS During my Bengal tour, I heard the astounding statement that the inmates of a public institution claimed to prefer the maintenance of their institution to that of their parents.
('32', 38, 5, 23, 85381) This was said to command my approval.
('32', 38, 5, 24, 85419) If anything I have written in t hese pages has given any such impression, I apologize to the readers.
('32', 38, 6, 25, 85521) 1 The reference presumably is to the article “Are We Ready?”, 18 6 1925.
('32', 39, 0, 1, 85594) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 39, 1, 2, 85635) not conscious of any such guilt.
('32', 39, 1, 3, 85668) I owe all I am to my parents.
('32', 39, 1, 4, 85698) I felt towards them as Shravana is said to have done towards his parents.
('32', 39, 1, 5, 85772) So, when I heard the statement, it was with greatest difficulty that I could curb the anger that was rising in me.
('32', 39, 1, 6, 85887) The young man who took up the position was hardly serious about it.
('32', 39, 1, 7, 85955) But nowadays it has become the fashion with some young men to adopt the superior attitude and pose as paragons of perfection.
('32', 39, 1, 8, 86081) In my opinion, the maintenance of one’s aged and infirm parents is a first charge upon grown up sons.
('32', 39, 1, 9, 86183) They may not marry if they are not in a position to support their parents.
('32', 39, 1, 10, 86258) They may not take up public work till this primary condition is fulfilled.
('32', 39, 1, 11, 86333) They must starve so that their parents may be fed and clothed.
('32', 39, 1, 12, 86396) What, however, young men are not expected to do is to comply with the demand of thoughtless or ignorant parents.
('32', 39, 1, 13, 86509) Parents have been known to demand money for things not required for sustenance, but for false show or for uncalled for marriage expenses of daughters.
('32', 39, 1, 14, 86660) In my opinion, it is the duty of public workers respectfully to refuse to meet such demands.
('32', 39, 1, 15, 86753) As a matter of fact, I cannot remember having met a single deserving case of starvation of a public worker.
('32', 39, 1, 16, 86861) I have found some living in want.
('32', 39, 1, 17, 86895) I have found a few who should get more than they are able to give themselves.
('32', 39, 1, 18, 86973) But, as their work prospers and their worth is known, they will not suffer from want.
('32', 39, 1, 19, 87059) Difficulties and trials make a man.
('32', 39, 1, 20, 87095) They are a sign of healthy growth.
('32', 39, 1, 21, 87130) If every young man found himself in plenty and never knew what it was to go without anything necessary, he may be found wanting when the trial comes.
('32', 39, 1, 22, 87280) Sacrifice is joy.
('32', 39, 1, 23, 87298) It is, therefore, not right to parade one’s sacrifice before the public.
('32', 39, 1, 24, 87371) I was told by several workers that they did not mind any sacrifice.
('32', 39, 1, 25, 87439) On cross questioning, I was told that the sacrifice consisted in living by begging, in other words, on donations.
('32', 39, 1, 26, 87553) I told them that there was no sacrifice in living on donations.
('32', 39, 1, 27, 87617) Many public workers did so, but they did not on that account claim to have sacrificed anything.
('32', 39, 1, 28, 87713) Many young men have sacrificed lucrative careers.
('32', 39, 1, 29, 87763) That is certainly to their credit.
('32', 39, 1, 30, 87798) But even there I should respectfully suggest that praising can well be overdone.
('32', 39, 1, 31, 87879) No sacrifice is worth the name unless it is a joy.
('32', 39, 1, 32, 87930) Sacrifice and a long face go ill together.
('32', 39, 1, 33, 87973) Sacrifice is “making sacred”.

('32', 39, 1, 35, 88088) Buddha renounced everything because he could not help it.

('32', 40, 2, 9, 88839) SPINNING IN AFFILIATED SCHOOLS During this Bengal tour of mine, I am coming upon many revelations—many pleasant, some unpleasant.
('32', 40, 2, 10, 88969) There is a village called Upashi, not far from Madaripur.
('32', 40, 2, 11, 89027) A High School is being conducted in this village.
('32', 40, 2, 12, 89077) It is affiliated, but takes no aid from the Government.
('32', 40, 2, 13, 89133) Spinning for one hour has been compulsory for all the boys since the revival of spinning.
('32', 40, 2, 14, 89223) Weaving was introduced as an optional subject on the arrest in 1921 of Maulana Mahomed Ali.
('32', 40, 2, 15, 89315) Weaving has been still recently confined to half khaddar.
('32', 40, 2, 16, 89373) It was only a few months ago that full khaddar weaving was introduced.
('32', 40, 2, 17, 89444) Now the management has undertaken to do away with half khaddar and confine their attention only to pure khaddar.
('32', 40, 2, 18, 89557) It was a perfect pleasure to watch about a hundred boys spinning all at the same time.
('32', 40, 2, 19, 89644) Upon inquiry, I found that the attendance had not suffered by reason of compulsory spinning.
('32', 40, 2, 20, 89737) The head master told me that he could not have continued it if the parents had disapproved of it or the boys resented it.
('32', 40, 2, 21, 89859) The head master put the visitors’ book before me for my remarks.
('32', 40, 2, 22, 89924) On turning over the pages, I read a long report from the Inspector of Schools.
('32', 40, 2, 23, 90003) Whilst he had no prejudice against spinning, his experience of the experiment, wherever made, went to show that they were a failure as at this school.
('32', 40, 2, 24, 90154) The Inspector thought that the experiment to be called a success should be self supporting.
('32', 40, 2, 25, 90246) I do not know why a spinning class should be self supporting any more than a geometry class.
('32', 40, 2, 26, 90339) The success of the latter would be measured by the progress made by the boys in geometry.
('32', 40, 2, 27, 90429) The success of a spinning class should be measured by the proficiency of the boys in spinning.
('32', 40, 2, 28, 90524) And that the boys of the High School could show any day.
('32', 40, 2, 29, 90581) But I am quite prepared to accept the Inspector’s challenge and show that, whilst the literary classes cannot be made self supporting except in certain cases, a spinning class can always be made self supporting.
('32', 41, 0, 1, 90793) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 41, 1, 2, 90834) the first instance, a separate spinning master is not a necessity.
('32', 41, 1, 3, 90901) By small inducements the existing staff can be induced to acquire sufficient knowledge in spinning and they can teach their respective classes.
('32', 41, 1, 4, 91045) It is even enough to train willing school boys themselves to learn the science so as to be able to teach.

('32', 41, 2, 11, 91457) be no more than Rs. 2 1 2 per month, thus leaving a margin of Rs. 5 per month as saving.

('32', 43, 2, 13, 96631) 36. PLEA FOR HUMILITY
('32', 43, 3, 14, 96653) In my talks with public workers in Bengal, I came across a young man who among his claims for public recognition, mentioned his and his fellow workers’ brahmacharya or celibacy.
('32', 43, 3, 15, 96831) The manner of presenting the claim and the self assurance with which the young man spoke repelled me and I felt that he was talking about things he little knew.
('32', 43, 3, 16, 96992) His fellow workers repudiated the claim.
('32', 43, 3, 17, 97033) And the young man himself, when I cross questioned him, admitted that the claim could not be sustained.
('32', 43, 3, 18, 97137) A man who consciously sins with his mind, even though he may not sin with his body is not a celibate.
('32', 43, 3, 19, 97239) One who cannot remain unmoved at the sight of a woman, however beautiful she may be, is not a celibate.
('32', 43, 3, 20, 97343) One who keeps his body under control from sheer necessity, does well but is not a celibate.
('32', 43, 3, 21, 97435) We may not degrade sacred words by a loose use of them.
('32', 43, 3, 22, 97491) True celibacy has important results which can be verified.
('32', 43, 3, 23, 97550) It is a difficult virtue to practise.
('32', 43, 3, 24, 97588) Many attempt it but few succeed.
('32', 43, 3, 25, 97621) Those who walk about the country in the garb of sannyasins are often no more celibates than the ordinary man in the street.
('32', 43, 3, 26, 97745) Only the latter is often a better man as he makes no pretension to virtue.
('32', 43, 3, 27, 97820) He is satisfied that his Maker knows

('32', 48, 2, 6, 108648) 39. DUTY OF SATYAGRAHIS
('32', 48, 3, 7, 108672) CALCUTTA, June 25, 1925 We have been asked what is the duty of satyagrahis in view of the recent judgment of the District Court of Hooghly, appointing a Receiver for all the properties including the Temple at Tarakeshwar and purporting to belong to the Mohunt.
('32', 48, 3, 8, 108933) In our opinion, it is impossible for satyagrahis to resist the possession by the Receiver when he comes to take it, nor is there any meaning in resisting his possession.
('32', 48, 3, 9, 109103) The satyagraha was offered against the Mohunt or rather his methods.
('32', 48, 3, 10, 109172) He is not in possession and the Court’s order does not put him in possession.
('32', 48, 3, 11, 109250) On the contrary, the judgment makes it clear that the Mohunt could not succeed, though he tried in gaining whole or partial possession.
('32', 48, 3, 12, 109386) The object of satyagraha was to get rid of abuses in connection with the temple and to secure public entry to the Lakshmi Narain Temple.
('32', 48, 3, 13, 109523) There is no question under the Court’s order of any reversion to the old abuses or prohibition to temple entry.
('32', 48, 3, 14, 109635) It is a matter of no moment to satyagrahis who has possession so long as the Temple management is pure and it is not the Mohunt who has the management.
('32', 48, 3, 15, 109787) The satyagrahis’ duty will, therefore, be to hand [over], on demand, the possession to the Receiver.
('32', 48, 3, 16, 109888) It will be time to reconsider the position when and if abuses creep in.
('32', 48, 3, 17, 109960) It does not matter who become trustees of the Temple so long as there is a public trust

('32', 49, 1, 2, 110089) properly managed.

('32', 49, 4, 19, 111751) Yours sincerely,

('32', 57, 1, 2, 128536) 47. LONG LIVE DESHBANDHU!
('32', 57, 2, 3, 128562) I had the good fortune of being in Bombay when the Lokamanya passed away.
('32', 57, 2, 4, 128636) Providence favoured me also on the day when Deshbandhu was cremated, or, rather, Fate seemed to have waited for the first lap of my tour to be over, for had the cremation taken place one day earlier, I would not have been able to witness the scene which I did in Calcutta.
('32', 57, 2, 5, 128909) Just as the citizens of Bombay had abandoned themselves to grief on the day of the Lokamanya’s death, so did the people of Calcutta on this day.
('32', 57, 2, 6, 129054) At that time, countless men and women had come out to have darshan, to weep and express their love.
('32', 57, 2, 7, 129154) Now, as then, there was no community or race whose members were not present to honour the departed.
('32', 57, 2, 8, 129254) When the train arrived at the station, there was not an inch of space on the platform.
('32', 57, 2, 9, 129341) People vied with oneanother for the honour of carrying Deshbandhu’s bier, as they had for the Lokamanya’s.
('32', 57, 2, 10, 129448) On both these occasions, it was the people’s rule.
('32', 57, 2, 11, 129499) The crowds were not ruled by the police, but the latter of their own free will were ruled by the people.
('32', 57, 2, 12, 129604) The authority of the Government was voluntarily suspended and the people’s rule was in force.
('32', 57, 2, 13, 129698) On that day, people did what they chose.
('32', 57, 2, 14, 129739) What Deshbandhu wanted to see people doing when he was alive, they did on the day of his leaving this world for the next.
('32', 57, 2, 15, 129861) Is this an object lesson of small value?
('32', 57, 2, 16, 129902) Is there anything which the bond of love will not make people do?
('32', 57, 2, 17, 129968) On that day, they “endured hardships, bore hunger and thirst, cold and heat”, and did it all cheerfully.
('32', 57, 2, 18, 130073) It was not necessary to plead with them and persuade them to suffer what they did.
('32', 57, 2, 19, 130156) No such crowds collect on the death of an emperor.
('32', 57, 2, 20, 130207) People do not notice the death of a sannyasi, nor do newspapers and news agencies.
('32', 57, 2, 21, 130290) Urged by what sense of duty, then, had the old and the young, men and women, the rich and the poor, Hindus and Muslims gathered there, uninvited, in the twinkling of an eye?
('32', 57, 2, 22, 130464) It was their sense of duty to the nation.
('32', 57, 2, 23, 130506) People will in these days describe only those who do this duty as men imbued with the spirit of dharma.
('32', 57, 2, 24, 130610) They are even ready to forget the weaknesses of those who follow this dharma.
('32', 57, 2, 25, 130688) There is some mean ing in this.
('32', 57, 2, 26, 130720) People are not foolish in acting thus.
('32', 57, 2, 27, 130759) God alone is perfect.
('32', 57, 2, 28, 130781) Every human being is liable to err.
('32', 57, 2, 29, 130817) If, however,
('32', 58, 0, 1, 130830) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 59
('32', 58, 1, 2, 130875) any person does his own proper duty to the best of his ability, his weaknesses will not be noticed and, as he goes on doing his duty, they will ultimately disappear.
('32', 58, 1, 3, 131041) National service is the only dharma today, for unless we follow that we can follow no other.
('32', 58, 1, 4, 131134) The power of the State has penetrated every aspect of national life.
('32', 58, 1, 5, 131203) In countries where the power of the State is the power of the people, the subjects are happy on the whole, and where the State is hostile to the people, the latter are miserable and utterly weak.
('32', 58, 1, 6, 131399) In such countries the people lead a sinful life and call it good, for those who live in fear are incapable of good ness.
('32', 58, 1, 7, 131520) To free ourselves from this paralysing fear, i.e., to learn the first lesson in self realization, is what we call the dharma of national service.
('32', 58, 1, 8, 131666) What have our patriotic leaders been teaching us?
('32', 58, 1, 9, 131716) That we should not fear even a king, that we are men and men need fear God alone.
('32', 58, 1, 10, 131798) Neither King George V nor his representatives can inspire fear in them.
('32', 58, 1, 11, 131870) The Lokamanya had abandoned all fear of the State’s machinery of law and order and, therefore, he was the adored of the people, even of learned men, for he inspired them with courage.
('32', 58, 1, 12, 132054) Deshbandhu had also completely shed fear of the Government.
('32', 58, 1, 13, 132114) To his mind, the Viceroy and the gate keeper were equal.
('32', 58, 1, 14, 132171) He had seen with his inner eye that, everything considered, there was no difference between the two.
('32', 58, 1, 15, 132272) If it is unmanly to fear the Viceroy, so is it to try to overcome the gate keeper.
('32', 58, 1, 16, 132355) There is a profound spiritual vision behind this attitude, and that is the meaning of the dharma of national service.
('32', 58, 1, 17, 132473) For this reason, consciously or unconsciously and even against their will, people look with reverence upon those who follow this dharma.
('32', 58, 1, 18, 132610) The Lokamanya was a Brahmin.

('32', 69, 4, 12, 155705) July 1, 1925 My capacity for writing original articles on the same subject is strictly limited.
('32', 69, 4, 13, 155801) I must, therefore, turn to good account the request of the editor to write something on Deshbandhu.

('32', 79, 1, 5, 179107) FROM ‘A REVOLUTIONARY’
('32', 79, 2, 6, 179130) Shrimati Basanti Devi has handed me an anonymous letter received by her from ‘a revolutionary’, from which I take the following :
('32', 79, 3, 7, 179260) Tears roll down and blur my sight in my attempt to write to you at this moment.
('32', 79, 3, 8, 179340) I tried to go for a visit to 148, but could not sum up my courage to stand before you.
('32', 79, 3, 9, 179427) The sight is heart rending.
('32', 79, 4, 10, 179455) In the death of Deshbandhu Das a great man has fallen—perhaps the greatest the country has produced.
('32', 79, 4, 11, 179556) There is none to fill up the gap.
('32', 79, 4, 12, 179590) I am one of those who came to know him not when he gave up his extensive practice at the Bar and its princely income, but long before that when out of his seclusion— as it were—he came out to defend Sreejut Aurobindo Ghose in the Alipur Bomb Case, and from that time came to love him, came to have the highest regard and admiration for and devotion to him.
('32', 79, 4, 13, 179947) He, too, always had a very soft and warm corner for us in his heart though he has not seen eye to eye with us in politics.
('32', 79, 4, 14, 180070) For I am one of those who were, in the Partition days, wrongly called Anarchists and who are now very wrongly called the “Revolutionaries”.
('32', 79, 4, 15, 180210) He knew we were much misunderstood and misrepresented and much maligned because of our love of freedom for our common Motherland.
('32', 79, 4, 16, 180340) To everyone of us he always extended a brother’s hand, always trying to guide us in the right path.
('32', 79, 4, 17, 180440) We sadly miss him today.
('32', 79, 4, 18, 180465) We are overwhelmed with grief today to his death, for we know there is no man in the country whom we can turn to in our hour of sore need.
('32', 79, 5, 19, 180604) Leaders will come and leaders will go; but Deshbandhu Das will never come.
('32', 79, 5, 20, 180679) He was the hope and inspiration of the people.
('32', 79, 5, 21, 180726) He was the idol of the nation.
('32', 79, 5, 22, 180757) His help and guidance were always, as it were, at our disposal and our services, nay our very lives, he knew, were at his command.
('32', 79, 5, 23, 180888) And here I need only assure you, my dear sister, that our services—nay our lives—are, and shall ever continue to be, at your command.
('32', 79, 5, 24, 181022) The portion omitted is a reassurance of sympathy.
('32', 79, 5, 25, 181072) This letter is an unsolicited testimonial of Deshbandhu’s views on revolutionary activities.

('32', 80, 1, 4, 181649) AN ERROR?
('32', 80, 2, 5, 181659) Here is a letter from the Secretary, District Congress Committee, Pabna : 1
('32', 80, 3, 6, 181735) I appreciate the letter as it expects from me the utmost accuracy of statement and scrupulous impartiality.
('32', 80, 3, 7, 181843) I am anxious to live up to the expectation as far as it is humanly possible.
('32', 80, 3, 8, 181920) But, in spite of all my care, I may do an injustice to some and may be unduly biassed in favour of others; after all both are injustices in the long run.
('32', 80, 3, 9, 182074) A man or an institution that is undeservedly belauded may even suffer more than the one unjustly decried.
('32', 80, 3, 10, 182180) But in the case in point I have been most guarded.
('32', 80, 3, 11, 182231) And whilst almost everything that the secretary says may have been true at one time, it was not true at the time I wrote.
('32', 80, 3, 12, 182353) I was not adjudging the relative merits of the institutions named nor comparing their account.
('32', 80, 3, 13, 182448) I merely stated that, at the time of writing there were so many khaddar producing institutions which I had visited.
('32', 80, 3, 14, 182564) I included in these Satsang Ashram, though it was the latest recruit.
('32', 80, 3, 15, 182634) I saw more than 40 wheels going when I visited the Ashram.
('32', 80, 3, 16, 182693) Among those spinning were the relatives of the founder, including his wife.
('32', 80, 3, 17, 182769) I was shown too, khaddar woven at the place.
('32', 80, 3, 18, 182814) But above all, Deshbandhu, at whose instance I visited the Ashram, had told me that the founder had decided to make spinning and production of khaddar one of its principal activities.
('32', 80, 3, 19, 182998) The manager who was my guide during my visit confirmed that statement.
('32', 80, 3, 20, 183069) I would have been unjust if I had not, after all this evidence before me, included the Ashram as one of the khaddar centres.
('32', 80, 3, 21, 183194) I admit that, at the present moment, there can be no comparison between the Satsang Ashram and the Abhoy Ashram.
('32', 80, 3, 22, 183307) The letter is as old as, if not older than, the Khadi Pratishthan and was founded chiefly for khaddar and the wheel.
('32', 80, 3, 23, 183424) Its production is only next to that of Khadi Pratishthan, and [it] has branches in several parts.
('32', 80, 3, 24, 183522) But my purpose in writing the article in question was not to examine the relative merits, but to bring to the notice of the public the
('32', 80, 4, 25, 183657) 1 Not reproduced here.
('32', 80, 4, 26, 183680) This drew Gandhiji’s attention to an error in the article “Khadi Pratishthan”, 12 7 1925, in which he wrote of a Satsang Ashram at Pabna as a khaddar manufacturing centre comparable to the Abhoy Ashram at Comilla.
('32', 80, 4, 27, 183894) According to the correspondent, the Ashram did little work of this kind and actually helped to promote sale of foreign cloth.

('32', 81, 1, 4, 184307) ‘A REVOLUTIONARY IN THE MAKING’ You are too philosophical and too abstruse for me.
('32', 81, 1, 5, 184390) We must for the time being, therefore, agree to differ and pray for each other till we meet some day in the course of my wanderings.

('32', 81, 1, 11, 185417) AN ANCIENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY
('32', 81, 2, 12, 185446) When I was at Santiniketan, Mr. Andrews handed me the following extracts from a celebrated Tamil poet, Vemana 1, on untouchability :
('32', 81, 3, 13, 185579) BOOK II
('32', 81, 4, 14, 185587) 135. Consider not him a pariah who is so by birth; he who breaks his word is far viler.
('32', 81, 4, 15, 185675) He who reproaches the pariah is (go to) worse than him (sic).
('32', 81, 5, 16, 185737) 156. Why should you revile a pariah when you see him?
('32', 81, 5, 17, 185791) This is merely unmannerly language.
('32', 81, 5, 18, 185827) Of what caste is He who speaks in the pariah?
('32', 81, 6, 19, 185873) BOOK III
('32', 81, 7, 20, 185882) 111. “Thou art defiled and unclean, touch me not!” they cry.
('32', 81, 7, 21, 185943) What limits are there to defilement?
('32', 81, 7, 22, 185980) What is its source?
('32', 81, 7, 23, 186000) All human bodies are equally unclean; defilement is born with ourselves in the body.
('32', 81, 8, 24, 186085) 162. They that are born Sudras, and yet revile Sudras; who hold themselves twice born and rely on their title; still, if unable to restrain their
('32', 81, 9, 25, 186231) 1 Vemama was a Telugu poet who flourished in the early part of the fifteenth century.

('32', 82, 1, 2, 186362) hearts, are the lowest of Sudras.
('32', 82, 2, 3, 186396) 164. If a man still has in his heart the principles of a pariah, and yet scorns pariahs, how should he become twice born, while devoid of every good quality?

('32', 82, 8, 15, 187644) 61. DESHBANDHU MEMORIAL FUND Friends have pressed it upon me that, in the interest of the Memorial Fund that is being collected, it is necessary for me not to leave Calcutta at the present moment for the projected tour.
('32', 82, 8, 16, 187864) Whilst I recognize the usefulness of my presence, after comparing notes with Satcowri Babu, I have come to the conclusion that the tour already advertised ought not to be abandoned.
('32', 82, 8, 17, 188046) After all, the collections that are pouring in come from thousands of grateful hearts.
('32', 82, 8, 18, 188133) Personally I have never entertained the slightest doubt about the response of Bengal.
('32', 82, 8, 19, 188219) We are not an ungrateful nation, and Bengal is not [to] be surpassed by any province in gratefulness.
('32', 82, 8, 20, 188321) Given the proper cause, Bengal is capable of rising to the highest height.
('32', 82, 8, 21, 188396) And what cause can be more proper and sacred, more insistent, than a memorial in honour of Deshbandhu?
('32', 82, 8, 22, 188499) I do not, therefore, regard my presence in Calcutta as essential for ensuring the continuous flow, and shall carry out the tour in the full confidence that the subscriptions will continue with
('32', 83, 0, 1, 188692) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 83, 1, 2, 188733) unabated perseverance, until the whole of the sum of ten lakhs is made up.
('32', 83, 1, 3, 188808) I see that, at the time of writing this note, the total collections amount to over Rs. 2,40,000, of which over Rs. 61,000/ , being today’s collection, has to be still delivered to the treasurer.
('32', 83, 1, 4, 189003) If anything like the present rate of progress continues—and there is no reason why it ought not to—we shall reach ten lakhs by the middle of this month.
('32', 83, 1, 5, 189156) That we were not able to collect the whole sum by the end of June means no reflection on Bengal.
('32', 83, 1, 6, 189253) It was possible, but only just possible, to complete the collection in the eight days that were available.
('32', 83, 1, 7, 189360) It pre supposed a perfect organization or ability and willingness on the part of a few to find the whole sum.
('32', 83, 1, 8, 189470) I can almost say that, where ever I have gone, I have gone, I have found the will to pay, but owing to the great depression in trade, the ability to pay large sums has been lacking.
('32', 83, 1, 9, 189652) And it must be frankly confessed that nowhere in India are we sufficiently organized to reach the names for small collections amongst them in a short time.
('32', 83, 1, 10, 189808) It is a magnificient tribute to Deshbandhu’s memory that, with the very imperfect organization that the Committee have been able to bring into being, small sums are pouring in such a manner as to keep at least six workers at work, receiving monies from early morning to 10 o’clock at night and even later, not to mention a number of clerks that Sir Rajendra Nath has put on the work of receiving subscriptions and copying the very long lists, containing the names of subscribers, of annas, pice and even half pice.
('32', 83, 1, 11, 190323) Whilst, therefore, I shall undertake to finish the balance of the Bengal tour without any misgivings, I wish to notify it to the friends who have invited me to different places mentioned in the tour programme, that my principal work in the tour will be to deliver the living message of the late patriot and to collect subscriptions for the memorial.
('32', 83, 1, 12, 190673) And I hope that they will so arrange the programme in the respective places as to enable maximum amounts to be collected.
('32', 83, 1, 13, 190795) I trust that they will not spend much money on reception arrangements.
('32', 83, 1, 14, 190866) I suggest that all decoration will be carefully eschewed and the collections made for reception be saved to the utmost extent possible and be devoted to the Memorial Fund, as is already being done in North Calcutta.
('32', 83, 1, 15, 191082) I would like here gratefully to mention the fact that telegraphic and postal money orders are pouring in from all parts of Bengal and all other parts of India where Bengalis are domiciled.
('32', 83, 1, 16, 191271) I may add that those who are at present receiving monies at 148, Russa Road, will continue to do so in my temporary absence which will begin from part of next Saturday to Wednesday following.

('32', 84, 2, 4, 191709) 62. RAINING BANGLES It was a grand sight—the mass meeting on the Maidan.
('32', 84, 2, 5, 191782) The arrangements made by the volunteers were perfect.
('32', 84, 2, 6, 191836) Not a man moved from his seat up to the time of the passing of the resolution in solemn silence, the whole of the great audience standing for full one minute.
('32', 84, 2, 7, 191995) I have never witnessed in Bengal a meeting so dignified, so solemn and so respectful.
('32', 84, 2, 8, 192081) I tender my congratulations to those who gathered at the Maidan and the volunteers who carried out the arrangements.
('32', 84, 2, 9, 192198) I am sorry that I was unable to attend the Town Hall meeting, much as I had intended to.
('32', 84, 2, 10, 192287) I was detained for over an hour, i.e., up to 7.45 at the ladies’ meeting.
('32', 84, 2, 11, 192361) This meeting was a wonderful sight.
('32', 84, 2, 12, 192397) In response to the appeal made to them, they rained gold bangles, rings and necklaces.

('32', 84, 2, 17, 193197) It is for that reason that I lay emphasis upon those who will, collecting only amongst their friends, so as to avoid all possibility of fraud.

('32', 85, 1, 2, 193412) 63. ADVICE TO HINDUS 1
('32', 85, 2, 3, 193435) CALCUTTA, July 2, 1925
('32', 85, 3, 4, 193458) At the Hindu quarters, where Mr. Gandhi spoke to the Hindus, Maulana Azad was also present.
('32', 85, 3, 5, 193550) Mr. Gandhi asked the Hindus to leave their lathis and purify their minds.
('32', 85, 3, 6, 193624) He said that the Hindus had done wrong by molesting their Mohammedan brethren.
('32', 85, 3, 7, 193703) His information was that no kurbani (slaughter) took place before the eyes of the Hindus.
('32', 85, 3, 8, 193793) Even if there was a kurbani the Hindus had no right to kill men.
('32', 85, 4, 9, 193858) was the injunction of the Hindu Shastra to protect the cow, it was also the injunction to protect men in order to protect the cow.
('32', 85, 4, 10, 193989) They had no right to kill men.
('32', 85, 4, 11, 194020) To kill men was a greater crime than killing cows.
('32', 85, 4, 12, 194071) If Hinduism meant righting a wrong by committing a greater crime then his religion was not Hinduism.
('32', 85, 4, 13, 194172) Mr. Gandhi said : I have come to help you, if you have committed any crime.
('32', 85, 4, 14, 194248) I would ask the culprit to come forward and say : ‘I have killed or wounded men’.
('32', 85, 4, 15, 194330) Let him confess to the police and go to jail or be hanged.
('32', 85, 4, 16, 194389) The Hindu, 3 7 1925
('32', 85, 5, 17, 194409) 64. STATEMENT TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('32', 85, 6, 18, 194452) CALCUTTA, July 2, 1925 At about 4 p.m.
('32', 85, 6, 19, 194491) whilst I was attending a meeting of signatories to the Memorial, Mr. J. M. Sen Gupta gave the meeting the information that , there was a man waiting outside with a report of a serious riot in the coolie lines at Kidderpore dock.
('32', 85, 6, 20, 194720) We immediately asked the man to come inside and, hearing his report, I suggested to Mr. Sen Gupta that he might telephone and enquire what the matter really was.
('32', 85, 6, 21, 194882) He, however, preferred to motor himself and find out the situation and on reaching there, the scene of trouble, he sent a telephone message to Maulana Abul Kalam Azad Saheb asking him to go there and take me with him.
('32', 85, 6, 22, 195100) Maulana Saheb came and we immediately motored.
('32', 85, 6, 23, 195147) This was about 5.30 p.m.
('32', 85, 6, 24, 195172) On the way, we f ound a large number of Mussalmans in an excited state saying that
('32', 85, 7, 25, 195255) 1 Riots had broken out in Calcutta on the occasion of Bakr Id.
('32', 85, 7, 26, 195318) Vide also the following item.
('32', 86, 0, 1, 195348) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 87
('32', 86, 1, 2, 195393) many Mussalmans had been killed.
('32', 86, 1, 3, 195426) They had lathis with them.
('32', 86, 1, 4, 195453) Maulana Saheb pacified them and told them that he and I were going to investigate and that, whatever had happened, they must not think of taking revenge for what they might consider wrong done by Hindus.
('32', 86, 1, 5, 195657) They listened to Maulana Saheb and consented to disperse.
('32', 86, 1, 6, 195715) On reaching the gate, we met Mr. Sen Gupta who told us that when he arrived there, there was a free fight going on which was stopped with some difficulty.
('32', 86, 1, 7, 195870) Police were guarding the approaches and the compound seemed to have been cleared of strangers.
('32', 86, 1, 8, 195965) We then went to Coolie barracks and on the way met a large crowd of Hindus armed with lathis.
('32', 86, 1, 9, 196059) Upon enquiring, they said they had gathered there in self defence as they were afraid of being attacked by Mussalmans.
('32', 86, 1, 10, 196178) I spoke to them at some length and told them that the information at our disposal went to show that Hindus had mercilessly assaulted Mussalmans who were numerically much weaker than they.
('32', 86, 1, 11, 196366) And I told them that, if they had done wrong, they should apologize.
('32', 86, 1, 12, 196435) One of them said that a cow was killed in the lines contrary to custom and that enraged the coolies.
('32', 86, 1, 13, 196536) We then went to the spot where the cow was said to have been killed.
('32', 86, 1, 14, 196605) Upon reaching, we found there was no trace whatsoever of any cow having been killed on the spot that was shown to us.
('32', 86, 1, 15, 196723) There were parts of a carcass without the skin.
('32', 86, 1, 16, 196771) Mussalmans present told us that the cow was killed in a mosque and the meat, after the skinning, was brought to their homes in their carriage.
('32', 86, 1, 17, 196914) There was no blood or any other mark of slaughter.
('32', 86, 1, 18, 196965) The Commissioner of Police, Mr. Tegart, was present whilst we were making enquiry.
('32', 86, 1, 19, 197048) So far as I can judge the blame appears to me to be wholly that of Hindus.
('32', 86, 1, 20, 197123) I told accordingly, and I did not find any serious contradiction.
('32', 86, 1, 21, 197189) The Hindus even asked for forgiveness of Mussalmans and said that they would not repeat the wrong.
('32', 86, 1, 22, 197288) Up to that time, according to information in the possession of the Commissioner of Police, no deaths had occurred, though, among many injured Mussalmans, two were in a serious state.
('32', 86, 1, 23, 197471) Maulana Saheb pacified the Mussalmans and told them that they ought not to give any credence to exaggerated reports and up to that time no one had died.
('32', 86, 1, 24, 197624) He asked them all to disperse quietly which they consented to do.
('32', 86, 1, 25, 197690) Assuming the truth of what we heard and saw, there is no doubt that Hindu coolies were entirely in the wrong and that they had hurt innocent Mussalmans and made themselves responsible for at least one death which, as I now understand, has occurred.
