('32', 91, 4, 16, 209165) 68. MY NOTES DESHBANDHU’S LAST JOURNEY
('32', 91, 5, 17, 209204) The scriptures say that, as a man abandons an old house and goes to live in a new one, so the atman dwelling in a body aban dons it when it grows old, builds another and lives in that.
('32', 91, 5, 18, 209389) As one does not feel happy when leaving one’s old house, because of long association with it, likewise the soul is not happy when leaving the body because of the association, even if the legs are swollen and look like pillars, the body is emaciated into a mere skeleton and the man struggles for breath.
('32', 91, 5, 19, 209693) But one forgets the old house when the new one is ready and the soul, too, when it has a new home to dwell in, retains no memory at all of the old—such is the mystery of death and birth.

('32', 97, 1, 2, 219628) 73. SPEECH TO STUDENTS, MIDNAPUR 1
('32', 97, 2, 3, 219663) July 7, 1925
('32', 97, 3, 4, 219676) He said that he was pleased that the function at Midnapore began with a welcome from the students.
('32', 97, 3, 5, 219775) His present tour, he said, was meant for the realization of the teachings of Deshbandhu Das and for the raising of a subscription for his memorial.
('32', 97, 3, 6, 219923) He said that Deshbandhu sacrificed his property and life for the welfare of the young men and that he hoped and depended much on them, specially the students.
('32', 97, 3, 7, 220082) Mahatma said that the life of that illustrious patriot might be divided into two parts— external and internal.
('32', 97, 3, 8, 220193) The external only tended to help the internal.
('32', 97, 3, 9, 220240) Deshbandhu wanted to increase the strength of the nation and free the country.
('32', 97, 3, 10, 220319) So far as the external was concerned, it was only for the rich and the educated to follow, but as to the internal, it might be cultivated alike by the rich and the poor, by the educated and the illiterate, by the boy and the girl, by the young and the old.
('32', 97, 3, 11, 220576) For the last 6 or 9 months of his life, Deshbandhu tried to hold before the public the ideal of village reorganization or village reconstruction in which males and females of every age and grade in society might take part.
('32', 97, 4, 12, 220799) Mahatmaji directed the attention of the students to this and said that the foremost and easiest way of beginning work in the village is the introduction of charkha in every household.
('32', 97, 4, 13, 220983) He had long discussions with Deshbandhu over this at Darjeeling and both of them agreed as above, and the latter communicated the same to Babu Satcouripati Roy only a few days before he expired.
('32', 97, 4, 14, 221178) It is a pity, said the Mahatma, that Deshbandhu was not among them too complete the programme he had chalked out for his countrymen.
('32', 97, 4, 15, 221311) He said that, if they had any love or admiration for their Deshbandhu, they would take a vow to spin for at least half an hour every day, never use any foreign cloth and take up the work of village reconstruction in right earnest.
('32', 97, 4, 16, 221542) In conclusion, he appealed to the students to take the permission of their parents and contribute whatever they could to the Deshbandhu Memorial Fund.
('32', 97, 4, 17, 221693) He asked them to give any gold buttons or articles of luxury they had with them or curtail their daily expenditure, even by fasting, for one, two or three days, if necessary, and contribute the savings to the fund.
('32', 97, 4, 18, 221908) This sort of sacrifice, he said, was not new to the students, and that, during the last 30 or 40 years of his political activity, he received such help from them on many occasions, notably during the last Malabar flood relief.
('32', 97, 4, 19, 222135) He, however, warned them that, if this sacrifice on their part was not done with pleasure, he would not accept a farthing from them.
('32', 97, 4, 20, 222268) He asked them to choose one of
('32', 97, 5, 21, 222299) 1 Gandhiji was presented with an address by the students, to which he replied in Hindi.
('32', 98, 0, 1, 222387) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 99
('32', 98, 1, 2, 222432) them or one of their elders as their leader and collect subscriptions through him and take a vow to spin regularly and never to use foreign cloth.

('32', 98, 3, 4, 222610) 74. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BANKURA 2
('32', 98, 4, 5, 222650) July 8, 1925
('32', 98, 5, 6, 222663) Mahatmaji said that, after his arrival in the district, he had heard of the many activities of Anil Babu and the hold he had on the affection of the people.
('32', 98, 5, 7, 222820) Mahatmaji exhorted the people to carry on the work of Anil Babu and hoped that Anil Babu would soon be back from jail.
('32', 98, 5, 8, 222939) Then he said that he was carrying the message of Deshbandhu and the lessons the departed hero taught us—the lesson of sacrifice, of intense activity, of extreme devotion to the motherland and of love of the poor.
('32', 98, 6, 9, 223152) He asked the people to accelerate the work of the Swaraj Party, not by paying a mere subscription or enlisting the name, but by reconstruction of the village.
('32', 98, 6, 10, 223311) It was not possible for everyone to enter the Councils, but it was possible for everyone to help in the work of reconstruction.
('32', 98, 6, 11, 223439) Mahatmaji said that, at Darjeeling, he and Deshbandhu were in complete conformity so far as charkha and village reconstruction were concerned.
('32', 98, 6, 12, 223582) How was it possible to attain swaraj unless the village life was revived?
('32', 98, 6, 13, 223656) The charkha was the emblem of the unity of the village and the town.
('32', 98, 6, 14, 223725) The root of all famines, diseases and other calamities was India’s poverty.
('32', 98, 6, 15, 223801) That was the lesson he was taught from the early days of the Congress from the pages of the Dada of Hindusthan, Dadabhai Naoroji.
('32', 98, 6, 16, 223931) 3 And how could we get rid of that poverty?
('32', 98, 6, 17, 223975) By taking to the charkha.
('32', 98, 6, 18, 224001) He asked the people to reflect upon the immense possibilities of the charkha.
('32', 98, 6, 19, 224079) He then concluded by appealing for collections for the Deshbandhu Memorial Fund.

('32', 99, 1, 2, 224760) 75. NOTES TWO DIFFICULTIES
('32', 99, 2, 3, 224787) A distinguished countryman has sent me through a common friend the following questions for answer in Young India :
('32', 99, 3, 4, 224902) 1. You admit that untouchability is a blot not only upon Hinduism but upon humanity.
('32', 99, 3, 5, 224987) Why then do you restrict the circle of reformers to Hindus only?
('32', 99, 3, 6, 225052) Why may not Mussalmans take up the reform the same as Hindus?
('32', 99, 4, 7, 225114) 2. You insist continuously upon Hindu Muslim unity, will you please point out anything concrete you have done for Islam or Mussalmans?
('32', 99, 4, 8, 225249) As to the first question, although the evil of untouchability is not merely a blot upon Hinduism, but is also a blot upon humanity, it is a question which Hindus must solve for themselves, even as they are solving several other questions regarding Hinduism.
('32', 99, 4, 9, 225507) There is the question of devadasis, for instance.
('32', 99, 4, 10, 225557) Their existence is not a small evil.
('32', 99, 4, 11, 225594) The institution is a blot upon humanity.
('32', 99, 4, 12, 225635) But no non Hindu thinks of medling with it in the same sense in which Hindus are.
('32', 99, 4, 13, 225717) The reason is obvious.
('32', 99, 4, 14, 225740) Removal of these abuses has to come from within, not imposed upon Hindus.
('32', 99, 4, 15, 225814) This can only be brought about by Hindus.
('32', 99, 4, 16, 225856) Mussalmans, Christians and other non Hindus are at perfect liberty to criticize untouchability as any other evil in Hinduism.
('32', 99, 4, 17, 225982) They can lend the reform their moral support.
('32', 99, 4, 18, 226028) But they may not go further without exposing themselves to the charge of having designs upon Hinduism.
('32', 99, 4, 19, 226131) As to the second charge, I must content myself with having noted it.
('32', 99, 4, 20, 226200) I cannot answer it without committing a breach of propriety.
('32', 99, 4, 21, 226261) If I have to prove to Mussalmans my concrete contribution to unity, it follows that there is none.
('32', 99, 4, 22, 226360) And I must, therefore, submit to the condemnation that the question carries with it, till such time that my bona fides are self proved.
('32', 99, 4, 23, 226496) But, in fairness to the Mussalmans in general, I must say that it is for the first time that I have been called upon to produce a certificate of service.
('32', 99, 4, 24, 226650) Let me say, however, that they also serve who wait and pray.
('32', 99, 4, 25, 226711) And if there are many Mussalmans like the distinguished inquirer who want to inspect my record of service, I ask them not to bother their heads about it, but to be content with the assurance that I am at least watching, waiting and praying, if I am not actively serving.
('32', 99, 4, 26, 226982) “VAIDYAS” COMPLAINT
('32', 99, 5, 27, 227002) The vaidyas have been deeply hurt by my criticism of Ayurveda
('32', 100, 0, 1, 227064) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 101
('32', 100, 1, 2, 227110) and Unani physicians.
('32', 100, 1, 3, 227132) They accuse me of softness of brain and denial of ahimsa.
('32', 100, 1, 4, 227190) I am sorry to have caused so much hurt to them.
('32', 100, 1, 5, 227238) But I cannot plead guilty.
('32', 100, 1, 6, 227265) I have not criticized Ayurveda.
('32', 100, 1, 7, 227297) I have criticized those who have professed to follow it.
('32', 100, 1, 8, 227354) I have not criticized all of them, but I have criticized the large number who make the pretensions I have accused them of.
('32', 100, 1, 9, 227477) There is no contradiction between my endorsement of proposition to promote research in the indigenous drugs and plants and my condemnation of the method adopted by some to these physicians, even as there is none between my laying the foundation of the Ayurvedic College in Calcutta and my warning to the kavirajas.
('32', 100, 1, 10, 227792) It is open to the vaidyas of Poona to reject the criticism offered in a friendly spirit.
('32', 100, 1, 11, 227881) I shall be sorry for the decision, but the rejection will not alter my opinion which is based on experience.
('32', 100, 1, 12, 227990) I have chapter and verse for every statement I have made.
('32', 100, 1, 13, 228048) I do like everything that is ancient and noble, but I utterly dislike a parody of it.
('32', 100, 1, 14, 228134) And I must respectfully refuse to believe that ancient books are the last word on the matters treated in them.
('32', 100, 1, 15, 228245) As a wise heir to the ancients, I am desirous of adding to and enriching the legacy inherited by us.
('32', 100, 1, 16, 228346) Let me inform the protestants that some kavirajas have welcomed my criticism, which has set them thinking.
('32', 100, 1, 17, 228453) Needless to say that it was not directed against those who are carrying on scientific research in a spirit of humility and without counting the cost.
('32', 100, 1, 18, 228603) Only, they are too few to be counted.
('32', 100, 1, 19, 228641) I plead for an appreciable increase.
('32', 100, 1, 20, 228678) SPINNING RESOLUTION

('32', 100, 2, 22, 228775) The following figures have been supplied to me by the A.I.K.B. of the use made of the yarn received in terms of the resolution : 1
('32', 100, 3, 23, 228906) This brief report has its own moral.
('32', 100, 3, 24, 228943) The output is nothing compared to what it should be or can be.

('32', 100, 3, 26, 229104) An organization is like machinery; just as, if the smallest screw becomes loose, the whole machinery becomes loose and may even break down, so in an organization the least looseness affects its smooth working and the results expected.
('32', 100, 3, 27, 229339) The brief experiment of three months has a lesson for those who are dealing with the spinning franchise.

('32', 101, 1, 6, 229968) SPINNING A NEW HABIT
('32', 101, 2, 7, 229989) An esteemed American friend who has been practising spinning writes :
('32', 101, 3, 8, 230059) May I take the liberty of making a suggestion, growing out of my temporary failure some time ago to keep up my spinning regularly?
('32', 101, 3, 9, 230190) (I have reformed now.) It is this : that in asking people to spin or in talking with them after they have promised to spin, might it not be worth while to get them to realize that they are about to establish a new habit; that new habits must be
('32', 101, 4, 10, 230435) very assiduously tended until they get firmly established; that one failure in regularity, one omission will undo the work and strivings of many days in the early stages of formation of the habit; that new channels of nervous and muscular action and control have to be worn by constant, regular practice;
('32', 101, 5, 11, 230740) that probably the habit is not safely established until one can spin and at the same time talk with people and discuss matters entirely different, while keeping the hands going.
('32', 101, 5, 12, 230918) Then the control and response have become automatic.
('32', 101, 5, 13, 230971) People ought to realize that mere emotional enthusiasm does not always carry through the labour of firmly establishing the habit; that they should reinforce their emotions by their minds, by clearly thinking out the values, meaning, applications of charkha and khaddar to themselves, their family, their village and nation, —politically, economically, morally and spiritually.
('32', 101, 5, 14, 231348) Those who can afford to ought to buy your “Wheel of Fortune” and read all the discussions of the subject they can.
('32', 101, 6, 15, 231463) Personally I feel that people, especially intellectuals unused to hand work and simple realities, need to reinforce their enthusiasm by their minds.
('32', 101, 6, 16, 231612) I feel that one of the reasons for much of the back sliding since 1920 may have been due to this lack of realization by new converts of how they should go about the establishment of such a new habit, what are the dangers to guard against, how they can provide in advance to keep themselves in a favourable frame of mind of free from distractions or interruptions at the chosen spinning hour each day, how they can provide favourable surroundings and atmosphere, how to get a due sense of what is really important, etc.
('32', 101, 7, 17, 232131) Maybe, you always do give them advice, or maybe I am reasoning wrongly out of experience of American character and in ignorance of the
('32', 102, 0, 1, 232266) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 103
('32', 102, 1, 2, 232312) Indian nature.
('32', 102, 1, 3, 232327) Those were some of the things which caused my failure for several weeks, so I pass them along to you for whatever worth they may have.
('32', 102, 1, 4, 232462) The friend need not have apologized for relating his experience, for human nature at bottom is the same even as the American sky as a matter of fact is the same as the Indian.
('32', 102, 1, 5, 232638) Only the presentation is different from what the readers of Young India are accustomed to.
('32', 102, 1, 6, 232729) The voluntary spinners who have become accustomed to spinning have had the same difficulties that have faced the American friend.
('32', 102, 1, 7, 232859) What is wanted is resolution at the back of one’s mind.
('32', 102, 1, 8, 232915) It anticipates and overcomes all difficulties.
('32', 102, 1, 9, 232962) The value of the friend’s analysis of his difficulties lies in the fact that he has made plain to us what most of us have felt without perceiving.

('32', 102, 3, 11, 233131) 76. PAINFULLY ILLUMINATING
('32', 102, 4, 12, 233158) This letter 1 was handed to me at Chittagong and has been in my jacket, awaiting attention at the first opportunity.

('32', 102, 4, 20, 234202) It cannot be remedied by law.

('32', 103, 1, 3, 234684) The political domination of England is bad enough.
('32', 103, 1, 4, 234735) The cultural is infinitely worse.
('32', 103, 1, 5, 234769) For, whilst we resent and, therefore, endeavour to resist the political domination, we hug the cultural, not realizing in our infatuation that, when the cultural domination is complete, the political will defy resistance.
('32', 103, 1, 6, 234991) Let me not be misunderstood.
('32', 103, 1, 7, 235020) I do not wish to imply that, before the British rule, prostitution was unknown in India.
('32', 103, 1, 8, 235109) But I do say that it was not so rampant as now.
('32', 103, 1, 9, 235157) It was confined to the few upper ten.

('32', 103, 1, 16, 235592) Above all, unless they visualize God and seek His aid in keeping them from temptation, no amount of dry discipline will do them much good.
('32', 103, 1, 17, 235731) Truly has the Seer said in the Gita that “desire persists though man may by fasting keep his body under restraint.
('32', 103, 1, 18, 235846) Desire goes only when one has seen God face to face.” Seeing God face to face is to feel that He is enthroned in our hearts even as a child feels a mother’s affection without needing any demonstration.
('32', 103, 1, 19, 236048) Does a child reason out the existence of a mother’s love?
('32', 103, 1, 20, 236106) Can he prove it to other?
('32', 103, 1, 21, 236132) He triumphantly declares : “It is.” So must it be with the existence of God.
('32', 103, 1, 22, 236209) He defies reason.
('32', 103, 1, 23, 236227) But He is experienced.
('32', 103, 1, 24, 236250) Let us not reject the experience of Tulsidas, Chaitanya, Ramdas and a host of other spiritual teachers even as do not reject that of mundane teachers.
('32', 103, 1, 25, 236401) The correspondent has inquired whether Congressmen may do the many things he has enumerated, such as theatre going, etc.
('32', 103, 1, 26, 236522) I have already remarked that man cannot be made good by law.
('32', 103, 1, 27, 236583) If I had the power of persuasion, I would certainly stop women of illfame from acting as actresses, I would prevent people from drinking and smoking, I would certainly prevent all the degrading advertisements that disfigure even reputable journals and newspapers and I would most decidedly stop the obscene literature and portraits that soil the pages of some of our magazines.
('32', 103, 1, 28, 236961) But, alas, I have not the persuasive power I would gladly possess.
('32', 103, 1, 29, 237028) But to regulate these things by law, whether of the State or the Congress, would be a remedy probably worse than the disease.
('32', 103, 1, 30, 237154) What is wanted is an intelligent, sane, healthy and pure public opinion.
('32', 103, 1, 31, 237227) There is no law against using kitchens as
('32', 104, 0, 1, 237269) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 105
('32', 104, 1, 2, 237315) closets or drawing rooms as stables.
('32', 104, 1, 3, 237352) But public opinion, that is, public taste will not tolerate such a combination.
('32', 104, 1, 4, 237432) The evolution of public opinion is at times a tardy process but it is the only effective one.
('32', 104, 1, 5, 237526) Young India, 9 7 1925
('32', 104, 2, 6, 237548) 77. ‘THE SCIENCE OF SURRENDER’
('32', 104, 3, 7, 237579) Exception has been taken to my remarks at a meeting in Calcutta that Deshbandhu, in his relations with the Mussalmans, brought “the science of surrender to perfection”.
('32', 104, 3, 8, 237748) The exception has been taken because my critics impute to me the implication that by surrender I mean that Deshbandhu conferred on Mussalmans favours, that is, things they were not entitled to.
('32', 104, 3, 9, 237942) The critics opine that the Hindus are acting towards the Mussalmans much the same as Englishmen are acting towards us all—having first taken away everything and then offering us doles in the name of favours.
('32', 104, 3, 10, 238150) I know what I said at the meeting in question.
('32', 104, 3, 11, 238197) I have not read the reports of my speech, but I desire to abide by all I said at that meeting.
('32', 104, 3, 12, 238292) I make bold to say that without mutual surrender there is no hope for this distraught country.
('32', 104, 3, 13, 238387) Let us not be hyper sensitive or devoid of imagination.
('32', 104, 3, 14, 238443) To surrender is not to confer favour.
('32', 104, 3, 15, 238481) Justice that love gives is a surrender, justice that law gives is a punishment.
('32', 104, 3, 16, 238561) What a lover gives transcends justice.

('32', 106, 4, 8, 242800) I would ask the reader to share my grief over the death of an esteemed friend and silent servant—I mean Principal Sushil Rudra, who died on Tuesday, 30th June.

('32', 124, 2, 14, 287320) 87. KHADI PRATISHTHAN Readers of Navajivan know how deeply I have been impressed by the work of the Bengal Khadi Pratishthan.
('32', 124, 2, 15, 287446) After reading my report, Shri Lakshmidas 1 sent Shri Mathuradas to inspect its work; the latter has written down the conclusions which he has arrived at after personal inquiry and given me a copy of the report.
('32', 124, 2, 16, 287657) However careful my examination might have been, it could not be treated as scientific.
('32', 124, 2, 17, 287744) Shri Mathuradas’s inquiry, on the other hand, was scientific, for he has specialized in this field, has conducted careful inquiries into the working of other such establishments and is so well informed about the finances of some of them that he can reel off precise figures.
('32', 124, 2, 18, 288019) I, therefore, attach greater value to his inquiry than to mine.
('32', 124, 2, 19, 288083) In my report the reader would find my conclusions, but, little of the evidence on which they are based, whereas in the report of this scientific inquiry he would get the evidence as well.
('32', 124, 2, 20, 288271) Shri Mathuradas’s inquiry being of this character, its results are given elsewhere in this issue.

('32', 126, 1, 2, 291085) 88. MY NOTES I give below the summary of a statement 1, sent to me by the All India Khadi Association, relating to the disposal of the yarn received by it in virtue of the resolution on the subject passed last year by the All India Congress Committee.
('32', 126, 1, 3, 291337) These facts teach us some important lessons.
('32', 126, 1, 4, 291382) An organi zation is like a machine.
('32', 126, 1, 5, 291418) If in a machine one screw becomes loose, it slows down or, sometimes, even breaks down; the same thing happens to organizations, especially organizations doing constructive work.
('32', 126, 1, 6, 291597) If attention is not paid even to the minutest details of their working, production will fall.
('32', 126, 1, 7, 291691) Weak yarn, carelessly wound bundles of yarn, bundles of yarn not stored properly—any such negligence will bring down the quality of khadi, raise the cost of weav ing and reduce its speed.
('32', 126, 1, 8, 291879) We observe, too, that the slow progress in work was wholly due to negligence at the spinning stage.
('32', 126, 1, 9, 291979) SPINNERS, BEWARE!
('32', 126, 2, 10, 291997) The khadi produced has been priced at market rates, for the quantity available was so little that there was no meaning in selling it at reduced price.

('32', 127, 1, 2, 292816) 90. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, RAJSHAHI 1
('32', 127, 2, 3, 292857) July 12, 1925
('32', 127, 3, 4, 292871) After thanking those who gave him addresses and for the presents 2 made to him, Mahatmaji explained that he had only two objects in view in making his tour.
('32', 127, 3, 5, 293028) His first object was to secure 10 lakhs of rupees for Deshbandhu Memorial.
('32', 127, 3, 6, 293103) He hoped to receive suitable donation towards the Memorial Fund from the people of Rajshahi, where there were many big zamindars, pleaders and business men.
('32', 127, 3, 7, 293260) He asked everyone to contribute his mite to this fund.
('32', 127, 3, 8, 293315) He told that millions of people were lamenting the death of Deshbandhu Das and he wanted to utilize this feeling of deep love for Deshbandhu to increase the strength and power of Hindustan.
('32', 127, 3, 9, 293505) He pointed out that our first duty was to render our utmost help for the Memorial of Deshbandhu and then to carry out the wishes of late Deshbandhu.
('32', 127, 4, 10, 293654) Mahatmaji then spoke about his meeting with Deshbandhu at Darjeeling, when Deshbandhu impressed it clearly that nothing could be done without organizing the villagers and that charkha was the main centre of work for this village organization.
('32', 127, 4, 11, 293897) He asked the people to act in accordance with the wishes of late Deshbandhu, viz., (1) to work on charkha for at least half an hour a day, (2) to wear khaddar and (3) to maintain Hindu Muslim unity, which he said occupied the first place in Deshbandhu’s talk with him at Darjeeling.
('32', 127, 5, 12, 294180) Mahatmaji also told the people that Deshbandhu had no feeling of hatred for any man and that Deshbandhu had by his own life demonstrated that untouchability had no place in religion.
('32', 127, 5, 13, 294363) Mahatmaji again asked the people to act up to the wishes of Deshbandhu and win swaraj if they really loved and felt for Deshbandhu.

('32', 139, 1, 2, 321246) WHAT OF THE HOUSE ?
('32', 139, 2, 3, 321266) Doubts have been raised as to whether the proposed hospital is to be opened in the very mansion that has belonged to his family for two generations.
('32', 139, 2, 4, 321415) I thought that the matter was absolutely clear in the appeal signed by Lord Sinha and others.
('32', 139, 2, 5, 321509) That mansion is already in the hands of the trustees for such purposes as a hospital and the like.
('32', 139, 2, 6, 321608) Its value is over three lacs.
('32', 139, 2, 7, 321638) It is burdened with a debt of over two lacs.
('32', 139, 2, 8, 321683) The debt will be paid naturally out of the collections being now made.
('32', 139, 2, 9, 321754) But the trustees of the Memorial will then acquire a property worth three lacs for two lacs.
('32', 139, 2, 10, 321847) In other words, the trustees will have eleven lacs of capital when they have finished their collection of ten lacs.
('32', 139, 2, 11, 321963) TO DOUBTERS
('32', 139, 3, 12, 321975) There are still people who ask me whether I am really serious and sanguine about collecting 10 lacs.
('32', 139, 3, 13, 322076) All I can say is that I do not know Bengal at all if it does not give 10 lacs for this Memorial towards which I have not yet met a single person who has refused to give something.
('32', 139, 3, 14, 322256) The question of collecting the amount is merely a question of time and organization.
('32', 139, 3, 15, 322341) I do not entertain the slightest doubt about the success of the collection.
('32', 139, 3, 16, 322417) NOT INSPIRING ?
('32', 139, 4, 17, 322433) I have answered locally the charge that the object of the Memorial is not inspiring.
('32', 139, 4, 18, 322518) The sceptics imply thereby that the object should have been political.
('32', 139, 4, 19, 322589) But let me remind them that the signatories to the appeal had no choice.
('32', 139, 4, 20, 322662) Those who want to revere Deshbandhu’s memory cannot do so if they do not respect his own wishes.
('32', 139, 4, 21, 322759) I hold that his wishes must be a first charge upon any collection that may be made by us, the survivors, to perpetuate his memory.
('32', 139, 4, 22, 322890) Deshbandhu knew what he was doing when he made over his property to a trust.
('32', 139, 4, 23, 322967) He deliberately chose to give it for a charitable, not a political, purpose.
('32', 139, 4, 24, 323044) The survivors are not only, therefore, bound to acquire the house for the nation, but also to use it for the purpose intended by the donor.
('32', 139, 4, 25, 323184) Bengal is, therefore, in my opinion, in honour bound to use the mansion as a hospital for women and an institution for training nurses.
('32', 139, 4, 26, 323320) I hear that in some places Bengalis are collecting funds for local memorials.
('32', 139, 4, 27, 323398) I hope that every city will have a memorial worthy of the great patriot.
('32', 139, 4, 28, 323471) But that time is not yet.
('32', 139, 4, 29, 323497) In my humble opinion, the honour of every Bengali who cherishes Deshbandhu’s memory is pledged to finish the collection of 10 lacs for the All Bengal Memorial before diverting a single pice for a local memorial.
('32', 140, 0, 1, 323709) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 141
('32', 140, 1, 2, 323755) The Bengalis outside Bengal, beware.
('32', 140, 1, 3, 323792) They have not all yet made their returns.
('32', 140, 1, 4, 323834) If all the Bengalis who have known Deshbandhu will not exert themselves, the collection is likely to be unduly prolonged.
('32', 140, 1, 5, 323956) I hope, therefore, that those Bengalis who read these notes will exert themselves to the utmost within their own circles to secure the best subscriptions.
('32', 140, 1, 6, 324111) Young India, 16 7 1925
('32', 140, 2, 7, 324134) 98. TO REMOVE A MISGIVING I have lately been calling on a number of rich people to collect donations for the Deshbandhu Memorial Fund.
('32', 140, 2, 8, 324269) One of them was Shri Sadhuram Tularam.
('32', 140, 2, 9, 324308) There I not only secured a generous donation, but also had occasion to talk to those present about religious matters.
('32', 140, 2, 10, 324426) Untouchability was mentioned and it was said that something had appeared in the newspapers attributing to me the view that we should interdine and intermarry with the socalled untouchables.
('32', 140, 2, 11, 324616) What I said to disabuse them regarding this only seemed to surprise those who had raised the point, and they suggested that I might publish a summary of what I told them in the Hindi Navajivan.
('32', 140, 2, 12, 324810) I have accepted the suggestion and give here the required summary.
('32', 140, 2, 13, 324877) I must make it clear to the people, in the first place, that I do not as a rule read newspapers and on the rare occasions when I do, I find it impossible to repudiate all the false things that are attributed to me.
('32', 140, 2, 14, 325092) If, therefore, anyone at any time has a doubt, he should ask me what I had said on any given occasion.
('32', 140, 2, 15, 325195) Now, if someone has said in the newspapers that I stand for or encourage interdining and intermarrying with our untouchable brethren, he has made a mistake.
('32', 140, 2, 16, 325352) I have stated categorically a thousand times that abolition of untouchability does not mean the abolition of the social restraints governing eating and marrying.
('32', 140, 2, 17, 325514) With whom shall one eat or marry is an entirely different question and I do not find it necessary at the moment to pronounce upon it.
('32', 140, 2, 18, 325648) I believe on the contrary that our mixing the two questions may impede the reform we wish to bring about.
('32', 140, 2, 19, 325754) It is the duty of everyone who considers himself a Hindu to work for the eradication of untouchability.
('32', 140, 2, 20, 325858) By mixing it up with other issues we shall be harming our cause.
('32', 140, 2, 21, 325923) Yes, about accepting water to drink I shall say something.
('32', 140, 2, 22, 325982) If we accept clean water from a Sudra, as we should and as we do, we should
('32', 141, 0, 1, 326058) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 141, 1, 2, 326100) also accept water at the hands of an untouchable.
('32', 141, 1, 3, 326150) I recognize only four varnas.
('32', 141, 1, 4, 326180) There is to me no fifth varna called the untouchables.
('32', 141, 1, 5, 326235) We must, therefore, eradicate untouchability, and the sufferings of the Hindus considered untouchable, and purify Hinduism as well as ourselves.
('32', 141, 1, 6, 326380) In other words, there is no room for hatred and contempt in religion.
('32', 141, 1, 7, 326450) Hatred is implicit in untouchability.
('32', 141, 1, 8, 326488) We must do away with this hatred.
('32', 141, 1, 9, 326522) Hinduism is a religion which holds service to be of the highest importance.
('32', 141, 1, 10, 326598) Why should those considered untouchable be denied service?
('32', 141, 1, 11, 326657) [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 16 7 1925
('32', 141, 2, 12, 326697) 99. LETTER TO C. RAJAGOPALACHARI July 16, 1925
('32', 141, 3, 13, 326744) MY DEAR C. R., Somehow or other I need your letter to feel that all is well with you.
('32', 141, 3, 14, 326830) My position is this.
('32', 141, 3, 15, 326851) My body and mind are living in a world by which I remain unaffected, but in which I am being tried.
('32', 141, 3, 16, 326951) My soul is living in a world physically away from me and yet a world by which I am and want to be affected.
('32', 141, 3, 17, 327059) You are a part of that world and perhaps the nearest to me.
('32', 141, 3, 18, 327119) My innermost being wants your approbation of what I am doing and thinking.
('32', 141, 3, 19, 327194) I may not always succeed in getting it, but it craves for your verdict.
('32', 141, 3, 20, 327266) Now you understand exactly why I want to hear from you apart from many other reasons.
('32', 141, 3, 21, 327352) You must let me have if it is only a postcard every week.
('32', 141, 3, 22, 327410) Mahadev, Devdas, Pyarelal 1 should keep you posted with what is going on.
('32', 141, 3, 23, 327484) And you must keep well.
('32', 141, 3, 24, 327508) Your sadhana is the development of the place where you are and a scientific test of our theory of the value of hand spinning.
('32', 141, 3, 25, 327634) Even if it proves untrue in the end, neither we nor the world will have lost anything, for I know that we are true in the sense that we have full faith in the programme and, if it is intrinsically not immoral, our theory can be claimed to be true, when a fairly large number of villages sustain hand spinning and khadi without protection as the whole of India sustains home cookery without protection.

('32', 143, 6, 12, 330195) 102. RESOLUTIONS AT SWARAJ PARTY MEETING 2 CALCUTTA, July 16, 1925 1. The General Council of the Swaraj Party, whilst sharing with the country the deep grief universally expressed over the sudden and premature death of Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das, feels that the Party has lost its founder and infallible guide who kept it from harm in the midst of difficulties and led it in Bengal from victory to victory and set to the Party a standard of courage, self sacrifice and discipline for which the Party owes to the memory of the deceased Chief a debt which it can never hope to repay.
('32', 143, 6, 13, 330778) The Council tenders to Shrimati Basanti Devi and the family its respectful condolences.
('32', 143, 6, 14, 330866) 2. The meeting of the General Council of the all India Swaraj Party wholly endorses the sentiments regarding violence and the strong condemnation thereof contained, and the offer of honourable co operation with the Government and the conditions thereof laid
('32', 143, 7, 15, 331124) 1 As in the printed source
('32', 143, 8, 16, 331151) 2 The General Council of the All India Swarajists Party met at 148, Russa Road under the presidentship of Motilal Nehru.
('32', 143, 8, 17, 331272) Gandhiji and Sarojini Naidu attended on special invitation.
('32', 143, 8, 18, 331332) According to a report in The Bombay Chronicle, 17 7 1925, the second resolution was drafted by Gandhiji.
('32', 143, 8, 19, 331437) Presumably the first resolution too was drafted by him.

('32', 144, 1, 2, 331539) down, in the Faridpore speech, dated the 2nd day of May, 1925, of the late President of the Party, Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das.
('32', 144, 1, 3, 331667) The Council, however, regrets that the recent pronouncement of the Rt.
('32', 144, 1, 4, 331738) Hon’ble the Secretary of State for India in the House of Lords is not only no response to the late President’s offer, but, on the contrary, is calculated by reason of its tone and language to make the chances of honourable co operation difficult, if not impossible.
('32', 144, 1, 5, 332004) The Council, therefore, sees in that pronouncement no reason for a revision of the policy of the Swaraj Party, but will be pre pared to reconsider it if the final declaration to be made by the Government of India, and referred to by Lord Birkenhead, is found to be at all adequate to meet the requirements of the existing situation in the country.

('32', 144, 3, 7, 332371) 103. SPEECH AT SWARAJ PARTY MEETING 1 CALCUTTA, July 16, 1925
('32', 144, 4, 8, 332433) When the business of the meeting was finished, Mahatmaji addressed the gathering with reference to the question of giving up the spinning franchise.
('32', 144, 4, 9, 332582) He said that many Swarajists were present there.
('32', 144, 4, 10, 332631) To them he would submit that, if they wanted to drop the spinning franchise, he would call a meeting of the A.I.C.C. for that purpose.
('32', 144, 4, 11, 332766) Personally, he believed that much work had been done in regard to the spinning franchise in the course of the last six months and he expected that much would be done in course of the re maining half year.
('32', 144, 4, 12, 332971) But, still, if they wanted to drop it, he would no longer make delay in the matter.
('32', 144, 5, 13, 333055) The Searchlight, 19 7 1925
('32', 144, 6, 14, 333082) 1 Those present included Sarojini Naidu, V. J. Patel, N. C. Kelkar, M. S. Aney, Dr. Moonje, T. Prakasam, S. Srinivasa Iyengar, Rangaswami Ayengar and J. M. Sen Gupta.

('32', 145, 1, 2, 333519) 104. SPEECH AT SWARAJ PARTY MEETING 1
('32', 145, 2, 3, 333557) CALCUTTA, July 17, 1925
('32', 145, 3, 4, 333581) Mahatmaji, who was present at the meeting, declared clearly that if they wanted to abolish the said franchise he would at once accede to their demand and convene a meeting of the A.I.C.C. But for him personally the only course open would be to resign the Presidentship of the Congress Working Committee and work separately for spreading charkha and khaddar.
('32', 145, 3, 5, 333939) He said that he was ready to do away with the pact with the Swarajists and thereby make them completely independent of any obligation regarding Congress mandate.
('32', 145, 3, 6, 334101) The pact had made it obligatory to the Swarajists to abide by the spinning franchise for full one year and for this reason many of them were inclined to observe it for the full term.
('32', 145, 3, 7, 334284) But if the majority were for abolition, he must dissolve the pact in due deference to their wishes.
('32', 145, 3, 8, 334384) In conclusion he declared that, if the Congress would abolish the spinning franchise, he would, while remaining within the Congress, form a separate organization for spinning and would work it up just as Deshbandhu Das and others formed and worked up the Swaraj Party.

('32', 145, 5, 10, 334685) 105 A DECEPTIVE SPEECH
('32', 145, 6, 11, 334708) [July 18, 1925] Lord Birkenhead’s pronouncement is deceptive in a double sense.
('32', 145, 6, 12, 334788) It does not read as harsh on second reading as it did on first, but it disappoints more on the second than it did on the first.
('32', 145, 7, 13, 334916) 1 The meeting was held in the morning at the residence of S. C. Roy, son in law of C. R. Das, to discuss the abolition of the spinning franchise.
('32', 145, 8, 14, 335062) 2 The meeting of the A.I.C.C., it was decided, would be held late in September or early October to discuss the question of spinning franchise fully.
('32', 145, 8, 15, 335211) According to the report : “At the conclusion of the sitting, Mahatmaji sent a note to Pandit Motilal Nehru saying that since the Swarajists had majority in the Congress and since Panditji was the President of the Swaraj Party, he should also assume the Presidentship of the Congress Working Committee.
('32', 145, 8, 16, 335513) He did no longer like to be the President of this body.
('32', 145, 8, 17, 335569) This note had created a sensation in the Swarajists’ camp most of whom did not like to lose Mahatmaji’s counsel.
('32', 145, 8, 18, 335682) However, it was finally arranged that for at least the remaining period of this year, Mahatmaji will remain as the President of the A.I.C.C. But if the spinning franchise be dropped at the next meeting of the A.I.C.C., he will resign and set up a separate spinning organization.”
('32', 146, 0, 1, 335962) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 147
('32', 146, 1, 2, 336008) harshness of it is unintended.
('32', 146, 1, 3, 336039) The Secretary of State could not help himself.
('32', 146, 1, 4, 336086) He has spoken as he has felt or rather been coached to feel.
('32', 146, 1, 5, 336147) But his promises are only apparently alluring.
('32', 146, 1, 6, 336194) A closer perusal leaves one under the impression that the maker of them knows that he will never be called upon to fulfil them.
('32', 146, 1, 7, 336322) Let us take the most tempting of them.
('32', 146, 1, 8, 336361) It says, in effect, ‘produce your constitution and we will consider it.’ Is it not our thirty five years’ experience that we have made petitions that we have considered to be perfect, but that they have been rejected “after careful consideration”?
('32', 146, 1, 9, 336609) Having had that experience, we dropped the beggar’s bowl in 1920 and made up our minds to live by our own exertion, even though we should perish in the attempt.
('32', 146, 1, 10, 336770) It is not draughtsmanship that his Lordship really asks, it is swordsmanship he invites, with the full knowledge that the invitation will not be and could not be accepted.
('32', 146, 1, 11, 336942) The evidence is in the speech itself.
('32', 146, 1, 12, 336980) He had before him the Minority report of the Muddiman Committee, i.e., of Dr. Sapru and Mr. Jinnah, two among the cleverest lawyers we have in India and who have never been guilty of the crime of non co operation, and one of whom has been Law Member of the Viceregal Council.

('32', 146, 1, 17, 337766) When I was hardly twenty five years old, I was taught to believe that, if we wished to be satisfied with 4 annas, we must ask for 16 annas in order to get the 4 annas.
('32', 146, 1, 18, 337934) I never learnt that lesson because I believed in asking for just what I needed and fighting for it.
('32', 146, 1, 19, 338034) But I have not failed to observe that there was a great deal of truth in the very practical advice.
('32', 146, 1, 20, 338134) The silliest constitution backed by force, whether violent or non violent, will receive the promptest consideration especially from the British, who know only too well the value of at least one kind of force.
('32', 146, 1, 21, 338343) There is the Bill taken to England by that tireless servant of India, Dr. Besant.

('32', 146, 2, 24, 338547) 1 A member of the Viceroy’s Executive Council
('32', 147, 0, 1, 338593) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('32', 147, 1, 4, 338870) Let Lord Birkenhead say that he will accept any reasonable constitution that may be prepared by a party or parties overwhelmingly representative of Indian public opinion and he will have a constitution in a week’s time.

('32', 148, 1, 3, 341405) Deshbandhu showed a way out.
('32', 148, 1, 4, 341434) His offer stands.
('32', 148, 1, 5, 341452) But what hope is there of his offer being responded to in the spirit in which it has been made?
('32', 148, 1, 6, 341548) There are the different viewpoints which make us English and Indians see things contrarywise.

('32', 149, 4, 8, 343612) I never thought that I would have to write a note with this heading, and that too in connection with national activity in Gujarat.
('32', 149, 4, 9, 343743) But the unexpected has happened.
('32', 149, 4, 10, 343776) The Gujarat Khadi Mandal has resolved as under :
('32', 149, 5, 11, 343825) As it has become difficult to collect some of the outstanding dues of the Mandal and it has become necessary to file a suit to realize them, it is resolved that a statement containing the facts about these dues should be sent to Gandhiji through the Provincial Committee and, after his reply is received, necessary steps be taken to recover the dues in question.

('32', 149, 5, 14, 344415) I have already stated my view on this subject, to the effect that the resolutions of the Congress were not intended to harm its own interests.
('32', 149, 5, 15, 344558) When they were proposed, it was taken for granted that its members would not break their promises to one another at any rate, that they would be honest among themselves in the matter of Congress work.

('32', 150, 1, 5, 345615) I would urge those who have kept back the Khadi Mandal’s money to pay up, at any rate, the amounts which they have admitted as due from them.
('32', 150, 1, 6, 345757) ALL UNMARRIED
('32', 150, 2, 7, 345771) Through pride, maybe, or ignorance, or both, I thought that myself and my co workers were the only people who tried to keep all their sons and daughters unmarried.
('32', 150, 2, 8, 345935) But my pride has been humbled and my ignorance has been dispelled.
('32', 150, 2, 9, 346002) One of the volunteers attending on me is a nephew of the Secretary of the local Congress Committee.
('32', 150, 2, 10, 346102) Not only is he himself unmarried, but his father wants all his brothers to remain unmarried.
('32', 150, 2, 11, 346195) If the young men themselves wish to marry, he will agree to find suitable brides for them; he has no intention to force them to remain unmarried against their will.
('32', 150, 2, 12, 346360) But he is, at the same time, so training his sons that they will resolve to remain unmarried.
('32', 150, 2, 13, 346454) All his sons are grown up young men and settled in some profession or other, but so far they have remained unmarried of their own free will.
('32', 150, 2, 14, 346595) I observe that in Bengal even girls are being trained to remain unmarried.
('32', 150, 2, 15, 346670) The number of such girls is very small, but the movement does exist; it does not owe anything to Western influence; the parents of the girls who are trying to train their daughters in this manner are inspired solely by religious motives.
('32', 150, 2, 16, 346908) RIGHT v.
('32', 150, 2, 17, 346917) LEFT No one can say definitely why people came to make a distinction between the right hand and the left hand and how it became customary to avoid using the left hand for doing certain things and to use, instead, the right hand.
('32', 150, 2, 18, 347146) But the result, as we know, is that for want of practice the left hand has become useless for many purposes and also remains weaker than the right hand.
('32', 150, 2, 19, 347299) It is not so in Japan.
('32', 150, 2, 20, 347322) There people are taught to use both hands equally well from their early years.
('32', 150, 2, 21, 347401) As a result, their physical efficiency is greater than ours.
('32', 150, 2, 22, 347462) I place this suggestion before the reader for his benefit in the light of my present experience.
('32', 150, 2, 23, 347559) It is more than twenty years since I read about the practice in Japan.
('32', 150, 2, 24, 347630) When I came to know of it, I started learning to write with my left hand and acquired tolerable proficiency in it.
('32', 150, 2, 25, 347745) I now regret that I did not acquire the same speed in writing with the left hand as I had with the right, thinking that I could not afford
('32', 151, 0, 1, 347884) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 151, 1, 2, 347926) the time required for that.
('32', 151, 1, 3, 347954) Now my right hand does not give the desired service in writing.
('32', 151, 1, 4, 348018) It starts paining when I have written for some time with it.
('32', 151, 1, 5, 348079) Being anxious to retain as long as possible the ability to write with the right hand, I have again started using the left hand.
('32', 151, 1, 6, 348207) I do not have time enough now to do all my writing with the left hand and learn to write with it as fast as with the right hand.
('32', 151, 1, 7, 348336) But it has been serving me well whenever I am in difficulty; I have, therefore, placed my experience in this matter before the reader.
('32', 151, 1, 8, 348471) Those who can spare the required time and are keen enough should train themselves to write with the left hand too.
('32', 151, 1, 9, 348586) Everyone who does so will discover in the course of time the value of this ability.
('32', 151, 1, 10, 348670) Besides writing, it is useful to learn to do other things too with the left hand.
('32', 151, 1, 11, 348752) Most of us have come across many persons who cannot even manage to eat with the left hand when the right hand has become unserviceable for some reason.
('32', 151, 1, 12, 348904) I hope that this note will make no one go crazy about using the left hand.

('32', 155, 4, 8, 358620) The result of this act is that the Congress need no longer be a predominantly spinning association.

('32', 157, 3, 14, 362754) 113. AN ALL INDIA MEMORIAL [On or before July 22, 1925] 2
('32', 157, 4, 15, 362812) We the undersigned are of opinion that an all India fund is as much a necessity as an all Bengal one to perpetuate the memory of Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das.
('32', 157, 4, 16, 362970) He was as much an all India man as he was an all Bengal man.
('32', 157, 4, 17, 363031) Just as we knew what Deshbandhu would have himself wished us to do as an all Bengal Memorial, so do we know what he would have wished us to do regarding an all India Memorial.

('32', 159, 1, 3, 366344) The all India collection will last a considerable period, seeing that Bengal will have paid a heavy sum for the All Bengal Memorial.
('32', 159, 1, 4, 366477) The collection in Bengal for the All India Memorial need not be made for three months or a longer period if necessary.
('32', 159, 1, 5, 366596) The attention of Bengal should not be diverted from the all Bengal collection.
('32', 159, 1, 6, 366675) It must be a point of honour with every Bengali and everyone domiciled in Bengal to make the Bengal collection a full success.
('32', 159, 1, 7, 366802) Over five lakhs have now been already paid.
('32', 159, 1, 8, 366846) Though the balance, I take it, is assured, it is likely to take longer than the first five lakhs unless the workers will concentrate their effort on quickness in collection.
('32', 159, 2, 9, 367020) Manilal Kothari has shown what can be done in the direction by specialists.
('32', 159, 2, 10, 367096) In view of his success in inducing some of those who have already paid to double and even to quadruple their subscriptions, there is perhaps a possibility of some of the others, who have already subscribed, paying a second and substantial instalment.
('32', 159, 2, 11, 367347) But, apart from this possibility, there are schools and colleges left untouched.
('32', 159, 2, 12, 367428) Will the Principals of these institutions or the students themselves move, as I was told at the beginning of the month that they would, as soon as these institutions were open after the vacation?
('32', 159, 2, 13, 367624) There are all the Bengal merchants and traders in the busy centres of Calcutta mostly untouched.
('32', 159, 2, 14, 367721) I could see, when I was taken to some of these shops, that is was possible to collect, if not the whole sum, at least a large part of it from these merchants.
('32', 159, 2, 15, 367880) Again, all the districts have not yet sent in their returns, nor have the Bengalis from the other provinces, except in some cases.
('32', 159, 2, 16, 368011) Will all these friends respond in good time?
('32', 159, 2, 17, 368056) I would like to plead a little for myself.
('32', 159, 2, 18, 368099) I had hoped to be able to leave Bengal by the middle of this month.

('32', 160, 1, 2, 368369) subscribe and induce others to do so in finishing the collection as early as possible.

('32', 162, 6, 11, 372489) 118. THE SPINNING FRANCHISE
('32', 162, 7, 12, 372517) There was an informal meeting of the Swarajists and others on the 17th instant.
('32', 162, 7, 13, 372597) 1 It was a representative gathering.
('32', 162, 7, 14, 372634) All including myself felt that a revision of the franchise was necessary and all felt that the self spinning as an alternative should be permanently retained, and not merely by way of trial, in the Congress franchise.
('32', 162, 7, 15, 372852) That means permanent recognition of the right of labour to be directly represented in the Congress.
('32', 162, 7, 16, 372952) All agreed that yarn as distinguished from spinning franchise must be abolished.
('32', 162, 7, 17, 373033) It had given rise to hypocrisy and even dishonesty.
('32', 162, 7, 18, 373085) The question of quantity to self spun yarn or cash sub scription was held in abeyance.
('32', 162, 7, 19, 373172) There was a divergence of opinion.
('32', 162, 7, 20, 373207) An overwhelming majority favoured also the retention of khaddar wearing as a permanent part of the franchise.
('32', 162, 7, 21, 373317) This is, in my opinion, a decided gain.
('32', 162, 7, 22, 373357) The third proposition unanimously agreed to was that an All India Spinners’ Association should be formed to be an integral part of the Congress, with absolute powers, which would control the spinning part of the Congress activity and act as the Congress Agency for receiving and testing spinning subscriptions.
('32', 162, 7, 23, 373668) The result, if the recommendations are accepted, would

('32', 164, 3, 8, 377030) 119. FRUIT OF SUPPRESSION An esteemed American friend sends me the following illuminating passage from Dr. Miller’s Races, Nations and Classes :
('32', 164, 4, 9, 377175) Within a suppressed group there grow up many bitter factions.
('32', 164, 4, 10, 377237) This has become notorious among the Irish.
('32', 164, 4, 11, 377280) The dissension within all the suppressed nationalities is an illustration of the same thing.
('32', 164, 4, 12, 377373) Each has focussed on its own struggle for freedom and selected particular outlet for the struggle, and when these factions find it necessary to work together to accomplish a common end, there is the immediate tendency to call attention to the differences, which, though subsidiary, are considered of prime importance.
('32', 164, 4, 13, 377691) Under the conditions of freedom, both for the individual and the group, this particular aspect of the psychosis will gradually wear off, but it must be accepted as an inevitable consequence of restricted freedom.
('32', 164, 4, 14, 377904) The friend observes, “This illuminates the situation in India.
('32', 164, 4, 15, 377967) Doesn’t it?” It does, indeed, and it is for that reason that people like Dr. Besant persevere in their attempt to secure freedom in spite of the communal dissensions.
('32', 164, 4, 16, 378134) There is room for both—those who seek freedom despite differences and those who seek to remove differences for the sake of paving the road to freedom.
('32', 164, 5, 17, 378285) Young India, 23 7 1925
('32', 164, 6, 18, 378308) 120. NOTES ‘ALWAR ATROCITIES’
('32', 164, 7, 19, 378338) What has been known as “Alwar atrocities” came before the Congress Working Committee that met in Calcutta, in the form of a
('32', 165, 0, 1, 378462) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 165, 1, 2, 378504) motion by Sjt.
('32', 165, 1, 3, 378519) Jamnalal Bajaj for the appointment of a committee of inquiry.
('32', 165, 1, 4, 378581) Now it has been long a tradition of the Congress not to interfere in the internal affairs of Indian States.
('32', 165, 1, 5, 378689) The members of the Committee felt that it was a healthy tradition which it would be unwise to break.
('32', 165, 1, 6, 378790) Jamnalalji then did not press his motion.
('32', 165, 1, 7, 378832) I told him, however, that I should discuss the question in these pages and give my reasons for my personal opinion that the Congress should not interfere in the internal administration of the Indian States.
('32', 165, 1, 8, 379039) This may, if one chooses to put it so, be regarded as a virtue of necessity or a matter of policy, It is both and perhaps a little more.
('32', 165, 1, 9, 379176) It must be frankly admitted that the Congress possesses no authority for enforcing its will in Indian States even to the extent it does in British India proper.
('32', 165, 1, 10, 379337) Prudence, therefore, dictates inaction where action would be waste of effort, if not folly.
('32', 165, 1, 11, 379429) But if inaction is prudential, it is also benevolent.
('32', 165, 1, 12, 379483) The Congress seeks not to embarrass the States, it desires to help them.
('32', 165, 1, 13, 379556) It does not wish to destroy them, it wishes to reform them.
('32', 165, 1, 14, 379616) And this the Congress for the moment does by abstention as an earnest of its goodwill.
('32', 165, 2, 15, 379703) But abstention by the Congress does not mean absence of effort on the part of Congressmen.
('32', 165, 2, 16, 379794) Those who have any relation with the States will no doubt use their influence.
('32', 165, 2, 17, 379873) The local committes can help and guide the distressed people so long as they do not come in clash with authority.
('32', 165, 2, 18, 379987) Nor does the Congress regulate or control the action of individual Congressmen.
('32', 165, 2, 19, 380067) But when they take action, they do so not as Congressmen.
('32', 165, 2, 20, 380125) The position of the Congress must not be compromised.
('32', 165, 3, 21, 380179) May the subjects of Indian States then expect no relief from the Congress which claims to be a national institution?
('32', 165, 3, 22, 380296) I fear the answer must be party in the negative.
('32', 165, 3, 23, 380345) They may not expect any direct assistance.
('32', 165, 3, 24, 380388) But indirect assistance they do get.
('32', 165, 3, 25, 380425) For, to the measure that the Congress becomes powerful and efficient, to that measure also is levelled up the condition of the subjects of the Indian States.
('32', 165, 3, 26, 380583) The moral pressure of the Congress must be felt all over the land either directly or indirectly.
('32', 165, 3, 27, 380680) I hope, therefore, the afflicted people will realize that, if the Congress does not offer any direct help, it is not for want of will, but it is entirely due to want of ability and opportunity.

('32', 166, 1, 2, 380920) FOR ANGLO INDIANS
('32', 166, 2, 3, 380938) Dr.Moreno has handed me the following questions foranswers : 1
('32', 166, 3, 4, 381001) 1. The present distress of the Anglo Indians is deplorable and is becoming more acute as the days go on.
('32', 166, 3, 5, 381106) The unemployed themselves do not desire charity, they want work.
('32', 166, 3, 6, 381171) In my mind, industrial occupations would suit them best.
('32', 166, 3, 7, 381228) What is your suggestion?
('32', 166, 3, 8, 381253) I am glad the unemployed do not desire charity.
('32', 166, 3, 9, 381301) I must be pardoned for saying that the unemployed can find industrial occupation in hand weaving.
('32', 166, 3, 10, 381399) But I am free to confess that the Anglo Indian with his present training may be ill fitted for weaving unless he is gifted with an exceptionally strong will.
('32', 166, 3, 11, 381557) It is difficult to give advice on a hypothetical question.
('32', 166, 3, 12, 381616) It is for an enterprising and philanthropic Anglo Indian to prepare a census of the unemployed and then think out occupations for which the community is best fitted and prepare for training them therein.
('32', 166, 4, 13, 381820) 2. To bring such a community, as the Anglo Indians go to form, to your way of thinking as regards spinning and khaddar would require an active propaganda spread over a considerable length of time.
('32', 166, 4, 14, 382017) Would it meet your wishes if the Anglo Indians showed a mind not inimical to the programme you have set out?
('32', 166, 4, 15, 382126) I agree that the Anglo Indians as a class may take time before they grow to like spinning even as a sacrament; but there is no reason to delay over the use of khaddar.
('32', 166, 4, 16, 382294) A jacket made of khaddar is as serviceable as the one made of foreign cloth and bed sheets of khaddar are better to the touch than the ordinary mill manufacture.
('32', 166, 4, 17, 382456) It is the feeling of kinship with the masses that is needed to induce Anglo Indians to use khaddar.
('32', 166, 4, 18, 382556) That is, in my opinion, the first step to a real spirit of nationalism.
('32', 166, 5, 19, 382628) 3. The Anglo Imdian community goes to form one of the minorities of India.
('32', 166, 5, 20, 382703) How would your programme go to include them in your all party combination?
('32', 166, 5, 21, 382778) The Anglo Indians will be treated precisely in the same manner as the other minorities.
('32', 166, 6, 22, 382866) 4. In your desire to secure a Unity Congress for the future in India, how would you include Anglo Indian representatives, bearing in mind (a) your spinning franchise and (b) the non inclusion of Anglo Indian representatives hitherto in the Congress?
('32', 166, 7, 23, 383116) 1 Vide also “Interview to Dr. H. W. B. Moreno”, 31 5 1925.
('32', 167, 0, 1, 383175) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 167, 1, 2, 383217) Under the proposed change, a cash subscription will be accepted in lieu of yarn.
('32', 167, 1, 3, 383298) If hitherto Anglo Indians have not joined, it is largely due to their unwillingness.
('32', 167, 1, 4, 383383) If it is suggested that the Congress should have made a special effort to enlist their support, I can only say that it is difficult in respect of those who regard themselves superiors and strangers to Indians, as I fear Anglo Indians have hitherto done.
('32', 167, 2, 5, 383637) 5. You are aware that there is in the Anglo Indian community a desire among some to lean on the European side, and among others to go to the Indian side.
('32', 167, 2, 6, 383791) What would you advise the Anglo Indian community as a whole to do (a) for their own benefit and (b) for the benefit of India?
('32', 167, 2, 7, 383917) I know the existence of the painful attitude.
('32', 167, 2, 8, 383963) The only dignified attitude, in my opinion, is for Anglo Indians to throw in their lot with those in whose midst they are born and among whom they have to “live and move and have their being”.
('32', 167, 2, 9, 384156) Their fruitless attempt to hang on to the coat tails of Englishmen only retards their settling down to a permanent and progressive condition.
('32', 167, 2, 10, 384298) To aspire to be European is unnatural.

('32', 167, 2, 13, 384577) PREVENTIBLE WASTE
('32', 167, 3, 14, 384595) It was an ennobling sight, the meeting of ladies at Rajshahi.

('32', 168, 0, 1, 385824) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 169
('32', 168, 1, 2, 385870) the wheel and not make another till he has acquainted himself with the best wheel.
('32', 168, 1, 3, 385953) I have known in Bengal only three patterns which can at all be claimed to be good wheels.
('32', 168, 1, 4, 386043) Of these three, the Khadi Pratishthan pattern has appealed to me as the best.
('32', 168, 1, 5, 386121) The second is what is used by the workers at Duadando.
('32', 168, 1, 6, 386176) Its speciality is that the spindle is kept slanting.
('32', 168, 1, 7, 386229) A third is the old Bengal pattern with a short platform and a heavy revolving wheel and a long spindle.
('32', 168, 1, 8, 386333) The tests of a good wheel are: (1) noiselessness, and (2) yield of at least 400 yards of yarn of ten counts per hour by an ordinary spinner.
('32', 168, 1, 9, 386474) I have heard that the other two patterns have been known to yield 600 yards of at least ten counts per hour.
('32', 168, 1, 10, 386583) I have seen the Khadi Pratishthan wheel yield over 850 yards per hour.
('32', 168, 1, 11, 386654) All its workers can spin 400 yards per hour on the Khadi Pratishthan pattern.
('32', 168, 1, 12, 386732) Let the manufacturers of wheels know that they are injuring the cause when they put on the market a noisy charkha that will not yield the average quantity.
('32', 168, 1, 13, 386888) I warn the workers, too, against putting below standard wheels in the hands of spinners, professional or voluntary, when they know that they can get wheels that answer the standard that I have laid down.
('32', 168, 1, 14, 387092) If any man in Bengal has a better wheel, let him send it on to me.
('32', 168, 1, 15, 387159) I promise to test it and report the result without undue delay.
('32', 168, 1, 16, 387223) Spinning is a matter of life and death for the masses.
('32', 168, 1, 17, 387278) Let not those who are engaged in spreading it indulge in waste that a little knowledge can easily prevent.

('32', 169, 1, 11, 388808) If I once accept something, as a satyagrahi I stub bornly cling to it.

('32', 169, 1, 14, 389009) I openly proclaim any Western ideas that I wish to propagate.
('32', 169, 1, 15, 389071) For instance, with reference to Ayurveda I said once that, in the matter of health, we have far less to teach the West than we have to learn from it.
('32', 169, 1, 16, 389221) I consider myself a sanatani Hindu.
('32', 169, 1, 17, 389257) It increases our anguish when we have to suffer at the hands of outsiders.
('32', 169, 1, 18, 389332) I have repeatedly said that I accept the system of Varnashrama.
('32', 169, 1, 19, 389396) But I wish to cleanse it of the caste distinctions that have crept into it.
('32', 169, 1, 20, 389472) It is my belief that Hinduism is non violent.
('32', 169, 1, 21, 389518) Please sheathe the sword of ostracism.
('32', 169, 1, 22, 389557) This is not the time for it.
('32', 169, 1, 23, 389586) If a man marries off his very young daughter, you at once apply ostracism against him, but, if a man is a libertine and eats flesh, you do nothing to ostracize him.
('32', 169, 1, 24, 389751) Practice of ostracism in this manner will ultimately lead to the ostracized becoming a separate caste and to an increase of discord in the community.
('32', 169, 1, 25, 389901) Thus, when I went to England in 1887, I found on my return that, while some of my caste accepted me, some others ostracized me.
('32', 169, 1, 26, 390029) I, however, have no grievance against my caste on that account.
('32', 169, 1, 27, 390093) My policy is one of non violence.
('32', 169, 1, 28, 390127) I have no desire to cause them pain.

('32', 170, 1, 4, 390856) I am happy that, among the Hindus, the Marwari community enjoys affluence.

('32', 170, 1, 6, 390995) I am not unaware either that your community is well known for its generosity.

('32', 170, 1, 8, 391148) I know all this well enough.
('32', 170, 1, 9, 391177) But, with all this, they have a failing, and that failing is very marked : they waste money.
('32', 170, 1, 10, 391270) The Marwaris, it is true, earn money and also spend it on good works; it is usually their desire to have some religious cause to support.
('32', 170, 1, 11, 391408) But generally they do not spend their money properly.
('32', 170, 1, 12, 391462) I would, therefore, say to the Marwaris that they should keep certain things in mind when they spend money, thinking they are putting it to a good use.
('32', 170, 1, 13, 391614) It is necessary to give great thought to the question of spending money.
('32', 170, 1, 14, 391687) You should make quite sure, before you spend money, that you are making good use of it.
('32', 170, 1, 15, 391775) Since you are charitable and generous, it is all the more necessary for you to be thoughtful in spending.
('32', 170, 1, 16, 391881) You must be aware that in America there are millionaires and multi millionaires who are far richer than you.
('32', 170, 1, 17, 391990) There used to be a millionaire called Carnegie there (I do not know whether he is alive now).
('32', 170, 1, 18, 392084) It was his peculiarity that he would be guided in his actions entirely by his own ideas.
('32', 170, 1, 19, 392173) He paid absolutely no attention to the ideas of others.

('32', 174, 3, 4, 399445) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, I want to tender a double apology to you first because I have not arrived in time, but you know the difficulties that beset me at the present moment.
('32', 174, 3, 5, 399621) I have not a minute that I can call my own.
('32', 174, 3, 6, 399665) Hence the delay.

('32', 174, 3, 8, 399853) I am deeply grateful for these facilities which everywhere my countrymen and others afford to me, realizing as they do my situation.
('32', 174, 3, 9, 399986) I must confess to you that I know very little of the life of Kristo das Pal.
('32', 174, 3, 10, 400063) The best years of my life have been spent outside India and, as a busy man that I was in South Africa, I was not able to keep myself in touch with all that was going on in India.
('32', 174, 3, 11, 400242) It is a humiliating confession, but I must make that confession to you.
('32', 174, 3, 12, 400314) At the same time, I feel honoured in that I was invited to be present at this function.
('32', 174, 3, 13, 400402) It is a matter of privilege to me that I can associate myself with you in the tributes that will be paid, this evening, to the memory of that great and illustrious countryman of ours.
('32', 174, 3, 14, 400586) His grandson has been kind enough to place at my disposal some literature dealing with his writings and, during the spare moments I could get yesterday, I came upon a passage in one of his writings bearing upon Home Rule.
('32', 174, 3, 15, 400808) I little thought that, even in his bad time, that great man thought out things which we are today endeavouring to the best of our ability to reduce to practice.
('32', 174, 3, 16, 400969) He gave us those ideas of freedom which we are today endeavouring to translate into action.
('32', 174, 3, 17, 401061) I have read also something else from his writings.
('32', 174, 3, 18, 401112) As a youth I knew this much that he was one of the greatest journalists of his time, that he was a fearless patriot, but with his fearlessness he combined a polished and cultured courtesy which never left in anything that he wrote a sting behind.
('32', 174, 3, 19, 401359) We of the present generation, in our attempt to attain our freedom, need to treasure the lesson that we have inherited from the great man; we need also to copy his fearlessness and gentleness, because fearlessness without gentleness is mere brag and bluster.

('32', 185, 1, 9, 427540) Moreover, though their assessment is sometimes wrong, it is more often right.
('32', 185, 1, 10, 427618) Our dharma today is to serve the country in a non violent and truthful manner.
('32', 185, 1, 11, 427697) All of us should contribute our share of service, while maintaining an indifference towards the resulting praise or blame.
('32', 185, 1, 12, 427820) THE VOLUNTEER’S DHARMA
('32', 185, 2, 13, 427843) A volunteer writes as follows: 1
('32', 185, 3, 14, 427876) I have omitted from this letter portions dealing with certain facts.
('32', 185, 3, 15, 427945) The caution is quite relevant.
('32', 185, 3, 16, 427976) The purpose of the correspondent is to state that we should not be greedy and that we should do nothing which might go against the responsibility which has been entrusted to us.
('32', 185, 3, 17, 428154) We should have nothing to do with the private affairs of our host.
('32', 185, 3, 18, 428221) Where is the room for a personal connection when the relationship is a public one?
('32', 185, 3, 19, 428304) Wherever a volunteer happens to stay, he does so not because of any personal friendship but only because of his work, and therefore regards the place as a guest house.
('32', 185, 3, 20, 428472) Moreover, one who desires to be pure always avoids meeting a woman when she is alone.
('32', 185, 3, 21, 428558) This is the dharma not only of the volunteer but also of a friend, a guest, a dependent and of every man.
('32', 185, 3, 22, 428664) No one should sleep near a married couple’s room.
('32', 185, 3, 23, 428714) This is gentlemanly conduct.
('32', 185, 3, 24, 428743) Unfortunately, we do not have such facilities in our houses and we do not have the habit of practising such discretion; however, there can be no difference of opinion regarding the propriety and necessity of having a married couple’s room away from those of others.

('32', 191, 1, 2, 437036) 136. LETTER TO FRED E. CAMPBELL 148, RUSSA ROAD, CALCUTTA, July 28, 1925
('32', 191, 2, 3, 437109) MY DEAR YOUNG FRIEND 1 ,
('32', 191, 3, 4, 437134) I like your frank and sincere letter 2 for which I thank you.
('32', 191, 4, 5, 437196) You seem to have taken it for granted that I hate the British.
('32', 191, 4, 6, 437259) What makes you think so?
('32', 191, 4, 7, 437284) I have hundreds of friends among the British people.
('32', 191, 4, 8, 437337) I cannot love the Mussalmans and for that matter the Hindus if I hate the British.
('32', 191, 4, 9, 437420) My love is not an exclusive affair.
('32', 191, 4, 10, 437456) If I hate the British today, I would have to hate the Mohammedans tomorrow and the Hindus the day after.
('32', 191, 4, 11, 437561) But what I do detest is the system of government that the British have set up in my country.
('32', 191, 4, 12, 437654) It has almost brought about the economic and moral ruin of the people of India.
('32', 191, 4, 13, 437734) But just as I love my wife and my children, in spite of their faults which are many, I love also the British in spite of the bad system for which they have unfortunately made themselves responsible.
('32', 191, 4, 14, 437933) That love which is blind is no love, that love which shuts its eyes to the faults of loved ones is partial and even dangerous.
('32', 191, 4, 15, 438060) You must write again if this letter does not satisfy you.
('32', 191, 5, 16, 438118) Yours sincerely,
('32', 191, 6, 17, 438135) M. K. GANDHI
