('32', 192, 8, 22, 440443) From a copy : C. W. 11334. Courtesy : Dr. N. Rama Murthy and C. A. Reddi
('32', 192, 9, 23, 440516) 1 Vide “A Deceptive Speech”, 18 7 1925.
('32', 193, 0, 1, 440556) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 193, 1, 2, 440598) 139. SPEECH AT MEETING OF MISSIONARIES July 28, 1925 I had the pleasure of delivering an address before the missionaries in Calcutta at Y.M.C.A. on 28th ultimo.
('32', 193, 1, 3, 440759) I have been supplied with shorthand notes of that address, and as it was of general interest I reproduce below an abridgment of it.
('32', 193, 1, 4, 440891) I have omitted onsalient thought or expression, but I have omitted some descriptive passages.
('32', 193, 2, 5, 440985) M. K. G. No many of you perhaps know that my association with Christians, not Christians so called but real Christians, dates from 1889, when as a lad I found myself in London; and that association has grown riper as years have rolled on.
('32', 193, 2, 6, 441224) In South Africa, where I found myself in the midst of inhospitable surroundings, I was able to make hundreds of Christian friends.
('32', 193, 2, 7, 441355) I came in touch with the late Mr. Spencer Watton, Director of South Africa General Mission, and, later, with the great divine, Rew.
('32', 193, 2, 8, 441487) Mr. A. Murray and several others.
('32', 193, 2, 9, 441521) My acquaintance, therefore, this evening with so many missionaries is by no means a new thing.
('32', 193, 2, 10, 441616) There was even a time in my life when a very sincere and intimate friend of mine, a great and good Quaker, had designs on me.
('32', 193, 2, 11, 441742) (Laughter.) He thought that I was too good not to become a Christian.
('32', 193, 2, 12, 441812) I was sorry to have disappointed him.
('32', 193, 2, 13, 441850) One missionary friend of mine in South Africa still writes to me and asks me, ‘How is it with you?’ I have always told this friend that so far as I know, it is all well with me.
('32', 193, 2, 14, 442028) If it was prayer that these friends expected me to make, I was able to tell them that every day the heart felt prayer within the closed door of my closet went to the Almighty to show me light and give wisdom and courage to follow that light.
('32', 193, 2, 15, 442270) In answer to promises made to one of these Christian friends of mine, I thought it my duty to see one of the biggest of Indian Christians, as I was told he was,—the late Kali Charan Banerjee.
('32', 193, 2, 16, 442462) I went over to him—I am telling you of the deep search that I have undergone in order that I might leave no stone unturned to find out the true path—I went to him with an absolutely open mind and in a receptive mood, and I met him also under circumstances which were most affecting.
('32', 193, 2, 17, 442745) I found that there was much in common between Mr. Banerjee and myself.
('32', 193, 2, 18, 442816) His simplicity, his humility, his courage, his
('32', 194, 0, 1, 442863) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 195
('32', 194, 1, 2, 442909) truthfulness, all these things I have all along admired.
('32', 194, 1, 3, 442966) He met me when his wife was on her death bed.
('32', 194, 1, 4, 443012) You cannot imagine a more impressive scene, a more ennobling circumstance.
('32', 194, 1, 5, 443087) I told Mr. Banerjee, ‘I have come to you as a seeker,’—this was in 1901—‘I have come to you in fulfilment of a sacred promise I have made to some of my dearest Christian friends that I will leave no stone unturned to find out the true light.’ I told him that I had given my friends the assurance that no worldly gain would keep me away from the light, if I could but see it.
('32', 194, 1, 6, 443462) Well, I am not going to engage you in giving a description of the little discussion that we had between us.
('32', 194, 1, 7, 443570) It was very good, very noble.
('32', 194, 1, 8, 443600) I came away, not sorry, not dejected, not disappointed, but I felt sad that even Mr. Banerjee could not convince me.
('32', 194, 1, 9, 443717) This was my final deliberate striving to realize Christianity as it was presented to me.
('32', 194, 1, 10, 443806) Today my position is that though I admire much in Christianity, I am unable to identify myself with orthodox Christianity.
('32', 194, 1, 11, 443929) I must tell you in all humility that Hinduism as I know it, entirely satisfies my soul, fills my whole being and I find a solace in the Bhagavad Gita and Upanishads that I miss even in the Sermon on the Mount.
('32', 194, 1, 12, 444139) Not that I do not prize the ideal presented therein, not that some of the precious teachings in the Sermon on the Mount have not left a deep impression upon me, but I must confess to you that when doubts haunt me, when disappointments stare me in the face, and when I see not one ray of light on the horizon I turn to the Bhagavad Gita, and find a verse to comfort me; and I immediately begin to smile in the midst of overwhelming sorrow.
('32', 194, 1, 13, 444578) My life has been full of external tragedies and if they have not left any visible and indelible effect on me, I owe it to the teaching of the Bhagavad Gita.
('32', 194, 1, 14, 444735) I have told you all these things in order to make it absolutely clear to you where I stand, so that I may have, if you will, closer touch with you.
('32', 194, 1, 15, 444883) I must add that I did not stop at studying the Bible and the commentaries and other books on Christianity that my friends placed in my hands; but I said to myself, if I was to find my satisfaction through reasoning, I must study the scriptures of other religions also and make my choice.
('32', 194, 1, 16, 445171) And I turned to the Koran.
('32', 194, 1, 17, 445198) I tried to understand what I could of Judaism as distinguished from Christianity.
('32', 194, 1, 18, 445280) I studied Zoroastrianism and I came to the conclusion that all religions were right, but every one of them imperfect, imperfect naturally and necessarily,—because they were interpreted with our poor intellects, sometimes with our poor hearts, and more often misinterpreted.
('32', 194, 1, 19, 445554) In all religions, I found to my grief, that there
('32', 195, 0, 1, 445604) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 195, 1, 2, 445646) were various and even contradictory interpretations of some texts, and I said to myself, ‘Not these things for me.
('32', 195, 1, 3, 445761) If I want the satisfaction of my soul, I must feel my way.
('32', 195, 1, 4, 445820) I must wait silently upon God and ask Him to guide me.’ There is a beautiful verse in Sanskrit which says ‘God helps only when man feels utterly helpless and utterly humble’.
('32', 195, 1, 5, 445995) Some of you have come from the Tamil land.
('32', 195, 1, 6, 446038) When I was studying Tamil, I found in one of the books of Dr. Pope a Tamil proverb which means‘ God helps the helpless’.
('32', 195, 1, 7, 446159) I have given you this life story of my own experience for you to ponder over.
('32', 195, 1, 8, 446237) You, the missionaries come to India thinking that you come to a land of heathens, of idolators, of men who do not know God.
('32', 195, 1, 9, 446361) One of the greatest of Christian divines, Bishop Heber, wrote the two lines which have always left a sting with me: “Where every prospect pleases, and man alone is vile.” I wish he had not written them.
('32', 195, 1, 10, 446564) My own experience in my travels throughout India has been to the contrary.

('32', 200, 5, 22, 459990) 142. SPEECH AT MEETING OF ANGLO INDIANS 1
('32', 200, 6, 23, 460032) July 29, 1925
('32', 200, 7, 24, 460046) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, I suppose it is better for me at the outset of our conversation to say—because we are such a small, beautiful compact gathering —that I would like this to be turned into a conversation rather than a set address by me.
('32', 200, 8, 25, 460290) 1 Gandhiji spoke to a gathering of Anglo Indians at Wellesley Square in the evening.
('32', 200, 8, 26, 460375) 2 This paragraph has been extracted from a report in Forward, 30 7 1925.
('32', 201, 0, 1, 460448) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 201, 1, 2, 460490) At the outset I would like to clear the ground by taking up the last sentiment of the chairman.
('32', 201, 1, 3, 460586) 1 I appreciate the viewpoint that he has placed before me and there was a time when I could also say these things about loyalty.
('32', 201, 1, 4, 460715) But as you know, for the past six years I have not been speaking of loyalty, but of disloyalty.
('32', 201, 1, 5, 460811) It is not that I harbour disloyalty towards anything whatsoever, but I do so against all untruth, all that is unjust, all that is evil.
('32', 201, 1, 6, 460947) This I want to make clear as I do not want to sail under false colours.
('32', 201, 1, 7, 461019) I remain loyal to an institution so long as that institution conduces to my growth, to the growth of the nation.
('32', 201, 1, 8, 461132) Immediately I find that the institution instead of conducing to its growth impedes it, I hold it to be my bounden duty to be disloyal to it.
('32', 201, 1, 9, 461273) I cannot for one moment say that I am loyal to the present Government, that is, to the present system of Government.
('32', 201, 1, 10, 461390) I assert that I am, every moment of my life, seeking to destroy this system of Government which is sapping the manhood of India, which is sapping its vitality and its resources, which is degrading alike those who are in charge of the system and those who are governed by that system.
('32', 201, 1, 11, 461674) But I think that whilst we may agree to differ on this very fundamental question, we must seek to find out whether there are not many points of contact between you and me—between you and the vast mass of the people who inhabit this beautiful land—if I may say so—of ours.
('32', 201, 1, 12, 461946) What the ultimate destiny of India will be we do not know, or we know only this much that it is in our making, it will be what everyone of us whose lot is cast in India wants it to be.
('32', 201, 1, 13, 462131) But beyond this we do not know, having no control over the minds of millions of human beings who compose Hindustan.
('32', 201, 1, 14, 462247) But everyone should become an optimist and then there is nothing but the brightest future for this land.
('32', 201, 1, 15, 462352) That is, today, everyone should be able to say to himself, “I live for this land.
('32', 201, 1, 16, 462434) I shall die for this land.” I want you, therefore, to approach the question in a spirit of service and, when there is that spirit of service, we may erase that disturbing factor.
('32', 201, 1, 17, 462613) ‘Loyalty’ or ‘disloyalty’ does not matter much when a person really wants to serve.
('32', 201, 1, 18, 462697) I have come here this evening in a spirit of utter humility and in a spirit of absolute friendship and goodwill towards you.
('32', 201, 1, 19, 462822) During my incessant wanderings, I have come in contact not merely with Hindus, not merely with Mussalmans, but I have come deliberately in contact with all sorts and conditions of people.
('32', 201, 1, 20, 463010) I hope I have made myself
('32', 201, 2, 21, 463036) 1 Dr. Moreno had said that loyalty was the creed of Anglo Indians.
('32', 202, 0, 1, 463103) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 203
('32', 202, 1, 2, 463149) accessible to anybody who has wanted to see me, but I have even gone out of my way to search out the minorities.
('32', 202, 1, 3, 463262) As the Mussalmans are the big minority, I, as representing the majority of India, think it is my duty to befriend them even though they may reject my advice.
('32', 202, 1, 4, 463420) You do not occupy even that numerical position and, therefore, I have not, wherever I found opportunities to approach you, hesitated to meet you.
('32', 202, 1, 5, 463566) But I am here to confess to you that the Anglo Indians have not freely reciprocated that feeling.
('32', 202, 1, 6, 463664) My largest contact with the Anglo Indians has been on the railway trains, because they have somehow or other fought shy of the public meetings, perhaps because of the notion that these meetings were meetings of disloyalists.
('32', 202, 1, 7, 463889) And as you have made loyalty your creed, naturally these meetings have repelled you.
('32', 202, 1, 8, 463974) On the trains, however, I have sought you out.
('32', 202, 2, 9, 464021) As an instance of how the Anglo Indians have isolated themselves from the Indians, Mr. Gandhi gave a vivid narrative of his meeting with some Anglo Indian youngsters who travelled with him in the same train from Ajmer.
('32', 202, 2, 10, 464240) He had an occasion to listen to their profuse vocabulary of slang until they recognized him, shed their naturalness and put on manners.
('32', 202, 2, 11, 464376) And the behaviour of even those boys afforded ample proof of their isolation.
('32', 202, 2, 12, 464454) One of them liked Indian sweets.
('32', 202, 2, 13, 464487) But he dared not purchase them when others saw him.
('32', 202, 2, 14, 464539) “I eat the sweets only when no one sees me,” he said.
('32', 202, 2, 15, 464593) He was not an Indian, he thought, and did not want to be observed by Indians.
('32', 202, 2, 16, 464671) This, Mr. Gandhi said, was due to their schooling.
('32', 202, 2, 17, 464722) Though you have got Indian blood of which you need be proud—you need not be ashamed of that—I know when you receive a reminder of it you are pained.
('32', 202, 3, 18, 464871) Mr. Gandhi next told them the story of a young Anglo Indian who opened his heart to him, who though getting Rs. 400 was scarcely able to make the two ends meet, who had to live beyond his means, because “I must look a European every inch of me.” I was stabbed to listen to his story.
('32', 202, 3, 19, 465155) This is doing violence to humanity, I said to myself.
('32', 202, 3, 20, 465209) He was a Christian, there was nothing wrong in his demeanour and in spite of the surface polish there was the canker eating into his vitals that he was leading an untrue life.
('32', 202, 3, 21, 465385) Well, I have given you two telling instances.
('32', 202, 3, 22, 465431) You have to make a choice.
('32', 202, 3, 23, 465458) What shall you do?
('32', 202, 3, 24, 465477) Will you attempt the impossible or will you be what you should be : every inch of you Indian?
('32', 202, 3, 25, 465571) Let me tell you one thing more.
('32', 202, 3, 26, 465603) If you go to South Africa or Australia or any Dominion, you know that the same thing which is in store for me is in
('32', 203, 0, 1, 465719) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 203, 1, 2, 465761) store for you.

('32', 203, 1, 4, 465848) Those of you who may possess a white skin may deceive the Immigration Officer, but your relatives and sons may betray you.
('32', 203, 1, 5, 465971) That is the position.
('32', 203, 1, 6, 465993) The colour bar is too terrible there.

('32', 203, 1, 9, 466209) The “bar sinister”, as Lord Morley put it, applies to us even in England.
('32', 203, 1, 10, 466283) Now it is your privilege to fight this.
('32', 203, 1, 11, 466323) If you cast in your lot with the masses of India from which you have sprung, there is nothing but hope for you, me and even for Government to whom you think you are bound to be loyal.
('32', 203, 1, 12, 466507) You can become a bridge so that all Indians and all Englishmen may cross to and fro without either feeling injured or hurt or feeling any degree of inconvenience.

('32', 203, 1, 14, 466828) An important community like the Anglo Indians, brave, resourceful, you are going to perdition simply because you would not see the plain truth, but persist in an impossible attempt.
('32', 203, 1, 15, 467010) In this process, you are cutting yourselves away from the masses.
('32', 203, 1, 16, 467076) Thus you have been ostracized by Indians and Europeans both.
('32', 203, 2, 17, 467137) He gave another anecdote of a very cultured Anglo Indian in Kathiawar trying to live the European way of life, being ostracized everywhere.
('32', 203, 2, 18, 467277) He said : The picture of that tragedy still rises before me.
('32', 203, 2, 19, 467338) I do want to tell you at this critical moment of our national life, “Anglo Indians, make your choice with determination and courage, whether you want to go away from the nation and whether you want to live up to the style of Europeans.” Mind you, I am not asking you to cut yourselves adrift from Englishmen.
('32', 203, 2, 20, 467647) They are far more precious to me today than they were before, because today I am leading the natural life.
('32', 203, 2, 21, 467754) There was a time when I was also aping the Europeans.
('32', 203, 2, 22, 467808) Little things guided my life then.
('32', 203, 2, 23, 467843) But at a precious moment of my life, I threw them into the Indian Ocean, and turned my back on them.

('32', 212, 1, 4, 488918) ‘TOO COSTLY’
('32', 212, 2, 5, 488931) A correspondent from Jamshedpur says that khaddar is too costly for the common or middle class people; it does not last long; it gets dirty too soon, and to keep it clean means an additional expenditure; and adds, ‘Will you please explain in detail how it will be possible for men like us to wear khaddar in these circumstances?’ Although questions like these have been already answered in these pages, it is not superfluous to revert to them again and again.
('32', 212, 2, 6, 489391) Yard for yard, at the present moment, khaddar is undoubtedly dearer than mill cloth.
('32', 212, 2, 7, 489476) But my invariable experience is that those who have taken to khaddar have, consciously or unconsciously, simplified their dress.
('32', 212, 2, 8, 489605) They do not require so much as when they used mill cloth.
('32', 212, 2, 9, 489663) Itis not the experience of all that khaddar does not last as long as mill cloth.
('32', 212, 2, 10, 489744) In the beginning stages the hand spun yarn was ill twisted.
('32', 212, 2, 11, 489804) Therefore, khaddar woven from such yarn was undoubtedly not durable.
('32', 212, 2, 12, 489873) But the quality has since improved.
('32', 212, 2, 13, 489909) I suggest too that if khaddar is washed at home, it will last twice as long as when it is sent to the washermen.
('32', 212, 2, 14, 490022) I admit that, if khaddar is sent out for washing, the cost of washing khaddar would be greater than that of washing ordinary calico.
('32', 212, 2, 15, 490155) The only remedy is home washing which need not frighten people.
('32', 212, 2, 16, 490219) Soaking khaddar overnight in hot water with soap enables one to wash it perfectly clean in no time.
('32', 212, 2, 17, 490319) When the correspondent says that it gets dirty all too soon, I presume that he implies that being white it shows dirt.
('32', 212, 2, 18, 490438) If the intention be to conceal dirt the remedy is to colour it precisely in the same manner that mill cloth is coloured.
('32', 212, 2, 19, 490559) And at the present moment, plenty of coloured khaddar is available in the market.

('32', 212, 2, 21, 490794) The incentive to use khaddar must be national for the middle class people, and they are expected to put themselves to inconvenience in order to popularize it.
('32', 212, 2, 22, 490953) If the State had belonged to the people, it would have protected khaddar by legislation.
('32', 212, 2, 23, 491042) But seeing that the State is foreign and neutral, if not even hostile to khaddar, it is for the people who believe in its national value go give it due protection by putting up with the
('32', 213, 0, 1, 491228) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 213, 1, 2, 491270) inconvenience and extra expenditure that its use may involve before it becomes universal in India.
('32', 213, 1, 3, 491369) Only five years ago, I sold very coarse and ill spun and ill woven khaddar at 17 as.
('32', 213, 1, 4, 491454) per yard.
('32', 213, 1, 5, 491464) Such bad khaddar is now nowhere to be seen.
('32', 213, 1, 6, 491508) Its evolution has been phenomenal, so much so that much superior khaddar is today sold at nine annas per yard in the same part of India.
('32', 213, 1, 7, 491645) Every attempt is being made to bring down the price of khaddar and, if the All India Deshbandhu Charkha Memorial becomes a success and the scheme that is now being conceived comes into operation, I am expecting a still further decline in prices.
('32', 213, 1, 8, 491891) I would like the readers to remember what I said at Chittagong that, if khaddar is dear, freedom is dearer still.
('32', 213, 1, 9, 492005) And he who feels for the masses will not grudge them the extra price that during the transition stage has to be paid for khaddar.

('32', 216, 3, 16, 500499) 145. THE CONGRESS UNEMPLOYED Whilst I was discussing with friends the object of the All India Deshbandhu Memorial, certain friends asked, “Why should not the maintenance of dependents of those who are in prison or deported and alleviation of unemployment of Congressmen who are starving by reason of their non co operation be one of the objects, if not the object?” The same question has come before me during my stay in Bengal in a variety of ways.
('32', 216, 3, 17, 500949) In my opinion, it is not possible to raise the fund suggested from all over India and from all parties for such a purpose.
('32', 216, 3, 18, 501072) So far as the maintenance of the dependents of political prisoners and detenues is concerned, it is a matter that requires most
('32', 217, 0, 1, 501200) 218 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 217, 1, 2, 501242) delicate handling and must be left to each province to settle in the manner that may be considered most suitable in that province.
('32', 217, 1, 3, 501373) I cannot reconcile myself to a permanent fund for that object.
('32', 217, 1, 4, 501436) My own practical experience in South Africa, and to a limited extent here, has shown me that very often undeserving people get relief and the deserving are left out.
('32', 217, 1, 5, 501602) A permanent fund for distant contingencies of this nature offers temptation to those who do not mind living on charity.
('32', 217, 1, 6, 501722) In order to obviate chances of dishonest practices, I had to establish a settlement in South Africa where all those who needed and deserved relief could be accommodated, fed, and looked after.
('32', 217, 1, 7, 501915) At a single stroke it was possible by this arrangement to save thousands of rupees, to provide for every honest case of distress, to do absolute justice to everyone, to put people in distress in ideal surroundings, to find use ful employment for them and to provide education for the children of such families.
('32', 217, 1, 8, 502226) I suggested a similar course in Chittagong after the great strike in 1921. There is danger of charity being misplaced unless drastic measures as I have suggested be adopted to deal with cases of political imprisonment or detention.
('32', 217, 1, 9, 502458) The real fight, if it is to come at all on a large scale, is still to come.
('32', 217, 1, 10, 502534) We shall have to pay a price adequate to the freedom we want and, unless we think out and devise some plan of meeting such contingencies in a reaso nable manner, in the struggle for freedom, it is possible for us to be starved into an ignominious surrender.
('32', 217, 1, 11, 502792) Apart, therefore, from the question of Memorial and on the merits of the case, I am against any permanent fund for the relief of what may be called political distress.
('32', 217, 1, 12, 502960) The question of the Congress unemployed is more urgent and of a permanent character.
('32', 217, 1, 13, 503045) Although we have resolutions on the subject, hitherto we have been unable to establish an All India Congress Service or even a Provincial Congress Service, not for want of will but for want of ability.
('32', 217, 1, 14, 503247) Personally, I have endeavoured to tackle it more than once, but I own I have been baffled.
('32', 217, 1, 15, 503338) It has not been possible to fix a maximum to be paid nor has it been possible to devise grades of service.
('32', 217, 1, 16, 503445) Wherever, therefore, it has been sought to establish a system, it has been found necessary to leave well alone and try every case on its merits.
('32', 217, 1, 17, 503590) It is perhaps not possible as yet to establish a regular service, but I have no doubt that the scale and the system are gradually growing.
('32', 217, 1, 18, 503729) There are two branches of constructive activity which absorb the largest number of Congress workers,—khaddar and, to a lesser extent, education.
('32', 217, 1, 19, 503874) But here again every province will have to be responsible
('32', 218, 0, 1, 503932) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 219
('32', 218, 1, 2, 503978) for its own scheme and as it too depends, as a rule, upon local contributions, it is a fairly sound proposition that that Service only deserves to live which obtains local support, because the test of appreciation of service is the support given by those who are served.
('32', 218, 1, 3, 504249) The very existence of the Congress depends upon the fact that it supplies a local want.
('32', 218, 1, 4, 504337) It is not like a Government super imposed and, therefore, independent of the support of those whom it seeks to rule.
('32', 218, 1, 5, 504454) Both the khaddar and the educational services presuppose continued activity and continued preparation.
('32', 218, 1, 6, 504557) I have laid it down as a rule for my own guidance that, if neither of these activities has local support, it is due to want of tact or ability on the part of those who are engaged in the respective services.
('32', 218, 1, 7, 504765) I do not know a single case of starvation of deserving men.
('32', 218, 1, 8, 504825) I know cases of straitened circumstances of Congress workers eking out an honest but precarious life.
('32', 218, 1, 9, 504927) But I fear that that will be progressively our lot, and, if in some cases, some of us have not yet reconciled ourselves to the simplicity and severity that have entered into the national life, and if some owing to a long course of habit are even constitutionally unfitted to adopt themselves to the severe simplicity which is expected of them, in any case I hope it is now clear why the All India Deshbandhu Memorial may not take the form of giving relief to the distressed or finding employment for Congress workers.
('32', 218, 1, 10, 505445) The present object of the Memorial is calculated indirectly to do both.

('32', 219, 2, 12, 507439) 147. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('32', 219, 3, 13, 507467) July 30, 1925 Maulana Abul Kalam Azad informs me that the newspaper reports of my speech, 1 before the European Association, the other day, has given rise to a great deal of controversy among the Mus salman friends and even some resentment, because some Mus salman friends read into my speech the view that I could not find an able and honourable Mussalman who could occupy the Mayoral chair, and that the Maulana Sahib also had given me a similar opinion.
('32', 219, 3, 14, 507924) I have now read the report of my speech from which these deductions have been made.
('32', 219, 3, 15, 508008) Though it is not a verbatim report, even as it stands, I do not consider that it warrants the deductions that have been drawn from it.
('32', 219, 3, 16, 508143) What I said was that, instead of leaving it to those friends who had come to me to judge as to the ability and honesty of any Mohammedan name that might be suggested, if I had known such a one myself, I should have unconditionally recommended his name for adoption.
('32', 219, 4, 17, 508409) 1 Vide “Speech at European Association Meeting”, 24 7 1925.
('32', 220, 0, 1, 508469) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 221
('32', 220, 1, 2, 508515) The Maulana certainly never conveyed to me directly or indirectly, that his recommendation of Mr. J. M. Sen Gupta’s name was based upon the fact that there was no honest and able Mussalman in the Corporation or outside on whom the distinction could be conferred, but simply suggested a political motive for his recommendation, namely giving as much adventitious aid as possible to the Swaraj Party in the absence of its illustrious Chief.
('32', 220, 1, 3, 508954) Whatever the interpretation that my speech, as reported, may be capable of, the public will accept my assurance that nothing was more remote from my mind, or that of Maulana Sahib than to think that there was no honest and able Mussalman who could be recommended for the honour.
('32', 220, 1, 4, 509233) In fact, for me, it would be ludicrous presumption, when I did not sufficiently know any Mussalman in Calcutta except the Maulana, to say that there was no honest and able Mussalman who could occupy the chair.
('32', 220, 1, 5, 509443) Indeed, if the Maulana Sahib’s suggestion had not come to me or, having come, had not appealed to me, I would have continued to prosecute Mr. Suhrawardy’s claim as I had come to know something of his ability, and I was entitled to presume his honesty from his occupation of the chair of the Deputy Mayor.

('32', 220, 4, 8, 509780) 148. LETTER TO “THE STATESMAN”
('32', 220, 5, 9, 509811) 148, RUSSA ROAD, July 31, 1925 You will perhaps extend me the courtesy of finding room for a reply to your article headed “Civil Resistance” in today’s Statesman.
('32', 220, 5, 10, 509974) You see an inconsistency between my desire to prepare an atmosphere for civil resistance and my statement to the European Association that I was dying for co operation.
('32', 220, 5, 11, 510143) My speech before the European Association was delivered on July 24. I write for Young India on Saturday for the issue of Thursday following.
('32', 220, 5, 12, 510284) The reference to civil resistance which you have quoted appears in Young India of July 23. I give you the dates in order to show that the idea or preparation for civil resistance was not conceived after the statement to the European Association.
('32', 220, 5, 13, 510530) I see no inconsistency between the desire for civil resistance and
('32', 221, 0, 1, 510597) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 221, 1, 2, 510639) for co operation.
('32', 221, 1, 3, 510657) You will remember that my statement to the European Association was a recalling of an old story.
('32', 221, 1, 4, 510754) When, in the heyday of non co operation, an Englishman twitted me with the remark that, although I professed non co operation I was dying to co operate, I said to him emphatically that I was doing so.
('32', 221, 1, 5, 510955) And I say that that is my position also today.
('32', 221, 1, 6, 511002) Civil resistance to wrong in not a new doctrine or practice with me.
('32', 221, 1, 7, 511071) It is a life long belief and a life long practice.
('32', 221, 1, 8, 511122) To prepare the country for civil resistance is to prepare it for non violence.
('32', 221, 1, 9, 511201) To prepare the country for non violence is to organize it for constructive work which, to me, is synonymous with the spinning wheel.
('32', 221, 1, 10, 511334) You evidently seem to think that I have repented of my non co operation or civil resis tance.
('32', 221, 1, 11, 511428) I have never done so.
('32', 221, 1, 12, 511450) I remain a confirmed non co operator.
('32', 221, 1, 13, 511488) If I could carry educated India with me, I would declare non co operation in its entirety today.
('32', 221, 1, 14, 511585) Being a practical man, I recognize the facts that stare me in the face.
('32', 221, 1, 15, 511657) I have failed to convince some of my most esteemed colleagues that the particular form of non co operation which we embarked upon in 1920 can do good to the country at the present moment.
('32', 221, 1, 16, 511845) It, therefore, remains under suspension.
('32', 221, 1, 17, 511886) But I cannot hide from you the fact that, if I could reconvert my colleagues, I would certainly ask the Congress to renew the battle.
('32', 221, 1, 18, 512020) Personally, I have no desire to co operate voluntarily with the Government in my weakness; that would be the co operation of a slave.
('32', 221, 1, 19, 512154) I admit my weakness, and, therefore, I remain satisfied with the mere desire for co operation and I seek to fulfil that desire by developing strength.
('32', 221, 1, 20, 512305) If I believed in violence, I would make no secret of it and would take the consequences.
('32', 221, 1, 21, 512394) But I would let the country know publicly, and know in unequivocal terms, that there is no freedom for her and no room for honourable co operation with the Government, unless she is prepared to match the British bayonet with the Indian.
('32', 221, 1, 22, 512631) As it is, I do not believe in the creed of the bayonet.
('32', 221, 1, 23, 512687) I further believe that, fortunately or unfortunately, it will never succeed in India.
('32', 221, 1, 24, 512773) A substitute for it is, however, necessary and that is civil resistance.In your opinion it is as dangerous as violence, and if such is also the opinion of the Government, it has to suppress me, for after my discharge from prison, I have not allowed a moment to pass when I have not endeavoured to fit myself or the country for civil resistance.
('32', 221, 1, 25, 513118) Let me inform you in all humility that, if I could but secure the absolute co operation of my revolutionary friends by the entirecessation of their activity, and if I could produce an atmosphere
('32', 222, 0, 1, 513313) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 223
('32', 222, 1, 2, 513359) of general non violence, I would declare mass civil resistance today and thus prepare the ground for honourable co operation.
('32', 222, 1, 3, 513485) I admit that I failed to do so in 1921, and when I found that Chauri Chaura betrayed me, I had no hesitation within twenty four hours of the declaration of civil resistance to suspend it, and to take the consequences of a general depression in the country that followed.
('32', 222, 1, 4, 513756) And if I insist ad nauseam on Hindu Muslim unity, and the spinning wheel and khaddar, it is in order to ensure a state of non violence necessary for civil resistance.
('32', 222, 1, 5, 513923) I have, I confess, despaired of achieving Hindu Muslim unity in the very near future.
('32', 222, 1, 6, 514009) Untouchability is surely but slowly going, the spinning wheel is surely but slowly making its way.
('32', 222, 1, 7, 514108) Meanwhile, the ruthless exploitation of the country is proceeding apace.
('32', 222, 1, 8, 514181) I am, therefore, thinking out plans of some form of effective individual civil resistance which, if it brings no relief to this poor country, will at least bring some solace to those whose creed is non violence, to know that they have left no stone unturned to help the deliverance of the country from a bondage which is enervating a whole nation.
('32', 222, 1, 9, 514529) I confess, again that I have no ready made plan, for if I had, I would not keep it from you or the country.
('32', 222, 1, 10, 514637) But I am giving you the whole of the working of my mind.
('32', 222, 1, 11, 514694) I have no desire to obtain or retain the goodwill of Englishmen under false pretences.
('32', 222, 1, 12, 514781) Even as the Government abates no precaution or preparation for ensuring its existence and stability, when it may be offering terms to Indian politicians, even so do I want my country to abate no effort to arm itself with a weapon on which she may rely when the Government fails to respond to its wishes.
('32', 222, 1, 13, 515085) You may know (for the communication is published) that Deshbandhu did not sign Dr. Besant’s manifesto on her Bill, one of the grounds for which was that there was no sanction stipulated for in the event of rejection.

('32', 222, 1, 15, 515344) Will you have the country’s manhood absolutely paralysed and rendered utterly ineffective for any resistance, violent or non violent, before the British Government can possibly think of offering any terms or considering proposals that might be made by the Swaraj Party or any other?

('32', 223, 0, 1, 515778) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 223, 1, 2, 515820) 149. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, CALCUTTA 1
('32', 223, 2, 3, 515862) July 31, 1925
('32', 223, 3, 4, 515876) Mahatma Gandhi, who presided, said that two things were dear to the heart of the deceased patriot, one of which was that he stood, without any mental reservation, out and out for Hindu Muslim unity.
('32', 223, 3, 5, 516075) He was also an ardent advocate of swadeshi.
('32', 223, 3, 6, 516119) The times when Rasul lived were comparatively ancient, and he wished to interpret his message in the spirit of modern times.
('32', 223, 3, 7, 516244) In the programme that was sketched out for the nation in 1920, both Hindu Muslim unity and swadeshi were duly emphasized.
('32', 223, 3, 8, 516366) But they gave a new meaning to both these two things.
('32', 223, 3, 9, 516420) They then decided that it was not enough that a few educated Indians should stand shoulder to shoulder, work together, perhaps mix socia lly also.
('32', 223, 3, 10, 516567) They then felt the necessity of taking that message to the masses.
('32', 223, 3, 11, 516634) They had not half done the task.
('32', 223, 3, 12, 516667) In fact, they had not yet made a beginning.
('32', 223, 3, 13, 516711) They all wanted Hindu Muslim unity, but they would not get it by simply talking about it.
('32', 223, 3, 14, 516801) Then and then only would Hindu Muslim unity be established when Hindus would learn to serve the Mohammedans without expecting the slightest reward and Mohammedans would learn to serve Hindus in a similarly disinterested spirit.
('32', 223, 3, 15, 517029) The new meaning of swadeshi was, not that they should put together the several parts of an article, say a watch or harmonium, imported from abroad and label it as swadeshi, but their swadeshi now consisted in every part being made in India.
('32', 223, 3, 16, 517270) They now recognized that the central fact round which swadeshi should revolve was “khaddar”.
('32', 223, 3, 17, 517363) That was the modern dictionary meaning of swadeshi and not until they had done this one thing would they be able to realize the dream that Abdur Rasul dreamt.
('32', 223, 4, 18, 517522) Proceeding, Mahatma Gandhi said that he had that afternoon seen hundreds of hungry people being fed in front of the Marble Palace in Chor Bagan.
('32', 223, 4, 19, 517667) The sight was one which was neither ennobling nor honourable to those who had organized the meal for the hungry people of Calcutta from day to day.
('32', 223, 4, 20, 517815) They did not know what they were doing.
('32', 223, 4, 21, 517855) They were ignorant of the irreparable harm they were doing to India by this misplaced benevolence.
('32', 223, 4, 22, 517954) Not one of these men and women who were being fed were incapacitated for work.
('32', 223, 4, 23, 518033) They had just as strong arms and legs as anyone of them had.
('32', 223, 4, 24, 518094) Did they think there was any merit in feeding people who could work for their living?
('32', 223, 4, 25, 518180) He differed from those who considered this as a merit.
('32', 223, 4, 26, 518235) Let them not be flattered with the testimony that was sometimes ignorantly given by European writers that there were no such things as work houses in India.
('32', 223, 4, 27, 518392) These European writers believed that the Indians had a system of feeding the poor and the hungry which was self organized, and which did away with the necessity of having work houses.
('32', 223, 5, 28, 518576) 1 This was held on the eighth anniversary of Abdur Rasul’s death, and was held at Albert Hall.
('32', 224, 0, 1, 518671) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 225
('32', 224, 1, 2, 518717) statement was only partially true, and the system had done no good to India.
('32', 224, 1, 3, 518794) They were today feeding the idlers.
('32', 224, 1, 4, 518830) Some of them were thieves and, if this process continued for any length of time, he saw no bright future for this unhappy country.
('32', 224, 1, 5, 518961) Let them, therefore, beware of this system.
('32', 224, 1, 6, 519005) He did not introduce this story to criticize the philanthropist.
('32', 224, 1, 7, 519070) He wished he had their 1ear, and then he would ask them not to misplace their philanthropy in this way; rather he would ask them to give some work to these men and women.
('32', 224, 1, 8, 519241) Had they ever paused to enquire why these people were idlers, why millions of people of India were idling away their time?
('32', 224, 1, 9, 519364) Indians were not a nation of idlers.
('32', 224, 1, 10, 519401) Had they been so, they would have died long ago.
('32', 224, 1, 11, 519450) The fact was that there was not enough work for them and therefore this glorious land of theirs, because of their ignorance, because of their want of real patriotism, was throwing out people who could not be sustained on the land.
('32', 224, 1, 12, 519681) Therefore the remedy lay in finding an occupation for them.
('32', 224, 1, 13, 519741) And what better occupation could be provided for these millions of men than the spinning wheel or the charkha.
('32', 224, 1, 14, 519852) Let the educated community, therefore, spin for at least half an hour if they wanted to remove this degrading poverty of the masses.

('32', 225, 4, 6, 520788) DEAR FRIEND, It was a pleasure to meet you and have that little discussion, and an equal pleasure to have received your letter.
('32', 225, 4, 7, 520916) 1 What I said at the meeting 2 was based upon recent experiences.
('32', 225, 4, 8, 520982) I know that individual instances of a broader and truer outlook upon religions are on the increase.
('32', 225, 4, 9, 521082) The tolerance with which I was listened to at that meeting is a proof of it.
('32', 225, 4, 10, 521159) But the literature that was sent me by unknown friends in the jail and the letters that I received almost every month from Christian friends, both in India and outside, demonstrate the truth of my remarks.
('32', 225, 4, 11, 521365) As to Bishop Heber’s Hymn 3, you will realize, perhaps, that it is one thing for a man to think of himself as vile and unclean, but it is another for the world to pronounce him as such.
('32', 225, 4, 12, 521551) Augustine considered himself as chief among sinners.
('32', 225, 4, 13, 521604) The world calls him a saint.
('32', 225, 4, 14, 521633) Tulsidas had no adjective harsh enough to describe himself as a sinner.
('32', 225, 4, 15, 521705) The world regards him also as a saint.
('32', 225, 4, 16, 521744) Lastly, I wonder if you know that the Christian Literature Society continues to sell the utterly unbalanced views and opinions of Mr. Murdoch and others.
('32', 225, 4, 17, 521898) And if you only knew the literature in the vernaculars that is distributed through tens of thousands of leaflets and booklets, you will, perhaps, appreciate the force of my remarks.
('32', 225, 4, 18, 522080) These things hurt me only because I know that they believe the teachings of Jesus, in whose name they are said and written; and it hurts me also because Indian Christians are fed upon such ignorance which they, in their simplicity, imbibe as God’s truth, and hence learn to hate those who were once their friends, companions and relatives.
('32', 225, 4, 19, 522420) You perhaps do not know that I mix as freely with Christian Indians in the lower strata of society as I mix with a similar class of Hindus and Mussalmans.
('32', 225, 4, 20, 522575) I say these things

('32', 227, 1, 2, 525162) 152. LETTER TO A FRIEND 1
('32', 227, 2, 3, 525188) 148, RUSSA ROAD, CALCUTTA, August 1, 1925
('32', 227, 3, 4, 525230) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('32', 227, 3, 5, 525263) A man who owns land which is haunted by wild beasts will be able to excuse himself for shooting them.
('32', 227, 3, 6, 525365) It would be classed as inevitable himsa.
('32', 227, 3, 7, 525406) It will be justified on the ground of necessity, but there is no doubt that, if one has a full perception of ahimsa, it would be well for him to let his land be overrun by wild beasts or be himself killed by them.
('32', 227, 3, 8, 525620) Ahimsa is not a mechanical matter, it is personal to everyone.
('32', 227, 3, 9, 525683) Moreover, possession of property against the whole world is inconsistent with ahimsa.
('32', 227, 3, 10, 525769) A man who will follow the principle of non violence to its uttermost limit has nothing in this world he can call his own.
('32', 227, 3, 11, 525891) He must merge himself into the whole, which includes snakes, scorpions, tigers, wolves, etc.
('32', 227, 3, 12, 525984) There are instances on record of innocent men whose innocence even wild beasts have recognized.
('32', 227, 3, 13, 526080) We must all strive to reach that stage.
('32', 227, 3, 14, 526120) The same remark applies to your second question.
('32', 227, 3, 15, 526169) It is himsa to kill the germs and the insects, but even as we commit himsa by taking vegetable food (for vegetables have life) but regard it as inevitable, so must we treat the germ life.
('32', 227, 3, 16, 526357) You will recognize that the doctrine of necessity can be stretched so as to justify even man eating.
('32', 227, 3, 17, 526458) A man who believes in ahimsa carefully refrains from every act that leads to injury.
('32', 227, 3, 18, 526543) [My] argument only applies to those who believe in ahimsa.
('32', 227, 3, 19, 526602) The necessity that I have in mind is a universal necessity, hence it is not permissible to take ahimsa beyond a limit.
('32', 227, 3, 20, 526721) That is why the Shastras of custom only permit himsa in certain cases.
('32', 227, 3, 21, 526792) It is not only lawful but obligatory upon everyone to make the least use possible of the permission and relaxation.
('32', 227, 3, 22, 526908) It is unlawful to go beyond the limitation.
('32', 227, 4, 23, 526952) Yours sincerely,
('32', 227, 5, 24, 526969) M. K. GANDHI
('32', 227, 6, 25, 526982) From a photostat: S.N. 10595

('32', 228, 1, 2, 527162) 153. SPEECH AT TILAK ANNIVERSARY MEETING1
('32', 228, 2, 3, 527204) CALCUTTA, August 1, 1925
('32', 228, 3, 4, 527229) Mahatma Gandhi, speaking in Hindustani, said that the great mantra that Bal
('32', 228, 4, 5, 527305) Gangadhar gave to India was that “Swaraj was their birthright.” By swaraj he (Lokamanya) meant swaraj for the toiling crores of India.
('32', 228, 4, 6, 527440) To Mahatmaji’s mind the call was clear: If they wished to achieve swaraj for the masses of India, they must have to work for it through charkha and khaddar and thus identify them with the poor, starving millions of Hindustan.
('32', 228, 4, 7, 527666) If they really wanted to get inspiration from the memory of Lokamanya and if they really desired swaraj for the poor, then they should hear the old man speaking to them in season and out of season and take to the spinning wheel.
('32', 228, 4, 8, 527895) Let them promise from the very day that they would discard foreign cloth and take to swadeshi homespun and hand woven cloth.
('32', 228, 5, 9, 528020) The other day, Mahatmaji proceeded, they declared a boycott of British goods in reply to Lord Birkenhead’s statement.
('32', 228, 5, 10, 528138) He had his doubt as to the possibility of its achievement.
('32', 228, 5, 11, 528197) But although he was on principle against boycott, he would be glad if the people discarded British cloth.
('32', 228, 5, 12, 528303) They had failed to act up to their leaders’ advice for the last four years, they had not as yet universally taken to charkha and khaddar.
('32', 228, 5, 13, 528441) They might, however, from now rectify their mistake the take a solemn vow from
('32', 228, 6, 14, 528520) today onward to discard the use of foreign goods and use swadeshi.
('32', 228, 7, 15, 528587) Foreward, 4 8 1925
('32', 228, 8, 16, 528606) 154. NEW RITUALS
('32', 228, 9, 17, 528623) In the meetings and functions that were held after the death of Deshbandhu, besides the commonly practised rites, people introduced such new rituals as they found appropriate.
('32', 228, 9, 18, 528799) Kirtans were held at many places in Bengal, the poor were fed at some places while, at other places, people took baths, etc., and performed religious ceremonies.
('32', 228, 9, 19, 528961) The villagers of Chadia, in Kathiawar, observed the day 3 in the following manner: 1. They prayed to God for peace to the departed soul and for the birth in India of others like Deshbandhu.
('32', 228, 10, 20, 529151) 1 The meeting was held at the Albert Hall.
('32', 228, 10, 21, 529194) J.M. Sen Gupta presided.
('32', 228, 10, 22, 529219) 2 At the conclusion, Gandhiji addressed an overflow meeting at College Square.

('32', 229, 0, 1, 529415) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 229, 1, 2, 529457) 2. They gave balls of sweetmeat to dogs and cows.
('32', 229, 1, 3, 529507) 3. They refrained from using the bullock to plough or to draw water from the well.
('32', 229, 1, 4, 529590) 4. They decided to store enough good quality cotton in the coming year for their own domestic use.
('32', 229, 1, 5, 529689) At some other places, the day was spent in fasting and spinning.
('32', 229, 1, 6, 529754) Such innovations are to be welcomed.
('32', 229, 1, 7, 529791) To make such days the occasion for promoting those beneficial activities which one can think of and which were dear to the departed persons, is a good way of showing our love for them.
('32', 229, 1, 8, 529976) Not using the bullock for ploughing or drawing water indicates kindness to animals.
('32', 229, 1, 9, 530060) Except during the monsoon, we are almost always callously engaged in drawing water and so on.
('32', 229, 1, 10, 530154) Actually, this does more harm than good.
('32', 229, 1, 11, 530195) People have lost nothing but have rather gained something where it is customary to give a weekly day of rest to servants and animals; hence it is a good beginning to stop drawing water with the leather bucket and thereby giving rest to servants and animals on such occasions of mourning for great men.
('32', 229, 2, 12, 530497) MISPLACED KINDNESS Giving sweetmeat balls to dogs and cows, however, is misplaced kindness.
('32', 229, 2, 13, 530589) There is no reason to believe that just because we like these sweets, cows and dogs also like them and are benefited by eating them.
('32', 229, 2, 14, 530722) Animals have not had their taste for food spoilt.
('32', 229, 2, 15, 530772) If even among human beings the taste for food varies, what can we say of animals?
('32', 229, 2, 16, 530854) An Englishman, if given a sweetmeat ball, would throw it away.
('32', 229, 2, 17, 530917) Many of us would not like English sweets.
('32', 229, 2, 18, 530959) If anyone served a meal of rotis in Madras, our countrymen there would be unable to eat it.
('32', 229, 2, 19, 531051) It is useless to serve a meal of rice in the Punjab.
('32', 229, 2, 20, 531104) What then is the meaning of serving such sweets to cows and dogs?
('32', 229, 2, 21, 531170) The fact that dogs eat these up is no argument in support of feeding them with these sweets.
('32', 229, 2, 22, 531263) It is kindness to give grass to undernourished cattle.
('32', 229, 2, 23, 531318) In villages, however there should be no such cattle.
('32', 229, 2, 24, 531371) There is no kindness in giving such food to dogs; I see only ignorance in it.
('32', 229, 2, 25, 531449) We are exchanging wakefulness for sleep.
('32', 229, 2, 26, 531490) We increase their progeny by tempting dogs in an improper way and, then, since no one owns them, they remain undernourished.
('32', 229, 2, 27, 531615) All dogs should be kept as pets.
('32', 229, 2, 28, 531648) The existence of stray dogs is a sign of our sin and our ignorance.
('32', 229, 2, 29, 531716) Ahmedabad claims to practise the religion of compassion by driving out its dogs without any owners from one place to another.

('32', 230, 1, 3, 532046) Violence is involved, first, in catching these dogs and driving them away from familiar surroundings and second, in releasing them in other poor villages.
('32', 230, 1, 4, 532201) For the nuisance of stray dogs, civilized human beings should seek out a solution on a consideration of both ethics and expediency.

('32', 234, 1, 2, 541911) 156. MY NOTES
('32', 234, 2, 3, 541925) DADABHAI CENTENARY
('32', 234, 3, 4, 541944) The centenary of Dadabhai Naoroji’s birth falls on the ensuing 4th September.
('32', 234, 3, 5, 542022) Shri Bharucha has given us a timely reminder of this.
('32', 234, 3, 6, 542076) We knew Dadabhai as the Grand Old Man of India.
('32', 234, 3, 7, 542124) He dedicated his life to the country.
('32', 234, 3, 8, 542162) He made the service of the country our dharma.
('32', 234, 3, 9, 542209) He was the friend of the poor of our land.
('32', 234, 3, 10, 542252) It was he who first presented the picture of the poverty of India.
('32', 234, 3, 11, 542319) To this day, no one has been able to contradict the statistics he furnished.
('32', 234, 3, 12, 542396) He made no distinction between Hindus, Muslims, Parsis, Christians and others.
('32', 234, 3, 13, 542475) He regarded them all as the children of Mother India and hence all received equal service from him.
('32', 234, 3, 14, 542575) His two grand daughters have, we find, inherited in full measure this trait.
('32', 234, 3, 15, 542652) How shall we celebrate the centenary of this great servant of India?
('32', 234, 3, 16, 542721) We shall, of course, hold meetings and that too not only in cities, but also in all villages to which the voice of the Congress can be carried.
('32', 234, 3, 17, 542865) And what shall we do there?
('32', 234, 3, 18, 542893) Praise Dadabhai?
('32', 234, 3, 19, 542910) If this is all that we wish to do, why should we not sit comfortably, send for bards and minstrels and call upon them to employ their imagination and their torrential flow of words?
('32', 234, 3, 20, 543092) If, however, we wish to emulate his virtues, we should think of them and take stock of our capacity to acquire them.
('32', 234, 3, 21, 543209) Dadabhai saw the poverty of India.
('32', 234, 3, 22, 543244) He taught us that swaraj is the remedy for it.
('32', 234, 3, 23, 543291) However, he left to us the task of seeking out the key to swaraj.
('32', 234, 3, 24, 543357) The principal reason for exalting Dadabhai was his devotion to the country and he spent himself in it.
('32', 234, 3, 25, 543460) We know that the spinning wheel is the chief means of winning swaraj.
('32', 234, 3, 26, 543530) India’s poverty is due to its peasants remaining idle for four to six months in a year.
('32', 234, 3, 27, 543618) And, if this enforced idleness becomes a voluntary one, or in other words, we become habitually lazy, not only will this country not gain its freedom, but it will perish altogether.
('32', 234, 3, 28, 543800) The spinning wheel is the only way of getting rid of this idleness.
('32', 234, 3, 29, 543868) Hence, all activities which encourage its use amount to an imitation of Dadabhai’s virtues.
('32', 234, 3, 30, 543960) The spinning wheel means khadi, it means the boycott of foreign cloth, it means sixty crores of rupees finding their way into the huts of the poor.
('32', 234, 3, 31, 544108) The spinning wheel is the sole answer to the appeal for All India

('32', 239, 1, 2, 553762) 157. CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE IN THE CONGRESS
('32', 239, 2, 3, 553802) We have, very often, said in the Navajivan that civil disobedience may be practised not only towards those whom we regard as our enemies or those who regard us as enemies, but also towards those whom we regard as our friends or our elders.
('32', 239, 2, 4, 554042) It is now time to apply this to the Congress.
('32', 239, 2, 5, 554088) The constitutional changes which it is necessary to bring about are stated elsewhere in this issue.
('32', 239, 2, 6, 554188) Ordinarily, however, the Congress Committee is not authorized to make these changes.
('32', 239, 2, 7, 554273) They can be made only by amending the constitution.
('32', 239, 2, 8, 554325) The Congress alone is authorized to amend it.
('32', 239, 2, 9, 554371) This power is not vested in the Congress Committee.
('32', 239, 2, 10, 554423) The latter would have to make use of its extraordinary powers in order to do so.
('32', 239, 2, 11, 554504) The use of such powers may also be called “civil disobedience” of the law.
('32', 239, 2, 12, 554579) Not only has every person and every organization the right to practise this if occasion arises, but it may become even their duty to do so.
('32', 239, 2, 13, 554719) If we recognize the necessity of the reforms suggested by me, this is now our duty.
('32', 239, 2, 14, 554803) This matter should certainly be discussed at the Congress session.
('32', 239, 2, 15, 554870) The rule which permits the purchase of yarn to be contributed must be annulled because, not only has spinning gained nothing by it but, on the contrary it has led to an increase in hypocrisy and falsehood.
('32', 239, 2, 16, 555076) If the Congress Committee does not make this necessary change, it may be regarded as having failed in its duty, because the public will be wasting a few months.
('32', 239, 2, 17, 555237) Perhaps, there would have been room for difference of opinion on this subject if Deshbandhu had not died and if Lord Birkenhead had not made his speech; but there is no such room left now.
('32', 239, 2, 18, 555426) It may be that some members of the Congress Committee do not accept the immediate necessity of making the change; in that case, they have no right to practise civil disobedience and, hence, I have stated that the Congress Committee can make such changes only by near, if not complete, unanimity.
('32', 239, 2, 19, 555722) The necessity of making such changes is not a sufficient ground for offering civil disobedience.
('32', 239, 2, 20, 555819) Those against whom it is offered must also be benefited by it.
('32', 239, 2, 21, 555882) This condition is wholly fulfilled in this case as the above changes are necessary only for the benefit of the Congress.
('32', 239, 2, 22, 556003) The second condition is that those who practise such disobedience must bear no ill will.
('32', 239, 2, 23, 556092) This is implied in its very name, as ‘civility’ is opposed to ill will.

('32', 257, 0, 1, 599514) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 257, 1, 2, 599556) means a government never strong enough to override by force of arms the wishes of the majority, in other words, a government responsible to public opinion.
('32', 257, 1, 3, 599712) Today the teachers have public opinion behind them in many things, but it is helpless against a power that is armed for dealing with any possible physical combination on the part of the people of India.
('32', 257, 1, 4, 599915) No government in the world is so irresponsible and so unresponsive to the opinion of the millions of men and women of India as the Government of India.
('32', 257, 1, 5, 600067) It was the realization of this fact that made Gokhale postpone everything else to the effort for winning self government.
('32', 257, 1, 6, 600189) Lokamanya was so impatient that he made his formula, “Swaraj is my birthright”, ring from one end of India to the other.
('32', 257, 1, 7, 600310) He suppressed his taste for scholarship and philosophy in favour of swaraj.
('32', 257, 1, 8, 600386) Deshbandhu laid down his life in the same pursuit.
('32', 257, 1, 9, 600437) All those who are like the teachers have, therefore, no remedy for their disease save that of gaining swaraj as quickly as possible.
('32', 257, 1, 10, 600570) How is that to be attained.
('32', 257, 1, 11, 600598) I have pointed out the remedy and the country is supposed to have adopted it.

('32', 257, 1, 16, 601297) Swaraj government will be a sorry affair if people look up to it for the regulation of every detail of life.
('32', 257, 1, 17, 601406) Do the teachers realize that the pupils are an exaggerated edition of what they themselves are?

('32', 257, 1, 19, 601575) The examination system, as it is, becomes doubly oppressive by reason of the mechanical method of instruction.

('32', 258, 1, 4, 602575) We have got into the very slovenly habit, in order, as we fancy to give point to our conversations, of using English adjectives, adverbs and even phrases of the English language.

('32', 258, 1, 8, 603104) I am, therefore, recommending what is, in some respects, more difficult of accomplishment.
('32', 258, 1, 9, 603195) It is easier for the average man to run away from evil than remain in it and still remain unaffected by it.
('32', 258, 1, 10, 603303) Many men can shun grog shops and remain teetotallers, but not many can remain in these pestilential places and avoid the contagion.

('32', 258, 1, 13, 603747) Many of them even enter the teaching profession with a view to preparing for what they regard as a better thing.

('32', 258, 1, 16, 604169) I believe in the ancient idea of teachers teaching for the love of it and receiving the barest maintenance.
('32', 258, 1, 17, 604277) The Roman Catholics have retained that idea and they are responsible for some of the best educational institutions in the world.

('32', 258, 1, 21, 604653) The masses got their training in their homes and in their hereditary occupations.
('32', 258, 1, 22, 604735) It was a good enough ideal for those times.

('32', 258, 1, 25, 604870) The masses claim the same attention as the
('32', 259, 0, 1, 604913) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 259, 1, 2, 604955) classes.
('32', 259, 1, 3, 604964) How far it is possible and beneficial to mankind generally cannot be discussed here.
('32', 259, 1, 4, 605049) There is nothing inherently wrong in the desire for learning.
('32', 259, 1, 5, 605111) If it is directed in a healthy channel it can only do good.
('32', 259, 1, 6, 605171) Without, therefore, stopping to devise means for avoiding the inevitable, we must make the best use possible of it.

('32', 261, 6, 17, 609607) 167. SPEECH AT KRISHNATH COLLEGE, BEHRAMPUR 1
('32', 261, 7, 18, 609653) August 6, 1925
('32', 261, 8, 19, 609668) MAHARAJA SAHIB, FRIENDS AND FELLOW STUDENTS, I address you as fellow students because I regard myself as a student, 56 years though I am.
('32', 261, 8, 20, 609806) The more I live on this earth, the more I realize how much I have yet to learn and possibly how much I have yet to unlearn.
('32', 261, 8, 21, 609930) It gives me great pleasure to meet you this afternoon.
('32', 261, 8, 22, 609985) It is a double pleasure.
('32', 261, 8, 23, 610010) I always seek an opportunity of meeting the student world all over India.
('32', 261, 8, 24, 610084) It was, therefore, a pleasure to find this function amongst the various functions arranged by the Reception Committee, but the knowledge that this College is associated with one of the magnificient charities of the Maharaja Bahadur was an additional pleasure when I understood what this College was.
('32', 261, 8, 25, 610384) I have known his great charities since 1915, when I had the honour of coming in contract with the Maharaja Bahadur, but I never realized till
('32', 261, 9, 26, 610526) 1 Gandhiji visited the Krishnath College on August 6, where he was presented with an address and a purse of Rs. 1,067 for the Deshbandhu Memorial Fund.
('32', 261, 9, 27, 610678) Gandhiji’s reply was recorded in shorthand and reproduced as an appendix in the College Commemoration Volume.
('32', 262, 0, 1, 610788) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 263
('32', 262, 1, 2, 610834) I came here what was the quantity of these charities.
('32', 262, 1, 3, 610888) I understand from reliable sources that they amount to more than one crore of rupees.
('32', 262, 1, 4, 610974) I had flattered myself with the belief that my Parsi friends beat everyone on the face of the earth in their charities, and I suppose, now, that statement will stand unchallenged so far as the whole community is concerned; but so far as individuals are concerned, I do not recollect a single Parsi name that has exceeded the charities of Cossimbazar.
('32', 262, 1, 5, 611325) As I told you, therefore, it is a double pleasure for me to meet you this afternoon.
('32', 262, 1, 6, 611410) I thank you for the purse that you have presented towards the Deshbandhu Memorial.
('32', 262, 1, 7, 611493) You know better than I do how much the student world is indebted to Deshbandhu not merely because he was one of their patrons, not merely because the students found his purse open for them, but also because his advice was always at the disposal of students, and he has left to the student world a legacy of self sacrifice and devotion to the motherland which is not to be surpassed by anybody, if it can be at all equalled.
('32', 262, 1, 8, 611917) It is, therefore, nothing out of the way that you have given this good purse for this memorial and I hope that students all over Bengal will follow your noble example.
('32', 262, 1, 9, 612085) You have asked me to answer certain questions which you have put to me.
('32', 262, 1, 10, 612157) I have understood these questions.
('32', 262, 1, 11, 612192) I have not given myself much time to speak to you this afternoon, but before I come to these questions, I want to talk to you of things that are much more permanent for students and, therefore, of much greater importance than even the important questions that you have put to me.
('32', 262, 1, 12, 612472) Throughout my travels in the world and my association with students and my experience as an amateur teacher of youth and of girls, I have come to the conclusion that the literary knowledge that a schoolmaster or a professor gives is by no means composed of what he has to give.
('32', 262, 1, 13, 612750) You are not to be judged by the excellene of your pronunciation or by the excellence of your grammar, not even by the excellence of your eloquence; for that matter you might have never come to colleges, and yet it is possible for you to give a good account of yourselves to the world, it is possible for you to live a decent life as citizens of India—as citizens of the world.
('32', 262, 1, 14, 613127) What you come to schools and colleges for is essentially to build your character.
('32', 262, 1, 15, 613209) The highest ideal that can possibly be conceived for the student life has been placed before us by our Hindu ancestors, the great rishis of old.
('32', 262, 1, 16, 613354) They likened the life of a student to that of a sannyasi, and they have laid
('32', 263, 0, 1, 613431) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 263, 1, 2, 613473) down laws for the guidance of students just as rigorous as those they have laid down for the fourth ashrama, the fourth stage—the stage of a sannyasi.
('32', 263, 1, 3, 613624) What a sannyasi is expected to do after a full expericnce of the world, out of the fullness of his knowledge, a student is voluntarily expected to do because of tradition, because of regard for his spiritual and for his worldly preceptors.
('32', 263, 1, 4, 613864) You know the distinction between worldly knowledge and divine knowledge.
('32', 263, 1, 5, 613937) They used worldly ambition and worldly knowledge also for the uplift of the soul, and even whilst they discoursed on matters of the world, they gave us a secret knowledge of the soul.
('32', 263, 1, 6, 614121) Anyone who has studied the glorious Upanishads will be able, without the slightest hesitation, to corroborate what I am just now telling you.
('32', 263, 1, 7, 614263) Ask yourselves then, “Are you leading the life of a sannyasi, are you—all of you—brahmacharis ?” Throughout my travels in Bengal I have heard a lot about the students of Bengal.
('32', 263, 1, 8, 614441) I have heard something to your credit.
('32', 263, 1, 9, 614480) I have also heard something to your discredit.
('32', 263, 1, 10, 614527) I have been told that the life of the average student in Bengal, if not throughout India, is not particularly pure.
('32', 263, 1, 11, 614643) He spends his time not in reading the purest literature, but he even devotes his spare hours to reading magazines which should never find a place in a decent library or in a gentleman’s drawing room.
('32', 263, 1, 12, 614843) I do not know how far this is true.

('32', 264, 1, 2, 616261) spoke from knowledge, she spoke from the bitterness of her own experience and she said, “You may ask anybody you like, and you will find that, in general, my remarks will be corroborated by the parents in Bengal.” I have read only lately a paragraph in newspapers that a girl—I forget her name—committed suicide.

('32', 264, 1, 14, 618179) May God give you strength and the wisdom to understand the substance of what I am telling you.

('32', 265, 0, 1, 618968) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 265, 1, 2, 619010) The rishis of old tell us that the education of a student begins not with literature.
('32', 265, 1, 3, 619096) Do you know what the student in the Vedic times was called upon to do when he went to the teachers?
('32', 265, 1, 4, 619196) Not to pass any examination in letters.
('32', 265, 1, 5, 619236) He had to go before the rishis with samid khand—with a bundle of wood—in his hand.
('32', 265, 1, 6, 619319) What did that signify?
('32', 265, 1, 7, 619342) It signified purity of heart, sincerity of heart.

('32', 265, 1, 9, 619533) He was not to ask any questions; he was to take what the preceptor gave him.

('32', 265, 1, 13, 619961) It is obligatory upon every student to observe these fundamental maxims of life.
('32', 265, 1, 14, 620042) You know what the Mahabharata taught us about the value of truth.
('32', 265, 1, 15, 620108) He said, “Put truth in one scale and put your yajnas in another scale.
('32', 265, 1, 16, 620179) Still truth will weigh heavier.” There is nothing on this earth, the seer of Mahabharata tells us, that can possibly excel truth.
('32', 265, 1, 17, 620309) And he was right.
('32', 265, 1, 18, 620327) No matter how much in your little bit of experience you may find untruth work, no matter how you find in history also, fraud has given princes and potentates power and kingdoms, remember that these are only momentary changes.

('32', 265, 1, 21, 620763) If you only remember these sign posts, you will never go wrong and then you may add all the literature and all the science and everything.
('32', 265, 1, 22, 620902) But if you have not this foundation, then however beautiful the house may appear to be for the time being, remember it is only a house of cards, and a mere whiff of wind will bring it down.
('32', 265, 1, 23, 621092) Now I come to the questions.
('32', 265, 1, 24, 621121) You ask me what the spinning wheel can do.
('32', 265, 1, 25, 621164) Well, I think I have demonstrated to you what the spinning wheel can do.
('32', 265, 1, 26, 621237) The spinning wheel will do for India what it did when the rishis lived.

('32', 271, 2, 15, 635899) 170. PROBLEMS OF NON VIOLENCE
('32', 271, 3, 16, 635929) People keep asking me which acts may be termed violent and which non violent and, what is one’s duty at a particular time.
('32', 271, 3, 17, 636052) While some of these queries reveral the ignorance of the inquirers, others serve to bring out the difficult dilemmas involved.
('32', 271, 3, 18, 636179) A Punjabi gentleman has put a question the answer to which is worth giving here.
('32', 271, 3, 19, 636260) It is as follows : What should be done when tigers, wolves and other wild beasts come and carry away other animals or human beings?
('32', 271, 3, 20, 636392) Or, what should
('32', 272, 0, 1, 636408) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 273
('32', 272, 1, 2, 636454) be done about germs in water?
('32', 272, 1, 3, 636484) In my humble opinion the simple answer is that where there is danger from tigers, wolves and so on, then killing them becomes inevitable.
('32', 272, 1, 4, 636622) The germs that water contains must also be inevitably destroyed.
('32', 272, 1, 5, 636687) Violence which is inevitable does not therefore cease to be so and become non violence.
('32', 272, 1, 6, 636775) It has to be recognized as violence.
('32', 272, 1, 7, 636812) I have no doubt that it would be best if we could contrive to sruvive without destroying tigers, wolves, etc.
('32', 272, 1, 8, 636922) However, who could do so?Only he who is not afraid of these animals and can regard them as friends, he alone could do so.
('32', 272, 1, 9, 637044) Anyone who refrains from violence because he is afraid, is nevertheless guilty of violence.
('32', 272, 1, 10, 637136) The mouse is not non violent towards the cat.
('32', 272, 1, 11, 637182) At heart, he always has a feeling of violence towards the cat.
('32', 272, 1, 12, 637245) He cannot kill the latter because he is weak.
('32', 272, 1, 13, 637291) He alone has the power to practise the dharma of ahimsa who although fully capable of inflicting violence does not inflict it.
('32', 272, 1, 14, 637418) He alone practises the ahimsa dharma who voluntarily and with love refrains from inflicting violence on anyone.
('32', 272, 1, 15, 637530) Non violence implies love, compassion, forgiveness.
('32', 272, 1, 16, 637582) The Shastras describe these as the virtues of the brave.
('32', 272, 1, 17, 637639) This courage is not physical but mental.There have been instances of physically frail men having indulged in grave acts of violence with the help of others.
('32', 272, 1, 18, 637796) There have also been cases where those as physically strong as Yudhishthira 1 have granted pardon to such persons as king Virata 2. Hence, so long as one has not developed inner strength, one can never practise the dharma of ahimsa.
('32', 272, 1, 19, 638029) The non violence practised by the banias today does not deserve the name; one finds in it cruelty sometime and ignorance all the time.
('32', 272, 1, 20, 638164) It was because I know this weakness of ours that during the War I went all out to recruit soldiers in Kheda.
('32', 272, 1, 21, 638273) 3 And, it was for this very reason that I said at that time that perhaps the most brutal act of the British Government was to have disarmed and thus emasculated the Indian people.
('32', 272, 1, 22, 638453) I hold the same view even today.
('32', 272, 1, 23, 638486) If anyone afraid at heart cannot, while remaining unarmed, rid himself of that fear, he should certainly arm himself with a stick or an even more deadly weapon.
('32', 272, 1, 24, 638647) Ahimsa is a great vow; it is more difficult than walking on the
('32', 272, 2, 25, 638711) 1 The eldest of the five Pandava princes in the Mahabharata
('32', 272, 3, 26, 638771) 2 At whose court the Pandavas had lived in disguise 3 In 1918; vide “Appeal for Enlistment”, 22 6 1918 & “Appeal for Enlistment”, 22 7 1918.

('32', 273, 1, 2, 638954) edge of a sword.

('32', 274, 4, 7, 641635) 171. LOKAMANYA’S DEATH ANNIVERSARY
('32', 274, 5, 8, 641670) This death anniversary has come and gone.
('32', 274, 5, 9, 641712) It was celebrated here—in Calcutta—too.
('32', 274, 5, 10, 641752) I had to attend the celebrations.
('32', 274, 5, 11, 641786) Meetings were held at two places and I attended both.

('32', 274, 5, 15, 642073) In the present day meetings too we shall not invite the sons and relatives of the departed leaders to make speeches.
('32', 274, 5, 16, 642190) Both they and we should be ashamed if we did.

('32', 276, 1, 2, 645815) 172. TO CHAIRMEN OF MEETINGS The function of a judge is not to speak much.
('32', 276, 1, 3, 645890) It is to listen to good, bad or indifferent speeches.
('32', 276, 1, 4, 645944) Hence some of these gentlemen scrawl on the papers lying in front of them, others draw good pictures on them, while some others keep fidgeting with pieces of string.
('32', 276, 1, 5, 646110) The chairman of a meeting is in the same pitiable condition.
('32', 276, 1, 6, 646171) On the occasion of Moulvi Abdul Rasul’s death anniversary, I was given the honour of presiding over the meeting.
('32', 276, 1, 7, 646284) I had not known the said gentleman personally but, on inquiry, was informed that although he was a learned barrister, he was humble, a whole hearted supporter of swaraj and one who maintained his independence and self respect.
('32', 276, 1, 8, 646511) He regarded Hindu Muslim unity as a dharma and was a devotee of swadeshi.
('32', 276, 1, 9, 646585) How could I make myself worthy of presiding over a meeting on the death anniversary of such a gentleman?
('32', 276, 1, 10, 646690) My takli which shares whatever fate has in store for me, which is my goddess of peace, which is the source of relief to the poor and miserable in India— is always with me.
('32', 276, 1, 11, 646862) For fear of having it some day separated from me, through oversight, it is now included in the same case as my spectacles or, more precisely, the latter share the same case with the takli.
('32', 276, 1, 12, 647051) I cannot leave it behind any more than I can my spectacles.
('32', 276, 1, 13, 647111) I took it out and started spinning.
('32', 276, 1, 14, 647147) I was no longer worried whether the speeches were interesting or otherwise and I started giving an object lesson in swadeshi which was dear to Maulana Rasul.
('32', 276, 1, 15, 647305) At the same time as the speeches, my stock of slivers was coming to an end too.
('32', 276, 1, 16, 647385) The audience benefited in two ways, by listening to the words of the speakers and by looking at the message spelt out by my hands.
('32', 276, 1, 17, 647516) What else would I have to say even at the conclusion of the meeting?
('32', 276, 1, 18, 647585) My true speech took the form of action.
('32', 276, 1, 19, 647625) Hence, by way of explanation, I spoke on the spinning wheel.
('32', 276, 1, 20, 647686) Swadeshi was dear to Maulana Rasul but he had not fully understood its true implications.We had come to bestow the name of “swadeshi” on those musical instruments or clocks whose parts had all been imported but which had been assembled here.

('32', 276, 1, 22, 648026) This was the interpretation of the message given by my hands.
('32', 276, 1, 23, 648088) All chairmen cannot have this twofold benefit.
