('32', 277, 2, 4, 648458) 173. MY NOTES
('32', 277, 3, 5, 648472) BASANTI DEVI’S SPINNING WHEEL I take every opportunity of paying a visit to Shrimati Basanti Devi.
('32', 277, 3, 6, 648571) I have not yet succeeded in persuading her to go out daily for a walk.
('32', 277, 3, 7, 648642) Her courage knows no bounds.
('32', 277, 3, 8, 648671) However, she cannot shake off her mental agony.
('32', 277, 3, 9, 648719) She can take interest in nothing.
('32', 277, 3, 10, 648753) Often, late at night, she visits the cremation ground.
('32', 277, 3, 11, 648808) But that is not to forget her sorrow; it is rather to add to it.
('32', 277, 3, 12, 648873) There is only one thing in which she can keep herself occupied.
('32', 277, 3, 13, 648937) She plies the spinning wheel for two hours at a stretch and likes the work.
('32', 277, 3, 14, 649013) The famous European poet Goethe makes the heroine of his best play—Faust—hold a spinning wheel and sing the sweetest of songs.
('32', 277, 3, 15, 649140) Sir Prabhashanker Pattani described in his public speech the effect the spinning wheel had on him.
('32', 277, 3, 16, 649239) It is worth while remembering it on this occasion.
('32', 277, 3, 17, 649290) He suffers from insomnia.
('32', 277, 3, 18, 649316) Hence, even at midnight he plies the spinning wheel.
('32', 277, 3, 19, 649369) In this way, he overcomes various mental anxieties suffered during the day and then he can sleep peacefully.
('32', 277, 3, 20, 649478) The spinning wheel, in this manner, has been able to bring relief to a politician, one who is separated from a dear one and a widow.
('32', 277, 4, 21, 649611) PROPAGANDA FOR KHADI IN MAHA GUJARAT From some figures published by the Gujarat Khadi Mandal relating to propagation of khadi, I find that there are thirty khadi promoting institutions in Maha Gujarat.
('32', 277, 4, 22, 649813) The khadi produced in the last twelve months by 16 of these institutions out of yarn spun by its members themselves or of purchased hand spun yarn, amounted to more than 2,64,000 square yards.
('32', 277, 4, 23, 650006) The sale of khadi in that period amounted to Rs. 3,85,761 1 3. The net sale proceeds after deducting various charges, etc., are slightly smaller.
('32', 277, 4, 24, 650152) The figures include khadi that has been brought from outside— for example, Andhra.
('32', 277, 4, 25, 650235) This quantity of khadi cannot be regarded as the total quantity produced by Gujarat.
('32', 277, 4, 26, 650320) For instance, at some places in Kutch and Kathiawar, where the spinning wheel had never ceased working, the weaving of khadi goes on all the time.
('32', 277, 4, 27, 650467) Nevertheless, the above
('32', 278, 0, 1, 650491) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 279
('32', 278, 1, 2, 650537) quantity is far less than what we wish to achieve.
('32', 278, 1, 3, 650588) Besides these figures, the following is worth knowing: the number of spinning wheels, the number of persons who weave hand spun yarn, how many of these latter have taken to weaving again because of the swadeshi movement and how many of them are weavers who have recently learnt this art, how many of them are the so called untouchables and what is their monthly income, etc.
('32', 278, 1, 4, 650963) We should find out: the number of spinning wheels that are in use as a means of livelihood and the number of those which are being used as a sacrificial offering, what is the value of the khadi which was brought over from other parts; how many volunteer workers there are in these organizations and of these how many are paid workers and how many honorary; the amount of the average salary paid to a person and what is the maximum and minimum salary paid to a single individual.

('32', 281, 3, 7, 656745) 179. THE LION OF BENGAL
('32', 281, 4, 8, 656769) The death of Sir Surendranath Bannerjea removes from Indian political life one who has left upon it the deep impress of his own personality.
('32', 281, 4, 9, 656910) What though with new ideals and new hopes withing recent times he receded into the background?
('32', 281, 4, 10, 657005) Our present is the result of our past.
('32', 281, 4, 11, 657044) Ideals and aspirations of the present day would have been impossible without the invaluable work done by pioneers like Sir Surendra.
('32', 281, 4, 12, 657177) Time was when the student world idolized him, when his advice was considered indispensable in all national deliberations, and his eloquence held audiences spell bound.
('32', 281, 4, 13, 657345) It is impossible to recall the stirring events of the partition days in Bengal and not to think with gratitude and pride of Sir Surendranath’s matchless services in connection with it.
('32', 281, 4, 14, 657530) It was then that Sir Surendranath justly earned from his greatful countrymen the title of “Surrender not”.
('32', 281, 4, 15, 657637) During the blackest period of the time of partition, Sir Surendranath never wavered, never lost hope.
('32', 281, 4, 16, 657739) He threw himself into the agitation with all his might.
('32', 281, 4, 17, 657795) His enthusiasm infected the whole of Bengal.
('32', 281, 4, 18, 657840) His determination to unsettle the ‘settled fact’ was unshaken.
('32', 281, 4, 19, 657903) He gave us the necessary training in courage and resolution.
('32', 281, 4, 20, 657964) He taught us not to fear authority.
('32', 281, 4, 21, 658000) His work in the Education department was no less valuable than in the political.
('32', 281, 4, 22, 658081) Through the Ripon College thousands of young men came under his direct influence and received their liberal education.

('32', 282, 3, 13, 659523) KHADDAR WORKERS’ CENSUS The Secretary, A.I.K.B., had circularized all the provinces to send a list of their khaddar workers with particulars about their qualifications, work and remuneration.

('32', 283, 2, 7, 661526) NO LABOUR, NO MEAL Some time ago, I was taken to a magnificent mansion called the ‘Marble Palace’ in Calcutta.
('32', 283, 2, 8, 661637) It is richly furnished with some very expensive and some very beautiful paintings.
('32', 283, 2, 9, 661720) The owners feed, in the compound in front of the palace, all the beggars who choose to go there, and I am told that the number every day is several thousands.
('32', 283, 2, 10, 661879) This is no doubt a princely charity.
('32', 283, 2, 11, 661916) It does great credit to the benevolent spirit of the donors, but the incongruity of this ragged humanity feeding whilst the majestic palace is, as it were, mocking at their wretched condition does not seem to strike the donors at all.
('32', 283, 2, 12, 662151) Another such painful sight was witnessed by me on my visit to Suri, where the reception committee had arranged for feeding the beggars of the district.
('32', 283, 2, 13, 662303) At the Marble Palace, the crowd that besieged me passed through the line of baggars eating off their dusty leaves spread on the gound.
('32', 283, 2, 14, 662438) Some almost trampled over them.
('32', 283, 2, 15, 662470) It was by no means a pleasant spectacle.
('32', 283, 2, 16, 662511) In Suri it was a little more decently managed, for the crowd was not to pass through the line of baggars, but the motor car that drove me to my destination was slowly taken through the line of the beggars as they were eating.
('32', 283, 2, 17, 662737) I felt humiliated, more so to think that this was all done in my honour, because, as it was put to me by one of the friends there, I was ‘friend of the poor’.
('32', 283, 2, 18, 662896) My friendship for them must be a sorry affair if I could be satisfied with a large part of humanity being reduced to beggary.
('32', 283, 2, 19, 663022) Little did my friends know that my friendship for the paupers of India has made me hard hearted enough to contemplate their utter starvation with equanimity in preference to their utter reduction to beggary.
('32', 283, 2, 20, 663230) My ashimsa would not tolerate the idea of giving a free meal to a healthy person who has not worked for it in some honest way, and if I had the
('32', 284, 0, 1, 663374) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 285
('32', 284, 1, 2, 663420) power I would stop every Sadavarta where free meals are given.
('32', 284, 1, 3, 663483) It has degraded the nation and it has encouraged laziness, idleness, hypocrisy and even crime.
('32', 284, 1, 4, 663578) Such misplaced charity adds nothing to the wealth of the country, whether material or spiritual, and gives a false sense of meritoriousness to the donor.
('32', 284, 1, 5, 663732) How nice and wise it would be if the donor were to open institutions where they would give meals under healthy, clean surroundings to men and women who would work for them.
('32', 284, 1, 6, 663905) I personally think that the spinning wheel or any of the processes that cotton has to go through will be an ideal occupation.
('32', 284, 1, 7, 664031) But if they will not have that, they may choose any other work, only the rule should be: no labour, no meal.
('32', 284, 1, 8, 664140) Every city has its own difficult problem of beggars, a problem for which the monied men are responsible.
('32', 284, 1, 9, 664245) I know that it is eaiser to fling free meals in the faces of idlers, but much more difficult to organize an institution where honest work has to be done before meals are served.
('32', 284, 1, 10, 664423) From a pecuniary standpoint, in the initial stages at any rate, the cost of feeding people after taking work from them will be more than the cost of the present free kitchens.
('32', 284, 1, 11, 664599) But I am convinced that it will be cheaper in the long run, if we do not want to increase in geometrical progression the race of loafers which is fast overrunning this land.
('32', 284, 2, 12, 664773) “VARNASHRAMA” AND UNTOUCHABILITY A correspondent writes:
('32', 284, 3, 13, 664830) With reference to your comments on my letter on Varnashrama published in Young India of the 23rd April 1925, I fully appreciate the distinction between Varnashrama and untouchability and agree that there is
('32', 284, 4, 14, 665037) no sanction whatsoever for the latter in Hinduism.
('32', 284, 4, 15, 665088) But is it not clear that, if the principle of ‘division of work based on birth which you approve continues to be the basis of our social organization, the untouchables will be always with us?
('32', 284, 4, 16, 665280) What is more reasonable than to suppose that in tha cas those members of society who hereditarily perform such social duties as scavenging, corpse bearing and grave digging will continue to be looked upon as too unclean to be touched by the rest of the community?
('32', 284, 4, 17, 665544) In all other countries, scavengers,cobblers,barberswashermen, grave diggers, undertakers etc.,are not considered untouchable either as individuals or as a class for the simple reason that in those countries these occupations are not hereditary and any member of any of the classes can at any a soldier, trader, teacher, lawyer, politician or priest.
('32', 284, 4, 18, 665894) It seems to me, therefore, that the root of the evil of the untouchability so peculiar to our country lies in our peculiar social system exclusively based on the principle of heredity.
('32', 284, 4, 19, 666079) And it also seems to me that so
('32', 285, 0, 1, 666111) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 285, 1, 2, 666153) long as we adhere to that principle we cannot hope to get rid of untouchability.
('32', 285, 1, 3, 666234) It is just conceivable that, under the influence of mighty reformers like Ramanuja or under the stress of a strong political passion, its virulence may abate from time to time but the evil cannot be wholly eliminated.
('32', 285, 1, 4, 666452) I am afraid that every attempt to end untouchability without ending the caste idea will prove as futile as attempting to cut off a tree at its top.
('32', 285, 1, 5, 666600) The letter is very plausible and, unless the reformer takes care, the danger which the correspondent fears may become a stern reality.
('32', 285, 1, 6, 666735) There is, however, a clear confusion of thought in the argument.
('32', 285, 1, 7, 666800) Does untouchability in the case of a cobbler or scavenger attach to birth or to occupation?
('32', 285, 1, 8, 666892) If it attaches to birth, it is hideous and must be rooted out; if it attaches to occupation, it may be a sanitary rule of great importance.
('32', 285, 1, 9, 667032) It is of universal application.
('32', 285, 1, 10, 667064) A collier, whilst he is engaged in his work, is practically an untouchable.
('32', 285, 1, 11, 667140) He himself refuses to shake the hand extended to him and says, “I am too dirty”.
('32', 285, 1, 12, 667221) But his work finished, he takes his bath, changes his dress, and very properly mixes with the highest in the land.
('32', 285, 1, 13, 667336) Immediately, therefore, we remove the taint of birth, i.e., the idea of superiority and inferiority attaching to birth, we purify Varnashrama.
('32', 285, 1, 14, 667479) The scavenger’s children may remain scavengers without being or feeling degraded and they will be no more considered untouchables than Brahmins.
('32', 285, 1, 15, 667624) The fault does not, therefore, lie in recognizing the law of heredity and transmission of qualities from generation to generation, but it lies with the faulty conception of inequality.
('32', 285, 1, 16, 667809) Varnashrama, in my opinion, was not conceived in any narrow spirit.
('32', 285, 1, 17, 667877) On the contrary, it gave the labourer, the Sudra, the same status as the thinker, the Brahmin.
('32', 285, 1, 18, 667972) It provided for the accentuation of merit and elimination of demerit, and it transferred human ambition from the general worldly sphere to the permanent and the spiritual.
('32', 285, 1, 19, 668144) The aim of the Brahmin and the Sudra was common—moksha, or self realization—not realization of fame, riches and power.
('32', 285, 1, 20, 668263) Later on, this lofty conception of varnashrama became degraded and came to be identified with mere empty ceremonial and assumption of superiority by some and imposition fo degradation upon others.
('32', 285, 1, 21, 668460) This admission is not a demonstration of the weakness of Varnashrama, but of human nature which, if it has a tendency under certain circumstances to rise to the highest point, it has also a tendency under certain other circumstances to go down to the lowest.
('32', 285, 1, 22, 668719) What the reformer seeks to do is to end the curse of untouchability and to restore Varnashrama to its
('32', 286, 0, 1, 668821) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 287
('32', 286, 1, 2, 668867) proper place.
('32', 286, 1, 3, 668881) Whether Varnashrama thus transmuted will survive the reform or not remains to be seen.
('32', 286, 1, 4, 668968) It will surely depend upon the new Brahmin class that is imperceptibly coming into being, namely, those who are dedicating themselves, body, soul and mind, to service of Hinduism and the country.
('32', 286, 1, 5, 669164) If they have nothing of worldly ambition, it will be well with Hinduism, if they have, Hinduism, like any other ism, coming into the hands of ambitious men will perish.
('32', 286, 1, 6, 669333) But I have an immutable faith in the capacity of Hinduism to purge itself of all impurities from time to time.
('32', 286, 1, 7, 669444) I do not think that that capacity is now exhausted.
('32', 286, 2, 8, 669496) ADVICE FROM JAPAN Some time during last months two Japanese friends came to me, engaged me in a pleasant conversation and left with me the following document:

('32', 290, 3, 4, 679094) 182. SOME STRIKING FACTS
('32', 290, 4, 5, 679119) The following report received from the Secretary of the All India Khaddar Board will be read with the greatest interest: 1
('32', 290, 5, 6, 679242) The report does not only show us how much work has been possible in a year’s time amongst the villagers through the simple instrumentality of the spinning population.
('32', 290, 5, 7, 679409) But what is more striking is a comparison between the figures regarding the earnings from hand spinning and from agriculture.
('32', 290, 5, 8, 679535) These figures dispel the idea once for all about the insignificance of the wages received from hand spinning by professional spinners.
('32', 290, 5, 9, 679670) The lowest income from the charkha is 14% of the other income, but in some individual families the percentage is as high as 66. The reader will not fail to note too how other reforms naturally come in side by side with spinning.
('32', 290, 5, 10, 679899) The foregoing report refers to temperance work.
('32', 290, 5, 11, 679947) In many places in Bengal I have noticed that those who are interested in introducing spinning amongst the villagers took up medical relief as a matter of course and, if they do not touch the other departments of life in the villages, it is not because of want of will, but because the workers are too few, and the villagers too conservative to respond merely for the asking.
('32', 290, 5, 12, 680322) What is true of the villages 2 examined in Tamil Nadu is equally true of many villages in Bengal.
('32', 290, 5, 13, 680420) My enquiries have led to the discovery that thousands of cultivators make no more than Rs. 7 to 8 per month during the year.
('32', 290, 5, 14, 680545) An addition of Rs. 2/ out of spinning done only by the family members is a very substantial relief for these poor cultivators.

('32', 292, 3, 21, 685048) 185. LETTER TO SAMBAMURTI
('32', 292, 4, 22, 685074) 148, RUSSA ROAD, August 15, 1925
('32', 292, 5, 23, 685107) DEAR FRIEND, My unexpectedly long stay in Bengal has upset all my arrangements.
('32', 292, 5, 24, 685187) Up to the end of October I am booked in Bihar.
('32', 293, 0, 1, 685234) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 293, 1, 2, 685276) will then remain the following provinces which I was expected to visit before the end of the year.
('32', 293, 1, 3, 685375) They are Andhra, Tamilnad, Kerala, Karnatak, C.P. Marathi, C.P. Hindi and Maharashtra.
('32', 293, 1, 4, 685462) It is impossible to visit all these provinces in less than two months.
('32', 293, 1, 5, 685533) Unless, therefore, it is absolutely necessary, I would ask you to disengage me from the projected visit to your province.
('32', 293, 1, 6, 685655) If, however, you consider that it is absolutely necessary for me to visit your province, please let me know how long you will want me.
('32', 293, 1, 7, 685790) If more provinces require my presence than it is possible for me to visit during the time available, I propose to draw lots.
('32', 293, 1, 8, 685915) I would urge you, therefore, to waive the visit if it is at all possible.
('32', 293, 1, 9, 685989) I am in Calcutta up to the 31st instant.
('32', 293, 1, 10, 686030) I would like you to let me have your reply by letter or telegram before that date.
('32', 293, 1, 11, 686113) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI SJT.
('32', 293, 1, 12, 686148) SAMBAMURTI PRESIDENT, P.C.C. RAJAHMUNDRY

('32', 293, 3, 14, 686219) 186. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, CALCUTTA 1
('32', 293, 4, 15, 686261) August 15, 1925
('32', 293, 5, 16, 686277) With profound feelings of sorrow, this meeting of the citizens of Calcutta, representative of all parties and all communities, desires to place on record its deep and abiding sense of the loss sustained by the country by the demise of Sir Surendranath Banerjea, Kt., the high priest of Indian nationalism.
('32', 293, 5, 17, 686583) His undaunted and unremitting labours for the last 50 years in the service of the motherland, fired with the warmth of apostolic fervour, constitute an unparalleled record of noble endeavour and high achievement which will ever remain enshrined in the grateful recollections of his countrymen and be a source of unfailing inspiration to the nation he served.
('32', 293, 5, 18, 686942) This meeting tenders its respectful homage to his adored memory, and conveys its deep sympathy to the members of the bereaved family in their great loss.
('32', 293, 6, 19, 687096) Mahatmaji said that he regarded it as a privilege to be able to attend the
('32', 293, 7, 20, 687171) 1 The meeting was held at the Town Hall to pay homage to the late Sir Surendranath Banerjea.
('32', 294, 0, 1, 687264) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 295
('32', 294, 1, 2, 687310) meeting—a privilege to be able to move the resolution.
('32', 294, 1, 3, 687365) He knew that they did not want him to make a long speech in praise of the old patriot.
('32', 294, 1, 4, 687452) The resolution itself summed up what Sir Surendranath was to them and what he meant to the nation.
('32', 294, 1, 5, 687551) Of late, from many a platform, he had been obliged to warn them against being satisfied with mere lip praise.
('32', 294, 1, 6, 687661) At one meeting he had said: “Let us not be bards.” He had the honour of making the acquaintance of and paying his respect to the late Sir Surendranath in 1896, when he came from South Africa to pay a temporary visit.
('32', 294, 1, 7, 687878) Long before that he had heard about his matchless oratory.
('32', 294, 1, 8, 687937) When the speaker approached the great leader in 1896, as a young man, he then dimly realized what he was.
('32', 294, 1, 9, 688043) He had the pleasure of renewing that acquaintance in 1901. He was able, if he might say so in all humility and reverence, to study him at close quarters.
('32', 294, 1, 10, 688197) He watched him at the Subjects Committee; he watched him haranguing huge crowds that used a hang upon him during those days.
('32', 294, 1, 11, 688322) The speaker saw then how indispensable his presence was considered at every meeting, whether it was a mass meeting or whether it was a private conference.
('32', 294, 1, 12, 688477) He was needed for every national deliberation and he was needed in order to fire the enthusiasm of his countrymen.
('32', 294, 1, 13, 688592) Whilst he was in South Africa, reading the proceedings of one of the National Congress sessions, he read that as soon as Sir Surendranath rose and made an appeal to the audience for money, ornaments were flung by ladies into his lap or on his table.
('32', 294, 1, 14, 688842) Monied men threw notes on the table.
('32', 294, 1, 15, 688879) Many promises were forthcoming.
('32', 294, 1, 16, 688911) Whenever money was wanted, Sir Surendranath was also wanted and so throughout his observations, he understood what Sir Surendranath meant to Bengal and what he meant to India.
('32', 294, 1, 17, 689087) Let us, the present generation, not forget the services of those heroes of the nation—services they rendered before many of us were born.
('32', 294, 1, 18, 689225) It makes not the slightest difference that we may not see eye to eye with such illustrious men.
('32', 294, 1, 19, 689321) If they had not laid the foundation, we would not have been able to build; if they had not laid the foundation, we would not have been able to do what we are doing today.
('32', 294, 1, 20, 689492) They set in those days an example when others were not forthcoming—an example in courage, an example in sacrifice, an example in diplomacy—not the diplomacy of the mean sort which is so much in vogue today.
('32', 294, 1, 21, 689699) I am talking of that diplomacy which every nation requires, which every individual requires.
('32', 294, 1, 22, 689792) Let us think of his services of those days, let us treasure the memory of the great deeds wrought by men like Sir Surendranath whom the nation in its admiration called ‘Surrender not’.
('32', 294, 1, 23, 689977) And is it not true?
('32', 294, 1, 24, 689997) Was not the title deserved by him during those dark but brilliant days of Partition?
('32', 294, 1, 25, 690082) Was he not able, through the assistance of Bengal behind him and the whole of India, to unsettle the ‘settled fact’?
('32', 294, 1, 26, 690199) Was he not able to do many things of which we, the present generation, have every reason to be proud?
('32', 295, 0, 1, 690301) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 295, 1, 2, 690343) us not, therefore, in our better wisdom, which we so impute to ourselves, forget the great services of the great heroes.
('32', 295, 1, 3, 690464) Let us shed, therefore, tears over the ashes of Sir Surendranath.
('32', 295, 1, 4, 690530) But let us do a little better.
('32', 295, 1, 5, 690561) Let us follow some of the things which it is given to every one of us today.
('32', 295, 1, 6, 690638) We may not have his eloquence, probably not one of us has his great memory, but every one of us can imitate his love of the land, every one of us can imitate his unfailing regularity.
('32', 295, 1, 7, 690822) Until the other day, when I had the honour of waiting upon him at Barrackpore, he told me that the secret of his health and the secret of his vitality was his unfailing regularity.
('32', 295, 1, 8, 691003) I remember in 1901, when an important meeting was going on, the meeting could not be finished.
('32', 295, 1, 9, 691098) Sir Surendranath apologized and said, “Gentlemen, I must catch my last train for Barrackpore.” Sir Surendranath could not wait for the meeting.
('32', 295, 1, 10, 691242) The meeting had to be postponed for Sir Surendranath.
('32', 295, 1, 11, 691296) What did he do ?
('32', 295, 1, 12, 691313) He kept his time not from selfish motives, but he did so for the sake of the nation he loved so much.
('32', 295, 1, 13, 691415) Let us, therefore, remember these constructive virtues.
('32', 295, 1, 14, 691471) What has he not done for the education of Bengal!
('32', 295, 1, 15, 691521) Was he not at one time the idol of young men of Bengal?
('32', 295, 1, 16, 691577) Let us imitate him in the love of the motherland; every one of us, man, woman or child, all of us can imitate.
('32', 295, 1, 17, 691688) There are many more things, but one thing I must not omit because it is a treasured memory.
('32', 295, 1, 18, 691780) When I was with him at Barrackpore, he said to me, “I am going to live till 91 years.
('32', 295, 1, 19, 691866) I am now preparing the second edition of my reminiscences.
('32', 295, 1, 20, 691925) I am going to give many a battle to the Government, many a battle to the Swarajists.
('32', 295, 1, 21, 692010) I shall be engaged in all these things.
('32', 295, 1, 22, 692050) But do you know what is the nearest to my heart?”“I don’t know,” said I.“I belong,” replied Sir Surendranath, “to the school of Vidyasagar.
('32', 295, 1, 23, 692190) You will find it written in the first page of my book.
('32', 295, 1, 24, 692245) If I had to rewrite the whole of my life, what do you think I would do?
('32', 295, 1, 25, 692317) I would serve the neglected widow.
('32', 295, 1, 26, 692352) I would repair the fortunes of many a broken home.
('32', 295, 1, 27, 692403) I cannot bear the sight of innocent children having widowhood enforced upon them.” Let the young men of Bengal remember their little innocent sisters.
('32', 295, 1, 28, 692554) I hear such cases from every side of Bengal.

('32', 295, 1, 33, 692863) The political freedom of this country involves our contract with

('32', 296, 1, 2, 692974) every department of life.
('32', 296, 1, 3, 693000) You may not get political freedom but cannot wait for social amelioration.
('32', 296, 1, 4, 693075) If you will have little girls marrying and becoming mothers, we shall have to live as a race of pigmies.
('32', 296, 1, 5, 693180) No wonder, then, if we are not able to think clearly for ourselves, no wonder, then, if in the words of Lord Willingdon, we will not say “yes” when we should say “yes”and “no” when we mean “no”.

('32', 300, 2, 21, 703985) 189. MY NOTES
('32', 300, 3, 22, 703999) VISIT TO JAMSHEDPUR Jamshedpur was originally called Sakchi.
('32', 300, 3, 23, 704060) It is in the province of Bihar.
('32', 300, 3, 24, 704092) Born of the vision of Jamshedji Tata it has become one of the largest iron producers in the world.
('32', 300, 3, 25, 704191) This place was formerly an unpopulated forest; now 1,06,000 people live there.
('32', 300, 3, 26, 704270) Among them there are people of all communities and faiths—Bengalis, Biharis, Sikhs, Kabulis, Parsis and Christians.
('32', 300, 3, 27, 704386) There are several factories there.
('32', 300, 3, 28, 704421) This township owes a debt of gratitude to the courage of Jamshedji Tata.
('32', 300, 3, 29, 704494) Hence the then Governor or Viceroy named it Jamshedpur.
('32', 300, 3, 30, 704550) It is also called Tatanagar by the labourers.
('32', 300, 3, 31, 704596) I had planned to see this factory many years ago.
('32', 300, 3, 32, 704646) One thing

('32', 304, 5, 7, 711110) 194. SPEECH AT ROTARY CLUB 3
('32', 304, 6, 8, 711139) CALCUTTA, August 18, 1925
('32', 304, 7, 9, 711165) After thanking the Rotarians for the delicate courtesy that they had extended to him in making their luncheon a Bengali widow’s luncheon—a mere potato and cabbage luncheon—and for inviting him to speak to them on a subject which was perhaps as uninteresting as the menu spread before them, Mr. Gandhi said: “Charkha” is not an inviting word though I see that your magazine is called Charkha.
('32', 304, 7, 10, 711557) I did not know that this was an Indian word you had copied.That means charkha—a wheel.
('32', 304, 7, 11, 711644) I have also come to represent the potency of the wheel, the spinning wheel or the spindle I hold in my hand (showing a little instrument), and I have so often humorously said to my mill owning friends that I propose to compete with them with this little spindle.
('32', 304, 7, 12, 711907) But beyond that humour it has a seriousness all its own.
('32', 304, 7, 13, 711964) First of all, as to its economic value.
('32', 304, 7, 14, 712004) You know that the surface of India is 1,900 miles long from north to south and 1,500 milesbroad from east to west and it includes 700,000 villages over this vast surface.
('32', 304, 7, 15, 712175) The majority of the villages are not served by any railway system at all.
('32', 304, 7, 16, 712249) There was a time in India when the spinning wheel was a supplementary occupation of this vast agricultural population.The present agricultural population of India as the Government statistics
('32', 304, 8, 17, 712441) 1 The reference seems to be to Gandhiji’s treatment of the Phoenix Settlement and the Tolstoy Farm in the chapters relating to them in the History, of Satyagaraha in South Africa in Gujarati which was serially published in Navajivan from April 13, 1924 onwards.
('32', 304, 8, 18, 712703) 2 J. P. Bhansali 3 Gandhiji was the chief guest and speaker at the Rotarians’ meeting held in the Grand Hotel.

('32', 305, 1, 2, 712856) tell us is nothing less than 85 per cent.The Government statistics also tell us that this 85 per cent of the population of India has at least four months in the year absolutely idle.
('32', 305, 1, 3, 713039) Some of them who are in the know tell me that in Bengal there are agriculturists who have nothing to do for six months in the year.
('32', 305, 1, 4, 713171) You can imagine what will happen to a man who takes four months’ or six months’ holiday without pay.
('32', 305, 1, 5, 713272) Not even the Viceroy of India can afford that vacation.
('32', 305, 1, 6, 713328) Besinessmen, I think, even though they may be millionaries never give themselves all that holiday and do no business.
('32', 305, 1, 7, 713446) Much less can this vast agricultural population which the historian of India, the late Sir William Hunter, told us 30 years ago was living a hand to mouth existence.
('32', 305, 1, 8, 713612) He said that one tenth of the population of India was living on one meal only per day and that meal consisted of dry bread and a pinch of dirty salt.
('32', 305, 1, 9, 713762) They did not know what milk or ghee was.
('32', 305, 1, 10, 713803) Nor did they get any vegetables.
('32', 305, 1, 11, 713836) As you know, famine is chronic in India, It is a money famine.
('32', 305, 1, 12, 713899) I suggest to you, as business people, that for such people a supplementary occupation is an absolute necessity, and if it is an absolute necessity it must fulfil certain conditions to apply to this vast mass of mankind.
('32', 305, 1, 13, 714119) It must, therefore, be a universal occupation.
('32', 305, 1, 14, 714166) It must be an occupation whose products can be easily taken over by the whole of the population.
('32', 305, 1, 15, 714263) Therefore it will be idle to suggest that they should make articles of luxury.
('32', 305, 1, 16, 714342) It must be one that they could easily learn.If it requires a good deal of skill or if the instrument of production requires a great manufacturing skill or if it was expensive, it would not answer.
('32', 305, 2, 17, 714539) Showing a small spindle in his hand Mr.Gandhi said that that little simple device could produce 50 yards of yarn per hour.
('32', 305, 2, 18, 714662) A spinning wheel on an average could give 400 yards per hour.
('32', 305, 2, 19, 714724) The highest output of a spinning wheel was 850 yards per hour.
('32', 305, 2, 20, 714787) No mill spindle had yet produced 850 yards of 10 counts per hour.
('32', 305, 2, 21, 714853) That could only be done by the human hand.
('32', 305, 2, 22, 714896) What the mill could do was that thousands of spindles could be worked by a few women with a great power behind it.
('32', 305, 2, 23, 715011) It was good, it had its place.He did not want to displace the machinery from its proper place.
('32', 305, 2, 24, 715106) He ventured to suggest that for these few millions of peasantry of India there was no other cottage occupation of that universal character as the spinning wheel.
('32', 305, 2, 25, 715268) Any body going to the villages would find some remnants of spinning wheel.
('32', 305, 2, 26, 715343) Women throughout the length and breadth of India were taking it up without the slightest difficulty because they were born to it.
('32', 305, 2, 27, 715473) They knew what it was.
('32', 305, 2, 28, 715496) But one other condition had to be fulfilled.
('32', 305, 2, 29, 715541) Who would use the product of that wheel?
('32', 305, 2, 30, 715582) Naturally the
('32', 306, 0, 1, 715596) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 307
('32', 306, 1, 2, 715642) people of India, as they did 200 or even 100 years ago, when every Indian was clothed in garments spun by Indian women and woven by Indian weavers.
('32', 306, 1, 3, 715790) The weaving industry had not died out entirely but the spinning industry had all died out and there was a reason for it.
('32', 306, 1, 4, 715911) The spinning industry could not support a large body of people by itself.
('32', 306, 1, 5, 715985) It could only be a supplementary industry and therefore there was not that resistance to its destruction which the weaving industry offered, for the simple reason that the weavers lived purely upon weaving as their sole occupation whearas the peasantry had their agriculture as the backbone.
('32', 306, 1, 6, 716277) India imported Rs. 60 crore worth of foreign yarn and adding a similar quantity to it produced by local mills, they could easily imagine what it meant to a poor country like India whose average income, according to Lord Curzon, was in his time Rs. 30 to 33 per year.
('32', 306, 1, 7, 716544) The late Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji calculated the average annual income to be Rs. 26.The late Mr. R.C. Dutt challenged Lord Curzon’s figure, and Mr.Gandhi thought that it was successfully proved that Mr. Dadabhai’s figure was more reliable and more correct.
('32', 306, 1, 8, 716797) Even taking Lord Curzon’s figure what did it signify?
('32', 306, 1, 9, 716851) Less than Rs. 3 a month.
('32', 306, 1, 10, 716876) If the spinning wheel could add even Rs. 5 or Rs. 6 per year to their income, was it not a fortune to them ?
('32', 306, 1, 11, 716985) It was, said Mr.Gandhi.
('32', 306, 1, 12, 717009) That was the economic aspect of the spinning wheel.
('32', 306, 1, 13, 717061) That would solve largely the problem of the economic distress.
('32', 306, 1, 14, 717124) It would solve the problem of famine.
('32', 306, 1, 15, 717162) It would solve the problem of poverty.
('32', 306, 1, 16, 717201) People need not live on charity which must be shameful to the giver as well as to the taker who had his limbs unimpaired.
('32', 306, 2, 17, 717323) As for the spiritual aspect of the charkha, Mr. Gandhi said that it flowed naturally from the former.
('32', 306, 2, 18, 717425) If they must industrialize India in the English and American fashion by covering it with factories, they could do with a small population but could not deal with a vast population in a summary fashion.
('32', 306, 2, 19, 717627) He asked : Do you want the people to congregate in boxes where men and women are huddled together in a manner which I could not picture to you.
('32', 306, 2, 20, 717771) I save them from such an immorality by giving them this occupation.
('32', 306, 2, 21, 717839) There is another spiritual aspect about it.
('32', 306, 2, 22, 717883) A man is often known by his occupation.
('32', 306, 2, 23, 717923) There is a great deal of truth in the proverb ‘When Adam delved and Eve span, who was then the gentleman?’ That was the time when men were really contented and there was real brotherhood.
('32', 306, 3, 24, 718111) If the mills made superfluous additions to the treasures of the already rich, the spinning wheel was certainly spiritually superior to it inasmuch as it filled the pockets not of those who were already rich but of the starving and the needy millions.
('32', 306, 4, 25, 718362) 1 The paragraph that follows is taken from Mahadev Desai’s report in Young India, 27 8 1925.
('32', 307, 0, 1, 718455) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 307, 1, 2, 718497) I read with deep interest Drummond’s book Natural Law in the Spiritual World long ago, and I am sure that if I had that writer’s facile pen, I would demonstrate even better that there is a spiritual law in the natural world.
('32', 307, 2, 3, 718722) He had read books by sane men seriously advocating electrocution to end the race of the starving and the diseased and the infirm.
('32', 307, 2, 4, 718852) It may be an eminently economical remedy, but it was not a human or a spiritual remedy.
('32', 307, 2, 5, 718940) In the spinning wheel he was offering to his countrymen a spiritual remedy, a remedy with which they had been familiar for ages, and a remedy which if seriously tried would save them from the hideous consequences that town and factory life involved.
('32', 307, 2, 6, 719190) And need he say anything as to the spiritual reaction on the mind, of the simple instrument?
('32', 307, 2, 7, 719283) Well so many who had tried it bore witness to the fact that it brought peace to the distracted and troubled mind, and the genius of Goethe had woven that effect into song for ages, when he represented Margaret spinning away at the wheel and through its inspiration spinning out of her lips a song as perfect as the yarn from the wheel.
('32', 307, 2, 8, 719619) He was not an enemy of inventions, said he, clinching the argument, but as matter misplaced was dirt, all inventions misplaced were abominations, to be shunned if they did not add to human dignity and peace.
('32', 307, 3, 9, 719827) Questions were invited.
('32', 307, 3, 10, 719851) Mr. A. T. Weston said that he gathered from Mr. Gandhi’s observations that weaving was also necessary besides spinning.Why should not then mill made yarn be used for weaving on a large scale?
('32', 307, 3, 11, 720043) Mr. Gandhi replied that everyone of the millions of India could spin during their spare time but they could not weave in a similar manner.
('32', 307, 3, 12, 720182) That was why he had placed the spinning wheel in the forefront.
('32', 307, 4, 13, 720246) Gandhiji had studiously avoided the political aspect of the spinning wheel throughout his discourse, but Dr. Sarbadhikari, a Rotarian, who spoke last compelled him to do so.
('32', 307, 4, 14, 720420) ‘If the spinning wheel’, he asked in effect, ‘had played such a large part in Hindu ritual and was a living thing in the Bengali home, how had it fallen into disuse?
('32', 307, 4, 15, 720586) Is it not the cost of the product of the wheel which had driven it out?’ That, said Gandhiji, involved the spiritual aspect too.
('32', 307, 4, 16, 720715) If he had the authority of Queen Elizabeth he would deal with the question just as she had done.
('32', 307, 4, 17, 720812) She made it criminal for her people to use Holland lace,and imported workmen from abroad to teach the people how to make lace, and interdicted the use of lace until then.
('32', 307, 4, 18, 720983) He was not an out and out free trader and he would if he could effectively stop all import of foreign cloth by heavy import duties.
('32', 307, 4, 19, 721115) He said warming up: And you have asked how the industry had died.
('32', 307, 4, 20, 721181) Well it is a painful answer, but I must give it.
('32', 307, 4, 21, 721230) It was made to die.

('32', 308, 1, 3, 721490) It would make the blood of every honest man and women boil to turn over the pages written not by Indians but by the servants of the Company.

('32', 312, 2, 4, 730000) 199. PUBLIC FUNDS I have critics who see nothing but flaws in everything I say or do.

('32', 315, 0, 1, 737333) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 315, 1, 2, 737375) 200. FOR CHRISTIAN INDIANS [The other day 1 I was privileged to address what was to be a meeting of Christian Indians predominantly, but what turned out to be a meeting of European Christians predominantly.
('32', 315, 1, 3, 737582) My address, therefore, took naturally a different shape from what it was to be.
('32', 315, 1, 4, 737662) Nevertheless, I give below a brief summary of portions of the address, as, in my opinion, it is of interest to know what one who has lived in their midst, amid various scenes and surroundings, has thought about and felt for them.
('32', 315, 1, 5, 737892) M. K. G.] When I was a youth, I remember a Hindu having become a convert to Christianity.
('32', 315, 1, 6, 737982) The whole town understood that the initiation took the shape of this well bred Hindu partaking of beef and brandy in the name of Jesus Christ and discarding his national costume.
('32', 315, 1, 7, 738161) I learnt in later years, that such a convert, as so many of my missionary friends put it, came to a life of freedom out of a life of bondage, to a life of plenty out of one of penury.
('32', 315, 1, 8, 738345) As I wander about throughout the length and breadth of India I see many Christian Indians almost ashamed of their birth, certainly of their ancestral religion, and of their ancestral dress.
('32', 315, 1, 9, 738535) The aping of Europeans on the part of Anglo Indians is bad enough, but the aping of them by Indian converts is a violence done to their country and, shall I say, even to their new religion.
('32', 315, 1, 10, 738725) There is a verse in the New Testament to bid Christians avoid meat if it would offend their neighbours.
('32', 315, 1, 11, 738829) Meat here, I presume, includes drink and dress.
('32', 315, 1, 12, 738877) I can appreciate uncompromising avoidance of all that is evil in the old, but where there is not only no question of anything evil but where an ancient practice may be even desirable, it would be a crime to part with it when one knows for certain that the giving up would deeply hurt relatives and friends.Conversion must not mean denationalization.
('32', 315, 1, 13, 739227) Conversion should mean a definite giving up of the evil of the old, adoption of all the good of the new and a scrupulous avoidance of everything evil in the new.
('32', 315, 1, 14, 739389) Conversion, therefore, should mean a life of greater dedication to one’s own country, greater surrender to God, greater self purification.
('32', 315, 1, 15, 739528) Years ago I met the late Kali Charan Banerjee.
('32', 315, 1, 16, 739575) Had I not known before I went there that he was a Christian, I should certainly not have noticed from the appearance of his home that he was one.
('32', 315, 1, 17, 739721) It was no different from an ordinary modern Hindu home,—simple and meagre in furniture.
('32', 315, 2, 18, 739809) 1 Vide “Speech at Meeting of Christians”, 4 8 1925.
('32', 316, 0, 1, 739861) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 317
('32', 316, 1, 2, 739907) The great man was dressed like an ordinary un European and Hindu Bengali.
('32', 316, 1, 3, 739981) I know that there is a marvellous change coming over Christian Indians.
('32', 316, 1, 4, 740053) There is on the part of a large number of them a longing to revert to original simplicity, a longing to belong to the nation and to serve it, but the process is too slow.
('32', 316, 1, 5, 740224) There need be no waiting.
('32', 316, 1, 6, 740250) It requires not much effort, but I was told, and even as I write, I have a letter from a Christian Indian before me telling me that he and his friends find it difficult to make the change, because of the opposition of their superiors.
('32', 316, 1, 7, 740485) Some of them tell me that they are even jealously watched, and any movement on their part to identify themselves with national movements is strongly condemned.
('32', 316, 1, 8, 740645) The late Principal Rudra and I used often to discuss this evil tendency.
('32', 316, 1, 9, 740718) I well remember how he used to deplore it.
('32', 316, 1, 10, 740761) I am offering a tribute to the memory of a dead friend when I inform the reader that he used often to express his grief that it was too late in life for him to change some of the unnecessary European habits to which he was brought up.
('32', 316, 1, 11, 740996) Is it not truely deplorable that many Christian Indians discard their own mother tongue, bring up their children only to speak in English?
('32', 316, 1, 12, 741135) Do they not thereby completely cut themselves adrift from the nation in whose midst they have to live?
('32', 316, 1, 13, 741238) But they may answer in self defence that many Hindu and even Mussalmans have become denationalized.
('32', 316, 1, 14, 741338) The tu quoque argument serves no useful purpose.
('32', 316, 1, 15, 741387) I am writing not as a critic but as a friend who has enjoyed for the past thirty years the closest intimacy with hundreds of Christian Indians.
('32', 316, 1, 16, 741531) I want my missionary friends and Christian Indians to reciprocate the spirit in which these lines are written.
('32', 316, 1, 17, 741642) I write in the name and for the sake of heart unity which I want to see established among the people of this land professing different faiths.
('32', 316, 1, 18, 741785) In nature there is a fundamental unity running through all the diversity we see about us.
('32', 316, 1, 19, 741875) Religions are no exception to the natural law.
('32', 316, 1, 20, 741922) They are given to mankind so as to accelerate the process of realization of fundamental unity.
('32', 316, 2, 21, 742017) Young India, 20 8 1925
('32', 316, 3, 22, 742040) 201. NOTES
('32', 316, 4, 23, 742051) A DECLARATION ON SWARAJ An esteemed correspondent has sent me a letter which is so well reasoned and otherwise able that, in spite of my inability to agree with all that is said in it, I should like to publish it.
('32', 316, 4, 24, 742265) But the correspondent
('32', 317, 0, 1, 742287) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 317, 1, 2, 742329) has himself advanced very cogent reasons for non publication of the major, and the most interesting, part of his letter.
('32', 317, 1, 3, 742450) The burden of the letter is to prove to me that my insistence on Hindu Muslim unity and the manner of achieving it, have really resulted, at least for the time being, in an ever growing estrangement.
('32', 317, 1, 4, 742650) He then advises me not to harp upon it any longer and then ends the letter thus:
('32', 317, 2, 5, 742731) Now that you know the unexpected results of these acts of commission and omission on your part, let me request you to declare in the most public and unmistakable way that the swaraj you are immediately aiming at for your country is a (modern) democratic raj or government, that the State shall not take note of men’s religious beliefs, that there shall be ‘no compulsion in religion’, that no one shall be debarred from doing anything or going anywhere merely because of his or her birth (as an ‘untouchable’, ‘unapproachable’, or ‘unseeable’, or ‘unhearable’), and that equality of opportunity to all shall be the motto of the State, including, as a necessary corollary, the policy of special encouragement to the poor and the backward
('32', 317, 3, 6, 743468) of all creeds and communities in accordance with their needs and in proportion to their poverty and backwardness the manner and the degree of the encouragement to be judged on the merits of each individual case and not
('32', 317, 4, 7, 743687) by the accident of birth or the fact of creed alone or at all, or, in short, that a ‘free field’ to every citizen in his or her life—and no favour nor handicap by reason of birth or creed—shall be the immutable rule for the State in every department to follow.
('32', 317, 5, 8, 743948) Secure the acceptance of these principles by the chief communal leaders and you shall have more than half won the battle of unity among the children of Madar i Hind.
('32', 317, 5, 9, 744114) But as regards the declaration I have mentioned, you owe it
('32', 317, 6, 10, 744174) to yourself and to your deluded Hindu and Muslim fellow countrymen.
('32', 317, 6, 11, 744242) It would be well if you got the Brothers Ali, too, to make such a declaration on behalf of the Khilafatists.
('32', 317, 6, 12, 744351) I have anticipated the advice of the correspondent about Hindu Muslim unity.
('32', 317, 6, 13, 744428) I agree that it will do no good for me to be speaking upon it, as I used to.
('32', 317, 6, 14, 744505) I am satisfied with letting my action speak for itself.
('32', 317, 6, 15, 744561) So far as the declaration about swaraj is concerned, I accept the advice in full and ask the reader to regard the declaration suggested by the correspondent as my own.
('32', 317, 7, 16, 744729) A TRAVELLING CHARKHA
('32', 317, 8, 17, 744750) The travelling wheel of the Khadi Pratishthan has solved the question of providing an efficient travelling spinning wheel.
('32', 317, 8, 18, 744873) I have been using one for the last three months with the greatest satisfaction.
('32', 318, 0, 1, 744953) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 319
('32', 318, 1, 2, 744999) It yields as much to me as the ordinary charkha.
('32', 318, 1, 3, 745048) I therefore use the same thing, whether at home or travelling.
('32', 318, 1, 4, 745111) I have been able to use it in a moving train also.
('32', 318, 1, 5, 745162) It is lighter than the ordinary wheel, and the principle of construction is the same.
('32', 318, 1, 6, 745248) Success has been attained by making the wheel collapsible.
('32', 318, 1, 7, 745307) When it is put away, it is an elegant and handy little box, capable of being carried without any effort.
('32', 318, 1, 8, 745412) Its dimensions when packed up are 16”x6”x6” and the weight is 7 lb.
('32', 318, 1, 9, 745480) The wheel is made of steel wires.
('32', 318, 1, 10, 745514) It takes no more than two to three minutes to put it up, and no more to pack it up.
('32', 318, 1, 11, 745598) By suspending the spindle inside the uprights, rather than the outside, the motion becomes perfectly noiseless and easier.
('32', 318, 1, 12, 745721) There is also less danger of the spindle being bent.
('32', 318, 1, 13, 745774) Holders are made of pieces of gut collected out of the breakage of carding guts and, therefore, cost nothing.
('32', 318, 1, 14, 745884) The guts are held in position by wedges being driven from outside into the receiving poles made in the uprights.The box can accommodate an oil can, simple tools, slivers, etc.The price of this wheel is Rs. 15. Satis Babu informs me that it is possible for him to supply a few only of these charkhas at a time.
('32', 318, 1, 15, 746194) I bring it to the notice of the readers only for the sake of those who would not suspend their spinning while travelling.

('32', 320, 13, 22, 749192) Party, Mr. Gandhi who returned to Calcutta from Cuttack on Friday morning was interviewed by a representative of The Englishman.

('32', 320, 14, 24, 749349) would enlighten the public as to Dr. Suhrawardy’s resignation, Mr. Gandhi replied: All I can say is that I am surprised at the resignation.
('32', 320, 14, 25, 749489) Evidently, all of Dr.Suhrawardy’s grievance is purely against me, but I am not a member of the Swaraj Party.
('32', 320, 14, 26, 749598) He may express all the resentment that he wishes to against me regarding the opinion that I gave at the meeting to which I was invited.

('32', 331, 3, 4, 773165) At a meeting of the College Branch of the Young Men’s Christian Association, Calcutta, Gandhiji was called upon to speak, last month, on a subject he had not thought of before.
('32', 331, 3, 5, 773342) There was evidently some misunderstanding.
('32', 331, 3, 6, 773385) He was under the impression that he had to speak on ‘Village Organization’ whereas he was asked to speak on ‘Value and Possibility of Personality’ a subject which puzzled him a little.
('32', 331, 3, 7, 773570) But he came to a compromise and spoke on the subject of the evening incidentally touching on the subject of village organization too.
('32', 331, 4, 8, 773704) If personality meant character, as he had no doubt it did, then almost anyone could be got to address on the value of character.
('32', 331, 4, 9, 773833) Bhartrihari, king, philosopher and poet rolled into one, thus summed up the power of character: ‘What will not satsang
('32', 331, 5, 10, 773952) do for a man?’
('32', 331, 6, 11, 773967) Character should be lived into one’s own life.
('32', 331, 6, 12, 774014) He who places purity of public life before anything else and say that a nation which disregarded purity of public life was doomed to perdition.Village organization seemed a simple word, but it meant the organization of the whole of India, inasmuch as India was predominantly rural.
('32', 331, 6, 13, 774296) Sir Henry Maine had left a work on Village Communities which everyone might treasure.
('32', 331, 6, 14, 774382) He had shown to India and to the world that the village life of India today was what it was five thousand years ago, which did not imply that the Indians were barbarous.
('32', 331, 6, 15, 774552) On the contrary, the writer had made it clear that the Indian village life had so much vitality and character that it had persisted all these long years and weathered many a storm.
('32', 331, 6, 16, 774733) He had described these villages as so many village republics completely self contained, having all that one may want—schools, arbitration boards, sanitation boards, and no Poor Law, indeed, but ample provision for the relief of the poor.
('32', 331, 7, 17, 774971) He had also shown the treasures of art that the genius of the Indian villager had produced.
('32', 331, 7, 18, 775063) The villager then learnt from his parents by word of mouth all the wisdom that he should learn.
('32', 331, 7, 19, 775159) In daily contact with people, he was able to realize the value and possibility of personality.
('32', 331, 7, 20, 775254) To him the village headman was a personality in himself.
('32', 331, 7, 21, 775311) He was not the impostor of today; he was the servant of the people whom they could go to in times of difficulties, whom every child in the village knew and loved.
('32', 331, 7, 22, 775474) He was incorruptible, he was a gentleman.
('32', 331, 7, 23, 775516) But such a one was a rare bird today.
('32', 331, 7, 24, 775554) The speaker asked with a sigh: What has come over this land that all these beautiful things are not to be found anywhere, that instead of those self contained villages

('32', 334, 1, 2, 780797) 215. NOTES
('32', 334, 2, 3, 780808) “SANATANA” HINDU I have a correspondent who always brings me to book for the slightest negligence on my part.
('32', 334, 2, 4, 780918) He is evidently a regular student of Young India, but no blind admirer.
('32', 334, 2, 5, 780990) Here is a candid but friendly critic, and, if he sees something good in my writings, he detects also errors.
('32', 334, 2, 6, 781099) One of his letters drawing attention to a possible inconsistency in my writings has long remained in my file.
('32', 334, 2, 7, 781209) One portion of it deals with the definition of ‘sanatana Hindu’.
('32', 334, 2, 8, 781274) Here is the letter:
('32', 334, 3, 9, 781294) You have often declared yourself a sanatana Hindu, defining one as a believer in the Vedas, Smritis etc., and laid emphasis on the institution of castes by birth as legitimately following from those ‘scriptures’.
('32', 334, 3, 10, 781507) Of course you limit the number of castes to the supposed pristine four.
('32', 334, 3, 11, 781579) (I say ‘supposed pristine’ advisedly—for, even as early as the times of the production of Manu [’s] and other Smritis, there had been already so many castes evolved out of and recognized over and above the ideal four, although, be it noted, interd ining and intermarriage amongst them all had not yet come to be interdicted.) Now the fourth or, last in order of the ‘fundamental’ castes, is the Sudra, which is debarred by those very ‘scriptures’ a belief in which you regard as the sine qua non of a sanatana Hindu, as well as by their ‘twice born’ professors, from studying or reciting the Divine Vedas including the Gayatri, a recitation of which you mention as obligatory upon a sanatana Hindu (without distinction of caste).
('32', 334, 3, 12, 782309) So the question arises: How can anyone (e.g., a Sudra) be said to belong to a religion (viz., Hinduism as defined by you), if the mere reading, reciting or even the hearing of its scripture is tabooed to him, as though it were a sacrilege?
('32', 334, 3, 13, 782549) How can you expect a man to be a swimmer without letting him step into water?
('32', 334, 3, 14, 782627) Either one who is born a Sudra cannot be a sanatana Hindu in your sense, or else a sanatana Hindu must be something very different from what you define one to be.
('32', 334, 3, 15, 782790) (I refer you to your old article on ‘Hindusism’ in 1921 and your address to the cow conference at Belgaum as printed in Young India, 29 1 ’25).
('32', 334, 3, 16, 782934) I for one, who am a Brahmin by birth, cannot glory in the name of ‘Hindu’ so long as an exemplar of real sanatana dharma like you permits the term to cover a bundle of contradictions like the one I have pointed out.
('32', 334, 3, 17, 783150) Lastly, in view of your mention of Gayatri, may I humbly inquire whether you have in your ‘twice born’ life never omitted to include the Gayatri in your daily prayers?” I am not a literalist.
('32', 334, 3, 18, 783342) Therefore, I try to understand the spirit of the various scriptures of the world.
('32', 334, 3, 19, 783424) I apply the test of Truth and Ahimsa laid down by these very scriptures for interpretation.
('32', 334, 3, 20, 783516) I reject what is inconsistent with that test, and I appropriate all that is consistent with it.
('32', 334, 3, 21, 783612) The story of a Sudra having been punished by Ramachandra for daring to learn the Vedas I reject as an
('32', 335, 0, 1, 783714) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 335, 1, 2, 783756) interpolation.
('32', 335, 1, 3, 783771) And in any event, I worship Rama, the perfect being of my conception, not a historical person, facts about whose life may vary with the progress of new historical discoveries and researches.
('32', 335, 1, 4, 783962) Tulsidas had nothing to do with the Rama of history.
('32', 335, 1, 5, 784015) Judged by historical test, his Ramayana would be fit for the scrap heap.
('32', 335, 1, 6, 784088) As a spiritual experience, his book is almost unrivalled, at least for me.
('32', 335, 1, 7, 784163) And then too, I do not swear by every word that is to be found in so many editions published as the Ramayana of Tulsidas.
('32', 335, 1, 8, 784285) It is the spirit running through the book that holds me spell bound.
('32', 335, 1, 9, 784354) I cannot myself subscribe to the prohibition against Sudras learning the Vedas.
('32', 335, 1, 10, 784434) Indeed, in my opinion, at the present moment, we are all predominantly Sudras so long as we are serfs.
('32', 335, 1, 11, 784537) Knowledge cannot be the prerogative of any class or section.
('32', 335, 1, 12, 784598) But I can conceive the impossibility of people assimilating higher or subtler truths, unless they have undergone preliminary training, even as those who have not made preliminary prepartaions are quite unfit to breathe the rarefied atmosphere in high altitudes, or those who have no preliminary training in simple mathematics are unfit to understand or assimilate higher geometry or algebra.
('32', 335, 1, 13, 784990) Lastly, I believe in certain healthy conventions.
('32', 335, 1, 14, 785040) There is a convention surrounding the recitation of the Gayatri.
('32', 335, 1, 15, 785105) The convention is that it should be recited only at stated times and after ablutions performed in the prescribed manner.
('32', 335, 1, 16, 785226) As I believe in those conventions, and as I am not able always to conform to them, for years past I have followed the later Saints, and therefore have satisfied myself with the Dwadasha Mantra of the Bhagavata or the still simpler formula of Tulsidas and a few selections from the Gita and other works, and a few bhajans in Prakrit.

('32', 336, 7, 17, 787504) THE CATTLE PROBLEM Mr. Andrews has sent me the following cutting for disposal:
('32', 336, 8, 18, 787583) ‘What other country on earth pays such a staggering price for the veneration of an animal?’ asks the June issue of The Round Table, the quarterly review of the
('32', 336, 9, 19, 787743) politics of the British Commonwealth.
('32', 336, 9, 20, 787781) Figures are supplied by the article entitled ‘The Disabilites of Rural Indian’, showing that the annual economic loss ‘is greater than the total revenue of British India’,—an economic waste which is ‘almost unbelievable’.
('32', 336, 9, 21, 788003) The article referred to points out that ‘the regard, even veneration, which some of the people have for all forms of animal life prevents them from restricting its multiplication, even when it comes into direct economic competition with men for the produce of the soil, or makes it impossible for him to develop it to its full capacity’, and the following are the figures representing India’s ‘staggering price’ for cow veneration:
('32', 336, 10, 22, 788435) What surplus oxen cost India.
('32', 336, 10, 23, 788465) Rs. 1,15,20,00,000
('32', 336, 11, 24, 788484) What surplus cows cost India.
('32', 336, 11, 25, 788514) Rs. 61,20,00,000
('32', 336, 12, 26, 788531) Total Rs. 1,76,40,00,000
('32', 336, 13, 27, 788556) This amount calculated at Rs.15 to the £ equals £117,600,000. The annual land revenue for British India, we are told, amounts to 36 crores of rupees, so that the annual economic loss due to surplus cattle is over four times the land revenue.
('32', 337, 0, 1, 788798) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 337, 1, 2, 788840) There is no doubt that, like the growing poverty of India, the cattle problem is growing more and more serious.
('32', 337, 1, 3, 788952) But the cattle problem of India is, for the vast majority of the population—the Hindus, the problem of cow protection, taking the expression in its broad sense.
('32', 337, 1, 4, 789113) There is, therefore, no doubt that we shall have to pay ‘a staggering price’ for ever.
('32', 337, 1, 5, 789200) If we have no ‘cow veneration’, we could make short work of all the surplus and dilapidated cattle, and save the seventeen hundred and sixty four millions of rupees which the writer has dished out for us.
('32', 337, 1, 6, 789405) Similarly, no doubt, we could free this land from poverty by killing out all the surplus population, all the diseased, all the weaklings, and a few thousands of us may then live on this vast surface of the earth, with a few pistols or some more quickly working weapon of destruction for ridding ourselves of those men and animals, ferocious or otherwise, whom we may regard as a burden.
('32', 337, 1, 7, 789792) But in India, like the poor and the diseased everywhere, we shall have to have our brethren the cattle also, and we must, therefore, solve the cattle problem, as the poverty problem, along our own, or as some might say, superstitious lines.
('32', 337, 1, 8, 790033) I have endeavoured to show the way in my address to the Cow Protection Conference.
('32', 337, 1, 9, 790116) Within the limitations prescribed by religious sentiment, we must adopt the latest scientific methods.
('32', 337, 1, 10, 790219) We must resort to scientific castration, we must find out an economical method of feeding our cattle, we must take the maximum of service consistently with the welfare of the cattle, we must increase the milk supply from the existing cows and buffaloes, and we must make the best economical use of the hides of all dead cattle.
('32', 337, 1, 11, 790547) If we succeed in doing these things, we shall have gone a long way towards solving the cattle problem.
('32', 337, 1, 12, 790650) There will still have to be a price paid for religious sentiment, but a religious sentiment is not worth the name if it is not worth paying for.
('32', 337, 1, 13, 790795) The money that is daily being paid in the name of cow protection blindly and in utter ignorance of scientific facts can be well utilized for the purposes above mentioned.
('32', 337, 1, 14, 790966) It will make no direct return, but it will, under better conditions, prevent the wicked waste that is going on, and certainly save thousands of cattle from the butcher’s knife to which they fall victim, not because of Mussalman or English cussedness, but because of Hindu stupidity.
('32', 337, 1, 15, 791249) Today, because of our ignorance and slothfulness, millions of human beings and millions of cattle are dying of semi starvation—a sad reflection upon religious India.

('32', 338, 1, 2, 791461) STEADY PROGRESS The reader will remember my note on the progress made in eleven days in spinning at Satyashram, in Baherok.
('32', 338, 1, 3, 791585) I have now another letter showing further progress, which I reproduce below:
('32', 338, 2, 4, 791662) Perhaps you remember my last letter re the progress I made in spin ning within 11 days.
('32', 338, 2, 5, 791750) I am glad to inform you that we have been continuing the practice of spinning in competition almost every day.
('32', 338, 2, 6, 791861) In the last four years, all our work would stop when the rains would set in, as the country at that time becomes a vast sheet of water.
('32', 338, 2, 7, 791997) But since your last visit, we have been making steady progress in our work, in spite of the inelement weather of the rainy season.
('32', 338, 3, 8, 792128) The total amount of yarn produced in the locality, which was only 1 or 2 seers at the time of your visit, has reached up to half a maund per month.
('32', 338, 3, 9, 792276) The progress made by the boys of the national school is much more encouraging.
('32', 338, 3, 10, 792355) The speed of a boy of 16 has come up to 730 yards of 15 counts per hour.
('32', 338, 3, 11, 792428) The quality of the yarn is also appreciably improved.
('32', 338, 4, 12, 792482) As regards the wheels, they are the same machines shown to you in the demonstration held in the Ashram compound.
('32', 338, 4, 13, 792595) We have only changed the spindles.
('32', 338, 4, 14, 792630) We hope to make further progress.
('32', 338, 4, 15, 792664) May we have your sympathy and blessings?
('32', 338, 4, 16, 792705) If the authorities continue their faith in the spinning wheel unabated, I have very little doubt that progress in spinning will also be continuous.

('32', 339, 5, 12, 795034) Last time the Bill came up, it received a very great deal of support in the country and in the Assembly, and I think that during the next session, there will not be much difficulty in passing it, if only we get a certain amount of expression of public opinion from the people.
('32', 339, 5, 13, 795311) To my certain knowledge, there are quite a large number of meetings being held all over the country, especially my women, supporting this Bill, and I am sure that it is in line with the wishes of the majority of women that the age for the consummation of marriage for little girls should be raised to at least 14.
('32', 339, 6, 14, 795625) I am sure that it would be a considerable help to the passage of the
('32', 339, 7, 15, 795694) Bill if you could express your opinion strongly in support of it and also urge
('32', 339, 8, 16, 795773) on men and women the importance of both supporting the Bill and living up
('32', 339, 9, 17, 795847) to its principles in daily practice.

Whilst, therefore, I can say nothing about the text of the Bill, I should heartily endorse any movement whose object is to save innocent girls of tender age from man’s lust.

('32', 343, 5, 9, 803437) 219. A COMMON SCRIPT If we are to make good our claim as one nation, we must have several things in common.
('32', 343, 5, 10, 803545) We have a common culture running through a variety of creeds and sub creeds.
('32', 343, 5, 11, 803622) We have common disabilities.
('32', 343, 5, 12, 803651) I am endeavouring to show that a common material for our dress is not only desirable but necessary.
('32', 343, 5, 13, 803751) We need also a common language not in supersession of the vernaculars, but in addition to them.
('32', 343, 5, 14, 803847) It is generally agreed that that medium should be Hindustani—a resultant of Hindi and Urdu, neither highly Sanskritized, nor Persianized or Arabianized.
('32', 343, 5, 15, 804000) The greatest obstacle in the way are the numerous script, we have for the vernaculars.
('32', 343, 5, 16, 804087) If it is possible to adopt a common script we should remove a great hindrance in the way of realizing the dream which, at present, is of having a common language.
('32', 343, 5, 17, 804250) A variety of scripts iss an obstacle in more ways than one.
('32', 343, 5, 18, 804310) It constitutes an effectual barrier against the acquisition of knowledge.
('32', 343, 5, 19, 804384) The Aryan languages have so much in common that, if a great deal of
('32', 344, 0, 1, 804452) VOL.32 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 345
('32', 344, 1, 2, 804496) time had not to be wasted in mastering the different scripts, we should all know several languages without much difficulty; for instance, most people who have a little knowledge of Sanskrit would have no difficulty in understanding the matchless creation of Rabindranath Tagore, if it was all printed in Devanagari script.
('32', 344, 1, 3, 804819) But the Bengali script is a notice to the non Bengalis—“hands off”.
('32', 344, 1, 4, 804887) Conversely, if the Bengalis knew the Devanagari script, they would at once be able to enjoy the marvellous beauty and spirituality of Tulsidas and a host of other Hindustani writers.
('32', 344, 1, 5, 805070) When I returned to India in 1915, 1 I had a communication from a society whose headquarters were, I believe, in Calcutta, and whose object was to advocate a common script for all India.
('32', 344, 1, 6, 805256) I do not know the activities of that society, but its object isworthy, and a great deal of substantial work can be done by a few earnest workers in this direction.
('32', 344, 1, 7, 805420) There are obvious limitations.
('32', 344, 1, 8, 805451) A common script for all India is a distant ideal.
('32', 344, 1, 9, 805501) A common script for all those who speak the Indo Sanskrit languages, including the Southern stock, is a practical ideal, if we can but shed our provincialisms.
('32', 344, 1, 10, 805661) There is little virtue, for instance, in a Gujarati clinging to the Gujarati script.
('32', 344, 1, 11, 805746) A provincial patriotism is good where it feeds the larger stream of all India patriotism, as the latter is good to the extent that it serves the still larger end of the universe.
('32', 344, 1, 12, 805925) But a provincial patriotism that says “India is nothing, Gujarat is all”, is wickedness.
('32', 344, 1, 13, 806014) I have selected Gujarat because it is the half way house, and because I am myself a Gujarati.
('32', 344, 1, 14, 806108) In Gujarat, somewhat fortunately, those who settled the principles of primary education decided to make Devanagari script compulsory.
('32', 344, 1, 15, 806242) Every Gujarati boy or girl who has passsed through a school, therefore, knows both the Gujarati and the Devanagari scipts.
('32', 344, 1, 16, 806365) If the committee had decided upon purely Devanagari script, it would have been better still.
('32', 344, 1, 17, 806458) No doubt, the research scholars would still have learnt the Gujarati script for deciphering old manuscripts, but the Gujarati boy's energy would have been spared for more useful labour, if he had to learn only one instead of two scipts.
('32', 344, 1, 18, 806695) The committee that settled the education scheme for Maharashtra, was more enlightened, and it simply required the Devanagari script.
('32', 344, 1, 19, 806828) The result is that a Mahratta reads, so far as mere reading is concerned, Tulsidas with as much facility as he reads Tukaram, and Gujaratis and Hindustanis read Tukaram with equal facility.

('32', 345, 1, 5, 807500) These reflections arise, because, I was called upon to solve, during my visit to Cuttack, a practical question.
('32', 345, 1, 6, 807612) There is a tribe wedged between the Hindi speaking people in Bihar and Uriya speaking people of Orissa.
('32', 345, 1, 7, 807716) What was to be done for the education of its children ?
('32', 345, 1, 8, 807772) Were they to be taught through Uriya or through Hindi?

('32', 345, 1, 12, 808281) And for them it would be a toss whether the script to be adopted should be Devanagari or Uriya, if not even a newly invented script, as has happened in modern times in at least two instances I know.
('32', 345, 1, 13, 808480) Endeavouring to think in terms of all India, I suggested to my friends that, whilst it was proper for them to strengthen the Uriya language among the Uriya speaking people, the children of this tribe should be taught Hindi and, naturally, the script should be Devanagari.
