('32', 346, 1, 2, 809885) 220. HOOKWORM AND CHARKHA
('32', 346, 2, 3, 809911) In the letter enclosing the cutting about cattle, dealt with elsewhere in this issue, Mr. Andrews writes:
('32', 346, 3, 4, 810017) I have just had with me here Dr. Tendrich of the Rockefeller International Health Board who has been plodding away in Madras.
('32', 346, 3, 5, 810143) He tells me that on examination 92 to 85 p.c.
('32', 346, 3, 6, 810189) of the peasantry have hookworm, and other infections from night soil, like typhoid and dysentery, which are rife owing to evacuations getting everywhere mixed up with the water supply.
('32', 346, 3, 7, 810374) He says that they were just in the same condition as the Negroes in the Southern States twenty years ago.
('32', 346, 3, 8, 810480) The consequence also was the same, —no vitality, a wretched life of weakness.
('32', 346, 3, 9, 810558) Now, in the very same States today there is prosperity and vitality, because hookworm, typhoid, etc, have been conquered by the night soil being got under control.
('32', 346, 3, 10, 810722) He said to me that, if a change were made in the people's habits in this direction by the very simple method of a village drainage, which would be filled in every six months, and then every six months afterwards dug out and used as a perfectly safe fertilizer, as they do mostly in China, Japan and the States, the economic gain is so great as to be quite incalculable.
('32', 346, 3, 11, 811092) My point is that the charkha has opened the village problem, but it has not solved it.
('32', 346, 3, 12, 811179) And if you say that it alone will solve it, by concentrating on it alone, that is too narrow.
('32', 346, 3, 13, 811273) The cattle problem and the sanitation problem are equally vital.
('32', 346, 3, 14, 811338) In this paragraph Mr. Andrews has raised the question of sanitation.
('32', 346, 3, 15, 811407) I am not blind to the necessity of sanitation.
('32', 346, 3, 16, 811454) I became a sanitary reformer long before I discovered the charkha.
('32', 346, 3, 17, 811521) I was myself carrying on at the farm in Phoenix, Natal, experiments in burying night soil and converting it into rich manure.
('32', 346, 3, 18, 811647) We had there no scavenger; we were our own scavengers, and as, Mr. Andrews himself knows, one could walk about the settlement in Phoenix bare footed without the danger of treading upon any dirt.
('32', 346, 3, 19, 811842) The same treatment of night soil is being continued at the Satyagraha Ashram on the banks of the Sabarmati.
('32', 346, 3, 20, 811950) But I do not carry on any propaganda about it for the simple reason that it cannot solve the problem of the daily growing poverty immediately and directly.
('32', 346, 3, 21, 812106) Moreover, in dealing with this question of insanitation, one has to fight against old prejudices and old habits.
('32', 346, 3, 22, 812219) It is a matter of sustained education and one that cannot be dealt with without State aid.
('32', 346, 3, 23, 812310) I regret to have to confess that ingrained bad habits handed down from generation to generation do not yield to persuasion.
('32', 346, 3, 24, 812434) Legislation seems to me to be the only effective remedy.
('32', 347, 0, 1, 812491) 348 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 347, 1, 2, 812533) But the same objection does not apply to the charkha.
('32', 347, 1, 3, 812587) On the contrary, it is to be the precursor of every reform, and if I can only concentrate the attention of the nation upon the charkha, it will automatically solve all the other problems and pave the way for legislation where legislation is required.
('32', 347, 1, 4, 812838) The charkha is calculated to make an immediate return, be it ever so small, to the individual.
('32', 347, 1, 5, 812933) It presents the least difficulty in its working.
('32', 347, 1, 6, 812982) There is no rooted prejudice against it.
('32', 347, 1, 7, 813023) For the simple folk at least it requires no elaborate reasoning.
('32', 347, 1, 8, 813088) It needs the smallest capital.
('32', 347, 1, 9, 813119) It is the only constructive effort that is possible on a national scale.
('32', 347, 1, 10, 813192) It is fraught with tremendous political consequences if it becomes successful, and seeing that it cannot succeed without co operation it makes for a mighty co operative effort.
('32', 347, 1, 11, 813369) Hence the claim that concentration on charkha alone leads to swaraj, and if this is too strong a proposition, let it be put in another way— ‘Without the charkha and all it implies there is no swaraj, and therefore a wise economist will concentrate his attention upon the charkha alone, knowing that the rest will follow.’ Let me diagnose the disease a little deeper.
('32', 347, 1, 12, 813736) It is not the drain that matters so much as poverty, and it is not even poverty that matters so much as idleness which was at first enforced, and has now become a habit that matters.
('32', 347, 1, 13, 813919) The drain may be stopped and poverty is merely a symptom, but idleness is the great cause, the root of all evil, and if that root can be destroyed, most of the evils, can be remedied without further effort.
('32', 347, 1, 14, 814126) A nation that is starving has little hope or initiative left in it.
('32', 347, 1, 15, 814194) It becomes indifferent to filth and disease.
('32', 347, 1, 16, 814239) It says of all reforms ‘to what good?’ That winter of despair can only be turned into the ‘sunshine of hope’ for the millions only through the life giving wheel, the charkha.

('32', 347, 5, 21, 814699) The date has been fixed in consultation with Pandit Motilal Nehru who has chosen it after consultation with the members of the Assembly.

('32', 348, 0, 1, 814889) VOL.32 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 349

('32', 348, 1, 4, 815105) Even as it is, a telegram has been received from Sind protesting against the venue being fixed at Patna.
('32', 348, 1, 5, 815210) I appreciate the difficulty of the Sindhi friends.

('32', 348, 1, 7, 815367) The real Puja holiday commences on the 24th and I have promised the Bengal friends that, even though there may have to be a late night sitting, I shall finish the deliberations of the All India Congress Committee on the 22nd so as to free the members to leave for Calcutta the night of 22nd.
('32', 348, 1, 8, 815659) If any routine matters requiring the attention of the All India Congress Committee remain over, and on which Bengali friends might not have any fixed views, subject to their consent, the proceedings will be prolonged beyond the 22nd.

('32', 353, 1, 17, 829119) I want the freedom of my country so that other countries may learn something from this free country of mine.
('32', 353, 1, 18, 829228) I want freedom of my country so that the resources of my country might be utilized for the benefit of mankind just as the cult of patriotism teaches us today that the individual has to die for the family, the family has to die for the village, the village for the district, the district for the Province and the Provinces for the whole nation, and when we indulge in provincialism I as a Gujarati say, Gujarat first, Bengal and the rest of Provinces next.
('32', 353, 1, 19, 829684) There is no nationalism in it.

('32', 354, 6, 18, 831832) But, as he had said repeatedly, these subscriptions he regarded only as an earnest of what the subscribers were going to do for their country.

('32', 355, 1, 2, 832641) into being a little organization.

('32', 355, 1, 5, 832931) These aspirations of theirs still more or less remained only as ideals and a few of them, who were endeavouring to translate those ideals into action, were too few to bring into being organizations that were necessary in order to permeate the masses of India.
('32', 355, 1, 6, 833191) Another requirement for efficient organization was a leader, or more than a leader, soldiers.
('32', 355, 1, 7, 833285) They might have a towering personality like Deshbandhu and people in their adoration and admiration might follow such a man for the time being irresistibly attracted to him.
('32', 355, 1, 8, 833459) But that did not bring into being an organization.
('32', 355, 1, 9, 833510) The test of an organization was that they should work as soldiers, not because they were irresistibly drawn to a personality but because they were irresistibly drawn to the principle.
('32', 355, 1, 10, 833694) Therefore, the requirements of an organization were common will, common purpose, a leader, disciplined soldiers.
('32', 355, 2, 11, 833807) How could students then learn the spirit of organization?
('32', 355, 2, 12, 833865) That was to say, in concrete terms, what was to be their own purpose, what was to be their common will in connection with India in terms of the nation?

('32', 355, 2, 19, 834840) If they would go to the villages, they would see for themselves that the root cause of the deep, distressing poverty of India was slothfulness.
('32', 355, 2, 20, 834984) Nay he would go so far as to say that idleness was the cause of their foreign domination.
('32', 355, 2, 21, 835074) For it was his settled conviction that a nation which was not a nation of idlers, a nation which utilized all its time for its existence, defied the whole might of the universe.
('32', 355, 2, 22, 835252) India should do likewise.
('32', 355, 2, 23, 835278) Every villager should consider it his duty to work every spare moment at his disposal for the sake of the motherland.

('32', 356, 1, 2, 835834) Speaking about swadeshism, Mahatmaji said that swadeshism is a conservative spirit—not conservative or radical—but conservative in its original root meaning, i.e.
('32', 356, 1, 3, 835997) something that conserved.
('32', 356, 1, 4, 836023) The spirit of swadeshi would enable and teach them to conserve all that was best.
('32', 356, 1, 5, 836105) There was a process of rejection also, but not summary rejection nor blind adoration of all that was ancient, simply because it was ancient.
('32', 356, 1, 6, 836246) They must use the God gifted reason, discrimination.
('32', 356, 1, 7, 836299) Swadeshism was a discriminating, conservative spirit which would retain all that was best in national life, in ancient tradition and at the same time absorb by assimilation—not by base imitation—all that was best in the modern world, all that was best in the West, so that from good they might grow to better and from better to still better.
('32', 356, 1, 8, 836641) But there was some fundamental principle in their religion which could not be improved upon.
('32', 356, 1, 9, 836734) What possible improvement could they make on the statement “God is Truth and Love”?

('32', 356, 1, 11, 836896) All these customs must vary according to the varying circumstances and here they must reject them if they conflicted with reason, with their moral sense of mankind.

('32', 356, 2, 13, 837113) Anything imported from Germany, Japan became a swadeshi article.
('32', 356, 2, 14, 837178) To him that was a parody of swadeshism.
('32', 356, 2, 15, 837218) My swadeshi is khaddar, because I have taken my stand on one thing, and restricted my swadeshism.
('32', 356, 2, 16, 837316) Manufactured goods we must not use—goods from outside which we can usefully manufacture in our own country.
('32', 356, 2, 17, 837424) That is not antagonistic to anything, but it is the law of charity beginning at home it is the law of charity which teachs us that, if we do not serve our family, our neighbour, we will not be able to serve our distant neighbour.

('32', 356, 2, 20, 837854) Make your choice—one pie or four annas and decide for yourselves.

('32', 357, 1, 2, 837981) 225. SPEECH AT BENGAL CHRISTIAN CONFERENCE, CALCUTTA August 29, 1925
('32', 357, 2, 3, 838050) On rising to speak, Mahatmaji was accorded a great ovation and he began by saying that, when the son 1 of late Babu Kalicharan Banerjee requested him to address the meeting of the Indian Christian community, he could not but comply with his request, because the request was made by the son of one whom he revered most and whom he had the good fortune to meet on an occasion of seeking his advice at a critical time.
('32', 357, 3, 4, 838466) Mahatmaji continued to say that he had no new message to deliver to them.
('32', 357, 3, 5, 838540) Whatever he had got to say to his Christian brethren of Indian nationality he had said on many previous occasions and they had read it in newspapers.
('32', 357, 3, 6, 838690) His first intimate relations with the Indian Christians began while he was in South Africa.
('32', 357, 3, 7, 838782) There he made acquaintance with a large number of Indian Christians who used to share his joys and trials equally with him.
('32', 357, 3, 8, 838906) Ever since that time his intimacy with them had been on the increase.
('32', 357, 4, 9, 838976) Mahatmaji next referred to the deplorable condition of the Indian Christians for their mixing Christianity with European modes and methods.
('32', 357, 4, 10, 839116) He said that, for the first time, he detected this perverse mentality of the Indian Christians in South Africa and from that time he had been all along striving hard to combat this evil idea.
('32', 357, 4, 11, 839308) He had very often tried to prove that there was a clear distinction between the modes and manners of Europeans and Indian Christians.
('32', 357, 4, 12, 839442) On the previous evening, he showed that race hatred was not nationalization 2. Similarly, he had shown that Christianity did not mean denationalization.
('32', 357, 4, 13, 839595) He was quite sure that for them Christianity did not mean Europeanization.
('32', 357, 4, 14, 839670) It had no geographical limit.
('32', 357, 4, 15, 839700) Jesus lived every inch of him in Asia and certainly Christianity had no relation whatsoever with Europeanization.
('32', 357, 5, 16, 839814) Mahatmaji further observed that there seemed to exist a wide gulf between the Indian Christians and Indian Hindus and Mohammedans.
('32', 357, 5, 17, 839945) No doubt the gulf was getting narrower day by day.
('32', 357, 5, 18, 839996) But it should be bridged over without any further delay.
('32', 357, 5, 19, 840053) Everyone of a particular religion must love those who belonged to other religions.
('32', 357, 5, 20, 840136) Referring to his experience in Travancore, Mahatmaji said that in that State there was a large number of highly educated and cultured Indian Christians.
('32', 357, 5, 21, 840289) He was glad to find them try to do away with hatred and ill will of any sort for men of other religions.
('32', 357, 5, 22, 840394) The sooner the number of such Christians increased, the better for India.

('32', 358, 1, 2, 840614) Mahatmaji continued that they had gone away far from their original religion.
('32', 358, 1, 3, 840692) Therefore, they must be prepared to come back to their old brethren with loving hearts.
('32', 358, 1, 4, 840780) They had gone within the fold of another religion simply to rise above, at least as they thought it to be, superstition and errors of their ancient forefathers.
('32', 358, 1, 5, 840941) So, they must rise above any malice or despite for their brethren.
('32', 358, 1, 6, 841008) Next he referred to internationalism and said that his strong belief was that, without being nationalist, none could lay claim to internationalism.
('32', 358, 1, 7, 841156) Unless a man could serve his family, his village and his country he could not serve the world.
('32', 358, 1, 8, 841251) Internationalism had got no malice, no ill will or contempt, but it had only peace and goodwill in it, and unless a man began to love heartily his neighbours, he could not cultivate the spirit of love for the outside world.
('32', 358, 1, 9, 841475) He continued that Christianity to them must be a better expression of nationalism, so they should be prepared to die for the nation before they could claim to give up their life for the cause of the world.
('32', 358, 1, 10, 841681) In his opinion, Christianity must not be repugnant to nationalism.
('32', 358, 1, 11, 841748) It must mean a greater dedication of their lives to the country’s cause and for that they must enter into the hearts of the masses.
('32', 358, 1, 12, 841880) He had heard many Christians say that they had nothing to do with the masses of India.
('32', 358, 1, 13, 841967) He thought no religion could say so, since all of them were imperfect in some sense or other.
('32', 358, 1, 14, 842061) Mahatmaji requested the Indian Christians to dispel such ideas from their minds.
('32', 358, 2, 15, 842142) Referring to the poverty of India, Mahatmaji next said that certainly Christianity did not mean multiplication of wants—wants which poor India could ill afford to supply.
('32', 358, 2, 16, 842313) Many might say that their outlook was not limited within a narrow sphere.
('32', 358, 2, 17, 842387) He would ask them to examine their hearts and see whether their utterances were at one with their belief, and he was sure they wouldn’t be able to reconcile their utterances with their beliefs.
('32', 358, 3, 18, 842581) Last of all, Mahatmaji appealed to them to put on khaddar at least, if they could not spin.
('32', 358, 3, 19, 842673) For every yard of hand spun and hand woven khaddar they bought, they paid in a way at least four annas to their suffering brethren in the villages who were dying of starvation practically for want of work.
('32', 358, 3, 20, 842879) Mahatmaji concluded his speech by saying that in pursuance of the high tenets of their religion which was absolutely based on the spirit of service to mankind they should buy khaddar and thus save their millions of starving brethren who lived in the remote villages.

('32', 358, 4, 22, 843178) 226. A GREAT DISEASE
('32', 358, 5, 23, 843199) India is a land of peasants.
('32', 358, 5, 24, 843228) In a way the whole world belongs to peasants.
('32', 358, 5, 25, 843274) In other countries, however, people do not live by farming alone.
('32', 358, 5, 26, 843340) In some countries people earn their living by hunting.
('32', 358, 5, 27, 843395) England
('32', 359, 0, 1, 843403) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 359, 1, 2, 843445) lives by its industries.
('32', 359, 1, 3, 843470) It imports much of the grain that it needs.
('32', 359, 1, 4, 843514) For India, however, farming is the only means of subsistence.
('32', 359, 1, 5, 843576) If the rains fail, the people have to starve.
('32', 359, 1, 6, 843622) The farmers have to look up to the clouds in the monsoon.
('32', 359, 1, 7, 843680) However, as only a few persons can cultivate the land all the year round, crores of people are without any occupation for four to six months.
('32', 359, 1, 8, 843822) Hence we have become idle.
('32', 359, 1, 9, 843849) This has not always been our plight.
('32', 359, 1, 10, 843886) Crores of people were kept employed when we made cloth ourselves.
('32', 359, 1, 11, 843952) All these crores suffer from idleness today.
('32', 359, 1, 12, 843997) Their eyes have lost lustre.
('32', 359, 1, 13, 844026) They are without hope; their faces are devoid of enthusiasm.
('32', 359, 1, 14, 844087) We are in such a sad plight where idleness has become second nature to us.
('32', 359, 1, 15, 844162) This idleness of the peasants is shared by the middle class too.
('32', 359, 1, 16, 844227) There can be no swaraj for an idle nation.
('32', 359, 1, 17, 844270) Idleness leads to destruction.
('32', 359, 1, 18, 844301) While moving amidst hundreds of thousands of people, I find that they do not get weary of chatting or just sitting doing nothing.
('32', 359, 1, 19, 844431) If I don’t look out, many people would sit around me and believe that they were doing something meritorious.
('32', 359, 1, 20, 844540) This idleness is a great disease with us, whose symptom is poverty.
('32', 359, 1, 21, 844608) I believe that while the drain of money from this country is the cause of our poverty, it is not the cause.
('32', 359, 1, 22, 844716) It is our idleness that is responsible both for our poverty and the drain of our resources.
('32', 359, 1, 23, 844808) And, what else can an idle person become but a slave?
('32', 359, 1, 24, 844862) Idlers have never become, and never will become, self reliant.
('32', 359, 1, 25, 844925) How to get rid of this idleness?
('32', 359, 1, 26, 844958) By taking up some sort of activity.
('32', 359, 1, 27, 844994) Which is the activity that can be taken up by crores of human beings?
('32', 359, 1, 28, 845064) In my opinion the spinning wheel is the only activity of this kind.
('32', 359, 1, 29, 845132) Anyone who can find a better activity for the people is free not to work on the spinning wheel.
('32', 359, 1, 30, 845228) I have been claiming from the very beginning that the spinning wheel is the best possible means of making an idle person active; however, if anyone points out a more fruitful means which could be generally adopted, I will readily bow to him.
('32', 359, 1, 31, 845470) I have come across many persons who are hard working themselves .
('32', 359, 1, 32, 845536) But does this make the whole country industrious?
('32', 359, 1, 33, 845586) There are ten or twenty millionaires in India, there are twenty five or fifty rulers; does that, however make everyone a millionaire or a ruler?
('32', 359, 1, 34, 845731) We can be called a single nation when those who are well to do partake of the misery of the country.
('32', 359, 1, 35, 845832) Even a person like Shri Krishna had to work for the mass of people even though it was unnecessary so far as he himself was concerned.
('32', 359, 1, 36, 845966) Moreover, it is not sufficient to be engaged

('32', 360, 1, 2, 846055) in work that is directed to one’s self interest.
('32', 360, 1, 3, 846104) Those who can be called public leaders or public servants will pursue for the good of others an activity which crores of persons pursue in mere self interest.
('32', 360, 1, 4, 846263) If they do not do this, even those who work of the sake of self interest will give it up under a false glamour or illusion.
('32', 360, 1, 5, 846387) In this case, we have to fashion workers out of idlers.
('32', 360, 1, 6, 846443) We have also to teach them an activity which will bring about the good of the individual and society.

('32', 360, 1, 9, 846763) Mr. Andrews has posed two questions.
('32', 360, 1, 10, 846800) We incur a loss of crores of rupees every year as cattle are not properly looked after.

('32', 360, 1, 13, 847242) I have taken up the responsibility of cow protection by way of protecting cattle.

('32', 360, 1, 17, 847746) Hence, from whichever angle you look you will see the very same thing.
('32', 360, 1, 18, 847817) Idleness is the great disease of India and the spinning wheel is the sole remedy for it.

('32', 362, 2, 14, 851711) GUJARATIS LIVING OUTSIDE GUJARAT
('32', 362, 3, 15, 851744) Wherever I go I happen to meet Gujaratis living outside their province.
('32', 362, 3, 16, 851816) I get their help at every place.
('32', 362, 3, 17, 851849) After Shri Manilal Kothari came to Calcutta, his contribution to the Bengal Deshbandhu Fund exceeds all expectations.
('32', 362, 3, 18, 851967) The Gujaratis of Kharagpur have also sent in their contributions.
('32', 362, 3, 19, 852033) There are only a few Gujaratis in Cuttack; they have, however, contributed a good sum.
('32', 362, 3, 20, 852120) I had a novel experience in Kharagpur which pained me.
('32', 362, 3, 21, 852175) There were three gentlemen who were afraid of coming to me and handing in their contribution, for fear of losing the contracts that they had been getting from Englishmen.
('32', 362, 3, 22, 852346) At present, there is no ground for such fear.
('32', 362, 3, 23, 852392) Even Englishmen are friendly to me.
('32', 362, 3, 24, 852428) Fear is something internal.
('32', 362, 3, 25, 852456) Everyone frightens one who is afraid; no one dares to frighten one who is fearless.
('32', 362, 3, 26, 852540) And it is not even true that the fearless cannot earn a living.
('32', 362, 3, 27, 852604) Yes, a guilty conscience makes a man miserable.
('32', 362, 3, 28, 852652) Those who earn a living dishonestly are afraid of everyone.
('32', 362, 3, 29, 852712) Why then were these gentlemen afraid?
('32', 362, 3, 30, 852750) Those who resort to fraudulent practices in contracts see fear where there is none.
('32', 362, 3, 31, 852834) However, I hope that these timid gentlemen had no such cause for fear.
('32', 362, 3, 32, 852905) I do not wish to see any Indian, man or woman, being frightened.
('32', 362, 3, 33, 852970) I had imagined that Gujaratis who live outside their province must have rid themselves of ordinary fears.

('32', 363, 1, 2, 853354) 228. OUR DIRTY WAYS
('32', 363, 2, 3, 853374) Elsewhere in this issue appears my article written at the request of Mr. Andrews, on the question of our dirty habits; nevertheless, it is necessary to take it up separately for discussion.
('32', 363, 2, 4, 853564) I do remember having written on this subject even when I first took up the editorship of Navajivan.
('32', 363, 2, 5, 853664) It is, however, a subject on which one can write repeatedly.
('32', 363, 2, 6, 853725) Our rules regarding cleanliness are fine: one should always take a bath.
('32', 363, 2, 7, 853798) We do not, however, know the implications of all these acts; hence they have become merely a ritual.
('32', 363, 2, 8, 853899) Alternatively, we give in to superstitions and believe that the touch of water—of whatever quality and in however small a quantity—purifies us and makes us fit for heaven.
('32', 363, 2, 9, 854071) Science, however, tells us that a bath is beneficial only when it is taken with clean water and when the body is rubbed and cleaned.
('32', 363, 2, 10, 854204) There is no sense in sprinkling a few drops of water or just in pouring water on oneself and putting on dirty clothes; this may even be harmful.
('32', 363, 2, 11, 854349) Our lavatories are like hell on earth.
('32', 363, 2, 12, 854388) To visit these is like committing a sin.
('32', 363, 2, 13, 854429) We could improve these with a little effort, thought and discretion.
('32', 363, 2, 14, 854498) There is no question of any expense involved in it.
('32', 363, 2, 15, 854550) Knowledge is all that is required.
('32', 363, 2, 16, 854585) Even the poorest of the poor can, if he wishes to follow the rules of cleanliness.
('32', 363, 2, 17, 854668) It is true that he cannot afford to have an aversion for looking at and cleaning up his own excreta.
('32', 363, 2, 18, 854769) The farmer has no such aversions.
('32', 363, 2, 19, 854803) He fills up cart loads of filth in a very dirty way.
('32', 363, 2, 20, 854856) The lanes of Ahmedabad are dirty not because of poverty but because of great ignorance and idleness.
('32', 363, 2, 21, 854957) In Madras in the well to do localities I found wealthy persons of fifty using the lanes as latrines in the morning.
('32', 363, 2, 22, 855073) I feel disgusted even when I think of that sight.
('32', 363, 2, 23, 855123) In Hardwar, the pilgrims fill the banks of the holy Ganges with foul smell, morning and evening.
('32', 363, 2, 24, 855220) It becomes impossible to sit or walk there.
('32', 363, 2, 25, 855264) At some places these people clean themselves directly in the river and do not even carry water in vessel to clean themselves with.
('32', 363, 2, 26, 855395) In the river near Trichinopoly one can see excreta with the naked eye!
('32', 363, 2, 27, 855466) And , the same water is used for bathing and drinking!
('32', 363, 2, 28, 855521) In Bengal hundreds of puddle like tiny lakes are used for the purpose of bathing, washing and drinking—by cattle and human beings.
('32', 363, 2, 29, 855652) The complaint made by Mr. Andrews’s friend, however, relates to something else.
('32', 363, 2, 30, 855732) He says, “the farmers make dirty the soil by defecating and urinating at any place.
('32', 363, 2, 31, 855816) When it rains there, the water is
('32', 364, 0, 1, 855850) VOL.32 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 365
('32', 364, 1, 2, 855894) polluted by all this filth and, since lakhs of people walk bare foot, they fall a prey to hookworm, dysentery, etc.
('32', 364, 1, 3, 856010) Many people suffer and many die an untimely death.
('32', 364, 1, 4, 856061) Fine manure can be made out of this filth.
('32', 364, 1, 5, 856104) The people of China save crores of rupees by doing so.
('32', 364, 1, 6, 856159) Why should not Indians do so and, at the same time, keep healthy?
('32', 364, 1, 7, 856225) At one time the conditions in South America were the same as those obtaining in India.
('32', 364, 1, 8, 856312) They have been changed in twenty years with great effort and the people are free from many diseases”.
('32', 364, 1, 9, 856414) We, too, could save ourselves if we so desire.
('32', 364, 1, 10, 856461) Next week, we shall discuss how to do so.

('32', 365, 2, 7, 858040) THE FORTHCOMING A. I. C. C.
('32', 365, 3, 8, 858068) I hope that every member of the A.I.C.C, unless he is prevented by unforeseen circumstances, will make it a point to attend the forthcoming meeting of the Committee and take part in its deliberations and register his vote.
('32', 365, 3, 9, 858291) The change sought to be made in the constitution can only be justified, if there is a unanimous and insistent demand for it.
('32', 365, 3, 10, 858416) Unanimity and insistence can only be proved by every member attending even at considerable inconvenience and sacrifice if necessary.
('32', 365, 3, 11, 858549) It will not do for members to assume anything as a foregone conclusion, and let those who attend do what they like.
('32', 365, 3, 12, 858665) Absence from the meeting will be presumed to be a sign of want of sense of responsibiltiy unless the absence is otherwise duly accounted for.
('32', 365, 3, 13, 858807) Members should realize that I have not worried them throughout the year, and but for the emergency I would certainly not have worried them now.
('32', 365, 3, 14, 858951) In my opinion, a meeting of the All India Congress Committee and the expense attendant upon it can only be warranted if a new policy has to be initiated or important resolutions of an educative character are required to be passed.
('32', 365, 3, 15, 859182) The intention at first was to hold the meeting on the 1st of October in Bombay.
('32', 365, 3, 16, 859262) But it was suggested that an earlier meeting will be more convenient for the members of the Committee, and that it could be more conveniently held at Patna.
('32', 365, 3, 17, 859419) There is hardly a place which is equally suitable for all.

('32', 365, 3, 22, 859925) And I had no hesitation in fixing Patna when I knew that Panditji’s health would be better conserved by selecting Patna as the venue.
('32', 365, 3, 23, 860059) He is by no means yet strong or completely restored.

('32', 365, 3, 25, 860202) I, therefore, hope that no member will absent himself because Patna is too far away for him.

('32', 366, 2, 8, 861079) Why Not All Parties
('32', 366, 3, 9, 861099) The idea running through my mind is to lighten the burden of the forthcoming Congress, to adjust defferences that there may be amongst Congressmen, and to explore avenues, if any, of common action by all parties so that the Congress may be free to discuss and initiate new policies and new programmes if any.
('32', 366, 3, 10, 861408) It may be asked why I am not inviting leaders of other parties also to meet at Patna.
('32', 366, 3, 11, 861494) I had given most anxious consideration to the matter, and I have come to the conclusion that such an invitation at this stage will bear no fruit.
('32', 366, 3, 12, 861640) It will be time enough to take the next step when all the Congressmen know their own minds and become of one mind.
('32', 366, 3, 13, 861755) The differences between the Congressmen and others are well known and well defined.
('32', 366, 3, 14, 861839) It will be for the Congressmen first to consider how far it is possible for them to go, and then to hold consultation with the leaders of the other parties.
('32', 366, 3, 15, 861996) For the time being, I must content myself with giving the assurance to all concerned that I yield to no one in my disire to see all the parties united on a common platform.
('32', 366, 3, 16, 862169) But I know that when the differences are fundamental, it is difficult, in spite of all the desire in the world, to construct a common platform.
('32', 366, 3, 17, 862313) What is true of Chemistry is true of human beings.
('32', 366, 3, 18, 862364) Incompatibles meet but to explode.
('32', 366, 3, 19, 862399) What every Congressman aims at, and must aim at, is a real union or combination which would mean strength, not a patched up makeshift which can only weaken the nation and, therefore, retard the national cause.

('32', 367, 1, 2, 862651) KHADDAR IN BIHAR
('32', 367, 2, 3, 862668) A friend writes from Purulia:
('32', 367, 3, 4, 862698) As you are expected to come to Purulia, all the people are buying khaddar just to wear it during your stay.
('32', 367, 3, 5, 862806) Your visit has reminded some of these men of their promise to use khaddar, and some are buying it just to escape public criticism.
('32', 367, 3, 6, 862937) Now, if a man uses foreign cloth as a rule, but only wears khaddar on certain occasions, he is a hypocrite.
('32', 367, 3, 7, 863045) And if your visit increases the number of such men, what is the use?
('32', 367, 3, 8, 863114) Hypocrites never help the self government of any country.
('32', 367, 3, 9, 863172) There was a time when I deemed it a pleasure to present khaddar garments on marriage ceremonies.
('32', 367, 3, 10, 863269) But I found by experience that it was almost impossible to get pure khaddar locally.
('32', 367, 3, 11, 863354) What is generally bought as such is made in Japan or in Indian mills, and what I have bought from Swaraj Ashram has warp made of mill yarn.
('32', 367, 3, 12, 863494) This letter raises two important points.
('32', 367, 3, 13, 863535) One is whether there is any use in occasional use of khaddar.
('32', 367, 3, 14, 863597) On the principle that something is better than nothing even an occasional use of khaddar is to be encouraged.
('32', 367, 3, 15, 863707) We want to sell home made, home woven, and home spun cloth.
('32', 367, 3, 16, 863767) Any demand for such cloth is, therefore, welcome and those who make occasional use are likely to make even habitual use of khaddar.
('32', 367, 3, 17, 863899) I would, therefore, encourage its use of every occasion.
('32', 367, 3, 18, 863956) Nor can I endorse the remark that those who wear khaddar on particular occasions are necessarily hypocrites.
('32', 367, 3, 19, 864065) If a man pretends to be what he is not, he is a hypocrite, not one who makes no such pretences.
('32', 367, 3, 20, 864161) One who drinks secretly and makes his neighbour believe that he is a teetotaller is a hypocrite to be shunned.
('32', 367, 3, 21, 864272) A man who makes no secret of his habit of drinking, but omits drinking in society, or out of regard for his friends, is not only not a hypocrite, but a sensible and considerate man, and there is every hope of his being weaned from his habit.
('32', 367, 3, 22, 864514) If, therefore, the people of Purulia, who are reported to be buying khaddar in view of my forthcoming visit, are doing so in order to induce the belief in me that they have never worn any other cloth, they are undoubtedly hypocrites.
('32', 367, 3, 23, 864748) But I do not believe that they are buying khaddar with any such unholy design.
('32', 367, 3, 24, 864827) It is no secret to me that a vast number of people have not yet given up the habit of using mill made cloth, foreign or indigenous.
('32', 367, 3, 25, 864959) But they do not mind using khaddar occasionally, and, since it has now become the Congress dress, people who attend Congress functions even occasionally consider it proper to wear khaddar.
('32', 367, 3, 26, 865148) Whilst, therefore, I should like all
('32', 368, 0, 1, 865185) VOL.32 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 369
('32', 368, 1, 2, 865229) those in Bihar who are buying khaddar to enable them to appear at Congress functions during my tour, to wear it habitually, I am unable to condemn its use for the occasion of my tour.
('32', 368, 1, 3, 865413) It is some gain, be it ever so small, that the surplus khaddar stock in Bihar will be used up and so much money freed for manufacture of more khaddar.
('32', 368, 1, 4, 865564) The second point raised by the correspondent is serious.
('32', 368, 1, 5, 865621) The only way to avoid fraudulent imitations is for purchasers to ensure the purity of their purchases.
('32', 368, 1, 6, 865724) Congress organizations, or khaddar organizations can do a great deal to prevent, or, at any rate, to check the evil.
('32', 368, 1, 7, 865841) The correspondent states khaddar stores should be run by the Congress in all principal centres.
('32', 368, 1, 8, 865937) Some such thing has been attempted, but it is a matter of finance and organization.

('32', 368, 1, 10, 866120) Meanwhile I would urge writers like my correspondent not to give up khaddar for want of facility.
('32', 368, 1, 11, 866218) It is because the successful organizing of khaddar and the spinning wheel means the evoking of all that is best in us that I often say that the adoption of the spinning wheel will lead to swaraj.
('32', 368, 2, 12, 866414) HALF KHADDAR
('32', 368, 3, 13, 866427) The correspondent also deals with the evil of half khaddar being manufactured and sold by Congress organizations.
('32', 368, 3, 14, 866541) The evil is serious enough.
('32', 368, 3, 15, 866569) A Congress organization, which is pledged to sell khaddar, can have nothing to do with half khaddar.
('32', 368, 3, 16, 866670) So long as Congressmen do not see the simple truth that manufacture of half khaddar prevents the evolution of hand spun yarn, spinning will be done indifferently.
('32', 368, 3, 17, 866833) To subject hand spun yarn to the test of the loom by using it for the warp is the surest and the quickest way of improving the quality of hand spun yarn.
('32', 368, 3, 18, 866987) It is a superstition to believe that by and by one would be able to displace mill yarn from warp.
('32', 368, 3, 19, 867085) The difficulty will have to be faced one day.
('32', 368, 3, 20, 867131) It has already been faced by several Congress organizations.
('32', 368, 3, 21, 867192) There is no difficulty about getting hand spun yarn woven, if not in the district of its production, in some other district.
('32', 368, 3, 22, 867317) I wish, therefore, that Congress organizations should cease to weave or deal in half khaddar.

('32', 369, 2, 10, 869059) SPINNING AT A GOVERNMENT INSTITUTE There is at Serampore a weaving institute run by the Government of Bengal, through its Department of Industries, where hand spinning is being systematically taught.
('32', 369, 2, 11, 869259) I was curious to know its progress and the methods of instruction.
('32', 369, 2, 12, 869326) I, therefore, applied for permission to visit the institute which was readily granted.
('32', 369, 2, 13, 869413) Mr. Hoogwerf showed me round.
('32', 369, 2, 14, 869443) There was hand weaving, dyeing, and spinning not restricted to cotton only, but extended to jute, silk, etc.
('32', 369, 2, 15, 869552) I propose, however, to confine my attention to cotton spinning only.
('32', 369, 2, 16, 869621) I appreciated the anxiety of the staff about it, but I discovered at once that there was not that technical ability and guidance which one would expect in a teaching institution.
('32', 369, 2, 17, 869800) I had gone there to find a spinning expert with faith in hand spinning.
('32', 369, 2, 18, 869872) I had expected to find also up to date spinning wheels.
('32', 369, 2, 19, 869928) I say this not by way of idle criticism, but in the hope of definite improvement taking place in the near future.
('32', 369, 2, 20, 870042) Some of the spinning wheels I saw there were indifferently made and open to the same objections which I have raised in these columns to many specimens I saw during my tour.
('32', 369, 2, 21, 870215) Some of them
('32', 370, 0, 1, 870228) VOL.32 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 371
('32', 370, 1, 2, 870272) even created a jarring sound.
('32', 370, 1, 3, 870302) The slivers were also not of the best.
('32', 370, 1, 4, 870341) Under the circumstances I should not at all wonder if in a short time one finds a report to the effect that the experiment in hand spinning was a failure.
('32', 370, 1, 5, 870496) Any experiment, before it can be pronounced a failure, must be given the fairest chance.
('32', 370, 1, 6, 870585) It must, therefore, be conducted by one who has faith in it, and the requisite ability.
('32', 370, 1, 7, 870673) There is, I understand, a desire to introduce instruction in power loom weaving also at the Institute.
('32', 370, 1, 8, 870776) As it is, the Institute is living on starvation wages.
('32', 370, 1, 9, 870831) It is intended to promote cottage industries.
('32', 370, 1, 10, 870877) In my opinion, the introduction of the power loom will be a waste of public money, and I say this not because of my disbelief in power looms, but because it dos not promote the object for which the Institute has been founded.
('32', 370, 1, 11, 871103) Every rupee voted for its management must be devoted to the development of cottage industries, and, therefore, all the activities of the Institute should be devoted to the exploration of possibilities of hand spinning, and the antecedent processes and instruction therein.
('32', 370, 1, 12, 871376) One thing I noticed in the Institute which can be copied by all national institutions where hand spinning is taught and developed.
('32', 370, 1, 13, 871507) Mr. Hoogwerf took me to his home which contains testing instruments for testing the strength and the count of yarn, its evenness, the staple of cotton and the durability of cloth when it is woven.
('32', 370, 1, 14, 871704) If some of these simple instruments are kept in national institutions and judiciously used, they will help spinners to make rapid progress and to check their spinning.

('32', 370, 1, 16, 871990) It is really a home for girls to which a missionary lady has devoted herself.
('32', 370, 1, 17, 872068) There, too, hand spinning is one of the things taught.
('32', 370, 1, 18, 872123) But my criticism applies equally to this home.
('32', 370, 1, 19, 872170) The superintendent, in spite of all her will to make it a success, cannot do so, until she herself learns the art, so as to enable her to know a good wheel from a bad [one] and to know when spinning is done properly.
('32', 370, 2, 20, 872387) Young India.
('32', 370, 2, 21, 872400) 3 9 1925
('32', 370, 3, 22, 872409) 231. WHAT OF THE WEST?
('32', 370, 4, 23, 872432) A European friend thus writes:
('32', 370, 5, 24, 872463) What can be done, what would you suggest that could be tried in favour of the starving millions of the West?
('32', 370, 5, 25, 872572) By starving millions I mean the masses of the European and American proletariat who are being driven to the
('32', 371, 0, 1, 872680) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 371, 1, 2, 872722) abyss, who live a life not worth the name, full of the direst privations, who can nourish no dream of future relief by any form of swaraj, who are perhaps more hopeless than the millions of India because the faith in God, the consolation of religion, has left them to be replaced by nothing but hatred.
('32', 371, 2, 3, 873025) The iron hands which press down the Indian nation are at work there also.
('32', 371, 2, 4, 873099) the devilish system is at work in each of these independent countries; politics do not count as there is a close solidarity of greed.
('32', 371, 2, 5, 873233) Vice is devastating these masses who natually try to escape the hell of their life at any cost, at the cost of making it a greater hell, and who have no longer the outlet of religious hopes, as Christianity by siding for centuries with the powerful and the greedy has lost all credit.
('32', 371, 3, 6, 873518) Of course, I expect Mahatmaji to answer that the only way to salvation for these masses, if there is any left, if the whole Western world is not already doomed, lies in the application of a disciplined non violent resistance carried on, on a large scale.
('32', 371, 3, 7, 873773) But there are no traditions of ahimsa in the European soil and mind.
('32', 371, 3, 8, 873842) Even the spreading of the doctrine would encounter huge difficulties, what about its right understanding and application!
('32', 371, 3, 9, 873964) The problem underlying the question so sincerely put by the friend lies outside my orbit.
('32', 371, 3, 10, 874054) I, therefore, attempt an answer merely in courteous recognition of friendship between the questioner and myself.
('32', 371, 3, 11, 874167) I confess that no value attaches to my answer, save what we attach to every considered argument.
('32', 371, 3, 12, 874264) I know neither the diagnosis of the European disease nor the remedy in the same sense that I claim to know both in the case of India.
('32', 371, 3, 13, 874398) I, however, feel that fundamentally the disease is the same in Europe as it is in India, in spite of the fact that in the former country the people enjoy political self government, No mere transference of political power in India will satisfy my ambition, even though I hold such transference to be a vital necessity of Indian national life.
('32', 371, 3, 14, 874740) The peoples of Europe have no doubt political power but no swaraj.
('32', 371, 3, 15, 874807) Asian and African races are exploited for their partial benefit, and they, on their part, are being exploited by the ruling class or caste under the sacred name of democracy.
('32', 371, 3, 16, 874982) At the root, therefore, the disease appears to be the same as in India.
('32', 371, 3, 17, 875054) The same remedy is, therefore, likely to be applicable.
('32', 371, 3, 18, 875110) Shorn of all the camouflage, the exploitation of the masses of Europe is sustained by violence.
('32', 371, 3, 19, 875206) Violence on the part of the masses will never remove the disease.
('32', 371, 3, 20, 875272) Anyway, up to now experience shows that success of violence has
('32', 372, 0, 1, 875336) VOL.32 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 373
('32', 372, 1, 2, 875380) been short lived.
('32', 372, 1, 3, 875398) It has led to greater violence.
('32', 372, 1, 4, 875430) What has been tried hitherto has been a variety of violence and artificial checks dependent mainly upon the will of the violent.
('32', 372, 1, 5, 875559) At the crucial moment these checks have naturally broken down.
('32', 372, 1, 6, 875622) It seems to me, therefore, that sooner or later, the European masses will have to take to non violence if they are to find their deliverance.
('32', 372, 1, 7, 875764) That there is no hope of their taking to it in a body and at once does not baffle me.
('32', 372, 1, 8, 875850) A few thousand years are but a speck in the vast time circle.
('32', 372, 1, 9, 875912) Someone has to make a beginning with a faith that will not flinch.
('32', 372, 1, 10, 875979) I doubt not that the masses, even of Europe, will respond, but what is more emergent in point of time is not so much a large experiment in non violence as a precise grasp of the meaning of deliverance.
('32', 372, 1, 11, 876181) From what will the masses be delivered?
('32', 372, 1, 12, 876221) It will not do to have vague generalization and to answer “from exploitation and degradation”.
('32', 372, 1, 13, 876316) Is not the answer this that they want to occupy the status that capital does today?
('32', 372, 1, 14, 876400) If so, it can be attained only by violence.
('32', 372, 1, 15, 876444) But if they want to shun the evils of capital, in other words, if they would revise the viewpoint of capital, they would strive to attain a juster distribution of the products of labour.
('32', 372, 1, 16, 876631) This immediately takes us to contentment and simplicity, voluntarily adopted.
('32', 372, 1, 17, 876709) Under the new outlook multiplicity of material wants will not be the aim of life, the aim will be rather their restriction consistently with comfort.
('32', 372, 1, 18, 876859) We shall cease to think of getting what we can, but we shall decline to receive what all cannot get.
('32', 372, 1, 19, 876960) It occurs to me that it ought not to be difficult to make a successful appeal to the masses of Europe in terms of economics, and a fairly successful working of such an experiment must lead to immense and unconscious spiritual results.
('32', 372, 1, 20, 877195) I do not believe that the spiritual law works on a field of its own.
('32', 372, 1, 21, 877264) On the contrary, it expresses itself only through the ordinary activities of life.
('32', 372, 1, 22, 877347) It thus affects the economic, the social, and the political fields.
('32', 372, 1, 23, 877415) If the masses of Europe can be persuaded to adopt the view I have suggested, it will be found that violence will be wholly unnecessary to attain the aim and they can easily come to their own by following out the obvious corollaries of non violence.
('32', 372, 1, 24, 877664) It may even be that what seems to me to be so natural and feasible for India, may take longer to permeate the inert Indian masses than the active European masses.
('32', 372, 1, 25, 877827) But I must reiterate my confession that all my argument is based on suppositions and assumptions and must, therefore, be taken for what it is worth.
('32', 372, 1, 26, 877976) Young India, 3 9 1925
('32', 373, 0, 1, 877998) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 373, 1, 2, 878040) 232. INDIA AND SOUTH AFRICA
('32', 373, 2, 3, 878068) The following cable has been received by me from Mr. Amed Bhayat, President of a mass meeting of Indians held in Durban:
('32', 373, 3, 4, 878189) The Asiatic Bill 1 in the Union Parliament is far reaching in its results.
('32', 373, 3, 5, 878264) It is inequitous and disastrous to Indian interests and is deliberate violation of Gandhi Smuts understanding to recognize vested interests.
('32', 373, 3, 6, 878405) The Bill provides for allocating residential and trading areas only within which Indians may buy and lease property.
('32', 373, 3, 7, 878522) In rural districts Indians will be confined to thirty miles from the coast line wherein areas may be defined.
('32', 373, 3, 8, 878632) The result will be that the business of thousands of Indians must cease on the expiry of present leases.
('32', 373, 3, 9, 878737) It amounts to compulsory segregation, deliberate deprivation of Indian property.
('32', 373, 3, 10, 878818) Ultimate aim is apparently repatriation and confiscation of rights.
('32', 373, 3, 11, 878886) The right of bona fide Indians to enter the Union is seriously jeopardized.
('32', 373, 4, 12, 878962) Many provisions of the Bill will enable the Government to declare Indians as prohibited immigrants and domicile rights will be practically forfeited.
('32', 373, 4, 13, 879112) Mere absence over three years causes forfeiture.
('32', 373, 4, 14, 879161) The wives and children of domiciled Indians cannot enter the Union after five years from August 1925. Thousands of ex indentured Indians who are now for thirty years here and their descendants may be declared prohibited immigrants and cannot claim domicile.
('32', 373, 4, 15, 879419) South African born Indians domiciled in one province of the Union must return to the province of their birth, and there also into segregated areas.
('32', 373, 4, 16, 879567) Indians born here could also be declared prohibited immigrants if unsuitable to the requirements of the Union .
('32', 373, 4, 17, 879679) Such prohibited Indians will lose all property and vested rights in the Union and be driven away.
('32', 373, 4, 18, 879777) Protest mass meeting Natal Indians been called for 31st in Durban.
('32', 373, 4, 19, 879844) We rely upon you for creating strong influential public opinion so that the Indian Government may be roused into determined action to protect us.
('32', 373, 4, 20, 879990) Affront to Indian nation must be met with dignified protests from India.
('32', 373, 4, 21, 880063) The insult is gratuitous and we resent same in a most strenuous and emphatic manner.
('32', 373, 4, 22, 880148) We implore you to press Indian Government to give immediate public expression to its attitude as supineness may be misunderstood by all concerned.
('32', 373, 4, 23, 880295) Although it has been published in the Press, it can bear repetition here.
('32', 373, 4, 24, 880369) I have also received a copy of the Gazette containing the full text of the Bill.
('32', 373, 4, 25, 880450) It is a long Bill divided into three chapters, containing 27 sections and a schedule.
('32', 373, 4, 26, 880536) It occupies 9 foolscap sides
('32', 373, 5, 27, 880565) 1 The Areas Reservation and Immigration and Registration (Further Provision) Bill, introduced in the Union Parliament in July 1925. The Bill was intended to prevent the acquisition of land by Asiatics save in certain specified areas.
('32', 374, 0, 1, 880799) VOL.32 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 375
('32', 374, 1, 2, 880843) closely printed.
('32', 374, 1, 3, 880860) I do not print the Bill, as without the aid of previous enactments with which it deals and which it modifies or repeals, it is not capable of being undrstood by the reader.
('32', 374, 1, 4, 881033) Suffice it to observe here that the cablegram faithfully summarizes the restrictions sought to be imposed by the Bill.
('32', 374, 1, 5, 881152) It reduces the position of the resident Indian population to such an extent that, without the Union Government having to pay any compensation whatsoever, there will be no Indian settlers in South Africa within a few years’ time.
('32', 374, 1, 6, 881381) If the provisions of the Bill are applied with enough stringency, there will be powers given to the administration to freeze out every Indian, no matter what the step may be, in the land of his adoption and even of his birth, for the Bill makes no distinction between Indians born in South Africa and domiciled.
('32', 374, 1, 7, 881693) The safeguards provided by the Bill are all illusory and can be rendered perfectly nugatory.
('32', 374, 1, 8, 881786) That the Bill has not yet become law is a matter of little comfort.
('32', 374, 1, 9, 881854) The Bill is an indication of the determination of the Union Government to starve the Indians out of South Africa.
('32', 374, 1, 10, 881968) Mr. Malan has made no secret of it.
('32', 374, 1, 11, 882004) It is a matter of time when every Indian will have left South Africa.
('32', 374, 1, 12, 882074) Let the reader remember, or know, that the Chinese labourers who were imported for developing the gold mines of Johannesburg, were summarily repatriated when the Government had made up its mind.
('32', 374, 1, 13, 882269) The Chinese had no voice.
('32', 374, 1, 14, 882295) So it will be with Indians unless the Government of India choose to do its duty.
('32', 374, 1, 15, 882376) Mr. Bhayat has made a pathetic appeal to us here.
('32', 374, 1, 16, 882426) So far as public opinion is concerned, it is unanimously for the Indian settlers.
('32', 374, 1, 17, 882508) Unfortunately for them, it is at present ineffective.
('32', 374, 1, 18, 882562) Such as it is, it will certainly be mobilized for the purpose of preventing the impending spoliation of our countrymen in South Africa in total disregard of the Agreement of 1914, which was designed to guarantee the then existing rights of the Indian residents in South Africa.

('32', 377, 1, 2, 887555) 236. INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('32', 377, 2, 3, 887596) [September 3, 1925]
('32', 377, 3, 4, 887616) Mahatma Gandhi arrived in Bombay yesterday.
('32', 377, 3, 5, 887660) On his arrival at the Victoria Terminus station in the morning he was received by Mrs. Sarojini Naidu and several other friends.
('32', 377, 3, 6, 887789) He is staying in Revashanker Jagjivans's house, Laburnum Road, Gamdevi, his usual Bombay residence.
('32', 377, 3, 7, 887889) Knowing that he would soon be caught up in the maze of engagements that have been fixed for him even in advance of his arrival, a representative of The Chronicle sought an interview with him soon after his arrival
('32', 377, 4, 8, 888103) at his residence.
('32', 377, 4, 9, 888121) Gandhiji readily consented to give one, though visitors had already begun to call.
('32', 377, 4, 10, 888204) He had a slightly tired look but otherwise was as cheery and fit as ever.
('32', 377, 5, 11, 888278) Our representative began by asking about Gandhiji’s outstanding impressions of his Bengal tour and he replied that so far as khaddar was concerned, the thing that counted most, the province in general showed as much enthusiasm for khaddar and as much disposition to work out the programme as any other province.
('32', 377, 5, 12, 888590) It might even do more.
('32', 377, 5, 13, 888613) Asked what advice he had given or would give to the Bengal Swarajists with regard to the policy in the Legislative Council, he replied that he had only advised them to follow the lead of Pandit Motilal Nehru.
('32', 377, 5, 14, 888822) Gandhiji had by now taken out his twirligig 1 and begun plying it.
('32', 377, 6, 15, 888889) “What remedy would you suggest against the prevailing stagnation in the country?” was the next question.
('32', 377, 6, 16, 888994) He fixed a fond look on the twirligig, drew out a fine long thread, and said with a beaming smile: Well, I have already prescribed my remedy.
('32', 377, 6, 17, 889136) Spin, spin, spin, till stagnation vanishes.
('32', 377, 6, 18, 889180) That is my remedy and it holds the field till another or an alternative remedy is suggested and a case made out for it.
('32', 377, 7, 19, 889300) Our representative pointed out that village panchayats were being suggested in several places, especially in Maharashtra and also co operative societies for khaddar work as adjuncts for village organizations.
('32', 377, 7, 20, 889509) Gandhiji said: They are all right where they can properly be worked out in a spirit of absolute self reliance.
('32', 377, 7, 21, 889620) Where this spirit prevails, I would welcome almost any organization as better than none, but I fear that in many cases these institutions might turn out to be additional instruments to accustom people to lean on officials or their agents.
('32', 377, 7, 22, 889859) What we want to unite and vitalize the whole nation is a common industry which all can carry on entirely by themselves.
('32', 377, 7, 23, 889979) Universal spinning is the thing.
('32', 377, 8, 24, 890012) 1 The takli or spindle like contrivance for spinning
('32', 378, 0, 1, 890065) VOL.32 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 379
('32', 378, 1, 2, 890109) “Do you see any signs , even if stray, of the Hindu Muslim tension easing?” he was asked next.
('32', 378, 1, 3, 890204) He said gravely: No, it is growing worse, but only to grow better.
('32', 378, 1, 4, 890271) I fear the growing tension may end in an explosion, though we shall try to make it as little violent as possible.
('32', 378, 1, 5, 890385) But with the reaction following, the two communities must coalesce, and absorption in common constructive work can keep down the violence of the explosion and will further cement the union when it comes.
('32', 378, 2, 6, 890589) “What reply would you have the Congress give to Lord Birkenhead?” The prompt reply was: More work and more briskly on the lines I have already suggested.
('32', 378, 3, 7, 890743) “May we not,” our representative asked, “take him at his word in a sporting mood and spring a swaraj scheme upon him?” If the offer were made in a genuine sporting mood we could accept it so, but, in the absence of any actual signs of a change of heart on his part, I only fear that the offer to consider any scheme prepared by us may turn out to be a trap.
('32', 378, 3, 8, 891101) I would not walk into it.
('32', 378, 4, 9, 891127) Asked if he would not convene a representative leaders’ conference to re explore the avenues to the unity of all parties, he replied: I have answered this question several days ago.
('32', 378, 4, 10, 891309) I am also referring to the topic in today’s Young India.
('32', 378, 4, 11, 891366) Informal attempts are being made but the time for a formal conference is not yet.
('32', 378, 4, 12, 891448) At present almost each party wants unity, no doubt, but unity on its own terms.
('32', 378, 4, 13, 891528) No conference can succeed under these circumstances.
('32', 378, 4, 14, 891581) As soon as I see any general disposition to subordinate one’s individual or party views to the present needs of the country, I shall be the first to call such a conference.
('32', 378, 4, 15, 891754) The Bombay Chronicle, 4 9 1925
('32', 378, 5, 16, 891785) 237. MESSAGE ON CENTENARY OF DADABHAI NAOROJI
('32', 378, 6, 17, 891831) Dadabhai justly earned the affectionate title of the G.O.M. of India.
('32', 378, 6, 18, 891901) Was it not he who first introduced us to the problem of the deep poverty of the masses?
('32', 378, 6, 19, 891989) In discovering the growing poverty of the masses Dadabhai put his finger upon the root evil of the present system of Government.
('32', 378, 6, 20, 892118) In my opinion, therefore, the best way we can celebrate the forthcoming Centenary is to do something tangible for dealing with the problem of poverty.
('32', 378, 6, 21, 892269) It cannot be dealt with
('32', 379, 0, 1, 892293) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 379, 1, 2, 892335) satisfactorily save through the universal adoption of spinning wheel and khaddar.
('32', 379, 1, 3, 892417) Hence it is that I have unhesitatingly recommended the celebration of the Centenary by making collections for khaddar and charkha, by holding khaddar exhibitions, by hawking khaddar and in every becoming manner pushing forward the cause of khaddar and the spinning wheel, in other words the cause of the millions.

('32', 379, 2, 5, 892762) 238. INTERVIEW TO “FORWARD” 1
('32', 379, 3, 6, 892792) BOMBAY, September 4, 1925
('32', 379, 4, 7, 892818) A glowing tribute to Bengal and the Swaraj Party was paid by Mahatma Gandhi in course of a special interview for Forward which I had this morning.
('32', 379, 4, 8, 892965) Questioned whether the Swaraj Party had been weakened by Deshbandhu’s death, Mahatmaji replied: Any party, any institution must be weakened after Deshbandhu’s death.
('32', 379, 4, 9, 893131) But that in no sense means that the Party will break up.
('32', 379, 4, 10, 893188) On the contrary up to now the Party has been exceptionally loyal to the memory of Deshbandhu and has to the best of its ability carried out his wishes.
('32', 379, 5, 11, 893340) Has the resignation of Dr. Suhrawardy had any adverse effect on the Party?
('32', 379, 5, 12, 893415) Personally, I do not see.
('32', 379, 6, 13, 893441) In your opinion, Mahatmaji, are the election of Mr. Patel 2 as President of the Assembly and Panditji’s acceptance of a seat on the Skeen Committee 3 consistent
('32', 379, 7, 14, 893602) with the Swaraj Party’s principles?
('32', 379, 7, 15, 893638) I see no inconsistency in either of these things.
('32', 379, 7, 16, 893688) Any party which is growing in strength or wants to grow in strength must adapt itself to the circumstances.
('32', 379, 7, 17, 893796) I think the acceptance by Panditji of a seat on the Skeen Committee and the election of Mr. Patel were fine strokes.
('32', 379, 7, 18, 893913) Forward, 5 9 1925
('32', 379, 8, 19, 893931) 1 Some of the questions and answers occurring in this report are the same as those in “Interview to The Bombay Chronicle”, 3 9 1925, and are not being reproduced here.

('32', 380, 1, 2, 894425) 239. SPEECH AT DADABHAI NAOROJI CENTENARY MEETING, BOMBAY 1
('32', 380, 2, 3, 894485) September 4, 1925
('32', 380, 3, 4, 894503) Mahatma Gandhi said he was a real worshipper of Dadabhai Naoroji, the Dada of India.
('32', 380, 3, 5, 894588) Any man or woman who did his or her duty and died in the performance of it, the name of such a person would never die.
('32', 380, 3, 6, 894707) Dadabhai was with them in spirit, although he was not there in his physical body and his sweet voice could not be heard by them any more.
('32', 380, 3, 7, 894845) The passage of time had merely made Dadabhai’s name dearer to them and it was more deeply engraved on their hearts.
('32', 380, 3, 8, 894961) It was in 1888 that he had occasion to sit at the feet of Dadabhai and, although he was not reading newspapers then—in the same way as he was not reading them now—he had heard the name of Dadabhai.
('32', 380, 3, 9, 895159) A Deccani gentleman gave him a letter of introduction to Dadabhai, although he was not acquainted with him and, when he took it to him in England, although Dadabhai did not know the writer of the letter, he took him (Gandhiji) to his heart and said: If you are ever in any difficulty come to me.
('32', 380, 3, 10, 895455) Dadabhai was living in England not to enjoy life, or play any games or to go to the theatre, but to serve India.
('32', 380, 3, 11, 895568) He there had a large number of Indian students under his care, to whom he acted guardian, but had he done only that he would never have been remembered by Indians.
('32', 380, 3, 12, 895732) .Although Dadabhai had never been into the villages, yet his heart was so big that it found room for the poor villager.
('32', 380, 3, 13, 895852) He not only had a heart big enough to include all the Indian communities, but even the poorest of the poor were remembered by him.
('32', 380, 3, 14, 895983) He knew that the poor villagers were dumb and he wanted to make their voice heard by the rulers of this land.
('32', 380, 3, 15, 896093) He knew that the villagers could not get even one square meal a day, not to speak of such luxuries as ghee and milk.
('32', 380, 3, 16, 896210) And what Dadabhai had said 30 or 40 years ago was true even to this day.
('32', 380, 3, 17, 896283) Dadabhai knew that, so long as a majority of Indians were skeletons and were mere bags of bones, they could not achieve anything.
('32', 380, 3, 18, 896413) In England Dadabhai had a small office room for doing his work and he lived there like an ascetic serving the cause of India.
('32', 380, 3, 19, 896539) The speaker said he was a true worshipper of Dadabhai and it did not matter to him even if his idol had blemishes.
('32', 380, 3, 20, 896654) The audience that night had come to that meeting to worship Dadabhai, but how many of them were actuated by a sincere desire to do so?
('32', 380, 3, 21, 896789) Dadabhai had taught him two things: that he must give his idol his fullest love and worship without any reservation and that, if he wanted to serve India, he must serve the poor.
('32', 380, 3, 22, 896968) Gandhiji said he could only serve the poor by becoming the very poorest of the poor, the meanest of the mean by becoming a Hindu, a Muslim and a Parsi, for to Dadabhai all Indians were alike.
('32', 380, 3, 23, 897160) Although Dadabhai was staunch Zoroastrian, he never disliked the other

('32', 381, 1, 2, 897459) communities.

('32', 381, 2, 12, 898422) 240. COW PROTECTION
('32', 381, 3, 13, 898442) The more I study the problem of protecting cows, the more I realize its importance.
('32', 381, 3, 14, 898526) This problem will become increasingly serious in India, since it involves the economic well being of the country.
('32', 381, 3, 15, 898640) I believe that from its very nature religion embraces economic, political and other problems.
('32', 381, 3, 16, 898734) The religion which is opposed to true economics is no religion, nor that which is opposed to true politics.
('32', 381, 3, 17, 898842) Economics devoid of religion should be shunned, and political power uninformed with the spirit of religion is Satanic.
('32', 381, 3, 18, 898961) There is no such thing as dharma unrelated to economic and other activities.
('32', 381, 3, 19, 899038) Individuals and society, both survive through dharma and perish without it.
('32', 381, 3, 20, 899114) Accumulation of wealth, that is commerce, through truthful means fosters the growth of society, but commerce carried on without any regard for truth destroys it.
('32', 381, 3, 21, 899276) Many instances can be cited to show that what is gained through falsehood, through dishonest and devious means is but shortlived and proves harmful in the end.
('32', 381, 3, 22, 899436) Hence, while discussing our duty to protect cows we must consider its economic aspect as well.
('32', 381, 3, 23, 899531) If cow protection is opposed to true economics, we have no choice but to give up the effort.
('32', 381, 3, 24, 899624) Not only that, but we shall discover in that case that we cannot succeed in protecting cows even if we wish to do so.
('32', 381, 3, 25, 899742) It is because we have not even thought about the economic benefits of cow protection that, in a country where countless people regard the protection of the cow and her offspring as a sacred duty,
('32', 382, 0, 1, 899938) VOL.32 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 383
('32', 382, 1, 2, 899982) the latter starve.
('32', 382, 1, 3, 900001) We see them reduced to mere skin and bone, so much so that all their bones can be counted, and they are slaughtered only because of the indifference of Hindus.
('32', 382, 1, 4, 900161) Cow protection involves the very existence of Indian agriculture.
('32', 382, 1, 5, 900227) Cow slaughter would cease if every Hindu understood the economics of Cow protection.
('32', 382, 1, 6, 900312) The destruction of cows through the sheer stupidity of Hindus must be a hundred times greater than their slaughter in the name of religion.
('32', 382, 1, 7, 900452) So long as Hindus themselves do not understand the right method of protecting cows, not all the crores of rupees which they can spend will save the latter.
('32', 382, 1, 8, 900608) In Gujarat, Banias, Bhatias and Marwaris take interest in the cause of cow protection.
('32', 382, 1, 9, 900695) They spend large sums on it.
('32', 382, 1, 10, 900724) And even among them the Marwaris, especially, go to great lengths, Marwari business men run the largest number of goshalas in India.
('32', 382, 1, 11, 900857) They cheerfully contribute lakhs of rupees towards these and it is for this reason that I have said that the problem of protecting cows cannot be solved without the help of Marwaris.
('32', 382, 1, 12, 901040) I have often visited goshalas, but I cannot say that I saw any which was an ideal one.
('32', 382, 1, 13, 901127) These reflections were provoked by my visit to the goshala at Liluah in Calcutta.
('32', 382, 1, 14, 901209) Two and a half lakh rupees are spent on it every year, but the return is practically nil.
('32', 382, 1, 15, 901299) A goshala which gets two and a half lakh rupees every year should be able to save the lives of not less than 10,000 head of cattle in a year.
('32', 382, 1, 16, 901441) Even the cattle tended by this institution do not come to so many.
('32', 382, 1, 17, 901508) The organizers are not to be blamed for this, nor are they dishonest.
('32', 382, 1, 18, 901578) The secretary who took me round to show the institution is serving it to the best of his ability.
('32', 382, 1, 19, 901676) The system itself is to blame for this result.
('32', 382, 1, 20, 901723) We do not know how to run such institutions, and so the people do not derive the fullest benefit from them.
('32', 382, 1, 21, 901831) Practical ability is not considered necessary in matters concerning religion.
('32', 382, 1, 22, 901909) Such institutions are regarded as well run simply if those who manage them do not misappropriate funds.
('32', 382, 1, 23, 902013) In a business firm in which additional capital of two and a half lakh rupees is invested every year, the best available paid workers are employed, whereas in this case persons engaged in their own business spare some of their time as a social duty.
('32', 382, 1, 24, 902262) Those who do so deserve to be congratulated, but their work does not help the cause of cow protection.
('32', 382, 1, 25, 902365) This cause requires full time services of able and efficient persons.
('32', 382, 1, 26, 902435) Only men of spiritual knowledge who live a life of self denial
('32', 383, 0, 1, 902498) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('32', 383, 1, 4, 902822) All the moral rules which apply to business men also apply to charitable institutions.
('32', 383, 1, 5, 902909) if goshalas were run as commercial concerns, men with scientific knowledge of such matters would be working in them, and they would daily conduct new experiments and save the lives of more and more cows, would carry out many experiments about rearing cattle in goshalas and about ensuring the purity and increasing the quantity of milk.

('32', 387, 4, 19, 912904) 244. NOTES
('32', 387, 5, 20, 912915) A REMARKABLE RECORD
('32', 387, 6, 21, 912935) I have before me a brief and business like report of the remarkable work that is silently but most efficiently being done by the Labour Union managed under the gentle care of Shrimati Anasuyabai.
('32', 387, 6, 22, 913131) It deals with the educational work being done among the labourers.
('32', 387, 6, 23, 913198) In 1924 there were 8 day schools.
('32', 387, 6, 24, 913232) Today there are 9. Of these two are for all children, six for untouchables and one for Mussalmans.
('32', 387, 6, 25, 913331) There were 11 night schools in 1924. Today there are 15. Of these, 1 for all, 8 for untouchables, 5 for Mussalmans and 1 for Vaghris.
('32', 387, 6, 26, 913465) In 1924 there were 1,119 scholars and the attendance was 979.4. There were 692 untouchables, 221 touchables and 206 Mussalmans.
('32', 387, 6, 27, 913593) In the beginning of the year there were 1,166 scholars 798 being untouchables, 219 touchables and 169 Mussalmans and 60 Vaghris.
('32', 387, 6, 28, 913722) The attendance was 907 92. At the present moment there are 1,285.
('32', 387, 7, 29, 913788) 1 This is taken from Young India.
('32', 387, 7, 30, 913822) What follows is from The Bombay Chronicle.
('32', 388, 0, 1, 913865) VOL.32 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 389
('32', 388, 1, 2, 913909) The boys and girls learn all the subjects taught in the ordinary primary schools.
('32', 388, 1, 3, 913991) In addition they have hand spinning.
('32', 388, 1, 4, 914028) The management at first tried the wheels.
('32', 388, 1, 5, 914070) Among so many boys and girls, the wheels were found to be too expensive and inconvenient because of the space required.
('32', 388, 1, 6, 914190) They have, therefore taken up the takli which every scholar can possess.
('32', 388, 1, 7, 914263) It was a fine sight to see several hundred boys and girls spinning all at the same time.
('32', 388, 1, 8, 914352) Their average speed is 30 to 40 yards per hour each .
('32', 388, 1, 9, 914406) They have already spun 2 mds.
('32', 388, 1, 10, 914436) and 8 seers of good yarn.
('32', 388, 1, 11, 914462) There is also a residential school with 16 untouchable boys.
('32', 388, 1, 12, 914523) Of these 6 pay Rs.5 each towards boarding expenses.
('32', 388, 1, 13, 914575) The rest are free.

('32', 388, 2, 16, 914651) 1 4 mds.

('32', 389, 1, 2, 916115) IS IT OVER CONFIDENCE?
('32', 389, 1, 3, 916138) An esteemed friend, jealous of my reputation for correct conduct, asks how it is that I feel confident of my being right in my latest attitude of whole hearted support to the Swaraj Party.
('32', 389, 1, 4, 916327) Have I not made Himalayan blunders?
('32', 389, 1, 5, 916363) Do I not notice, the friend asks, that many of my No changer friends are bewildered over what to them appears to be my inconsistency?
('32', 389, 1, 6, 916497) Might I not be guilty of over confidence?
('32', 389, 1, 7, 916539) I do not think so.
('32', 389, 1, 8, 916558) For a man of truth must ever be confident, if he has also equal need to be diffident.
('32', 389, 1, 9, 916644) His devotion to truth demands the fullest confidence.
('32', 389, 1, 10, 916698) His consciousness of the fallibility of human nature must make him humble and therefore ever ready to retrace his steps immediately he discovers his error.
('32', 389, 1, 11, 916854) It makes no difference to his confidence that he had peviously made Himalayan blunders.
('32', 389, 1, 12, 916942) His confession and penance make him, if anything, stronger for future action.
('32', 389, 1, 13, 917020) Discovery of errors makes the votary of truth more cautious of believing things and forming things and forming conclusions, but once he has made up his mind, his conscience must remain unshaken.
('32', 389, 1, 14, 917215) His errors may result in men’s reliance upon his judgments being shaken, but he must not doubt the truth of his position once he has come to a conclusion.
('32', 389, 1, 15, 917370) It should further be borne in mind that my errors have been errors of calculation and judging men, not in appreciating the true nature of truth and ahimsa or in their application.
('32', 389, 1, 16, 917550) Indeed these errors and my prompt confessions have made me surer, if possible, of my insight into the implications of truth and ahimsa.
('32', 389, 1, 17, 917686) For I am convinced that my action in suspending civil disobedience at Ahmedabad, Bombay and Bardoli has advanced the cause of India’s freedom and world’s peace.
('32', 389, 1, 18, 917847) I am convinced that because of the suspensions we are nearer swaraj than we would have been without, and this I say in spite of despair being written in thick black letters on the horizon.
('32', 389, 1, 19, 918036) Such being my deep conviction, I cannot help being confident of my present position as regards Swarajists and other matters.
('32', 389, 1, 20, 918161) It is traceable to one source only, a lively understanding of the implications of truth and ahimsa.

('32', 390, 7, 14, 919536) The population of the village is 640. The cloth budget is estimated at Rs. 3,640. Therefore, when all the villagers are clothed in khaddar, they will add to their annual income Rs. 3,640 by simply using their waste moments.
