('32', 391, 3, 8, 921377) 247. ABOUT UNTOUCHABLES
('32', 391, 4, 9, 921401) T. N. Sarma of Andhra Desh came to me the other day at Calcutta and asked me certain questions regarding the difficulties found in the path of those who were serving the Panchamas.
('32', 391, 4, 10, 921582) 1 He has now reduced my answers to writing and sent them to me to correct and publish if possible.
('32', 391, 4, 11, 921681) As they are likely to help workers, I gladly find room for the questions and my answers.
('32', 391, 5, 12, 921770) 1. What methods do you suggest for the propaganda for the removal of untouchability?
('32', 391, 5, 13, 921855) Not much lip propaganda is necessary now.
('32', 391, 5, 14, 921897) Work is propaganda.
('32', 391, 5, 15, 921917) You should work fearlessly, unmindful of social ostracism, for bettering the condition of the untouchables.
('32', 391, 5, 16, 922025) Lectures may be arranged when leading men pay you a visit.
('32', 391, 6, 17, 922084) 2. There are two shades of opinion in our Andhra province, and a resolution was proposed to the effect that money should not be spent for the non Panchamas to do propaganda work.
('32', 391, 6, 18, 922263) Some people think that the Panchamas
('32', 391, 7, 19, 922300) should be educated first, and the demand for the removal should come from them, while others think that paid propaganda should be done among the higher classes to change their hearts, and to make them feel that untouchability is a sin, and pundits and workers should be appointed to do this work.
('32', 391, 7, 20, 922597) I would not spend even a single pie over the pundits.
('32', 391, 7, 21, 922651) if you pay them they become hirelings.
('32', 391, 7, 22, 922690) They must work for pay.
('32', 391, 7, 23, 922714) Money should be spent on the Panchamas to make them realize their own position.
('32', 391, 7, 24, 922794) Our methods should always be non violent.
('32', 391, 7, 25, 922836) Men of the so called higher classes must change their attitude, and remove the ban for their
('32', 391, 8, 26, 922929) 1 Castes regarded as untouchables

('32', 392, 1, 2, 923007) own elevation and purification.

('32', 392, 1, 4, 923200) I am trying my utmost to prevent such a catastrophe, and so must we all do who believe untouchability to be a sin.
('32', 392, 2, 5, 923315) 3. Do you think that schools started exclusively for the Panchamas will help
('32', 392, 3, 6, 923392) in any way in removing untouchability?
('32', 392, 3, 7, 923431) They must in the long run do so, as all education must.

('32', 392, 3, 13, 923793) Nobody can ask you to go away from your house.

('32', 392, 3, 15, 923908) Induce other boys to come and attend that school.

('32', 392, 4, 17, 924093) You may encourage them.
('32', 392, 4, 18, 924117) But you should not refuse help to schools or institutions where there are only untouchables.

('32', 395, 1, 4, 928770) He knew before he entered that town that Purulia was the place of rest for Deshbandhu.

('32', 395, 2, 9, 929244) his life.
('32', 395, 2, 10, 929254) He did not see any other method by which he could get rid of the poverty of India.
('32', 395, 2, 11, 929337) The poverty of Bihar was well known.
('32', 395, 2, 12, 929374) Barring Orissa and perhaps one or two more provinces, he thought Bihar was the poorest of all the provinces in the country.
('32', 395, 2, 13, 929498) There was a time when Bihar used to export to other places some very fine hand woven cloth made of hand spun.
('32', 395, 2, 14, 929608) Like Bengal, Bihar too was famous for production of fine cloth.
('32', 395, 2, 15, 929672) But today there were people in Bihar who did not know how to satisfy their hunger.
('32', 395, 2, 16, 929755) And for them there was no other course but to take to the charkha.
('32', 395, 2, 17, 929822) Today there were thousands of Biharis in Assam earning food in that province and at Calcutta.
('32', 395, 2, 18, 929916) It would not do for us to leave them there.
('32', 395, 2, 19, 929960) Man was not born only to amass money.
('32', 395, 2, 20, 929998) One who lost his soul did great harm to his soul.
('32', 395, 2, 21, 930048) They could know better than him about the character of those people living in Assam and in Calcutta.
('32', 395, 2, 22, 930149) But even if they left them out of consideration, there were lakhs of Biharis who did not know what was called two meals a day.
('32', 395, 2, 23, 930276) They did not know how to earn their livelihood.
('32', 395, 2, 24, 930324) I have become a Bihari from the date I began my work in Champaran.
('32', 395, 2, 25, 930391) If you do not know, I would like to tell you that there in Champaran women could hardly earn 5 pice a day.
('32', 395, 2, 26, 930498) For males 6 pice or two annas was considered to be too much.

('32', 395, 2, 28, 930671) Their condition today continues more or less the same as before.
('32', 395, 2, 29, 930736) But if the charkha was placed in their hands, what would be the result?
('32', 395, 2, 30, 930808) Let the economists judge for themselves.
('32', 395, 2, 31, 930849) But it lies in the hands of the educated people to revive it.
('32', 395, 3, 32, 930911) It was a fact that the masses followed the higher and the influential.
('32', 395, 3, 33, 930982) If they went to the villages, preached the charkha to them and plied the wheel themselves, it was only then they could evoke enthusiasm for the charkha among the villagers.
('32', 395, 3, 34, 931155) If they wanted Bihar to get rid of her poverty, if they wanted to give employment to the unemployed during the time of the flood, famine and other scourges of nature, then they must ply the charkha themselves and preach it to the people.
('32', 395, 3, 35, 931393) But that alone
('32', 395, 4, 36, 931408) 1 Gandhiji had earlier unveiled a portrait of C. R. Das, after the presentation of the addresses.

('32', 396, 1, 2, 931552) would not do.

('32', 396, 4, 16, 933036) 251. “WHAT SHOULD WE DO?”
('32', 396, 5, 17, 933062) Although I stayed in Gujarat for only five days 1, during that period I met co workers and came to know much through them.
('32', 396, 5, 18, 933185) I heard, too, about some serious matters.

('32', 396, 5, 21, 933333) Some co workers tell me that they do not get money from people in their districts.

('32', 405, 10, 15, 952644) THE INDIAN HERCULES AND BRAHMINS
('32', 405, 11, 16, 952677) I had a visit by appointment on the 8th instant during my brief stay at Sabarmati at 4 o’clock in the morning from the Indian Hercules, as Professor Rama Murti delights to describe himself.
('32', 405, 11, 17, 952867) He engaged me in an entertaining conversation on the wickedness of modern Brahmins and drew from me questions that seemed to give him full satisfaction, and there seemed to be, for the moment, a kinship between our non Brahmin souls and a vision was opened out before him of a non Brahmin war to the knife against the Brahmins who, as he said, after all represented but a microscopic minority.
('32', 405, 11, 18, 953261) After our conversation, the athletic Professor seriously

('32', 406, 1, 2, 953637) concerned himself about my bodily vigour and initiated me into the mysteries of ‘healthy mind in healthy body’.
('32', 406, 1, 3, 953749) He found in me a very willing convert.
('32', 406, 1, 4, 953788) The exercises which he gave me were delightful but I am inclined to think that they were a trifle too much for one like me who has passed the meridian of life.
('32', 406, 1, 5, 953948) He claimed for them a superiority over all the European methods, which certificate I heartily endorsed.
('32', 406, 1, 6, 954052) The exercises were nothing but a few Hatha Yoga practices.I commend them to all young men.
('32', 406, 1, 7, 954143) Pranayam has a great health giving value if practised under skilled supervision.
('32', 406, 1, 8, 954224) But let there be no self deception about it.
('32', 406, 1, 9, 954269) Those who practise these exercises should do so for the purpose of health and that only.
('32', 406, 1, 10, 954358) They have, no doubt, restricted spiritual value.
('32', 406, 1, 11, 954407) But I would strongly dissuade young men from going in for Hatha Yoga practices for spiritual regeneration.
('32', 406, 1, 12, 954514) In the present age such regeneration comes more from heart devotion than through physical practices.
('32', 406, 1, 13, 954615) And for acquiring spiritual merit through Hatha Yaga one needs a preceptor who is himself a spiritual adept through these practices.
('32', 406, 1, 14, 954748) I have searched for such and I have failed.
('32', 406, 1, 15, 954792) That does not necessarily mean that there are no pure Hatha Yogis in India, but where a diligent searcher like me has not succeeded, let young men beware of accepting claimants without severe examination.
('32', 406, 1, 16, 954997) But I have gone astray, I must redeem the promise I have made to the Professor when he sent me a digest of our political talk for revision that I would give the substance myself in these columns instead of revising his own reproduction which I received at a time when I had not a moment to spare.
('32', 406, 1, 17, 955294) He told me that, at Municipal and District Board elections, my name was being unlawfully exploited by those who described themselves as Congressmen or Swarajists and told me also that on that account I was losing my influence among the masses.
('32', 406, 1, 18, 955538) I informed him that I was not concerned with my influence and that I could not help if people made an unlawful use of my name.
('32', 406, 1, 19, 955665) But, retorted the Professor, could I not at least guide the voters by saying what I wanted them to do.
('32', 406, 1, 20, 955768) I told him that I had done so already on more occasions than one.
('32', 406, 1, 21, 955834) For me mere Congress label was of no avail.
('32', 406, 1, 22, 955878) I could only give my vote, if at all, to those who were Congressmen or Swarajists in reality and, therefore, I would give my vote to those who believed in the Congress creed, who habitually wore hand spun and hand woven khaddar, who believed in unity among all classes and, if Hindus, were active champions of the so called untouchables and believed that untouchability was an evil to be

('32', 407, 1, 2, 956308) removed without delay, who were total prohibitionists as to intoxicating drinks and drugs, and who otherwise conformed to the Congress resolutions.
('32', 407, 1, 3, 956456) If I found no such candidates, I would keep my vote with myself.
('32', 407, 1, 4, 956521) Not to give the vote is as much an exercise of the privilege of the voter as the giving of it.
('32', 407, 1, 5, 956616) The Professor then asked me for my definition of a Brahmin.
('32', 407, 1, 6, 956676) I told him that a Brahmin was one who sacrificed himself for his religion and his country and who accepted poverty as his happy lot in life for the sake of service.
('32', 407, 1, 7, 956841) “Are there any such Brahmins?” quickly asked the Professor.
('32', 407, 1, 8, 956901) “Not many,” I answered, “but more, perhaps, than you expect.”
('32', 407, 2, 9, 956963) HARSH V. PLEASANT TRUTH With reference to my removal of certain passages from a correspondent’s letter recently published, he thus complains:
('32', 407, 3, 10, 957105) In spite of the expurgation you have thought fit to effect in my letter, I may claim that in all my letters to you, especially where communal questions are involved, I have tried to observe not the ‘prudent’ maxim,
('32', 407, 4, 11, 957320) which means in brief ‘speak not the unpleasant truth’) although it be found in most of our received texts of Manu, but the saying of William Lloyd Garrison, the American slave liberator, which has stood for many years at the head of the Indian Social Reformer 1 of Bombay as its motto: I will be as harsh as truth, and as uncompromising as justice, etc.
('32', 407, 4, 12, 957674) I do not mind harsh truth but I do object to spiced truth.
('32', 407, 4, 13, 957733) Spicy language is as foreign to truth as hot chillies to a healthy stomach.
('32', 407, 4, 14, 957809) The passages removed by me were not necessary to elucidate the meaning of the correspondent or give point to it.
('32', 407, 4, 15, 957922) They were offensive without being useful or necessary.
('32', 407, 4, 16, 957977) There seems to be the fashion to think that, in order to be truthful, one must use harsh language; whereas truth suffers when it is harshly put.
('32', 407, 4, 17, 958122) It is like wanting to support strength; truth being itself fully strong is insulted when an attempt is made to support it with harshness.
('32', 407, 4, 18, 958260) I see no conflict between the Sanskrit text and Garrison’s motto quoted by the correspondent .
('32', 407, 4, 19, 958355) In my opinion, the Sanskrit text means that one should speak the truth in gentle language.
('32', 407, 4, 20, 958446) One had better not speak it if one cannot do so in a gentle way, meaning thereby that there is not truth in a man who cannot control his tongue.
('32', 407, 4, 21, 958591) In other words, truth without non violence is not truth but untruth.
('32', 407, 4, 22, 958660) Garrison’s motto requires to be interpreted in
('32', 407, 5, 23, 958707) 1 Weekly edited by K. Natarajan
('32', 408, 0, 1, 958739) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 409
('32', 408, 1, 2, 958785) terms of his own life.
('32', 408, 1, 3, 958808) He was one of the gentlest of men of his time.
('32', 408, 1, 4, 958855) Mark his language.
('32', 408, 1, 5, 958874) He will be as harsh as truth, but since truth to be truth is never harsh but always gentle and beneficial, the motto can only mean that Garrison would be as gentle as truth but no more.
('32', 408, 1, 6, 959060) Both the texts have relation to the inner state of the speaker or writer, not to the effect that will be produced upon those to whom the speech or the writing is addressed.
('32', 408, 1, 7, 959233) The Indian Social Reformer is rarely, if ever, harsh.
('32', 408, 1, 8, 959287) It tries to be fair though it often jumps to conclusions in a hurry and is obliged later to revise its estimate of men and things.
('32', 408, 1, 9, 959418) In these days of surrounding bitterness one cannot be too cautious.
('32', 408, 1, 10, 959486) After all who knows the absolute truth?
('32', 408, 1, 11, 959526) It is in ordinary affairs of life only a relative term.
('32', 408, 1, 12, 959582) What is truth to me is not necessarily truth to the rest of my companions.
('32', 408, 1, 13, 959657) We are all like the blind men who, on examining an elephant, gave different descriptions of the same animal according to the touch they were able to have of him.
('32', 408, 1, 14, 959819) And they were all, according to their own lights, in the right.
('32', 408, 1, 15, 959883) But we know also that they were all in the wrong.
('32', 408, 1, 16, 959933) Every one of them fell far short of the truth.
('32', 408, 1, 17, 959980) One cannot be too insistent therefore upon the necessity of guarding oneself against bitterness.
('32', 408, 1, 18, 960077) Bitterness blurs the vision and to that extent disables one from seeing even the limited truth that the physically blind men in the fable were able to do.
('32', 408, 2, 19, 960232) A STRING OF QUESTIONS
('32', 408, 3, 20, 960254) One of the best of national workers sends me questions for answers.
('32', 408, 3, 21, 960322) Here they are with answers:
('32', 408, 4, 22, 960350) You say we must help the Swaraj Party.
('32', 408, 4, 23, 960389) What is the meaning of this help?
('32', 408, 4, 24, 960423) My meaning is that everone should help this party to the best of his ability and as far as his conscience will permit.
('32', 408, 4, 25, 960542) Thus one who is inclined towards the Council programme and has no conscientious objections to it will join the Party.
('32', 408, 4, 26, 960660) One who has conscientious objections will refrain but, short of joining, give all the other help that he can.
('32', 408, 4, 27, 960770) He may object to vote also.
('32', 408, 4, 28, 960798) He will then refrain even from voting.
('32', 408, 4, 29, 960837) In no case will he vilify the Party.
('32', 408, 5, 30, 960874) Should young workers in the villages take part in the election turmoil and canvass for votes for the Swarajists?
('32', 408, 5, 31, 960987) I have not conceived that as possible except for Pro changers.
('32', 408, 5, 32, 961050) Those village workers who are, for instance, doing khaddar work, and who are not politically inclined will certainly not disturb themselves and their work to the extent contemplated in the question.
('32', 409, 0, 1, 961249) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 409, 1, 2, 961291) The Swarajists will want to capture village boards, municipalities, local boards, etc.
('32', 409, 1, 3, 961378) What are khadi workers to do?
('32', 409, 1, 4, 961408) I expect Swarajists also to be khadi workers.
('32', 409, 1, 5, 961454) The difference between them and No changers is that Swarajists add Council work to khadi work.
('32', 409, 1, 6, 961549) They, therefore, whilst remaining lovers of khadi, give the first place to Council work.
('32', 409, 1, 7, 961638) No changers have nothing but khadi and other constructive work to fall back upon.
('32', 409, 1, 8, 961720) Each may go his own way and each is expected to help the other to the best of his ability and conscience.
('32', 409, 2, 9, 961826) What is my position when there are Brahmin and Non Brahmin candidates,— one set opposing the other?
('32', 409, 2, 10, 961926) In such a case, if I were you, I would refrain from interfering except to remove strife and bitterness.
('32', 409, 3, 11, 962030) You have said not only should No changers refrain from opposition to the Swarajists but they should even help them.

('32', 410, 6, 9, 963984) 261. TO AMERICAN FRIENDS It is a privilege for me to enjoy the friendship of so many unknown American and European friends.
('32', 410, 6, 10, 964108) It pleases me to note that the circle is ever widening, perhaps more especially in America.
('32', 410, 6, 11, 964200) I had the pleasure of receiving a warm invitation about a year ago to visit that continent.
('32', 410, 6, 12, 964292) The same invitation has now been repeated with redoubled strength and with the offer to pay all expenses.
('32', 410, 6, 13, 964398) I was unable then as I am now, to respond to the kind invitation.
('32', 410, 6, 14, 964464) To accept it is an easy enough task, but I must resist the temptation, for I feel that I can make no effective appeal to the people of that great continent unless I make my position good with the intellectuals of India.
('32', 410, 6, 15, 964684) I have not a shadow of doubt about the truth of my fundamental position.
('32', 410, 6, 16, 964757) But I know that I am unable to carry with me the bulk of educated India.
('32', 410, 6, 17, 964830) I can therefore gain no effective help for my country from the Americans and Europeans so long as I remain isolated from educated India.
('32', 410, 6, 18, 964967) I do want to think in terms of the whole world.

('32', 410, 6, 20, 965070) Therefore, my service of India includes the service of humanity.
('32', 410, 6, 21, 965135) But I feel that I should be going out of my orbit if I left it for help from the West.

('32', 416, 1, 2, 978720) 262. AN INSTRUCTIVE TABLE
('32', 416, 2, 3, 978746) The following table prepared by the Provincial Congress Committee of Gujarat is a most instructive study:
('32', 416, 3, 4, 978852) Figures of the working of the franchise in Gujarat for the half year ended 31st August:
('32', 416, 4, 5, 978940) Members originally registered { A 2,215 B 365
('32', 416, 5, 6, 978986) Members who have paid full annual quota 266
('32', 416, 6, 7, 979030) Members who have paid 6 months’ quota 314
('32', 416, 7, 8, 979072) Irregular subscribers 1,273
('32', 416, 8, 9, 979100) Complete defaulters 727
('32', 416, 9, 10, 979124) Total yarn received in yards 15,83,000 Note: The table shows that out of a total of 2, 580 members who originally gave in their names only 580 are entitled to vote at the next A.I.C.C. elections.
('32', 416, 10, 11, 979320) The irregular subscribers have paid 6,750 thousand yards of yarn in 5,500 yards on an average instead of 12,000 yards that they should have paid.
('32', 416, 10, 12, 979466) These figures give one an idea of the work lying in front of us.
('32', 416, 10, 13, 979531) There is no lack of organization in Gujarat; no lack of khadi workers, but, strange as it may appear, less than one fourth of the number registered have actually carried out their obligation.
('32', 416, 10, 14, 979723) The figures need not disappoint any earnest worker who has faith in himself and his cause.
('32', 416, 10, 15, 979814) But he must not underrate the difficulties in his path.
('32', 416, 10, 16, 979870) We will not get swaraj without working for it.
('32', 416, 10, 17, 979917) Congressmen have got into the slovenly habit of making promises and straightway forgetting them, especially when it is a matter of giving any work.
('32', 416, 10, 18, 980065) In ordinary affairs of life we are made to fulfil the pledges we give.
('32', 416, 10, 19, 980136) A breach of promise to pay in a commercial transaction carries with it a penalty.
('32', 416, 10, 20, 980218) A voluntary promise made to a voluntary organization imposes in well organized societies a stricter obligation of the giver of the promise than a promise made in a commercial transaction.
('32', 416, 10, 21, 980406) Thus debts of honour have a prior claim for fulfilment than debts en forcible at law.
('32', 416, 10, 22, 980492) But somehow or other, Congress debts have not yet acquired any such sanctity as ordinary debts of honour.
('32', 416, 10, 23, 980598) Those who
('32', 417, 0, 1, 980608) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 417, 1, 2, 980650) have no faith in khadi will no doubt argue that the Gujarat figures are an eloquent testimony to the complete failure of the spinning franchise.
('32', 417, 1, 3, 980795) I should venture to join issue with such objectors.
('32', 417, 1, 4, 980847) The spinning franchise has enabled us to lay our finger on the weakest spot.
('32', 417, 1, 5, 980924) Let it be known that even the four anna franchise fared no better.
('32', 417, 1, 6, 980991) Those who registered their names once did not come the second time to pay of their own accord.
('32', 417, 1, 7, 981086) And had there been a monthly subscription we would have found almost as many defaulters as we have found among spinners.
('32', 417, 1, 8, 981207) But pecuniary obligation is a totally different proposition from the obligation to work from day to day.
('32', 417, 1, 9, 981312) Swaraj is not a pecuniary transaction.
('32', 417, 1, 10, 981351) It is not to be bought with money.
('32', 417, 1, 11, 981386) It has to be bought with solid, sustained, vigorous work.
('32', 417, 1, 12, 981444) And I venture to suggest that we would have noticed the same result, if, instead of spinning, the Congress had imposed the obligation to mend pencils for half an hour every day.
('32', 417, 1, 13, 981622) The lesson, therefore, that I draw from a study of these figures is that we must preserve along the same lines that we commenced at Belgaum if we are to make the Congress a working, effective and powerful organization.
('32', 417, 1, 14, 981841) In all probability compulsory spinning will be done away with, but if the Congress retains spinning as an alternative franchise, the effort to make it effective should in no way be relaxed.
('32', 417, 1, 15, 982031) Out of a population of three hundred millions, we should not have difficulty in finding a few lacs of men and women who would willingly and with unfailing regularity labour for the nation.
('32', 417, 1, 16, 982220) Spinning is the form chosen because of its great national value and its simplicity.
('32', 417, 1, 17, 982304) I have not burdened the reader with the detailed working of the franchise in the different districts of Gujarat.
('32', 417, 1, 18, 982417) The Provincial Congress Committee’s report does contain a detailed study.
('32', 417, 1, 19, 982491) The Committee’s organization is so thorough and so honest that, if the strength of the people is properly brought out, their weakness is never suppressed.
('32', 417, 1, 20, 982646) The detailed study shows that even the five hundred and forty members who are still paying their full quota are not distributed over all Gujarat.
('32', 417, 1, 21, 982792) But they are drawn from the five spinning organizations, for want of which there would not be even five hundred and forty members remaining.
('32', 417, 1, 22, 982933) Spinning organizations all over India are therefore a necessity, if voluntary spinning is to be universal.

('32', 421, 3, 7, 990825) At one of the meetings that I attended at Calcutta, I said that the first necessity for social service was character that, unless a man who aspires after social service has a character, to keep and to lose, he is unfit for that service.
('32', 421, 3, 8, 991062) Although apparently my life has been a life of political turmoils, all those who at all know me will tell you that it has been predominantly devoted to social service.
('32', 421, 3, 9, 991230) I am a lover of it and I have very often claimed to be an expert in that line of work—if 30 years’ unbroken experience of service can make one an expert.
('32', 421, 3, 10, 991384) In my life, I have had the great privilege of a long association not with dozens or even hundreds but of tens of hundreds of men and women, both Indian and European, devoted to social service.
('32', 421, 3, 11, 991577) In my humble opinion, even political service of the true type is hardly possible without social service, and it was at an early stage of my career as a social servant, whilst I was in South Africa, more so after I returned to India—that I realized the absolute necessity of character for social service.
('32', 421, 3, 12, 991881) For hard as it was in South Africa to render social service the difficulties there were nothing compared to the difficulties that confront one in India.

('32', 425, 9, 22, 1002463) It seems a certain business man in Ahmedabad who is trading in tea, puts out many advertisements.
('32', 425, 9, 23, 1002561) And in these my name has been used in such a manner as to give an impression that I have been encouraging his business or, that I approve of the habit of taking tea.
('32', 425, 9, 24, 1002727) I have received four or five letters of complaints on this matter.
('32', 425, 9, 25, 1002794) I do not wish to advertise his tea any further by giving the name and other particulars of the dealer.
('32', 425, 9, 26, 1002897) It is sufficient to state that I have given no certificate to any tea merchant in India for his tea.
('32', 425, 9, 27, 1002998) For many years, I
('32', 426, 0, 1, 1003016) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 427
('32', 426, 1, 2, 1003062) have not taken tea.
('32', 426, 1, 3, 1003082) I do not believe that it is essential for the human body.
('32', 426, 1, 4, 1003140) Tea, if boiled, is harmful.
('32', 426, 1, 5, 1003168) I believe that much harm has been done by people giving up milk because of tea.
('32', 426, 1, 6, 1003248) I do not approve of tea also because the labourers in tea gardens are subjected to much hardship.
('32', 426, 1, 7, 1003346) Those who get addicted to tea feel nervous when they cannot have it.
('32', 426, 1, 8, 1003415) It is better to give up a thing of this kind which becomes an addiction.
('32', 426, 1, 9, 1003488) For those especially who wish to court impr isonment, it is best to give up tea, as it is not served in prison.
('32', 426, 1, 10, 1003600) It is, therefore, improper to associate my name in any manner with advertisements of tea, and it pains me to see this done.
('32', 426, 1, 11, 1003724) Hence, I would ask those who have been using my name to remove it from their advertisements.
('32', 426, 1, 12, 1003817) Even otherwise, the story of the misuse of my name is a long one.
('32', 426, 1, 13, 1003883) Men have been killed and falsehood propagated in my name; my name has been misused at the time of elections; cigarettes, to which I am totally opposed, are sold in my name, as also medicines!

('32', 430, 4, 6, 1012154) 271. VIOLENCE IN AGRICULTURE
('32', 430, 5, 7, 1012183) A regular reader of Navajivan asks: 1
('32', 430, 6, 8, 1012221) It is indeed true that agriculture involves the destruction of countless insects.
('32', 430, 6, 9, 1012303) But another statement, equally true, is that the process of living, even respiration, involves violence of the same kind.
('32', 430, 6, 10, 1012425) But just as by committing suicide one does not completely get rid of the body, so also by refusing to take up agriculture one does not abolish it.
('32', 430, 6, 11, 1012572) A human being is made of earth.
('32', 430, 6, 12, 1012604) His body springs from the earth and derives its sustenance from the various forms which earth takes.
('32', 430, 6, 13, 1012705) Anyone who lives by begging his food in order to avoid the sin that is involved in agriculture commits a twofold sin.
('32', 430, 6, 14, 1012823) He is guilty of the sin involved in agriculture since the food which he begs was produced by the labour of some farmer.
('32', 430, 6, 15, 1012943) He who fills his stomach by begging shares the sin of which that farmer is guilty by virtue of his farming.
('32', 430, 6, 16, 1013051) Secondly, he is guilty of the sin of harbouring ignorance and the indolence which results from it.
('32', 430, 6, 17, 1013150) If it is desirable for one individual to keep away from agriculture, it is so for all.
('32', 430, 6, 18, 1013237) If too many people live by begging their food, a few poor farmers would be crushed under the burden of supporting beggars.
('32', 430, 6, 19, 1013360) Who would have to answer for this sin, if not the latter?
('32', 430, 6, 20, 1013418) Such essential work as farming is, like bodily functions, a form of violence which cannot be avoided.
('32', 430, 6, 21, 1013520) Such violence does not cease to be violence but, being unavoidable, is less sinful and, through spiritual knowledge and devotion to God, man secures deliverance from such sins and thereby also saves himself from the necessity of violence of this kind.
('32', 430, 6, 22, 1013772) This is why, if man’s body is a form of bondage for him, it is also a means of attaining deliverance.
('32', 430, 6, 23, 1013874) Likewise, farming becomes a cause of bondage to anyone who takes it up in order to become rich,

('32', 432, 1, 2, 1016151) 272. PRAYING TO GOD
('32', 432, 2, 3, 1016171) I do not know how to pray and sing devotional hymns and to whom to address the prayer and the hyms, and you constantly advise people to pray.
('32', 432, 2, 4, 1016313) Will you kindly explain how one may do so?
('32', 432, 2, 5, 1016356) A correspondent has put this question.
('32', 432, 2, 6, 1016395) A devotional hymn is in praise of God, and prayers are a confession of our unworthiness, of our weakness.
('32', 432, 2, 7, 1016501) God has a thousand, which means countless names, or say rather that He has no name.
('32', 432, 2, 8, 1016585) We may sing hymns to Him or pray to Him, using any name which we prefer.
('32', 432, 2, 9, 1016658) Some know Him by the name of Rama, some know Him as Krishna, others call Him Rahim, and yet others call Him God.
('32', 432, 2, 10, 1016771) All these worship the same spiritual Being.
('32', 432, 2, 11, 1016815) However, just as everyone does not like the same food so all these names do not find acceptance with everyone.
('32', 432, 2, 12, 1016926) A person knows God by that name which is familiar to him, and He, who ever dwells in our hearts and is omnipotent, understands our feelings and answers us according to our worthiness.
('32', 432, 2, 13, 1017110) This is to say that one can pray, sing devotional songs not with the lips but with the heart.
('32', 432, 2, 14, 1017204) That is why even the dumb, the stammerer and the brainless can pray.
('32', 432, 2, 15, 1017273) What avails honey on the tongue when there is poison in the heart?
('32', 432, 2, 16, 1017340) Can a paper rose ever smell sweet?
('32', 432, 2, 17, 1017375) Hence, anyone who wishes sincerely to cultivate devotion to God should purify his heart.
('32', 432, 2, 18, 1017464) Hanuman’s 1 strength was boundless because the same Rama who was on his lips was the lord of his heart.

('32', 436, 5, 10, 1023754) 276. SPEECH AT A.I.C.C. MEETING, PATNA 1
('32', 436, 6, 11, 1023795) September 22,1925 Mahatma Gandhi, in opening the proceedings, observed that a very heavy responsibility rested upon his shoulders because they had to revise one of the most important sections of the Congress constitution.
('32', 436, 6, 12, 1024017) He did not propose to give any ruling on the merits of the question as to whether the A.I.C.C. could revise the constitution, but wanted to leave the ultimate decision on it in the hands of the members themselves.
('32', 436, 6, 13, 1024231) He would give rulings on matters of procedure only.
('32', 436, 6, 14, 1024283) He emphasized the fact that the two questions of revising the franchise and of revoking the Pact 2 entered into last year were very important.
('32', 436, 6, 15, 1024426) It was for them to consider, in a free and frank manner but with calmness, the various difficulties involved in it and settle them, so that in Cawnpore they might be ready to revise their national programme in a manner conducive to the early attainment of swaraj.
('32', 436, 7, 16, 1024690) 1 The afternoon session of the A.I.C.C. was presided over by Gandhiji and attended by about a hundred members.
('32', 436, 7, 17, 1024801) 2 The Pact entered into between Gandhiji and the Swaraj Party, restricted Congress activity to specified items of the constructive programme and provided that the work in connection with Central and Provincial legislatures be carried on by the Swaraj Party as an integral part of the Congress.
('32', 436, 7, 18, 1025095) Vide “Joint Statement with Swaraj Party Leaders”, 6 11 1924.

('32', 439, 4, 18, 1032135) 278. SPEECH AT KHILAFAT CONFERENCE, PATNA 1

('32', 439, 8, 26, 1032959) The question was a very pertinent one and he was ready with his reply.
('32', 439, 8, 27, 1033030) He had told them so many times, both in his speeches and in his writing in the Press, that he
('32', 439, 9, 28, 1033124) 1 The Patna District Khilafat Conference commenced its sittings in the Anjuman Islamia Hall at 7 p.m.

('32', 440, 0, 1, 1033337) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 441
('32', 440, 1, 2, 1033383) had now lost his hold on both the Hindus and the Mussalmans.
('32', 440, 1, 3, 1033444) Today neither of the communities listened to him nor was ready to act up to his advice as was the case in 1921. And he claimed the same was the case with the Ali Brothers as well.
('32', 440, 1, 4, 1033624) They too had lost their hold on both the communities.
('32', 440, 1, 5, 1033678) Under the circumstances nothing was left to him but to pray and pray to God.
('32', 440, 1, 6, 1033755) Why should he go and speak to one who was not ready to listen to him?

('32', 440, 1, 12, 1034158) But he did not find that unity existing today.
('32', 440, 1, 13, 1034205) That was why he was silent about it, and preferred to speak to them once again about khaddar, of which he had already spoken so many times, khaddar was vital both to the Hindu and the Mussalman who regarded India as his own.
('32', 440, 2, 14, 1034430) They would have to realize that it was a sin both for the Mussalmans and for the Hindus to put on anything but khaddar, made of the yarn spun by the poor in the villages.
('32', 440, 2, 15, 1034601) Let Hindus and Mussalmans fight one another and fight to their heart’s content.
('32', 440, 2, 16, 1034681) Let them break each other’s heads and let there flow a stream of blood out of it.
('32', 440, 2, 17, 1034763) But let not the Government interfere with it.
('32', 440, 2, 18, 1034809) And despite all this, let not the Indians persist in saying that even in their degradation, they would use the cloth made in Manchester, Lancashire or Japan or even made in the mills at Bombay.
('32', 440, 2, 19, 1035003) He reprobated the use even of the latter in comparison with khaddar.
('32', 440, 2, 20, 1035072) They knew very well that in India millions of both the Hindus and the Mussalmans in the villages knew not what was called two meals a day.
('32', 440, 2, 21, 1035211) The speaker had seen the miserable condition of such people in villages in Bengal during his recent tour in that province.
('32', 440, 2, 22, 1035334) And if they also saw with his eyes, their eyes would, no doubt, be at once filled with tears.
('32', 440, 2, 23, 1035428) In villages near about Atrai, 90 per cent of the people were Mohammedans and in that very area Babu Satis Chandra Das Gupta had been carrying on his khaddar work under Dr. P.C. Ray, as a result of which, if the women in that area were able to earn even two and a half rupees a month, they were immensely pleased.
('32', 440, 2, 24, 1035741) Those who were well off might laugh at it and not be able to realize the value of it.
('32', 440, 2, 25, 1035827) But it was no doubt of considerable value to those families whose entire income from agriculture amounted to but seven rupees a month.
('32', 440, 2, 26, 1035962) The constables and the orderlies in the employ of the Government would readily be able to realize the value of it.
('32', 440, 2, 27, 1036077) If these people got an increase of even one rupee, how immensely pleased they were and grateful they felt to the officers concerned.
('32', 440, 2, 28, 1036210) Concluding, Mahatmaji eloquently appealed to the people in the name of the millions of starving people in the villages to take to khaddar and the charkha.
('32', 440, 2, 29, 1036365) Let them, for the sake of these poor people, spin and give their yarn to him so that he might be able to cheapen the cost of khaddar, mainly for these starving millions and ultimately for all.
('32', 440, 2, 30, 1036558) He had heard a Mussalman saying that Mahatmaji must have gone mad to expect that the Mussalmans would at all take to khaddar.
('32', 441, 0, 1, 1036684) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 441, 1, 2, 1036726) Mussalmans of the United Provinces wanted fine cloth like nainsook, malmal, etc.,
('32', 441, 2, 3, 1036808) for their use.
('32', 441, 2, 4, 1036823) The rough and coarse khaddar was not to their taste.
('32', 441, 2, 5, 1036876) But he did not agree with them.
('32', 441, 2, 6, 1036908) The Mussalmans also were born in and belonged to India.
('32', 441, 2, 7, 1036964) They also had the sense of humanity in them and they also felt for these starving millions in the villages.
('32', 441, 2, 8, 1037072) He hoped they would also take to khaddar as, in fact, many of them had already done.

('32', 442, 7, 11, 1039389) Provincial Conference at Purulia.

('32', 443, 1, 3, 1041339) Purulia has an old Leper Asylum managed entirely by the London Missionary Society.

('32', 443, 1, 13, 1042051) The Superintendent also told me that the cases that looked horrible—burnt up skin or burnt toes and fingers—were not contagious at all.

('32', 444, 3, 5, 1044118) 281. UNTOUCHABILITY AND GOVERNMENT
('32', 444, 4, 6, 1044153) A correspondent writes: 1
('32', 444, 5, 7, 1044179) Here there is evidently a confusion of thought, I know all about the manufactured addresses by Untouchables during the visit of the Prince of Wales.
('32', 444, 5, 8, 1044328) And whilst I know nothing about the British Government being at the back of the movement referred to by the correspondent I should not be at all surprised to find that the charge is well founded.
('32', 444, 5, 9, 1044524) The tendency of the Government is undoubtedly to divide us.
('32', 444, 5, 10, 1044584) Its strength lies in our divisions.
('32', 444, 5, 11, 1044620) Our unity will dissolve it.
('32', 444, 5, 12, 1044648) But such a policy of the Government is no proof of its interference with our work for untouchables.
('32', 444, 5, 13, 1044748) The Government, for instance, does not directly or indirectly obstruct us in removing untouchability, conducting schools for untouchables, digging wells for them or sharing our own with them.
('32', 444, 5, 14, 1044940) Reform on the part of the Hindus is a totally different thing from the exploitation of the untouchables.
('32', 444, 5, 15, 1045045) Indeed, that exploitation is a certainty if we obstinately refuse to do our duty and purge Hinduism of the curse.
('32', 444, 5, 16, 1045159) And we shall not be able to exert ourselves to the utmost in this direction if we put the blame on the shoulders of the Government and thus wait for the removal of untouchability till swaraj is attained.
('32', 444, 5, 17, 1045363) Young India, 24 9 1925
('32', 444, 6, 18, 1045386) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('32', 444, 6, 19, 1045423) The correspondent referred to Gandhiji’s remark in Young India of 27 8 1925 that he did not know of “a single instance where the Government have obstructed the public in its programme of removing untouchability”.
('32', 444, 6, 20, 1045636) The correspondent held that “the Government, if not actually hindering the reform, has been certainly trying to pervert it.” He cited instances of the “addresses of welcome” by chamars of Meerut manoeuvred by the Government at the time of the visit of the Prince of Wales, and of a “Adi Hindu Andolan” or movement in Manipuri, Itawah, Etah and Kanpur districts instigating the untouchables to demand separate representation and fair proportion in the services and to rise in revolt against caste Hindus.
('32', 444, 6, 21, 1046140) In the correspondent’s opinion, “it was an open secret that the authorities are at the back of this movement.”

('32', 445, 1, 2, 1046293) 282. WHAT OF THE BRITISH LION?
('32', 445, 2, 3, 1046324) Here is a letter all the way from California:
('32', 445, 3, 4, 1046370) Enclosed please find a small cutting.
('32', 445, 3, 5, 1046408) Read this cutting first:
('32', 445, 4, 6, 1046433) “Kennedy was seated in the ranch house and happened to glance into the yard
('32', 445, 5, 7, 1046509) where his four year old grand daughter was playing.
('32', 445, 5, 8, 1046561) He saw a mountain lion
('32', 445, 6, 9, 1046584) stealthily creeping upon her.
('32', 445, 6, 10, 1046614) Kennedy rushed for his rifle and fired through the
('32', 445, 7, 11, 1046665) window at the lion as it was ready to spring.
('32', 445, 7, 12, 1046711) The bullet pierced its heart.”
('32', 445, 8, 13, 1046742) Now give your opinion regarding the method used by the child’s father.
('32', 445, 9, 14, 1046813) answer the following questions:
('32', 445, 10, 15, 1046845) “Was he justified to kill the lion?
('32', 445, 10, 16, 1046881) Should the father remain non violent and let
('32', 445, 11, 17, 1046926) the lion devour his child?
('32', 445, 11, 18, 1046953) Should the father appeal to the soul of the lion and thus
('32', 445, 12, 19, 1047011) endanger the life of his child?
('32', 445, 12, 20, 1047043) Was it possible for the father to plead mercy in order to
('32', 445, 13, 21, 1047101) save the child?
('32', 445, 13, 22, 1047117) Are you going to keep on appealing to the soul of the British lion and
('32', 445, 14, 23, 1047188) let them devour the lives of many million Indians?” My answer to his first question is that the father was justified in killing the lion.
('32', 445, 14, 24, 1047326) In asking the other questions the correspondent has betrayed his ignorance of non violence and its working.
('32', 445, 14, 25, 1047434) Non violence is not so much a mental or intellectual attitude as a quality of the heart, the soul.
('32', 445, 14, 26, 1047533) If Kennedy had no fear of the lion—fearlessness being the first and indispensable condition of non violence—if he had a heart recognition of the fact that the lion possessed a soul as much as he himself did, instead of rushing to his rifle and relying upon the problematical chance of the lion waiting till he reached his rifle and of taking an unerring aim, he should have rushed to the lion and put his arms round him in the fullest confidence of being able to appeal to the soul within him and rescuing his child.
('32', 445, 14, 27, 1048050) That such non violence is reached by the fewest possible is only too true, and therefore mankind in general will always kill lions and tigers in order to save their children and cattle.
('32', 445, 14, 28, 1048236) But the fundamental position remains unaffected.
('32', 445, 14, 29, 1048285) The phenomenon of real sadhus fearlessly meeting and remaining unharmed without harming the wild beasts of the jungle is not an unknown thing in Hindustan.
('32', 445, 14, 30, 1048441) We have a historical record of such instances in the West also.
('32', 445, 14, 31, 1048505) The writer has further committed the error of imagining an unimaginable case with brave men.
('32', 445, 14, 32, 1048598) If Kennedy had remained a passive spectator of his child being devoured, the case would have been one not of non violence in any shape or form but of rank and heartless cowardice, the very opposite of non violence.
('32', 446, 0, 1, 1048813) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 447
('32', 446, 1, 2, 1048859) The last question put by the correspondent is really what his letter is intended to lead up to.
('32', 446, 1, 3, 1048955) In it the correspondent has shown woeful ignorance of the history of our own times.
('32', 446, 1, 4, 1049039) He must know that the movement for which I have made myself responsible is not an appeal of the kind he imagines to the soul of the British lion, but it is an appeal to the soul of India to find itself.
('32', 446, 1, 5, 1049242) It is a movement to develop internal strength.
('32', 446, 1, 6, 1049289) In its final form, therefore, it is undoubtedly an appeal to the soul of the British lion.
('32', 446, 1, 7, 1049380) But it then becomes an appeal from an equal to an equal, not an appeal of a beggar to a possible donor, or the vain appeal of a dwarf to a giant to save him.
('32', 446, 1, 8, 1049538) It will then be an irresistible appeal of soul to soul.
('32', 446, 1, 9, 1049594) In the process of development of internal strength, the inevitable devouring will no doubt go on.
('32', 446, 1, 10, 1049692) But it will not cease even when and if India rushes like Kennedy to the rifle.
('32', 446, 1, 11, 1049771) But whereas Kennedy tried to reach the rifle which he possessed and whose use he knew, the Indian Kennedy unlike the Californian would be trying to destroy the British lion without possessing the necessary weapon or the skill to use it.
('32', 446, 1, 12, 1050008) Under my method, there is the present possibility not of destroying the British lion but of changing his nature.
('32', 446, 1, 13, 1050121) Again, under the Kennedy method India will have to develop the same qualities which we at present deplore in the British lion.
('32', 446, 1, 14, 1050248) Lastly, the third course which evidently the correspondent imagines to be not merely possible but the alternative to his method does not arise at all in the case of India, as it did not in the Californian case.
('32', 446, 1, 15, 1050459) India to be free has only two choices.
('32', 446, 1, 16, 1050498) She must either become, for the purpose of achieving her freedom and to that extent only, non violent, or must endeavour to develop the Western methods of violence with all its implications.

('32', 450, 3, 4, 1058920) An Allahabad Graduate writes:
('32', 450, 4, 5, 1058950) I am a registered graduate of the Allahabad University.
('32', 450, 4, 6, 1059006) I am entitled to vote for a candidate seeking election to the Allahabad University Court.
('32', 450, 5, 7, 1059096) Exception has been taken to my opposition to making military training compulsory in the universities.
('32', 450, 5, 8, 1059198) On this point I seek your opinion through the columns of Young India.
('32', 450, 5, 9, 1059268) My view briefly is this:
('32', 450, 6, 10, 1059293) I admit that under a swaraj government our young men would be required to take to the Army as a career and we shall have to encourage that spirit.
('32', 450, 6, 11, 1059440) But under an alien government I feel there is absolutely no security that these university corps would not be used against the Indian nation, as the Indian army has been used in the past.

('32', 450, 7, 13, 1059737) take up military training?
('32', 450, 7, 14, 1059764) Does it not clash with the ideal of a university, where at least we can expect a free atmosphere for growth?
('32', 450, 7, 15, 1059873) Would it not cast our ideals in a militarist mould?
('32', 450, 7, 16, 1059925) My information about foreign universities is limited, but so far as I could gather I understand there is no compulsion even in universities of free countries like England and America.
('32', 450, 7, 17, 1060109) Even if we ignore political considerations should we not allow the individual his freedom of conscience to preserve which large numbers of Englishmen went to jail during the War.
('32', 450, 7, 18, 1060288) All of them were not afraid to die.

('32', 450, 10, 21, 1060453) matter of fact, I advocate.
('32', 450, 10, 22, 1060481) I feel that if it is made compulsory all the

('32', 450, 14, 29, 1060869) But the argument seems to be sound even from the purely utilitarian and national standpoint.
('32', 450, 14, 30, 1060962) Not only can there be no security against the use being made of university corps for purposes antagonistic to the national interest, but whilst the Government retains its anti national character there is every likelihood of these corps

('32', 453, 2, 8, 1066333) POWERS OF THE COUNCIL
('32', 453, 3, 9, 1066355) The Council shall take over all the funds and assets belonging to the All India Khadi Board and all Provincial Khadi Boards with full powers to administer these and other funds and shall discharge their existing financial obligations.
('32', 453, 3, 10, 1066590) The Council shall have the right to raise loans, to collect subscriptions, to hold immovable property, to invest funds under proper security, to give and take mortgages for the furtherance of hand spinning and khaddar, to give financial assistance to khaddar organizations by way of loans, gifts or bounties, to help or establish schools or institutions where hand spinning is taught, to help or open khadi stores to establish a khaddar service, to act as agency on behalf of the Congress to receive self spun yarn as subscription to the Congress and to issue certificates, and to do all the things that may be considered necessary for the furtherance of its objects, with power to make regulations for the conduct of affairs of the Association or the Council and to amend them, as also the present constitution, as may be considered necessary from time to time.
('32', 453, 3, 11, 1067453) Vacancies in the existing Council by death, resignation or otherwise shall be filled by the remaining members .
('32', 453, 3, 12, 1067565) The Council shall have the right to add to its numbers which shall not exceed 12 at any time and four members shall form the quorum for a meeting of the Council.
('32', 453, 3, 13, 1067727) All decisions shall be taken by majority of votes.
('32', 453, 3, 14, 1067778) The Council shall keep an accurate account of all subscriptions, donations and fees, whether in cash or kind, and of expenditure.
('32', 453, 3, 15, 1067908) The books shall be open to public inspection and shall be audited by competent auditors every three months.

('32', 456, 7, 7, 1071752) 286. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, PATNA1
('32', 456, 8, 8, 1071790) Septemb
('32', 456, 9, 9, 1071798) Replying to the address Mahatmaji, first of all, thanked the people of Patna and the members of the District Board for the addresses presented to him.
('32', 456, 9, 10, 1071949) Referring to the observation made by Khan Bahadur Nawab Sarfaraz Hussain Khan 2 about Hindu Muslim unity, he said that there was a time when he did claim that there had come about a real unity between the Hindus and the Mussalmans and that it was going to stay for ever.
('32', 456, 9, 11, 1072220) And he could have justly claimed for himself, then, a great deal of the credit for that result.
('32', 456, 9, 12, 1072316) But he was grieved to say that the same was not true of today.
('32', 456, 9, 13, 1072379) He had already said it so many times, and he would say the same thing that evening, that he had now lost his hold both on the Hindus as well as on the Mohammedans.
('32', 456, 9, 14, 1072543) In that meeting there were present both the Hindus and the Mussalmans but he did not at all deceive himself that their presence was any indication of their acceptance of his creed of Hindu Muslim unity.
('32', 456, 9, 15, 1072746) Indeed, it went against his grain to go to such meetings, which were attended by people whose hearts were not pure and whose relations with one another were not cordial, and thereby deceive the world and himself regarding the unity between the two communities.
('32', 456, 9, 16, 1073007) He did not like to go even to such meetings as were attended solely by the members of either community.
('32', 456, 9, 17, 1073111) He was trying to look equally on both the Hindus and the Mussalmans and treat them impartially.
('32', 456, 9, 18, 1073207) It was true, as both Indians and even the Westerners had admitted, that his ideal of swaraj and
('32', 456, 10, 19, 1073303) 1 The meeting, attended by a large number of people, was held in the Baptist Mission Compound at 7.30 p.m.
('32', 456, 10, 20, 1073410) 2 Member, Bihar Legislative Assembly and Chairman, Reception Committee
('32', 457, 0, 1, 1073481) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 457, 1, 2, 1073523) non co operation was not intended to do any harm to anyone.
('32', 457, 1, 3, 1073583) It aimed at the well being of the whole world.
('32', 457, 1, 4, 1073630) And so when the members of the two communities quarrelled among themselves and tried to associate him with one side or the other, he could not go to such meetings.
('32', 457, 1, 5, 1073794) He could not be partial to any one of the communities.
('32', 457, 1, 6, 1073849) He was not prepared to say that Hindus always did the right or that the Mussalmans did no wrong.
('32', 457, 1, 7, 1073946) In fact, both of them were in the wrong and both of them had gone mad.
('32', 457, 1, 8, 1074017) In the circumstances, therefore, the least that he could do was to keep himself away from them, and pray to God to relieve him of the pain and the pang that the existing state of things caused.
('32', 457, 1, 9, 1074211) Let the Hindus and the Mussalmans fight out to their heart’s content and, perhaps, then it would be time for him to interfere and ask them what they had gained?
('32', 457, 1, 10, 1074372) He had not wanted to tell them even those few words about the communal trouble, but he had been led to make those observations by the few words uttered by the Chairman.
('32', 457, 1, 11, 1074541) But all the same he had hope and trust that despite the present quarrels, Hindus and Mussalmans would unite once again and that soon.
('32', 457, 1, 12, 1074675) In the words of Maulana Shaukat Ali, it was but a temporary fever which was sure to pass off ere long.
('32', 457, 2, 13, 1074778) Mahatmaji proceeding dwelt upon the importance and necessity of the charkha and khaddar and said that in the present circumstances though Hindus Muslim unity was no doubt dear to his heart the only thing which was no less dear to him and which he could work was the charkha.
('32', 457, 2, 14, 1075053) It was his firm belief that if there was anything capable of removing the poverty of the country, it was the charkha.
('32', 457, 2, 15, 1075171) If they wanted to remove the poverty of the starving millions in the villages, if they wanted to provide useful occupation for the people in the villages who remained idle at least for four months in the year, they could do it only by the charkha.
('32', 457, 2, 16, 1075419) Those who were opposed to it, Mahatmaji thought, could not suggest any substitute for it.
('32', 457, 2, 17, 1075509) But the charkha could only succeed when all the people took to it.
('32', 457, 2, 18, 1075576) Proceeding, he referred to the newly formed All India Spinners’ Association and congratulated Khan Bahadur Sarfaraz Hussain Khan and the people on his becoming the member of the Association and his agreeing to ply the charkha.
('32', 457, 2, 19, 1075803) The use of khaddar was necessary for the membership of that Association.
('32', 457, 2, 20, 1075876) If the people of Bihar took to khaddar and the charkha, then alone could they remove the poverty of the people as only then would they be able to send millions of money direct to the poor without any intermediary agency.
('32', 457, 2, 21, 1076097) If they purchased, for instance, a yard of khaddar for ten annas, the whole of that amount, including the price paid for cotton, went directly to the poor.
('32', 457, 2, 22, 1076253) But where they used cloth made even in the mills of Bombay and Ahmedabad, not to speak of Manchester and other foreign made cloth, the major portion of the money went to the capitalists and only a very small portion of it to the poor.
('32', 457, 2, 23, 1076488) When he said that it did not mean that he was opposed to the capitalists amassing wealth—he could not be—but what they had to consider was whether it was just to feed the overfed or the millions of the starving poor.
('32', 457, 2, 24, 1076705) Undoubtedly those who satisfied the hunger of the poor deserved all
('32', 458, 0, 1, 1076773) VOL.32 : 17 JUNE, 1925 24 SEPTEMBER, 1925 459
('32', 458, 1, 2, 1076819) blessings.
('32', 458, 1, 3, 1076830) The khaddar, in spite of its dearness, was cheap and preferable to mill made cloth because through khaddar they could directly help the poor.
('32', 458, 1, 4, 1076972) That was why he had decided to devote his life to the cause of khaddar and the charkha and thereby save both the Hindus and the Mussalmans from utter ruin.
('32', 458, 1, 5, 1077128) He therefore wanted them all to become members of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('32', 458, 1, 6, 1077215) There were two classes of membership of the Association.
('32', 458, 1, 7, 1077272) The “A” class of members were required to contribute 1,000 yards of self spun yarn every month.
('32', 458, 1, 8, 1077368) But those who could not do so might become “B” class members and contribute annually 2,000 yards of yarn.
('32', 458, 1, 9, 1077474) Besides, the members would have always to wear khaddar and khaddar alone.
('32', 458, 2, 10, 1077548) But all this could not be done without money.
('32', 458, 2, 11, 1077594) He would, therefore, appeal to all to contribute their mite to the All India Deshbandhu Memorial Fund which would be utilized for the propagation of khaddar and the charkha.
('32', 458, 3, 12, 1077768) Concluding, Mahatmaji condemned untouchability and said that he as a sanatani Hindu would tell the sanatanists that untouchability was a great sin.
('32', 458, 4, 13, 1077916) Tulsidas preached that their religion demanded that they should be kind unto all.
('32', 458, 4, 14, 1077998) Hatred and contempt had no place in their religion.
('32', 458, 4, 15, 1078050) Let every Hindu be true to his religion and live in terms of peace and amity.

('32', 462, 7, 21, 1088277) therefore put it to you (i) that the picketing of the eastern road is a source of embarrassment to the authorities in pacifying the orthodox Hindus; (ii) that the authorities cannot and will not advance further without carrying the vast majority of Hindus with them; (iii) that the advance will be quicker if you withdraw and I would ask you kindly to consider whether if you still think it necessary to occupy the local

('32', 464, 12, 17, 1091532) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('32', 464, 13, 18, 1091548) The Swaraj Party is under a deep debt of gratitude to you for your generous support on the irreparable loss it sustained by the premature death of its great leader, Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das.
('32', 464, 13, 19, 1091742) You have now redoubled that debt by the noble offer contained in your letter of the 19th July.
('32', 464, 13, 20, 1091837) It seems to me that the only way to repay that debt is to accept your offer in all humility and strive with your help to meet the situation created by Lord Birkenhead’s speech in the spirit of the last pronouncement of Deshbandhu made at Faridpur.
('32', 464, 14, 21, 1092085) Lord Birkenhead seems to have spurned the honourable co operation offered by Deshbandhu and to have made it clear that in our struggle for freedom we have still to face many unnecessary obstacles and many ill informed opponents.
('32', 464, 14, 22, 1092314) Our plain duty at this stage is, therefore, to go ahead along the line chalked out for us and prepare the country for an effective challenge to irresponsible and insolent authority.
('32', 464, 14, 23, 1092496) In the words of the great Faridpur speech “We shall fight, but fight clean, not forgetting that when the time for settlement comes, as it is bound to come, we have to enter the Peace Conference not in a spirit of arrogance but with becoming humility, so that it may be said of us that we were greater in our achievement than in our adversity.” You have now enabled us to fulfil the message of Deshbandhu with the unite ‘strength of the Congress at our back.
('32', 464, 14, 24, 1092954) Under such auspices we need entertain no misgivings
('32', 465, 0, 1, 1093006) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('32', 465, 1, 2, 1093048) about the result which can only be what it has invariably been in all ages and countries : the ultimate triumph of right over might.
('32', 465, 2, 3, 1093181) I desire to say one word about the Pact from which you have so generously absolved the Swaraj Party.
('32', 465, 2, 4, 1093282) As you know, both Deshbandhu and I had no desire to have the conditions of the Pact altered in the course of the year.
('32', 465, 2, 5, 1093401) We wanted to give it a full and fair trial and it was our wish to help personally in every way in making it a success.
('32', 465, 2, 6, 1093520) Ill health and many preoccupations prevented us both from doing as much for it as we had wished, but I entirely agree with you that a new situation has been created by recent events and under the circumstances the Congress should without loss of time adapt itself to this situation by making itself a predominantly poli tical body.
('32', 465, 2, 7, 1093852) I therefore, welcome your offer.
('32', 465, 2, 8, 1093885) This, however, does not mean that the Congress should give up in any way the constructive programme.
('32', 465, 2, 9, 1093986) All our efforts would be of little avail if they are not backed up by the organized strength of the nation.

('32', 467, 1, 2, 1096946) APPENDIX VI
('32', 467, 2, 3, 1096958) SWARAJ OR DEATH
('32', 467, 3, 4, 1096974) In your Young India of the 25th June, I find things which I utterly fail to
('32', 467, 4, 5, 1097050) understand.
('32', 467, 4, 6, 1097062) On page 219 under the heading “On the Verge of It” you have, I think, asked your correspondent to explain—“Why do you think that we cannot spin and wear khaddar or remove untouchability or be friends with the Mussalmans till we get swaraj?
('32', 467, 4, 7, 1097302) How will the withdrawal of Englishmen help Hindus to trust the Mussalmans or vice versa, or open the eyes of blind orthodoxy and better the lot of
('32', 467, 5, 8, 1097449) the oppressed people or induce the idle to work the spinning wheel and those whose tastes are degraded to revise them and revert to khaddar?
('32', 467, 5, 9, 1097590) Surely, if we cannot do these things now under the pressure of adversity, we are not likely to do them when we are lulled into a sense of false security by nominal swaraj.
('32', 467, 5, 10, 1097762) What is there to prevent us now from attempting or accomplishing all or any of these three things if it is not our own unwillingness, lethargy or worse?”
('32', 467, 6, 11, 1097916) I cannot say what the correspondent will answer to these your queries but I respectfully like to point out to you that your assertion—that without khaddar, Hindu Muslim unity and the removal of untouchability there can be no swaraj— also appears to be based on wrong premises.
('32', 467, 6, 12, 1098193) There appears to be some truth also in the alternative assertion of your correspondent, and in his support I say this:
('32', 467, 7, 13, 1098312) (1) The spinning and use of khaddar will be wholly popularized only after the establishment of swaraj and not before.
('32', 467, 7, 14, 1098430) The reasons are as follows:
('32', 467, 8, 15, 1098458) The Government is a part and parcel of every society.
('32', 467, 8, 16, 1098512) Everybody seeks its help every moment.
('32', 467, 8, 17, 1098551) For the time being life, honour and property of all individuals under the Government are entrusted to it.
('32', 467, 8, 18, 1098657) Some have to win cases, some to get titles and honours, some are to be provided with appointments and so on.
('32', 467, 8, 19, 1098766) Everybody can do without the Government help only for a fixed period of time and that only a small one, but nobody can do without it (the Government) for a longer period.
('32', 467, 8, 20, 1098937) Everywhere in the country, specially in my district, the use of khaddar is a symbol of anti Government sentiment.

('32', 468, 3, 7, 1100698) (2) There can be no permanent Hindu Muslim unity before swaraj.
('32', 468, 3, 8, 1100762) The reasons are as follows:
('32', 468, 4, 9, 1100790) During my boyhood one of my paternal uncles told me a story which runs thus— “Once there were two young men who were fast friends.
('32', 468, 4, 10, 1100921) They appeared to have had two bodies but one soul.
('32', 468, 4, 11, 1100972) Their parents did not like it and were on the look out to effect enmity between these friends.
('32', 468, 4, 12, 1101067) They proclaimed probably by a beat of drum a handsome reward to anyone successfully effecting a breach between the friends.
('32', 468, 4, 13, 1101191) One old woman popularly known as ‘Kutni’ undertook the task.
('32', 468, 4, 14, 1101252) She went to the friends and called only one of them apart from the other but within his (other friend’s) sight.
('32', 468, 4, 15, 1101364) She took her mouth to the ears of the friend whom she had called apart, pretended to say something to him, said nothing and went away.
('32', 468, 4, 16, 1101499) The man returned to his friend who was left behind and was asked to state what the woman had told him.
('32', 468, 4, 17, 1101602) The poor man stated that she had said nothing.
('32', 468, 4, 18, 1101649) Suspicion naturally arose in the mind of the other man who saw so many performances with his own eyes and was in the dark as to their purposes and result, and it developed.
('32', 468, 4, 19, 1101822) In course of time their friendship came to an end and the woman got the reward.”
('32', 468, 5, 20, 1101903) Exactly in the same way, Mahatmaji, please do not expect perfect unity between the Hindus and Mussalmans so long as the third party, with not only all the available resources of the country but also with those of the whole British Empire and with a clear knowledge that its very existence depends only on the disunion and quarrel among the several races inhabiting this country, is always persistently trying every moment to keep the people fighting among themselves.
